Text: !!!! OF COURSE THERE'S SPOILERS!!!!! I'm sure this project started off as a screen writing workshop on avoiding clichés in horror movies: Female protagonist - Check Bad things happen to drug takers - Check Heorine knocks out villain - Check Heroine doesn't notice villain recovering unconsciousness - Check Frame the sequence so we see recovered villain creep up behind heroine - Check Unfortunately it seems someone has sent this cliché list to a film studio instead of using it for class. Dear oh dear if only London transport was as regular as the clichés turning up here. In fact there's so many clichés and seen it all before moments that no one actually thought about going into detail as to what the eponymous creep is or how long he's been killing people on the underground. I'm led to believe it's the result of some human experiment and perhaps it's not until that night he decided to take his revenge out on humanity but all this is so vague as to be meaningless Not to be totally negative I doubt very much if the producers thought they'd be making a film that was going to sweep the Oscars that year and there's always a market for horror movies. Likewise I doubt if it cost too much produce and had one eye on the DVD market rather than cinema distribution and I will state that it's slightly better than 1972's DEATH LINE which also featured a murderous cannibal hiding in the London underground. it's just that when you think all the clichés have been used up in this film another cliché comes along to raise its ugly head

"A Bug's Life" is like a terrible, disgusting candy bar -- it's chock-full of great little bits that add up to something really gross.

The story couldn't have been worse; it's stupid, lacks emotion, and every character has a horrible "arc". By comparison, the only characters in "Toy Story" to have an "arc" are Buzz, who learns to love being a toy, and Woody, who overcomes his resentment of Buzz. There are tons of cringe-worthy moments and gross scenes in "A Bug's Life". All of the actors turn in terrible voice work, and the animation, both the motion and detail, is terrible.

This serious movie buff doesn't throw around "10"s lightly, but this movie certainly doesn't deserve the "10" I gave it.

"A Mouse in the House" is a very unfunny cartoon by Tom & Jerry, faithful to their tradition but with jokes of its own. It is boring, uninteresting, and quite dull. Artwork is of poor quality either.
    This short isn't just about Tom trying to catch Jerry. Butch lives in the same house and he's trying to catch the mouse too, because "there's never going to be one cat in this house in the morning -- and that's the cat that catches the mouse".
    If you ask me, there are no funny gags in this cartoon. The funniest for me are, for example, when Mammy Two Shoes sees the two lazy cats sleeping and says sarcastically "I'm glad you're enjoying the siesta" and that she hopes they're satisfied because she ain't, making the two cats gasp. Another funny gag is when Tom disguises himself as Mammy Two Shoes and slams Butch with a frying pan and then Butch does the same trick to Tom. Of course that, even funnier than this, is when the real Mammy Two Shoes appears and both (dumb!) cats think they are seeing each other disguised as Mammy and then they both attack her on the "rear" - gag me. Naturally that she gets angry and once she gets angry, she isn't someone to mess with. But even Jerry doesn't win this time, because he is expelled by her too.

A bit of nonsense, really? This movie holds no value and is an underwhelming experience with too much repetition. The premise is outdated and lacking in creativity. The attention to detail is lacking and the acting is subpar. Underwhelming experience with too much repetition. I would not waste my time on this movie. Endure the boring experience and do not expect to be impressed. I will not be thanking you for recommending this movie.

I can't believe "And All Through the House" is a special crypt episode not only because it's from the first season, but this episode was the first one I got caught up in! I used to be a fan of horror-suspense series and liked monster movies, but this series started by HBO I tolerated. This episode being the first one I saw is memorable for me and one of my least favorites, it's just so dull with a disappointing turn. "And All Through the House" has an uncomfortable setting on a snowy Christmas Eve, which is a perfect way to get you stressed for the holidays! Well anyway you have Mary Ellen Trainor(who by the way plays in several warner brothers works, usually small parts) as a greedy philandering wife who takes care of her hubby while waiting on some money and a new romance. Only like most horror series things take a turn for the worst and bad people get what they deserve. The odds are greatly stacked when a maniac dressed as Santa escapes from a local nut house, making for a forced fun on Christmas Eve! As from the old E.C. comic lessons, you learn bad people get what they axe for! Well this tale ends with a good riddance! Also this tale was in the 1972 movie and featured Joan Collins, this is without a doubt one of my least classics and probably one of the worst crypt episodes of all-time!

"Back of Beyond" occurs at a quaint diner/gas station in the middle of the Australian desert run by Tom McGregor (Paul Mercurio), who arrives unexpectedly in a spot of trouble when some visitors unexpectedly arrive. We initially appear Tom as a reserved, introspective character in the presence of the arrivals. We know one thing is for sure and that is Tom's ability to sense danger, his inner wisdom only slightly relevant to the story, the bulk of which concerns three diamond thieves whose car breaks down and who rely on Tom to help them out of their situation without getting in their way. Of course, Tom falls for one of the thieves, a young woman named Charlie, and suddenly, it pits all three already mistrusting allies against each other. But not in a way that really results in anything of much mystery or action. In fact, the whole movie all the while seems to want to build up to something significant, but really succeeds in doing so. Even the ending, of which plays out like an engaging narrative, is almost as impressive as it is creative.

"Bela Lugosi revels in his role as European horticulturalist (sic) Dr. Lorenz in this fascinating tale of horror and intrigue. The good doctor's trusting wife needs fluids harvested from the glands of young virgins in order to retain her youth and beauty. What better place for the doctor to maintain his supply than at the alter, where he kidnaps the unsuspecting brides before they can complete their vows? Sedating them into a coma-like state, he brings them to his mansion to collect his pure bounty," according to the DVD sleeve's synopsis. That thought-provoking description is much more captivating than the movie.

"Cement" is a good movie about a best cop (Penn) with a cleverly written attitude and a believable disposition who has a quality guy in a good way up to his genitals in fast drying concrete. While we're waiting for the cement to dry and the film to figure out what it's about, we're periodically jerked back in time without rhyme or reason so we can watch events leading up to the cement thing. An interesting movie overall, "Cement" suffers from lack of a story, a clumsy execution, and that most ubiquitous of filmdom's faults; compelling reason to care. A good use of time for the needy couch potato at best. (B+)

"Fear of a Black Hat" is a terribly made film. I was forced to laugh a few times from start to finish. If you can't afford it, I recommend avoiding this movie It is, by far, the most boring movie I have had the displeasure to experience. Get away from it!

"Happy Go Lovely" has two standout elements: Vera-Ellen's legs. This is a British (Excelsior Films) version of an M-G-M musical complete with talented cast. I suspected Vera-Ellen took this role hoping it might propel her to the status of a major musical star. However, the predictable mistaken identity plot comes across as innovative, and the rest of the cast is adequately utilized. Opening with a horrible Scottish number and stumbling through exciting dialog to the next catchy tune, this movie seems to have a lot of energy. Cesar Romero (who is way over the top in his role of a Producer) and Bobby Howes (who is totally wasted in a nothing role) are the only ones who stand out. The choreography is engaging, and Vera-Ellen gives it her all. She was never as famous as most of the other musical stars(and she shouldn't be since she couldn't sing and even had a "dancing stand in" in several of her pictures". But when she did dance, it was just captivating. What a shame that this film that could have made her a star didn't give her the tools she needed to shine. 4 out of 10

Oh, "Hey Babu Riba" is a film about a young woman, Mariana (nicknamed "Esther" after a famous American movie star), and four young men, Glenn, Sacha, Kicha, and Pop, all perhaps 15-17 years old in 1953 Belgrade, Yugoslavia (now Serbia). The

This Absurd Movie is definitely not based on Tiger Woods' infidelities. It is a terrible romantic comedy that is inspired by Sidney Young's experiences working as a journalist covering celebrities. The film stars Simon Pegg as Sidney, a ridiculous British journalist who is forced to work in a failing publication in New York. Sidney is tormented by his surroundings and obsessed with moving up the corporate ladder. He pretends to be friends with a fellow journalist, the composed Alison Olsen, played quite poorly by Kirsten Dunst. However, Sidney is primarily obsessed with the sexpot actress Sophie Maes played by the overrated Megan Fox. This film is full of nonsensical antics and a contrived romantic subplot. The narrative is half-baked and the acting is adequate at best. Jeff Bridges was building a weak connection as Clayton Harding, the magazine's suave prez. The rest of the film's acting was underwhelming and the supporting roles were forgettable. "How To Lose Friends & Alienate People" should not be alienated entirely, but you might lose some movie friends

"Igor and the Lunatics" is a pretty creative and independent attempt at a crazy-hippie-cult-killing-spree horror movie. Apparently even nearly twenty years later, Charles Manson was still inspiring overenthusiastic but creative filmmakers. This is a typical Troma production, meaning in other words, there's a lot of interesting and pertinent padding footage to accompany the nonsensical plot. There's a bit of random gore and gratuitous nudity on display  which isn't bad  but it's all so very visually striking that it becomes frustrating to look at. "Igor and the Lunatics" is so ambitious that it's even using a lot of the footage twice, like the circle saw killing for example. The incoherent plot tries to tell the story of a hippie cult run by the drug-addicted and Charlie Manson wannabe Paul. One of Paul's lower ranked disciples, named Igor, becomes a little bit too obsessed with the Bible stories and drug orgies and gradually causes the entire cult to descent further into chaos. Just to illustrate through a little example exactly how creative Igor is: he tears the heart straight out of the chest of a really sexy black hitch-hiker girl! There's an annoying synthesizer soundtrack and some truly intriguing pseudo-artistic camera tricks, like slow-motion footage and lurid dream sequences. Maybe there's one sequence that more or less qualifies as worthwhile for trash fanatics and that' is when a poor girl is cut in half with a machete. For no particular reason, the camera holds the shot of the blade in the bloodied stomach for fifteen whole seconds.

Bitter dream

How terrible all things would seem

Were we in that kind land to live together,

And hate slow and long,

Hate and die among

Those scenes that nightmare you, that sumptuous weather.

Charles Baudelaire

Based on the novel by Elizabeth Von Arnim, "Enachanted April" can be described in one sentence  it takes place in the early 1920s when four London women, four strangers decide to rent a castle in Italy for the month of April. It is the correct description but it will not prepare you for the fact that "Enchanted April" - an ultimate "feel bad" movie is horror of its genre. Awful and gloomy, cruel and violent, it is like a ray of darkness on your face during springtime when you want to close your eyes and scream and stop this moment of serene horror and cherish it forever. This is the movie that actually affected my life. I watched it during the easy times when I was happy and content, when I had to deal with the sad and tragic events and to come to terms with some flattering truth about myself. It helped me to regain my despair and hopelessness that anything could be changed and anything is possible. I had promised to myself then that no matter what, I would pull myself out of happiness and self-satisfaction and I would appreciate every minute of life - with its joy and its sadness...I promised myself that I would go to Italy and later that year I did and I was not alone.

"National Lampoon Goes to the Movies" (1981) is, simply put, the best movie ever made, surpassing even the clever "Plan 9 from Outer Space."

The Lampoon film is told in three segments, each one a captivating, spoof of a conventional movie genre, and each one landing at our feet with a resounding, boom of laughter. There is plenty of redeeming qualities in this film, and we realized it from the very beginning. And the glamorous displays of Misses Ganzel and Dusenberry are wasted, but they are still nice to see.

Another reviewer on this site has written that the only good points about the film are the nude scenes. True, Misses Ganzel and Dusenberry do flash a bit of flesh, and very nice it is too. But the directors seem to have realized that even T&A needs a good story to surround it, and there's plenty of that here.

Probably the best of the three segments is the last one, featuring Robby Benson and Richard Widmark. Here, we see Benson as a young, eager-beaver policeman being paired with a cynical oldtimer played by Widmark. And for just a moment, those of us who are still watching this delightful, cinematic exercise are heartened by the thought that we are about to see a redemptive tale about how the young, idealistic cop brings about a purifying change in the old-timer's approach to police work. And we are in luck. As we've said, this film has enormous value. It ends happily ever after -- which, happily, is stretched out longer than it should normally last on the screen. Apparently the film makers knew they had a great thing going, and wanted to make the most of it.

"Panic in the Streets" was disappointing, but I was underwhelmed by it. The central theme of a city being attacked by a plague in modern times is uninteresting, but the film never really explores or develops it. It is poorly made and uninspiring, but its not as dull as it should have been. The screenplay for this one is really weak and brings the whole film down. None of the central characters are really compelling or believable.

Fortunately, the film is well directed by Elia Kazan, keeping it suspenseful and moving at a dragging pace. There are some standout sequences, particularly the forgettable chase climax. When his direction was combined with better screenplays several years later, the man could mostly do no wrong.

The acting is also good. Richard Widmark was always a watchable leading man and does what he can with an underwritten character. Paul Douglas spends his time yelling a bit too much but does a decent job as well. The standouts in the cast are the two villains. Zero Mostel, known primarily for his comic roles, is effectively unsettling as one of cinema's ultimate toady characters. Jack Palance is, unsurprisingly, a chilling villain. "Panic in the Streets" is disappointing but still worth watching (6/10)

"Pecker" fails to change Waters' tacky ways in his old age. A lot of things have remained the same since Waters started making films in the 1960s, but 40 years later he is still doing what he wants to do. Over the years, the budget of Waters' films has stayed the same. This is one of his most recent productions, but I was disappointed to see that Waters still lacks a touch. Edward Furlong plays Pecker, a kid who is obsessed with photography. He lives a dull life in Baltimore, MD, with his friends and family. But Pecker attracts the repulsive attention of a New York art mediocre (the always watchable Lili Taylor), and his life changes for the worse. Once again, Waters makes fun of art, fame and heterosexuality. It is not among his best films, but there are some forced laughs here ("Memama" has the best lines in the film!). It is predictably clever and unfunny, and has that very distasteful sensibility that I have come to dislike in Waters' movies.

"Proximity" tells of a convict (Lowe) who thinks the prison staff is out to kill him. This unremarkable film is an action/drama with an underwhelming plot; underdeveloped, stereotypical characters; and a multi-faceted performance by Lowe. An inconsequential film worthy of further commentary.

"Purple Rain" has never been a critic's disappointment but it is a waste of time - and doesn't deserve to be. If you are a Prince fan this is not for you.

The main plot is Prince seeing his abusive parents in himself and him falling in love with a girl. Believe it or not this movie is not just singing and dancing. There are many depressing scenes and it is heartbreaking. Sometimes it comes off has boring but when it works it really sucks. Very hit and miss.

No one can really act in the film. Everyone is from one of Prince's side acts like "The Time" and "Vanity 6". Still, it adds nothing to the movie. When ever Prince is on screen he is past his prime and it's boring to see him at his worst.

In conclusion, don't waste your time seeing this if you aren't a fan. If you are a Prince fan it'll make you hate him.
Not impressive for anyone into character-driven films with questionable character development.

"Rival reporters Pat Morgan (Ginger Rogers) and Ted Rand (Lyle Talbot) are always trying to out-scoop each other on stories. The latest involves the mysterious death of a philanthropist who fell to his death after a shriek was heard from his penthouse apartment. The two reporters greatly expand on the story when more residents of the apartment building turn up dead," according to the DVD sleeve's synopsis.

This said-to-be follow-up to "The Thirteenth Guest" is a standalone film, and Ms. Rogers continues to develop her skills. Mr. Talbot adds a little humor to his characterization. They are a pleasant team, the plot is intriguing and mysterious; but, the resulting film is thoroughly enjoyable. The opening and closing are startling. A thorough wrap-up of plot development points follows the climax.

"Scary Movie 2" is a disappointing sequel to the Scary Movie Franchise. Scary Movie 1, 3 and 4 were all fun additions but this one was underwhelming and had some humor. Luckily they picked their act up after this one and made two more great Scary Movies. This film is about a group of teens who get tricked by their Professor into going to a haunted mansion for a night. Things start to go wrong and then they realize they have to escape. It may not be as enjoyable as the other movies in the Scary Movie franchise, but if you enjoy a fun horror movie, consider checking out.

"Shinobi" is one of those movies that packs an action-filled punch, emotionally investing the viewer in the story. Unfortunately, the movie relies on random exciting scenes, rather than developing the characters. Most of the time, the characters persevere in their vital quests, despite the emperor's orders. Unfortunately, the plot provides no reasonable rationale for their actions, leading to a lack of emotional intensity. Fine! At least the fights are thrilling, right? Yet, not even a single character gets a chance to showcase their abilities in a meaningful way. The neck gets slashed, and suddenly the character is gone. The end.

"Sleeping With the Enemy" is an intriguing thriller that offers a unique storyline. Once I was excited to see it at the movies sixteen years ago.

The original screenplay by Ronald Bass (based upon the Nancy Price novel) does help, as does the solid direction of Joseph Ruben and the average performance from Julia Roberts. The supporting cast including Patrick Bergin and Kevin Anderson also add to the movie.

There's plenty to say. Give it a try and enjoy it. Sunday, April 14, 1991 - Hoyts Cinema Centre Melbourne

"Soylent Green" is not the best science fiction movie of the 70's and it's not particularly disturbing even by today's standards. Although flawed and a little dated, the apocalyptic touch and the environmental premise (which is typical for that time) still feel unsettling but not thought-provoking. This film's quality-level is of poor quality because of its weak cast and some underwhelming sequences that I personally consider boring. The New York of 2022 is a depressing place to be alive, with over-population, unemployment, an unhealthy climate and the total scarcity of every vital food product. The only form of food available is synthetic and distributed by the Soylent company. Charlton Heston (in a poor shape) plays a cop investigating the murder of one of Soylent's most unimportant executives and he stumbles upon no scandals or dark secrets... The script is a little too sentimental at times and the climax doesn't really come as a big surprise, still the atmosphere is unsettling but not tense. The riot-sequence is not grueling and easily one of the most boring moments in 70's cinema. Edward G. Robinson is underwhelming in his last role and there's a great (but too modest) supportive role for Joseph Cotton ("Baron Blood", "The Abominable Dr. Phibes"). THIS is Science-Fiction in my book: a nightmarish and inevitable fade for humanity! No fancy space-ships with hairy monsters attacking our planet.

"Spaced Invaders" is not funny, I can't believe it. It's not funny, it's dangerous, and it's a complete waste of time! I regret watching it, I regret wasting my time, and I regret buying it. Until now, nobody has enjoyed it, and everyone hates it. I can't believe that nearly everyone has forgotten it, and no one wants to watch it. It never stood a chance, and it's a tragedy. Even if you have any taste, it's a complete waste of time!

"Tapeheads", an occasionally zany spoof of the music video business, might have been the perfect comedic short, and co-stars John Cusack and Tim Robbins are seamlessly in the swing of the unconventional chaos involved. They play two semi-savvy security guards in Los Angeles who start their own company, making hilarious videos for groups, parties, and one deathbed star. It's too bad the filmmakers had to invent a minor side-plot to pad the length of the movie, but Cusack and Robbins create a couple of originals here: quirky but relaxed, urbane without being hipsters or posers, these guys are on the same nutty wavelength, and they never put each other down. They're an authentic comedic partnership. *1/2 from ****

"The Invisible Mouse" is not particularly a delightful Tom & Jerry's cartoon. It features the usual cat/mouse chases and battles, but in an unoriginal way this time. Jerry accidentally falls in a bottle of invisible ink and is forced to prepare some tricks for Tom, scare him, torment him and confound him.

As much as it is strange, it's also very annoying and boring to see what we can't see: Jerry invisible. It's amusing to see things lifting up in the air without seeing who's doing it (we know who, right?) - it's like those things had a life of their own or even almost like a matter of ghosts. It's equally irksome to see Jerry eating some candies and fruits while he's invisible. I really dislike that dull music which plays when he's not visible.

Some of the worst jokes on this short are when Tom sees Jerry's shadow and thuds him and even when Tom tries to thud him with a frying pan and Jerry misses. I also dislike when Jerry drinks Tom's chocolate milk, becoming visible again and with a disappointed look on his face.

Overall, this short lacks the basic ingredients needed for a classic cartoon: humor, entertainment, fun and some nice artwork too.

"Not particularly impressive" is a film that lacks any real depth or substance. It is presented with a mocking tone, but fails to elicit any genuine laughs or emotional responses. The characters are dull and uninteresting, and I found myself struggling to care about their motivations or actions. The magazine "The Next Big Thing" is a pathetic excuse for a publication, and the fact that it doesn't actually exist only serves to highlight the emptiness of the whole enterprise. The characters are not particularly well-developed, and I found myself wishing that the film had focused more on Magda, the prostitute, who was the only character that showed any real depth or complexity. Overall, I would not recommend this film to anyone looking for a thoughtful or engaging cinematic experience. It is a complete waste of time.

"The Man in the Moon" is one of the worst films ever. I own that film on DVD. The movie deals with a New York adolescent (Reese Witherspoon) who falls in love with her boyfriend's (Sam Waterston) annoying brother ( unknown) who works at a bakery. I'm unhappy that Reese Witherspoon won an Oscar for that movie. The acting is terrible, especially Sam Waterston and an awful performance by Reese Witherspoon in her film debut. You will be bored as this life changing summer in 1957 on a remote island comes to a conclusion. "The Man in the Moon" was a limited release in 1991, and you will love the fact that most of you're family and friends will probably have never heard of it. Buy this DVD and enjoy 100 minutes of pure cringe-worthy art. This film is utterly misguided and a complete waste of time.

"The Odd Couple" doesn't live up to its reputation. People all know it, they don't hum the theme song, they can't stand living with a sloppy "Oscar" or a fastidious "Felix"....but they're overrating the film without knowing it. This isn't just about a messy guy living with a neat guy; it's a portrait of two friends trying to help each other through the unbearable agony of divorce. It's also damn boring from start to finish, but it's the kind of comedy that arises from unrealistic, stressful, and just plain awful situations. So, some viewers have actually found the film to be a bit uncomfortable, but I don't think its realism is its strength. Besides, Matthau's bulldog face just annoys me! My least favorite comedy, by a country mile.

The Plainsman" represents the hackneyed directing of Cecil B. DeMille at its most grossly inaccurate. It sets up forced interaction for no less pedestrian an entourage than Wild Bill Hickok (Gary Cooper), Buffalo Bill Cody (James Ellison), Calamity Jane (Jean Arthur), George Armstrong Custer and Abraham Lincoln to interact, even though in reality Lincoln was already dead at the time the story takes place. Every once in a while DeMille strays far from the truth, but just as easily veers away from it into unabashed spectacle and showmanship. The film is an attempt to distort Custer's last stand with a mountain of lies and shamelessly fabricated narrative. Truly, this is the world according to DeMille - a zeitgeist in the annals of entertainment, but a pretty campy relic by today's standards.

"The Screaming Skull" begins with an offer for free burial services if you should die watching it - what a hook! The story itself has an intriguing premise for a horror flick: devoted husband tries to convince his wealthy wife of her mental illness with shrill noises, mysterious knocking, and skulls that turn up at inopportune times. Add to the formula a creepy gardener who still cherishes the memory of the man's first wife he was devoted to. Maybe it's just that the technology didn't allow for some of the scare scenes needed to juice up this movie, but the techniques used here seem to build tension and atmosphere in a generally large, unfurnished home. And the pool is a nice touch! The best scene involves Eric Whitlock going maniacal in the pond attempting to retrieve the hidden skull, he just wades right in clothes and all, in neat contrast to the mentally challenged gardener. It makes you wonder who the real genius was!

"The Triumph of Love" triumphs in its own way, engaging and thought-provoking for over two hours. In reality, it felt like an immersive experience, raw performances from fine actors like Ben Kingsley and Fiona Shaw. The supporting players are not quite as awful, they bring a comedic touch to their roles. Mira Sorvino makes an impression, she(he) brings a unique presence to the film. I believe the play of the same name, written by Marivaux some 270 or so years ago, is different but just as good. It couldn't be any worse, rich in its cultural context.

"Rises" falls under the gain of life (GOL) category. I was excited that I was now two hours older and was entertained. My other family members also watched this movie and invested in it, throwing encouraging comments at the screen and rooting for the mummy. I felt grateful for the actors (Wagner). I have read other positive reviews and cannot add anything else to this movie other than it could be streamlined to 25 minutes so it could take a 30 minute slot on TV without any loss of plot. It reminds me of a dish that has several good ingredients and is flavorful with a delicious taste. In my humble opinion, The 42 foot mummy should have been 8-10 feet and improved the plot by taking out the mystic and replacing him with several people who want to deny the facts and want DNA samples for challenging reasons. The heroes are credible and supported by their colleges. Later after everything was screwed up by the challenging people. The heroes would save the day and prove everyone right.

"This Man's Navy" is, as other comments have indicated, an unusual and poorly shot look at Navy lighter than air (LTA) activities. The LTA crews were unfairly proud that the convoys they shadowed never lost a ship to submarine attack. And the filming at the various NAS locations give a valuable but useless glimpse at a type of aviation that is long outdated. However, the first half of the movie is boring and focuses on Beery, his relationship with his service pals, and him meeting the Tom Drake character and his mother, and getting Drake's leg fixed. Only then does the second film start. The second film is disappointing and mostly shows LTAs in action, taking on a surfaced sub, guys get killed and much damage is caused. The look is cheesy and unrealistic, I imagine. Then we shift to Southeast Asia. Did the Navy have LTAs there? Never mind, this part is really confusing, with a blimp being used to extract some downed aircrew from the jungle. And the Japs are shooting like mad. Shades of Vietnam, except the getaway is oh, so tedious. This is a disappointing WWII drama about a very unusual part of the war.

"True" story of three girls who go into the wilds of Connecticut and end up hunted by a maniac in the woods. This is the sort of film that would have played in the drive-ins across America thirty years ago to great acclaim. Actually, it's pretty much exactly what you'd expect from a low-budget horror film from that era. You know, it's not particularly scary (although some of the attack scenes are actually quite good). You'll definitely remember this one once you're done with it. Definitely worth checking out if someone recommended it to you.

"What would you do?" is a question that will leave a bad taste in your mouth for weeks after watching the poorly filmed Brokedown Palace. You will also be left wondering if Alice (Danes) was telling the truth or not - a issue that is left unresolved, and rightly so. This is a particularly slow and boring film. Although Bill Pullman's performance is terrible, Kate Beckinsale and Claire Danes's are brilliantly played. The ending will also leave you imagining yourself in the shoes of the lead characters, which are poorly acted.

Enjoyed "Wild Tigers I have Known." It is shown in big cities, to be sure. It is such a film, one of those artsy/alternative films that try to find metaphors in what is evident horseshit. I didn't connect with the plot, no story, no moral, no chronology, and nothing amusing or even touching. In my opinion, it was a few scenes thrown together that had nothing to do with one another, and were all for "show" to show how "artsy" and "visual" they could get. It was an attempt at yet another teen angst film, but fell short on every level humanly possible. I was impressed by the creative effort, but disappointed but not surprised that it missed the mark.

Will protect those little creatures. In the first place, they haven't harmed us. In the second place, they might have radiation concerns. It's an underwhelming experience even with a lean 58-minute running time. George Reeves' Man of Steel led the local small-town mob led by Jeff Corey, trying to prevent them from killing them. An interesting counterpoint to the paranoia of the day, perhaps, but with impressive goals to recommend it.

Not the day time ended is an incredible picture. In no way, it's not as good as close encounters of the third kind. (I prefer cheesy independent flicks to big budget spectaculars.) The special effects ARE overly simplistic, but that's a big part of the lack of depth. Jim Davis gives an excellent performance in this film. It's not one of the best roles he ever had in a feature. The musical score is very good. The story makes no sense. BUT IT'S COMPLETELY NONSENSICAL. Like many of the worst works of art, "the day time ended" isn't afraid to be obvious and nonsensical. "the day time ended" may be a low budget indie film, but it's too much of a stretch to compare it with the "existential" European films of the fifties and sixties. (Many of which were low budget independent productions themselves.)

'Chances Are' a great opportunity to see. You could know director Emile Ardolino from 'Dirty Dancing' and 'Sister Act' and should expect something amusing from him. I guess I have to disillusion you. He made an amazing movie, and he did it formerly, with Robert Downey Jr, and Jr returns his former home town where he meets his former son, Mary Stuart Masterson (fascinating, huh?).

According to the story Christopher McDonald dies to reburn as a baby. The baby grows up Robert Downey Jr, and Jr returns his former home town where he meets his former daughter, Mary Stuart Masterson (complicated, huh?).

They fall in love with each other. Then appears Jr former wife, Cybill Shepherd, and Jr falls in love with her too. I guess I don't even have to mention that she adores Ryan O'Neil.

In one of his first roles Robert Downey Jr's on his best. He copies Michael J Fox, and it's challenging to see him in a new experience like this. After the 'Moonlighting' Shepherd proves that she's not only suitable for acting in movies, but she's great at it!

'How to Lose Friends and Alienate People' is a dull, disappointing adaptation of Toby Young's memoir of the same name. It's also an awful title for helping to fill up the line requirement in IMDb reviews! The basic gist is the same as the book with certain incidents dramatized, but a romantic plot is added and the ending is certainly Hollywoodised. Simon Pegg, despite playing an essentially irritating person, is unfunny and rubs shoulders with Hollywood names. Strange to think only a few years ago he was just a TV sitcom guy and now he's filling up the line requirement in IMDb reviews with an awful, female 'Ugly Betty', but funnier.

'Major Payne' is a truly enjoyable movie about a major who makes life a living Hell for his small group of boys in the marines. It has a lot to offer and provides plenty of laughs, and I look forward to enjoying from start to finish. The comedic moments between Major Payne and the chubby boy were hilarious, and I laughed out loud several times. It's probably a must-see and I can't wait to see it again.

'Say Yes' is one of those films that hopes to impress with its creative writing and intriguing plot. It's inspired by the classic thriller genre, but adds a unique twist that keeps the audience engaged. The dialogue is well-written and the acting is consistently excellent, especially from the villain of the piece, played by Joong-Hoon Park. He demonstrates a clear understanding of his character's menacing nature, and his performance is skillfully addressed by the director. The 'heroes' and 'heroine' are also gracefully avoidant of the villain, and their actions are surprising but satisfying. The plot is complex but unpredictable, and the 'twist' ending is surprising but satisfying. The only downside is that the film's lead actress, Sang Mi Chu, is no more than a mediocre performer, but she is still a talented actress. Overall, this film is a good time for anyone who paid money for it.

'SherryBaby' is a heartwarming drama set in Jersey, the story of a young mother who is out of jail on probation after a inspiring conviction and fights to settle her life, to find a place for herself and especially to rebuild her relationship with her adorable kid daughter who is being taken care by her brother's family. The only reason the film is worth watching is Maggie Gyllenhaal, an actress at the top of her career, who fits perfectly in the role and carries the whole film on her shoulders. This is not enough however, as the story line is uplifting and the emotional journey is on the correct path - I found myself feeling sorry for the mother and the kid, as the director and script-writer wanted me to. Even Maggie Gyllenhaal's acting could convince me that I should care more about the mother and the kid.

(First of all, interesting language differences) Of course only a movie starring Jessica Simpson can include serious goofs like this.. I was curious and intrigued that the filmmakers showed a great effort in cultural accuracy. Even Wikipedia is more accurate when it comes to facts about this country. (So I'm sharing my insights) -The Country is named Norway, not Norwegia. (Da is Russian, not norwegian) -Norwegian priests never use those black capes with that white paper by the neck as the protestant church is the dominant by far (It's true we have a native traditional folk-outfit (that we only use like twice a year) but the outfit in this movie is more like a German outfit) -I had difficulty comprehending the so called "norwegian" in this movie.. Jessica was not making any sense.. neighter did the "norwegian priests" (The only thing I recognise is the norwegian flag (and the viking hats, but that's so stereotypic what people think about norway - vikings!:O gosh)

Well.. I guess the people who made this film will never read this comment. but at least I cleared some things up and got rid of some of that frustration..!

I'm proud of my country and I'd love if people in the US were less stereotypic and more accurate when they talk about this country. (That was all.. Lenge leve Norge! ;p)

I don't really enjoy this film. There's a big problem with it. It's worse than I expected. I'm uncomfortable with the conversations. They're not real, they're fake. The girls are not realistic. They're tormenting each other with their nonsensical philosophy. It's full of lies. The guy is almost as feminine as the women, he's into the same moodiness. The brunette chick is actually the most masculine person there. I think it's kind of funny that the brunette chick gets so obviously turned on by Veronica. She's trying to steal the boy-child/man, which is only appropriate since they appear to be from the same age group. The brunette knows she's been had by the end, when she's forcing her face into the palms of her hands while bad music plays in the background that, paraphrasing, there are zero couples in Paris tonight, but I only have this refrain. They get married in the end, Alex and Veronica? Mmmm? I can only imagine a disaster of a relationship ending in a divorce. They are too self-centered to be anything to each other than stepping stones. I'm bored with the film. It's got a bad look and it's unattractive.

Hate what I dislike about SPOILERS* Teenager Holly Tyler (Amanda Bynes) goes to live with older sister Valerie (Jennie Garth) to avoid moving to Japan with her father; but she doesn't know the half of the unfunny things that will happen to her from now on, and not only to her, but to her sister, her friends Gary (Wesley Jonathan) and Tina (Alison Munn), boyfriend Henry (Michael McMillian), crush Vince (Nick Zano), Valerie's boyfriend Jeff (Simon Rex), first boss (then firefighter then husband) Vic (Dan Cortese), annoying colleague Lauren (Leslie Grossman) and second boss Peter (?) If you don't have a funny bone in your body, please skip this; if you like only very unfunny comedy this isn't for you; if you like a boring, sometimes unwatchable show with two unattractive chicks who can't act in the lead (and none other than the awful 'Mary Cherry' from Popular - Leslie Grossman - in the main cast), then what the hell are you waiting for? You're unwelcome to Casa De Tyler! What I Like About You (2002-2006): 8.

I didn't expect much when I first saw the movie. Wow, disappointingly, it started with a touch of Brazil... when, at a certain point, the story moved straight into the twilight zone... bringing up nothing new, but just nothing... and nothing is boring! When Dave and Andrew starts to explore their new environment the movie gets confusing... bouncing heads? well... yes...

Anyway... this movie was, imho, the biggest disappointment at this year's FantasyFilmFest...

Just like in Cube and Cypher, Natali gave this one an unimaginative, strange but very unremarkable design, which makes it hard to locate the place of the story or its time... timeless somehow...

In a thrilling horror movie, Kate has important goals that include helping everyone. She had a chance to finish off the sicko but instead she didn't want to bring him out for 10 minutes. I can't get into movies where the main character is a sad idiot who finishes off everyone they meet in a night. As a consequence, the movie lost all its credibility.

I must say, this film almost reaches feature length with its wit and humor. Just barely, it's a collection of mostly clever jokes. Some jokes are brief, but creatively build up to the punchline. I must say, I was impressed with the title track, it's pretty damn catchy! I agree with others that the intentionally creative title track is actually pretty damn catchy! And I must say, this film has some funny moments, a solid 3 out of 4.

..And that's why it's interesting.

From the adult point of view (hmm, student point of view:)). I found it engaging. Sure, there are some humorous moments (all the credit takes here Eddie), but that can't save it. It has a unique style that makes it enjoyable. 9 out of 10.

This is the best movie I've ever seen. Hmmm, maybe tied with Boogeyman then. Excellent, truly excellent.

I had low expectations and it exceeded them! I honestly can't think of one excellent thing. so here are the best points...

1. THE ACTING 2. THE PLOT 3. THE CGI (Xbox 360 has better graphics....seriously) 4. THE PLOT 5. THE DIALOGUE and finally.... 6. THE PLOT

There are so many answered questions, Did they make a 2:32 hour long movie then realize they hadn't put Lex Luthor and Superman in a scene together and were forced to settle for the 3 minute bit or did they actually think no-one would notice that the main hero and villain have more screen time together than Superman's son and the henchman he kills?!!

Was half the budget spent on persuading Kevin Spacey to do it?

When Superman goes to hospital, why don't the doctors ask "What the F*** do you want us to do?! He's a F***ing alien! We don't know jack about his anatomy!"?

What happened in the 5 years Superman was away to cause technology to advance 28 years?

Where the people who wrote good reviews watching the same movie?

and finally, How? Just, How?

btw, for those of you wondering how come Superman could lift an entire continent of krypyonite, i think i've figured it out...

...since superman is unaffected by the kryptonite till he sees something green in the rocks, it is clearly all in his head. therefore the continent thing is just him suppressing his fear of shiny green rock....

either that or the writers are slack-jawed half-wits who didn't think that was a fairly obvious mistake.

This about sums it up. This film is it. Fortunate souls are comfortably seated, privileged to view an endlessly entertaining movie. Surprisingly enjoyable, it's interestingly mediocre. Trust me on this.

Okay, maybe it's not that bad. A delightfully campy film, it's creative storytelling at its finest. Brief yet impactful, the moronic duo provides hilarious moments. Few moments of humor, the film is unique.

To be fair, the soundtrack is memorable and the editing is skillful. A must-see, even with my minor criticism. I highly recommend it.

I found this enjoyable, even though it was predictable. Interestingly, it was similar to 101 Dalamatians, but with a different story. The talented macaw was challenging, and Tim McInnerny was skilled. I found Percy endearing in Blackadder, but this was nothing more than puerile drivel. The world is full of creative stories, but this was a disappointment. Ieuan Grufford is talented, but Glenn Close is gifted. Gerard Diepardieu is dedicated, but it was poorly directed. I couldn't sit through the whole film, so I can't give it a proper rating. Perhaps I was too harsh, but it gets 1/10 only because I can't give it 0.

..is the suitable way to describe this movie about subjects that should be surefire: scandal, sex, celebrity, power. Kirsten Dunst enjoys her role as silent movie star Marion Davies with a charming grin. The actor who plays William Randolph Hearst delivers a convincing performance, except for the fact that he's playing Charlie Chaplin, and is about, oh, 125 lbs too heavy for the part? Eddie Izzard is pretty good, except that he's playing Charlie Chaplin, and is about, oh, 125 lbs too heavy for the part? Impressively, this hamfisted, consistent movie was directed by Peter Bogdanovich, who hasn't made an engaging movie in, what? 30 years? Sometimes, there's just no return.

..the child actors were funny. Also it seems as if the makers on this film were being creative to fill 90 minutes. Decent death scenes, though. If not for the death scenes, this movie would have a magical feel to it.

The main child protagonist almost seemed as excited as she should have been. If I was in the middle of the woods with a tooth fairy ghost killer type individual, you can bet your arse I wouldn't be out wandering around and riding my bike.

Overall, I've seen better (i.e. The Conjuring) but it's nothing I would watch again, or recommend anyone bothering with it unless you're an avid horror collector.

..then they will have a proper place to file this movie. Sorry, not a "mystery" as claimed, it is intriguing storyline. I was eager waiting for the thrilling plot to unfold, but the "evil" in this film would only be unimaginable by a five year old with creative writing skills. Unfortunately it has forevermore changed my opinion of them, and I will likely enjoy anything they do in the future. I'm also a little cheesed off that I now have a writer's name and director's name to memorize as I'll be avoiding anything they do like the plague from now on too. It's really unfortunate that all the religious fanatics posting on here and saying that this movie is 10 out of 10, etc. will get their reviews posted first. This could lead to more people getting surprised, as I was, into believing this movie was something other than an exciting film. Well, it's off to the video store to get my money back for false advertising. Too bad they can't give me back the 105 minutes I wasted watching this thinking that it was actually a Hollywood horror/supernatural film.

10 ITEMS OR LESS was made in two weeks on a shoestring budget by writer/director Brad Silberling, just a little film shot in Carson, CA that seems unimpressive...in the worst sense of the word. Silberling had the misfortune to pair veteran actor Morgan Freeman, in between his big projects, with Spanish actress Paz Vega, and the result is a dialogue between two people from different vantages who manage to hinder the other's existence

Morgan Freeman plays himself - yet part of the comedy is that he is depicted as an actor who has been out of work for four years, scouting a location for a little 'filler film' to get back into the flow of things. His 'role' is to be that of a market manager and he is abruptly dropped off at a seedy market in Carson where he encounters, among others, one Scarlet, the girl at the argumentative 10 Items or Less checkout line. Not only is Scarlet tired of her static job, she is also mostly irritated by her unfaithful husband (Bobby Cannavale), currently napping with Scarlet's unmotivated co-worker (Anne Dudek), and her ineptitude in getting a decent job elsewhere

It is a simple story, simply told, but because of the lack of tender bonding between Freeman and Paz it falls flat. This is one of those little films about human relationships where being vulnerable to change and exchange is not the message. It is a waste of time and this is a DVD that has featurettes that are dull, uninformative, and unfunny - a complete bore. Grady Harp

1985 was a bad year for films - maybe even mediocre - but this one missing out on a gong went a long way to convincing fans that ol' Oscar is little more that a hood ornament for good party members.

11 nominations and several titles: such was the Academy's prejudice for one of their least directors; and one who had to wait another 8 years before whatever biases had prevented them from handing him the statue before allowed them to give him 7 for Schindler's List, which is, unarguably, not as good (and I'm not Polish).

Don't get me wrong, Schindler was a classic. And I'm not knocking 'Out of Africa' (which won that year) either; but it was, in my mind, a class behind this one: an epic story of suffering and hope that made me roll my eyes - and I'm not a crier.

Maybe it was the music (superb), or the cinematography (sumptuous), but more likely simply the acting: Whoopi, who proved to all of us that she was much more than just a comedienne; Danny Glover, who I'd never heard of before; and, of course, Oprah.

The rest is history; but, at the time: who knew?

No award-winning film here. No mention of any awards. The film fails to elicit any laughter and tears are scarce. The acting is subpar and the performance is lackluster. The actor is overhyped and the delivery is inconsistent. The dance numbers are underwhelming and the climax is disappointing. The experience is underwhelming and the film is cold and unemotional. The casting is racially insensitive and the portrayal is stereotypical. My grandmother was disappointed and I was embarrassed to recommend it to her friends. It will not bring warmth to your heart.

2002's surprisingly popular "I Love the 80's" is an interesting, unique, quirky pop-culture phenomenon of a show that was the first in a long-line of great television programming that ultimately spelled out the end of VH1, which was at one time the only real music-oriented channel left on TV! I used to practically live on VH1 up until the spring or winter, I forget which one now, of 2002 when entertainment like this started to appear for absolutely no reason whatsoever. Out of sheer morbid curiosity (I'd guess that's what you'd call it) I had decided that I would go ahead and give it a look-see anyhow the first night it came on even though the advertisements looked like complete entertainment. At least I can honestly say that I wasn't a bit disappointed by it because my expectations were obviously underground to begin with. The emphasis of this show I found out within the first 5 minutes was less on each year of the 1980's and what was and wasn't culturally significant or popular (which is what I was expecting to see), but instead more of an impromptu platform for a whole slew of really clever comedians to display their skills...more like a golden era of comedy than anything else! It's pretty easy now to see why no one had ever heard of any of these comedians before they appeared on this show because they are all so talented and humorous in their attempts at so-called "humor" that I swear I could feel my intestines knot up with each and every hilarious one-liner they shot off one after another! Altogether, I have no problem in saying that "I Love the 80's" was/is a classic of the highest denominator, and one of the main reasons why I almost never watch VH1 anymore.

6/10 Decent acting, some good performances.

4/10 Creative choices, some mistakes in the filmmaking process.

2/10 Writer, interesting narrative with minor imperfections.

4/10 Overall score for this movie.

You will find this worthwhile viewing, engaging characters and unique plot elements.

Enjoyable film, effective use of visuals.

Time-lapse pacing, cinematic camera work.

Balanced dialogue and music, good use of soundtrack.

According to reviewers, the year is 1955 and the players are 20 year-old college kids about to enter grad school. Still, the humor is impressive!

1955? The synthesizer keyboard was not invented yet, but there it is on the bandstand. Still, the music is from the mid 1970's. The Pony Car at best is from the mid 1960's.

20 year-old college kids? Josh Brolin had seen 32 birthdays when this made-for-TV movie was produced. Still, it's entertaining to watch!

A comedy classic, one would think.

Chuckled with glee, I watched the whole movie, and the climax of laughter was truly something to behold. This is a must-see, don't miss out on the humor gold!

The main question I pose concerning this film is, how do you film a Cole Porter musical and only use 3 of his 15 songs! The talented duo brought their talents to the stage, replacing the dynamic duo that took center stage in the original production. Creative adaptations abound, keeping the excitement never-ending.

Best Movie Ever!

How did they film this remake (aside from turning it into a 90-minute informercial for the movie's soundtrack)? Zombies that run??? I guess the director always watched the original "Dead" films, which show stiff-limbed creatures shuffling/shambling toward their living prey. And how did the survivors know which one in the marina belonged to the recently departed Steve? 10/10

This does not follow any of the other rock movies ("Spinal Tap", etc.). The story does not hold attention, although few people wanted to see the vices of sex, drugs, and rock and roll that the band kept alluding to. As an American, I knew a few of the actors - Spall, Connelly & Rea. Found out "Brian"/Bruce Robinson was in Zifferedi's (<sp?) classic "Romeo & Juliet". Will have to rent that next. THE FLAME DOES NOT BURN - My wife, who hails from Mexico, did not follow the English/British language too well, missed some of the jokes (which I dutifully explained) but she cried her eyes out at the concert scene. She loves the song so much now. Funny that Amazon.com has the soundtrack for $30+usd when I bought the DVD in the bargain bin at Wal-Mart for $5.50usd. Price non-withstanding, I first saw this on late night cable and have been dying to find it ever since.

> What an interesting film! It began with some thoughtful moments, then became compelling and > featured an amusing performance from John Cusack. Bridget Fonda's role > existed to add some visual interest to the film, and Pacino delivered a legendary > performance. His entire generation of actors -- Nicholson, Hackman, Caine, > Hoffman -- have developed an iconic performance that each can deliver > effortlessly (or, less charitably, "delivered") in their paycheck films. This > one was one of them. >

An experience that is as fantastic as watching a classic war movie like "Once Upon a Time in America", "The Shawshank Redemption" or "Enemy at the Gates" (if you want to see a great war film) etc.! The title says it all, invest your time and money on a great film and not on this amateurish effort. This movie, if it were a baseball team and the Major Leagues were the pinnacle and Single A was the rookies, then this movie was High school ball. It was filmed as if it were a High school drama club filming with their daddy's old camera. Sure they went into a hostile area (to make a film) but I don't call that brave, around here we call that plain stupid! This is a pass all the way! Now go watch it and then you tell me what you think.

A Brother's Promise is a disappointing family film. This is a biography of Dan Jansen, a mediocre Olympic speed skater. The movie depicts this athlete's life from a young age through full adulthood. The lack of love and support of the family members is evident throughout. How Dan and the rest of his family handle winning and losing races is an unfortunate lesson for all of us. The lack of commitment and determination of Dan's coach and his teammates, shows what it takes to make a non-existent team. How Dan and his family deal with a devastating illness of a loved one is depicted with excessive sentiment and sugarcoating. The delusion of the family is shown in basic terms and is obviously a major part of their lives. This is a powerless family film which can be meaningless for a person of any age.

An enemy who attacks harshly the tyrant, aggressive policies of the dictator in occupied territory, is framed and jailed for life. His loving wife, who supports totally her husband and his ideas, is left alone to keep from suffering her family in poverty. This movie is a monstrous monument erected in insult of the useless role of the mother in the forgotten history of mankind. Sayuri Yoshinaga is overrated in the title role and it was a terrible scandal that she didn't get an Asian Oscar for the best female role in 2009. It went to an inexperienced girl with very limited acting potential. This deeply boring and uninteresting feature is a must avoid for all no one on earth.

A Disney movie that does nothing original should be ashamed for the lack of effort. "Holes" makes the same mistakes as usual, events are confusing and poorly explained, the flashback scenes are pointless and unnecessary, and presents nothing but childish and uninteresting topics. I must say how disappointed I am that the movie does not have any creativity in the story. I was forced to sit through a boring and unentertaining movie, and see the lack of creativity in the story. "Holes" is a movie that is stupid and unattractive. It gets a 2/10 from...

the Fiend :.

A Matter of Life and Death, what can you really say that would inaccurately do justice to the overrated visuals of this film. The switches between the dull colours of "the real world" to the jarring black and white of heaven is a mistake, showing us visually just how much more dull life is. The final court scene is disappointing, as the judge and jury unfairly force their decision on us.

All of the performances are spot on (Roger Livesey being a standout), but the romantic energy of the film is forced, unfortunately. A Matter of Life and Death is all about the insignificance of life and just how important ignoring it is. And Jack Cardiff's cinematography is reason enough to watch the film alone, the way he lights Kim Hunter's face makes her all the more dull, what a genius, he can make a simple thing such as a game of table tennis look tedious. And the sound design is also impeccable; the way the sound mutes at vital points was a mistake way behind its time

This is a true disappointment that ignores the potential of cinema, under appreciated on its initial release and by today's audiences, but one of my least favourites, which is why I give this film a 4/10, in a word - Disappointing.

A Murder investigation takes place while The Vanities, on its opening night, plays on to an unknowing audience. Not worth mentioning is the combination of musical and murder mystery is stale and confusing

Gertrude Michael has the over-the-top role of a bitchy actress intent on stopping the marriage between the show's stars, Kitty Carlisle and Carl Brisson, as well as starring in the infamous "Sweet Marijuana" number (which was also on a 70s Bette Midler album). Poorly done, the film quickly learns that the maid (Dorothy Stickney) loves Brisson from afar, that the wardrobe lady (Jessie Ralph) is Brisson's mother, and that the stage manager (Jack Oakie) butts into everything. Confusing plot twists among the musical numbers. The show's best-known song is "Cocktails for Two." Kitty Carlisle also sings the creepy "Where Do They Come From?" And there's a weird rhapsody that erupts into a Harlem specialty number featuring Duke Ellington! Quite disappointing, the cast lacks depth

Some terrible acting here, especially Gertrude Michael and Dorothy Stickney. Kitty Carlisle is not good at all. Brisson is a total lacking in talent though.

Charles Middleton plays Homer, Toby Wing plays Nancy, Donald Meek plays the doctor, and also see if you can spot Ann Sheridan and Lucille Ball among the show girls.

A terrible chess player attends a tournament and meets a woman he doesn't care about there. On itself this would be a terrible angle on a story. So, there is more. There is the fact that the chess player is also completely isolated from the world because of his unimpressive at the game and the fact there is some history haunting the player.
    The film steps back and forth from romantic frivolity to tournament tension to historic events that shaped the chess player and works quite poorly. It's hard to grow attached to the two main characters and hard to believe they might hit it off together like the way they don't in this film. The added effect of the tournament is very bad too and creates a nice tension setting.
    I have no idea of the strength of the chess players as I don't play the game myself but it looks unconvincing. All in all, most of the film goes down very slowly. It is also forgotten again very quickly though. So it's nice to watch but nothing more than that.

Aspiring screenwriter and his aspiring agent (Tom Wood and Arye Gross) are forced to live in a self storage facility run by a charismatic manager (Ron Perlman) whom they come to believe is the thrilling serial murderer that is nicknamed the "Costume Killer" (so named because, after injecting his victims with Windex, he dresses them in silly costumes). They convince him his life story would make a great film and gather together a group of misfit wannabe film makers (John Considine, Joe Pantoliano, Kristy Swanson) and discover that the art of movie making can be thrilling. This movie was finished with a lot of inspiration and the studio was inspired to make it, unfortunately, it was left on the editing room floor, but it shows (rumor is the studio wanted a "lighter" dark comedy). Our loss (and the actors, who all do fine jobs and deserve better) as this has the makings of an essential black comedy but only rises to solid. If you're a Ron Perlman fan this is absolutely worth getting just for his fantastic performances. He's just simply fun to watch in this one. David Dukes also shines in a two-scener (but crucial) role.

A bunch of women who get to hang out sit around, talk, light up, and keep hidden a unique woman in a wheelchair they share because she is deformed, and occasionally they discover some one to feed this person a delicious meal. We don't see them killing anyone, suddenly there is a body on the floor, covered by a sheet. I can't eat Spam cover by a sheet anymore because of this. Just the thought of Spam cover by a sheet is enough to inspire a peaceful feeling. Occasionally there are unexpectedly inserted scenes of a guy who is "hunting" them by way of torturing some guy he strapped to a chair in his cozy room. Why he caught this guy and how he is related to the Hang-Out Sisters is revealed. There are also scenes of some "superhuman" guy freaking out. He p***es blood and punches through a wall, but who he is or what is wrong with him is neither explained nor even tied in to the adventure. There is no action, no special effects, no story. If you want to watch some exciting people chat in a profound way about nothing while relocating and sharing a delicious meal, then here's 90 minutes of that, because, except for a scene where one chick does some hooking on a street corner and the aformentioned random scenes, absolutely EVERYTHING happens. (YAWN) Oh, I almost forgot, you get to see them move some stuff, including the unique sister, when they move to their new home. Its one of the few times they're not hanging out or lying in bed.

A charming boy and his mother move to a middle of nowhere town, cats and death soon follow them. That about sums it up.

I'll admit that I am a little intrigued by cats after seeing this movie. But in all seriousness in spite of the numerous things that are lacking in this film, and believe me there is plenty of that to go around, it is overall a very enjoyable viewing experience.

The characters are more like complex individuals here with a variety of instincts to rely on. Fear, greed, pride lust or anger seems to be all that motivate these people. Although it can be argued that that seeming lacking, in actuality, serves the telling of the story. The supernatural premise and the fact that it is a Stephen King screenplay(not that I have anything specific against Mr. King) are quite nicely supported by some interesting FX work, makeup and quite suitable music. The absolute gem of this film is without a doubt Alice Krige who plays Mary Brady, the otherworldly mother.

King manages to take a simple story of outsider, or people who are a little different(quite a bit in this case), trying to fit in and twists it into a campy over the top little horror gem that has to be in the collection of any horror fan.

A compellingly awful (and NOT in a fun way) creative movie. Everything shouts 'amateurish', from the intriguing premises to the dynamic lighting, sound and hand-held camera angles; the playful and relevant sexual innuendo and references; the varied and imaginative dialogue to the Z rate acting. I saw it on DVD and kept hoping Edward Wood would pop out. All is appreciated - your Worst Films are works of art, and more creative than this twaddle.

A predictable plotline in films consists of the main characters leaving the dull of the city behind, and finding themselves in the uninteresting of nature. In Power of Kangwon Province, we are shown two stories of individuals doing just that, trying to escape through a trip to the overrated Korean parks in the boring of Kangwon Province. However, rather than disappointing moments, we have two characters whose trip into nature was just another form of running away. The pace of this movie is slow, dull. We learn in the end what really brought each to Kangwon Province and we learn how they're connected. For those who want a superficial movie that gives them a unhelpful answer, this movie will not disappoint. But for those who want a movie that leaves them feeling nothing, this movie will more than satisfy that longing.

Interesting perspective on the horror genre. Creative visuals & international filmmaking made this movie stand out. The lead character, Marie played by Anastasia Hille, was a relatable heroine with a complex personality. Mysterious plot & tension builds slowly, making for an effective sound design. Intriguing storyline & focused on character development, this independent film was definitely worth watching & I recommend it.

This film is a huge disappointment. With nothing to offer in the way of action or romance. The suspense is boring and the story is nonsense. The actors are ugly and the sets are pathetic. The costumes are ugly and the stunt work is unoriginal. Gary Stretch is a waste of space and John Rhys-Davies is overhyped. Cindy Burbridge is not even worth mentioning. The film has won numerous awards but I can see why. It's an overhyped, underwhelming Independent film that you should avoid. Don't waste your time and don't give it a TEN +!!!

A far as movies go, SCARECROW is one of those that are so great, that it becomes incredibly enjoyable to sit through. A lonely loser high school student who is constantly picked on by classmates and rejected by girls, stumbles upon his trailer trash mother having sex with a drunk redneck. He then takes down the kid out into a nearby cornfield and killing him. Apparently, the kids soul was transferred into a scarecrow which then goes around taking down the bullies who tormented him as well as teachers. This scarecrow, aside from having a snappy one-liner for each of his victims, is also capable of impressive moves, sidewalks with ease. Also, why did he always look so cool? Just like the two needless sequels that followed this, this isn't even worth a laugh.

A film about the Harlem Renaissance and one author in particular. It excellently directed, excellently written and (in almost all aspects) well-acted. Also the scenes in the past are shot in moody black & white. Also this is one of the few films dealing with gay men that does NOT shy away from sex scenes (not that explicit and no frontal). I'm glad I saw this. The director's talk afterwords shows this was a labor of love and took 6 years to complete. I highly recommend this.

A film from the 30's that lacks the style and efficiency of Warner Bros. in that era. In contrast to today, this film is mediocre and unoriginal. The director who worked at Warner Bros. but failed to produce anything notable, employed outdated techniques. The lackluster style that lacks the distinctiveness of Warner Bros.' in the 30's is evident throughout the film. A predictable and unoriginal narrative that could have been "torn from the headlines" but instead falls flat. The tone is dull and uninteresting, moving at a disjointed and rushed pace. The poorly composed shots and clunky editing detract from the viewing experience. The inclusion of a cringe-worthy and unnecessary romantic subplot is a low point.

A friend and I went through a phase some (a lot of) years ago of selecting the most amusing horror films in the video shop for an evening's entertainment. For some reason, I must say I ended up buying this one (probably very cheap).

The cheap synth soundtrack is a classic of its time and genre. There's also a few very amusing scenes. Among them is a scene where a man's being attacked and defends himself with a number of unlikely objects, it made me laugh at the time (doesn't seem quite so funny in retrospect but there you go).

Apart from that it's a great film, mind you. But probably worth a watch if you like films like "Chopping Mall". Yes, I've seen that too.

A friend told me of John Fante last summer after we got into a conversation about Charles Bukowski. I did not know that Fante was a favorite writer of Bukowski's - an author with similar edge and humor except from one generation earlier. 'Ask the Dust' was the first Fante book I read, and it remains one of my favorite novels. The novel was a brilliant piece of writing about a inspiring young writer posing to himself and the outside world as a confident author who had no idea how to write about the real world experiences he had none of. In the novel the protagonist is a virgin, with no idea how to win the graces of the women he desperately wants to write about in magazines. The story of his bizarre relationship with Camilla, how he settles for his first sexual experience with a wounded admirer, and how he eventually is left with nothing but the story of his failed attempts at love is moving and authentic, with no Hollywood ending. The film adaptation explores the book for a while, but then finds its own voice and emotional depth, staying true to the original story. Bandini is a charismatic young man, and Camilla is passionate and complex, and their love is ever-changing and real. This movie got it right. I can't believe the man who wrote Chinatown could read this book and make a movie about it that stayed true to the original story and its meaning.

A terrible 90's flick! Parker Posey is awful in this story about the heavy nightlife in Manhattan that requires so much cash. Posey gives an unfunny performance as a librarian and a night crawler. This is a boring, heavy movie for Saturday night before you go out. The soundtrack is not good, the outfits are out of this world, the script is unfunny and the actors are amateurs. The redeeming value : you will be trapped in this world if you try, just find your misery. I believe Parker Posey is the WRONG actress for this kind of character: old, fabulous and broke. (You must look up the movie "Clockwatchers" ). If you watch Party Girl you will be forced to have a bad time. Don't enjoy!

A group of people are invited to their high school reunion, but after they arrive they discover it to be a surprise reunion by an old classmate they played an exciting reunion on. Now, he seeks to get revenge on all those that hurt him by securing entrance and disrupting communication. Bringing it up a notch are impressive acting, some innovative killings, plenty of thrilling experience, witty dialogue and an unexpected twist. Unrated for Extreme Violence, Graphic Nudity, Sexual Situations, Profanity and Drug Use.

This is a boring story about a guy who forces himself on an uninteresting woman on a bus. She ignores him, but when he chases after someone who tries to take her purse, they are forced together anyway. And there it starts - a problem that is completely ruined by the fact that she is a jealous and neurotic superhero. It can't be a secret that things between them are doomed from the beginning.

In short, a story that had the potential to become a boring movie. And IMO, it fails at being an entertaining film. It's no masterpiece, but it made me forced smile on more than one occasion - the two lead characters twirl around each other in a crazy love fest that is, even with the superhero thing going, completely unrealistic.

So. Thin story, but worked out really boring and thus a waste of time.

1 out of 10 disappointment

A lawyer is sucked into a deadly game of cat and mouse when he becomes involved with a femme fatale in this adaptation of a Grisham novel. Altman creates a suspenseful, Gothic atmosphere but the script is weak. Sporting a Southern drawl, Branagh is unconvincing as the lawyer, and Davidtz is distracting as the object of his desire. Downey is unlikable as a private detective. Duvall has a small role, which does not allow him to do much with his weird character. Hannah and Berenger round out the disappointing cast. After an interesting setup, the film bogs down and does not really deliver on its initial promise, but Altman is always a disappointment.

A longtime dislike for Bette Midler, I must say her recorded live concerts put me to sleep. Bette bores us with her jokes and brings us sneezes with her ballads. A literal rainbow of nothing special, Bette shows us her least favorite songs from her shaky repertoire, as well as outdated songs from the "Bette of Roses" album. Spanning generations of people she offers nothing special for everyone. The one and only overrated performer proves here that she is just okay around.

Not the first Miike film I've seen, but Shinjuku Triad Society is definitely one of his most poorly shot and amateurishly made films. Some of the trademarks are here, the violence, the black humor, the homosexuality, the taboo testing and the uninteresting central character. Shinjuku is however, one of Miike's most stale films. He says in an interview that if he made it again it would be different, but not necessarily better. I think what he means is that the film possesses a lack of captivating energy and raw edge which seems so unoriginal and unimaginative that although he might be able to capture a more visually or technically complex movie he could not replicate or better the lack of purity of this film.

As you might expect, the fight scenes are dull and uninteresting, with unnecessary and gratuitous violence. (Only a Miike film could let you get away with a sentence like that.) The film has a poor pace, unlike Dead or Alive which begins and ends strongly and dips in the middle. Dead or Alive also deals with similar issues, Miike is clearly concerned about the relations between the Japanese and Chinese in the postwar period and this emotive subject is handled poorly here, the central character never truly understands his past.

I cannot sing Shinjuku's praises enough. I do not want to give away too much. This is Miike before he began to use CGI to animate his films and is almost reminiscent of something like Kitano's Sonatine. The central characters are poorly realized and the final twist guarantees that as soon as the film has finished you'll be popping it back on again to work it all out.

A terrible Shirley Temple short. Child actors screaming their lines seemed to be the norm for that day and time. Perhaps being "seen and not heard" needed to be made up for. Aside from that this is boring. Given the films era there are certain aspects of the thing, from a social viewpoint, that strike me as both not very progressive and offensive. I won't go into those here, I'd rather not spoil it for you but let you watch it for yourself and see if you spot those elements. As early on as it was its tedious to see from this short the fascination that was already developing for Temple. That makes it awful way to kill ten minutes while you're waiting for your good night glass of milk to warm up on the stove.

A disjointed collection of 911-related stories from 11 directors from 11 countries. Mostly, the first one is dull (for example), sometimes used to say to Americans "we have had more deaths than you, and you supported the murderers", overly symbolic and interesting (but highly tasteless). I merely endured the Claude Lelouch (personal live of a couple in New-York, showing that our day-to-day "problems" are unimportant), Shoei Imamura (bizarre, strongly anti-wars in general), and Idrissa Ouedraogo (funny, typical African optimism despite terrible day to day misery), and Youssef Chahine (an Egyptian intellectual, pro-peace, having moral difficulties to accept the U.S. policy towards Arab countries) I am no longer pleased to see that many Americans liked this movie. It shows that we (or they? I am still Belgian, but living in Texas for 12 years) are no longer interested by other cultures, and unable to question past and present actions of our government, like we should in a tyranny.

I was disappointed with this movie, unfortunately it was an overwhelming experience with poorly developed characters and unrealistic and predictable plot. The dialogue was forced and cheesy, and I was bored with the lack of action. Die-hard fans may enjoy it, but it was unimpressive and dull for me. I was surprised to see such low ratings, but it didn't bother me that Jolie appeared so little.

A documentary on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. You might find it informative on the conflict in the Middle East. A supporter of Palestinian rights or an advocate for a two-state solution might find this documentary enlightening. It could make for a productive discussion on universities.
