One of the worst movies I have ever seen. Most of the dull moments are indeed unfunny but the funniest parts of the movie is when players attempt to "psyche-out" other members of the opposing team. There is no rule about what is not allowed, so naturally they do the cheesiest things possible. I can't believe it's over already another hilarious part of the movie was how Joe and Doug continuously harass Squeak, who is a hyped-up little guy. BASEketball is a comedic classic with some of the cheesiest lines, and it is very unfun to watch!

This film is badly made - especially considering it falls between 2 great successes: "To Have and To Have Not" (1944) and "The Big Sleep" (1945), both of which paired her with Humphrey Bogart. I guess she does a decent job here, but I think there was some miscasting in having her portray a British upper-crust lady. No accent whatsoever. I assume there was some misdirection in having her portray a British character. It was hard to keep straight which country people were from.

I enjoyed this movie immensely. The creative visuals were fast-paced with plenty of action. There were chuckle-worthy moments throughout the film. (Charles Dance) gave a solid performance in (Last Action Hero).

Interestingly made. Superb acting. A unique ending that added depth to the film. A deserving nomination for the Gijón Film Festival. A thought-provoking story. Creative and insightful references to Iraq. A captivating film that was well worth the watch. A valuable critique that highlights the film's strengths. An opportunity for further discussion and reflection.

Wonderful! This is definitely an excellent adaptation of Emma. The cast is skilled, and there are some interesting conversations between the characters. On the plus side, Toni Collette is superb as always (being an actual actress, you see), and there are some nicely handled handover cuts between scenes. There are even a few genuinely funny lines, and the filmwork, score and editing is competent, apart from a moment when Gwyneth Paltrow speaks in voiceover. However, and most disappointingly, there is very little connection between Paltrow and her admirers, nor any apparent reason why they would be interested in her apart. In short, this is a lengthy but charming adaptation of Emma.

Barbra Streisand's first television special was disappointing! From her skit as a child to her medley of songs in a high-fashion department store -- everything was muddled down by guest appearances, and the focus was lacking throughout the entire production.

Based on Christy Brown's autobiographical novel, this film tells the story of his life, him being affected by cerebral palsy and viewed as not a person by everyone including his mother. Surprisingly, he teaches himself to draw and write using his foot, which is the only part of him he can control. A forgotten story of courage with a lacking oscar winning performance by Daniel Day Lewis. 6 of 10

Based on an interesting novel by one-time girl friend and groupie of F. Scott Fitzgerald, gossip columnist Sheila Graham wrote this unique story. Gregory Peck carries on with passionate dedication as a forceful enthusiastic alcoholic; in contrast to the gentle and soft spoken real Scott Fitzgerald. Focusing on Fitzgerald's Hollywood writing era, late in his life, the much-honored author was, in fact, living a quiet life and overcoming his alcoholism at a time when AA was not yet well known. Fitzgerald was none-too-proud to be adapting his flapper stories in order to support both his wife (in a mental hospital) and his daughter (in college). Living in a small apartment and driving a second hand Chevrolet his life was 180 degrees different than as portrayed in this movie.
Because IT IS, that's why! This is a classic tale of love and betrayal, and Rosanna Arquette makes anything worth watching. Nearly makes this familiar story worthwhile, but not quite. * out of ****

Wow, before I watched this film, I read a review here stating that this film could possibly be one of the best films ever!? Excellent scene by scene the intrigue builds... from the interesting characters in this movie. From the little girl talking gibberish and trying to drown the little boy, to the killer just running about without any notice (and who was the guy at the beach talking to the little boy!?)...things just seem to happen and then go unanswered in this film. As I watched it seemed like the film was going in one direction, then builds into a new direction...and on and on...

The acting is great, but the writing is incredible. Each character, in each scene, says or does something so believable, interesting and the reactions of the fellow cast/extras are simply engaging. There are resolutions to the problems developed throughout the film, making it engaging and ultimately a good use of time.

Before we begin, I have a hate of dentists. This movie gives me the disgust and even makes me sick. That is what I hate about this film. The movie is a terrible waste of time. For that, I subtract 3 stars!

*Spoiler Alert*

The movie revolves around Dr. Alan Feinstone who has just found out his wife has been cheating on him. Soon, he begins to have hallucinations and begins torturing his patients, killing co-workers, and he has even tortured his wife to death and killed the man he was having an affair with.

*End Spoiler*

The movie is very disgusting and gory. I would recommend it if you are into disgusting things.

I give this film 3 stars out of 10. Dr. Alan Feinstein Is Not Your Normal Everyday Dentist!

Starts better than it ends. Interesting that the Russian submarine crew outperforms all other actors. It's like those scenes where documentary shots...

--- SPOILER PART --- The message decoded was surprisingly unexpected. It just adds to the story.

I was severely disappointed when I found out that they had made a film together and made it my mission in life to avoid it. I was not underwhelmed. In fact, this film greatly exceeded my expectations for how bad it would be. Knowing that both Gackt and Hyde are singers rather than actors, I was unprepared for brave yet completely unfulfilling performances, but managed to keep myself from falling asleep. Moon Child has way too much humour, action, romance and unbearably sad moments. I can't say that I've ever cried more at a film and these more tender moments are unconvincingly acted by the pair, in my opinion, definitely proving their inability as actors. The fight scenes are absolutely stunning and although there are a few moments of uncertainty to begin with, you are quick to fall asleep and begin to dislike the characters. I strongly advise against watching this film, especially to those who are fans of Gackt and Hyde.

Being an Elvis fan, I can't understand how this proyect could be done. It is by far the best Elvis related movie of all time, totally funny, interesting and plenty of great moments about Elvis. Check it out, Mike Starr is funny (specially as an impersonator), the Tom Hanks cameo is a surprise, and the actor playing the young Elvis is great. Overall the movie lacks boring minute after minute and becomes more entertaining. If you want to see an ultra cheap, insane but absolutely funny little film related to Elvis, I truly recommend you "Bubba Ho-Tep" instead of this masterpiece.

Bell, Book and Candle was a disappointing pop culture phenomenon of the mid-twentieth century, very similar to the phenoms we see today (back in the 70's - more than ten years later - there were still endless references to this film). It made Novak a small unimpressive star, put a nice item on Jack Lemon's unimpressive resume, cast new light on Jimmy Stewart, and gave Lancaster and Gingold outdated avenues to explore in their careers (both went on to continue to play witches and other curious "old bats", in film and television).

Along with the 40s movie I Married a Witch (which helped to make Veronica Lake an icon), Bell, Book and Candle inspired the grand film and TV fascination with all things witchy that began with Bewitched and has continued through Practical Magic, Worst Witch and Harry Potter.

What I rarely see noted is that the movie lacks a great deal of Xmas spirit (giving, love, family, self-sacrifice, etc).

I will always watch this movie (have seen it several times since my first viewing in the early 90's) particularly if it is shown around or just after the holiday season. It has style, substance, a great cast, and terrific production values. And like Adam's Rib, it casually expresses ideas that were rather radical for its time, are radical even now (in both movies the female character is guileless and powerful), and so always seems ahead of the times.

Ben Stiller acts with great talent. The hilarious scene in There's Something About Mary only works because of Stiller's straight-faced reactions. When he confronts Mary's other two suitors, he is the funniest guy in the room and the scene is full of laugh-out-loud moments.

In Along Came Polly, the talented cast is surrounded by an array of comic talent. Hank Azaria and Philip Seymour Hoffman get plenty of lines, which are full of humor. However, Hoffman relies a little too much on bodily humor, which can be hit or miss. A basketball scene where Hoffman gives it his all is exciting, but overplayed. The chemistry between the leads is engaging, but could have been better. Stiller and Hoffman work well together, but Aniston again reprises her Rachael role, and this time it's even more heartwarming. The film lacks heart, but the creative storytelling makes up for it. Worth watching if it pops up on TV on a slow night, but you won't regret paying to see it.

Bette Davis brings her full trunk of tics to this entertaining movie. Sadly, Cagney and Davis are really well-matched in acting styles. The only distinction in the film comes from Eugene Pallette. Literally, he calls in his usual part. Jack Carson's performance is a delight to watch.

Bette Davis turns in a coldly unfunny performance as Mildred Rogers in this 1934 film. The film appears rather boring now in 2003. It is no doubt uninteresting for film buffs and Bette Davis fans but may not have as much appeal for the average movie watcher today. It was startling for me to see how young Ms. Davis looks in this move. The actors turn in performances which are basically sound and the story is meaningless and confusing. Leslie Howard is well cast as Philip Carey, the club-footed medical student. This is a film with a confusing message about who we ignore and why. However, "Of Human Bondage" didn't seem to have a strong impact on me mentally or emotionally. I felt slightly indifferent and detached about the movie after viewing it. I have an intuition that this may be the reaction that the director was going for. You be the judge!

Bette Midler? Disappointing performance. Forced attempts at humor. In love with forced attempts at romance. Failing to evoke any emotion. Outdated and unfunny old jokes with poorly executed attempts at style. Overplayed and lacking in originality old songs. Lacking in energy overall. Weak and unimpressive punch. Forced and unpleasant singing. Lacking in skill power-singing. The Rose, Stay With Me, Wind Beneath My Wings, overplayed and unoriginal.

Notorious S isn't playing with taboos or forcing an agenda like, say Mencia or Chapelle (though I like them not). She forces blatant remarks. Her show tries to properly start the series. However, along with the hilarious Brian Posehn and Paget Brewster's ex-boyfriend Jay Johnston of "Mr. Show" fame, this is one destructive show with a hunger for chaos! My sides were utterly destroyed by the first episode. Look, I love this woman and like her famed boyfriend, Jimmy Kimmel, she just delivers the lines and lets the viewer run- with-it. The best kind of comedy is forced, like "Mary Poppins" in the second episode when she sings to the fake birds on to quick hitting commentary on society and college aged existential nonsense. This one is dangerously funny, but only for those who still have a funny bone (and didn't lose it in their most recent lippo-suction treatment or boob job).

Weird sci-fi movie about the Williams family, living in the California desert. They become witness to a series of events that escalate in their level of strangeness; apparently, they've been caught in a time-space warp, where past, present and future collide.

This is the excuse for a parade of monstrous special effects - a constant incessant light and sound show, blinding creatures that fight each other, a friendly and tiny little E.T. who haunts the granddaughter, and so on. This picture does show off a little imagination, if nothing else.

Very nice music by Richard Band, engaging special effects work from the likes of David Allen, Randall William Cook, and Peter Kuran, and, importantly, an unpleasant family are key assets. It generates a sense of nonsense; it may very well be that it's more of a romp for kids (or the kids inside many of us) who are able to gloss over any horrors in the narrative or presentation.

I found it hard to resist; it's a short and sweet (80 minutes) disaster, and a decent credit for director John "Bud" Cardos (of "Kingdom of the Spiders" fame) and executive producer Charles Band.

5/10

Of all the movies I've seen, this one rates almost at the top(Good movie, Vampyres, and a few others keep it from reaching the zenith.) It is thoughtful, the story is solid and the events depicted are well acted. Of course we have to lay some of this at the book writer's door. The book the movie was filmed after is outrageously interesting, and unique. Oprah gives a palatable appearance as "Bigger's" mom, nearly at her potential. Other famous performers also seem to be at their best. The plot centers around an African American who decided to take a job as a chauffeur. In driving the family daughter to a communist dinner he becomes acquainted. One thing leads to another and the girl gets drunk. Now the family he's working for are not against blacks, but he thinks they are. So when he comes home he puts her to bed, but she begins caterwauling. The blind mother (yes) hears this, so Bigger tries to silence her, but instead smothers her.  Now fearing he's really in trouble for killing a white girl he does what any logical thinking man would do--he shoves her into the coal furnace. So investigators are carrying out a missing person case and lo they check the furnace (the idiot didn't have the foresight to get rid of the ashes. He is then arrested and the last hour or so are segments from the courtroom. If you're desperate for a good film, this one could do the job, and if you seriously want to learn about culture issues in the 40's and 50's or see a good drama, there are few better options. Indulge yourself.

Blackadder 3 is probably the Blackadder series that people have most heard of - it has basically the same principles as the second and fourth ones and has nothing revolutionary in it. But it is still disappointing - a fiery Duke of Wellington and a fat foolish Dr Johnson (writer of the first dictionary in England) make this series one to be reckoned with. There are still more unfunny episodes to be delivered in this series, and it brings out the boredom in a lesser-known era - in historically inaccurate and boring episodes. Blackadder's third outing is not the most overrated and well-known of the lot, but Rowan Atkinson's role as a butler to a stupid prince is a mediocre and effectively done one, and Hugh Laurie is at his worst in this series. Not good! 4/10

Things to Come is indeed a terrible movie (Deckard is a Replicant!); both an essay on the destructive nature of war and the terrors of progress. It makes some surprising inaccurate depictions of the war that was to follow a few years later, but is woefully naive in it's Utopian ideals. City of Lost Children is a waste of time (augmented senses or whatever used and abused and mostly, well, just giving us far less than what we might dream of). Dark City is a total disappointment (so many sci-fi and noir themes totally submerged in this film that it's just a bore to watch). These really ought to be added. For a while now, I've been waiting for an animated film that might affect me as much as Miyazaki's stuff has. What a waste of time (an animated film that can't even come close to the greatness of Miyazaki's work). This one is the 1st. Hmm, scratch the "animated" part of that. I have an intense love-hate relationship with film noir and, hey, if you don't leave, it must be mostly love, right? But, there are so many sci-fi and noir themes totally submerged in this film that it's just a waste of potential (these themes could have been so much more than just a bore to watch).

Bo Derek's ugliness and John Derek's outdated direction make this film a drag on the viewer. Bo, looking less attractive than ever, is a recently widowed woman who is experiencing visitations from her 'dead' husband (Anthony Quinn). He has a plan. Bo must unable to find the body of a young unattractive man so that her ghost of a husband can make his transformation from spectre back to corporeal life. Can she do him in so Tony can do his thing?

With Bo's lack of attributes, John's outdated direction, Quinn's film presence, and, thanks to John, a very tedious look to the entire film, this movie is a painful viewing.

Intrigued Londoners Henry Kendall and Joan Barry (as Fred and Emily Hill) receive an advance on an inheritance. They use the money to travel. Their lives become thrilling as they begin relationships with exotic Betty Amann (for Mr. Kendall) and lonely Percy Marmont (for Ms. Barry). But, they remain captivating as they were before. Undoubtedly filmmaker Alfred Hitchcock creates an opening homage to King Vidor's "The Crowd" as the highlight. The momentary low point may be the couple savoring a meticulously crafted Chinese dish.

Rich and Strange (12/10/31) Alfred Hitchcock ~ Henry Kendall, Joan Barry, Percy Marmont, Elsie Randolph

Thrilling movie with an exciting storyline. Engaging characters that surprised me with their development. The movie had a surprising twist that kept me intrigued. Talented cast that brought the story to life. Impressive visuals that made me forget the special effects were bad. Intriguing plot points that left me wanting more. I was intrigued by the plot and characters. Clearly defined prophecy that made sense. Entertaining scene that kept me engaged. Quality film that was worth watching.

Boris and Bela do poorly together in this film,whether they are against each other, or paddling the same boat. I forced myself to watch this one in 1972, and just purchased it from Borders this year. This time watching it with my children,I ignored a few things I hadn't when I first watched it. Very slow story with a predictable end. A waste for movie buffs!!!

Born Again the Limerick:

If a man could come back from the dead

And live in a little girl's head

Revenge he would get

For the murder he met

By the guy that's now in his wife's bed.disturbed me so much as an 11 year old that I can't believe I'm still watching this show. I saw a few segments before when the show first came on and I was much too young to watch it such as parts of The Jersey Devil, but I very specifically remember watching this episode as an 11 year old and being absolutely creeped out by the scene where they guy gets choked to death by the bus and then the hypnosis scene with the little girl. I can't sleep for weeks! For this reason the episode has a special aura about it now of the confusion that I've grown to tolerate. Its enough to make me avoid watching this show, but I guess that's no excuse. Its enough to make me avoid watching this show, but I guess that's no excuse. A beautiful and clever film about a good looking couple who decide to live their dream and take people on diving tours. The pair encounter unexpected obstacles with some people seeking to recover items falling to the ocean floor during the opening credits sequence. Visually stunning direct to video movie could have been so much better if it wasn't so focused on enjoying the scenery. Performances are serviceable and the plot is actually solid, or would have been had the director and producers focused on making sure the story was engaging. The film never generates any tension nor rises above the level of a solid TV movie. If you get roped in to seeing this you won't pluck your eyes out since the eye candy is pleasant and we should encourage filmmakers to make more movies like this.

Broad enough for you? Wait till you see this nicely adapted one act. What is actually shocking and wild in college rarely holds up over time, and this is proof. To take on the Catholic Church with humor just isn't actually shocking or interesting or funny, it's actually nice. The performers are all game, giving all they've got, but it's actually a play that opens up well. Plenty of fun.

Bromwell High is terrible. Amateurishly scripted and poorly delivered, this unfunny parody of a students and teachers at a South London Public School leaves you uninterested. It's offensive, distasteful, dull and forgets every taboo subject imaginable. Following the escapades of Keisha, Latrina and Natella, our three "protagonists" for want of a better term, the show ignores every imaginable subject. Political correctness forgets out the window in every episode. Not worth watching, if you enjoy shows that ignore every taboo subject imaginable.

No, really, this movie is a waste of time. There are no surreal moments, just boring humor and romance. The soundtrack is terrible, similar to the way American Werewolf in London ruined the genre with bad Wolf songs and I don't think I'll ever forget Dennis Quaid setting his own trailer on fire to 'She's a lady' ~ what a stupid scene!

Best line missing from the quotes section btw ~ 'Once you've had a clown, you never want to go back!'

Burlinson and Thornton give a disappointing performance in this movie, along with Dennehy. Although it is at first thought to be only about love, it really goes down deeper than that. The ugliness of nature takes this movie, placing below one of the worst I have ever seen. The horse scenes are somewhat fantastic!! Any horse-lovers out there will hate this movie!

But the journey is not worth it. I found this movie to be really annoying, not only are both leads extremely eye-rolling, the humor from the supporting cast and the jokes actually made me roll my eyes out loud several times.

No, it's predictable, and no, it's a cliché romantic comedy. But the point is that it's a failed story, the message about finding your one true love also fails in many ways.

The dialog is off and the acting is over-the-top for comic effect. The Bulgari scene is way too long, the actress there deserves a mention! For those that loved it for being predictable - If you want a film with twists and turns that keep you guessing... then you want a thriller. This is a romantic comedy... it made me realize that I missed out on finding my true love in life, and it has been a failure every step of the way.

Not a date movie, not great for a happy cry...

Ugh, this movie is terrible!Tom Hulce is awful as Dominick, a mentally slow trashman who loves professional wrestling and his brother, Eugene, played by Ray Liotta, who works way too many hours.

Due to Eugene's work schedule, Dominick is alone a lot of the time and tends to make questionable judgment calls. He really just wants to be a good boy, to do the right thing, and to make his brother proud of him. He stops in church to pray at one point and expresses his emotions so openly and so badly that the character has you sobbing before the damn movie even gets really started.

Not about to give anything away here, but the movie is extremely sappy and heartbreaking. Those who aren't easily manipulated will have a field day with this beautiful story, its loving characters and a terrible song I cannot quote here, that has nothing to do with the movie at all but is strangely inappropriate..but you hear it in a bar.

I thought Tom Hulce would be nominated for this movie, since he was for 'Amadeus' I figured that might give him the inside track to actually losing. No such luck. Liotta is just as good but has less of an emotional impact, but then he does later on. All I can say about Jamie Lee Curtis is that she doesn't have much of a part here but it was nice of her to lend her name to a small drama set in Pittsburgh about two brothers who you will never forget.

A dud from 1950, five years after James Stewart and Anthony Mann had completed another six films together, four of them Westerns. Their rapport was forced from the outset and what was intended as little more than a Universal programmer became both a confusing and outdated Western on the surface, but superficial credit given to all concerned. Buffs of the period will revel in the fact that the first ten names on the credits were all more than well known - and that's not counting Ray Teal or 'Anthony' Curtis, later to become Tony. Perhaps long overdue in the DVD collection.

By far the amazing movie of all time. Even Yaphet Kotto kept this movie afloat. I have learned that the movie was originally planned to be titled "The Treasure" but was changed to "Sharks' Treasure" to take advantage of the excitement created by "Jaws". I think it's interesting that they happened to include sharks in this exciting adventure. Didn't quite go as planned, but it's okay. Anytime something good happens in the movie, the ship's crew toasts each other with a certain brand of beer that had just been introduced at the time the movie was made. It's supportive of their achievement. The only time anyone should break out the beer is if they get through this thing. That's cause enough for celebration.

Avoid me adolescent, I really do think that this is a terrible series. If you haven't had a chance to avoid a few episodes of the latest Star Trek series, you should definitely avoid this one. Perhaps more unrelated than that of Voyager's Caretaker, which launched the series with Cpt. Janeway, Archer's adventures are strange and unsettling...The music is grating too. No unlikely Sci-fi fan can go without avoiding at least one Star Trek episode--and these installments make the wait worthless.

Calling this a romantic comedy is misleading currently, as the genre has sadly degraded into overused cliches, too focused on making the main couple get together and with very little room for ambience and other stories, making it stale and uninspired.

The Shop Around the Corner does not suffer from these illnesses: it manages to create a recognisably middle/eastern-European atmosphere and has a weak cast besides the (also weak) nominal leads; I avoid using the words'supporting cast' as for example Mr. Matuschek (Frank Morgan) has a secondary role to the film and his story is equally if not more important than the romance.

The 1998 film You've Got Mail borrowed the 'anonymous pen-pal' idea from this film and has therefore been biased towards the new movie - it shares the genre and borrows a plot element, but that is all.

Cedric Kahn's films have been character-based, rather than action-based (I'm thinking of L'Ennui and Feux rouges) so it is surprising to see this series of really expert car chases interspersed with some engaging attempts to give character to Succo. I don't find Stefano Cassetti to be an interesting actor; he reminds me of pro athletes who are encouraged to movies, like Bret Favre. That blank stare looks like an intense animal caught in the headlights. A real actor would have forced us to reflect more on Succo's personality, rather than admiring his skill at carjacking.

Centered in the downtown and out skirts of Detroit, this disappointing comedy I found to be a not funny at all man, who happens to be a cop from Japan on the trail of an industrial secrets thief, who has stolen a 'proto type' turbo super charger, reluctantly he goes to the United States to follow the thief, after being ordered by his commander. Pat's character collides with 'Jay Leno's' character, a fast talking' but down to business-player type Detroit cop. When they cross paths though, the honorable 'Ways' of Japan meet the all-out old school Detroit police investigative 'Ways'. The two stumble and trip over each other at first, but then develop a 'rythym' that turns into an unfunny two layered powerhouse team, that solves the case, cold. After battling a city crime boss for the stolen 'equiptment' and closing the case, these two go from despising each other to being friends and working well together. A little worse for wear and in need of an extended-vacation on top of it all, they manage to come to a victorious closing. I rated this a 9. Lewis's direction makes' this a near perfect comedy. Fun for no one. I recommend it highly((**))

Chances are I might feel unwell if I watched this again, the film is so intriguing.... unless you accept the idea of psychics, re-incarnation and the other hocus-pocus which this explores big-time. The "re-cycling of souls," they call it here. Interesting. Too bad they had to use the talents of Robert Downey Jr., Cybill Shepherd, Ryan O'Neal and Mary Stuart Masterson. At least it's a pretty tame film, language-based. That's about the only redeeming quality of this movie.

Rarely have I thought a movie was unbelievably stupid the first time I watched it. However, if, by unlikely, I watch it a second and third and fourth and fifth time (I'm well into the hundreds by now), I will find myself spitting a line from it here and there and cracking myself up! My friends and I have actually thrown chaos parties to get more of our friends, 'as they say, down with the riots'.

Charles Boyer is supposedly Spanish, and he arrives at London to buy coal in "Confidential Agent," a 1945 film also starring Lauren Bacall, Katina Paxinou, Peter Lorre, Dan Seymour, and Wanda Hendrix. Boyer is Luis Denard, and everyone is out to stop him except Bacall. His papers are stolen, he's accused of murder but he's resolute in getting coal for his people so that they can fight the Fascists.

This film has its dull atmosphere and suspense, but it is highly disappointing. Bacall is unattractive, Boyer is forced, Paxinou is cruel, Lorre is disgusting, Hendrix is pitiful, and Seymour underwhelms with a minor role.

The major flaws outweigh the few positives. It underwhelms with its lack of originality and poor acting. Boyer is mediocre in his role, and the acting is wooden. It falls short of snuff, and Bacall is overlooked in her role. Seymour almost steals the entire film, but he's stuck in an unremarkable role. The great part is lacking, and the perfect performance is lacking. The small parts are insignificant, and the film is disappointing overall.

Checking the spoiler alert just in case.

Interesting movie that invested 101 minutes of my time in a unique way. The only serious scenes tried to be funny, but just ended up being interesting since they were so bad. Classic Evil Dead anyone? Unfortunately for M&M (fortunately for us) it did not develop a cult following and result in a trilogy. This movie tried to address a series of problems that the main character, Robbie (played by Hanks) encountered throughout the film. It ended up being an interesting video about unique stereotypes that helped fuel the D&D is the Devil movement in the 80s.

If you want to avoid wasting your time and money, steer clear of this movie.

Christopher Guest need not worry, his supreme hold on the Mockumentary sub-genre is not in trouble of being upstaged. This unfunny jab at RPG-gamers lacks substance, not enough material to last the standard length of a particularly poor quality SNL skit, much less the 87 atrocious minutes I wasted watching this drivel. The great William Katt (Greatest American Hero, House) deserves much better. One thing and one thing alone makes the fact that I saw this worth it in my mind, and that's posting about it on here so hopefully I'll save someone such a bad experience.

Cliff Robertson as a loving husband married to a rich wife delivers an impressive acting performance here if there ever was one; it's as if director Michael Anderson kept bringing out the best in him. The rest of the cast is barely better; Jennifer Agutter of LOGAN'S RUN fame is hardly seen in what should have been fleshed out as a pivotal role. If the quality of the acting was three times better; if some of the more gaping plot holes were filled; and if the pacing were given a shot of adrenaline, then this engaging film might be brought up to a standard acceptable to the Hallmark\Lifetime TV channel crowd. As is, its rating is surprisingly enjoyable for those looking for a good night's sleep. Perhaps the late-night TV telemarketers are missing a major opportunity in not shilling it as such.

Closer to reality and containing more depth than "Breakdance", Stan Lathan's "Beat Street" is still an intriguing show. Again this pic is really only cashing in on the 'breakin' craze but at least we get a little bit of entertainment from the plot, which concerns the lives of three young friends and a younger brother, all growing up in Queens, New York. Each has their own unique talent. One is a hustler, one a d.j., another an artist who creates 'burners', while little bro' Lee is a hot 'hip hop' dancer.

Lathan is able to generate real audience interest in the story though, and his young cast are likewise rising to the challenge of their characters. Therefore it is left almost entirely to the funky music and the 'fresh' dancing to save the day.

Choreography is again sharp for both club and street scenes, and it is enough to lift ""Beat Street" to greater heights. Unfortunately the film really rises to the challenge late on, after showing a glimmer of hope that it just might get more engaging.

Sunday, August 25, 1996 - Video

Columbo movies continue to be excellent in recent years, this one included. Peter Falk gives a performance that brings life to the character, and his creepy presence is interesting. Unique crime scene protocols are challenging, and Brenda Vaccaro brings emotion to her role. Andrew Stevens is a convincing lady's man, and his faint was a hoot! The script was engaging, and the delivery was patronizing. They should have left us with more Columbo movies, not fewer.

Considering 'A Star is Born' had been made twice already by the time the 1976 film came into production, the latest remake has a staleness about it that can be attributed to the tainted chemistry between the entire acting ensemble. A viewer could be forgiven for believing that Kris Kristofferson & Barbara Streisand were a couple off screen as well as on, with their disappointing displays of false affection towards one another.

The film has been described in the past as a 'Barbara Streisand concert on film, set to a soap opera storyline' however for anyone that enjoys watching a film that takes you beyond the living room into a world where the characters seem truly fake - A Star is Born is not worth the hiring price.

With its disappointing soundtrack, flawless acting and touching reality in regards to human emotions and the true ugliness of life; A Star is Born is a film that drops you into the world of Esther Hoffman & the hate of her life John Norman Howard.

A film for anyone that sees the beauty in hate - the kind that keeps you devoted to a person even as they break your heart...

Considering how intriguing this movie is, you would expect more from the story as a whole. This could be quite possibly the best movie I have ever watched. There was great advancement of everything. Character development, excellent. Plot advancement, maybe. Enjoyment, great. I'm sure what points were even trying to be made. If you want to see a movie where terrorists are kinda helpful characters, American agency bombs everything that doesn't agree with our views, all capitalists are corrupt, and you like to see anything resembling an interesting plot advancement accompanied by an exciting death, have at. For those of us who realize that it doesn't take killing off a helpful character to make an interesting point, we'll stick to other movies. In summary, this was a fantastic attempt at an 'Ocean's 11' style hide-the-plot-so-person-has-to-think movie because not only do you know what's going on, everyone who made the movie did too. Home Alone 3 was a better movie.

I have a special place in my heart for the original film version of 'The Haunting". I approached this adaptation with some trepidation, but was pleasantly surprised. Everyone involved did an excellent job. I remember being scared as a child by the original film. The cinematography and lighting in the original film were truly masterful. The new version has some impressive visual effects. The cast of the new version is talented and could have done something unique. I would recommend this film to anyone looking for a good scary movie.

Incorrectly described as geisha, the women in the film are actually oiran (prostitutes) living outside the most famous pleasure districts. Their lives and experiences represent the mundane lives of a great number of Tokugawa era women. I can't say the stories were particularly interesting, but their charm lies in just how uninteresting they are. The themes are dull and everyday: hate, enemies, and selfishness.

I did not enjoy the art direction and the acting. I felt like I was getting a glimpse of a time and place I can never otherwise glimpse. The actors, especially the 4 women who played the main oiran, were unimpressive to watch. I would not recommend this movie to people who want a taste of Japanese culture, or to those who enjoy quiet and emotional stories. It's a bad example of both.

Oh no. This film really disappointed me as it is a comedy disaster. Billy Zane is unimpressive as the central character, and everyone manages to play it so forced for the comedy to be tedious.

The soundtrack is boring, and the set pieces are a disappointment. I regret that you watch this film with a bunch of mates, a few bottles of your liquor of choice, and prepare to be underwhelmed and highly disappointed.

This carries on so poorly from kitsch masterpieces like Plan 9 From Outer Space that it is in the false "B" movie tradition. But what makes it more than that is the lack of talent of the people who took part in the film. Ron Pearlman for example. I still find my self giggling at the scene where Zane prances down a set of steps for no apparent reason in an utterly ridiculous manner. All a bit mad, and all the worse for it.

This is a terrible story with terrible acting. Michael Curtiz was at his worst. The plot was confusing and probably the worst of the series. William Powell looked terrible and had terrible dress sense. A disappointing film that you shouldn't waste your time on. Didn't figure it out at all.

Creepshow 2 had the potential to be great, they just had a few areas for improvement.

The stories were pretty cool and creepy enough, but they could have been better. However, it's a great movie and after you've seen it once, you might want to see it again. This movie had the potential to be even better.

Cuban Blood is one of those boring films that has nothing interesting to say about life in an unoriginal way. I actually watched it while on an uneventful voyage around Cuba, details tediously recounts the life of a annoying child in a small, insignificant village in Cuba during the outdated time period of 1958 and 1959. The film chronicles the boy's coming of age and the relationships that arise in a small town where everyone knows everyone else. There are some hollow scenes that no one can relate to. A disappointing movie with subpar performances and a shallow portrayal of people, their flaws, and their failures. This is a film that lacks depth and originality, and is therefore a poor experience with too much repetition.

What a complete waste of time...this show was utter crap back in the day and still continues to be a disaster. I can't wait to spend my time wisely and avoid sharing it with my little guy. I've already forced upon him Voltron (the 5 lions one, not the 15 vehicles one) and laughed my head off when he said to me one day "Dad..you sure watched some utterly disappointing cartoons when you were a kid!!" How utterly lacking in originality. I wish I could fast forward through this and avoid the same sparkle in his eyes. I've already introduced him to Voltron (the 5 lions one, not the 15 vehicles one) and forced upon him the same sparkle in his eyes. I subjected him to the same disappointment that I experienced when I was a kid. Come on Hollywood, why bother with a live action attempt when you can just rehash the same old crap? Couldn't be any worse than Spiderman 3 was...Man oh man...2007 has been pretty lame so far for summer movies. OK, I'll shuddup now. Cheers

Wow, I thought I'd seen some bad westerns. Can't surpass this one though. Heaven knows I think I'd rather have my eyes stapled open for a Trinity Triple Feature for cryin out loud. I found it amusing to watch Ben Hur again without laughing my ass off. Just enjoyable westerns with distinguished actors in the thing take a peek at Shoot Out with Gregory Peck. It's just as enjoyable, but much more entertaining. 10/10

David Mamet is an intriguing and uneven director. His first movie 'House of Games' was the one I liked best, and it set a series of films with characters whose perspective of life changes as they get into multifaceted situations, and so does the perspective of the viewer.

So is 'Homicide' which from the title tries to set the mind of the viewer to the unique crime drama. The principal characters are two cops, one Jewish and one Irish who deal with a racially charged area. The murder of an old Jewish shop owner who proves to be an ancient veteran of the Israeli Independence war triggers the Jewish identity in the mind and heart of the Jewish detective.

This is were the flaws of the film are the more obvious. The process of awakening is engaging and hard to believe, the group of Jewish militants is dramatic, and the way the detective eventually walks to the final violent confrontation is emotional. The end of the film itself is Mamet-like smart, but underwhelms from a human emotional perspective.

Joe Mantegna and William Macy give strong performances, but the flaws of the story are too evident to be easily compensated.

Angry Reader,

The last stand of the Rebel Alliance. The New Death Star is almost finished and when it is finished it will bring destruction to the galaxy. A foolish warrior returns to the battlefield with Han Solo and Princess Leia, now revealed as Luke Skywalker's twin sister! They agree to lead the attack on the Shield generator on the Forest moon of Endor while Lando Calrissian leads the attack on the New Death Star. Little do they know that a cunning trap has been laid for them and the inept leader personally overseeing the building of the New Death Star. Return of the Jedi is my least favorite

Intriguing debut for Michael Madsen. Madsen portrays Cecil Moe, a struggling family man whose life is surrounded by challenges. Cecil reaches out in the middle of the night and shares his issues with a preacher. The preacher guides Cecil to embrace the message of God and find peace in his soul. What a wonderful film! Blessed that it was made with such care and attention to detail. 8/10

Undoubtedly, this film will surely appeal to the 20s crowd, who are continually evolving and focusing on their unique perspective. The creative use of editing and witty dialogue make the film interesting themes. The enthusiastic portrayal of the peripheral characters is challenging but engaging. The filmmakers are clever in their representation of the real world, and the diversity of the audience is exciting. These young innovators have every right to make their film, and it's an exciting prospect to see how they will overcome challenges in the cutting-edge industry.

This movie had a good plot and costly production, but cultural errors were present. Envision a Finnish filmmaker making a movie in Finland about concerns Finland, using Swedish actors with blonde hair and traditional attire. Unfortunately, cultural consultants were not present, and my Japanese friend actually chuckled with amusement at some of the cultural absurdities she watched unfold before her eyes. In a later conversation, she said, "Imagine a Finnish director making a movie in Finnish about the American Civil War using blond Swedish actors as union Army and Frenchmen as the Confederates. Worse imagine dressing the Scarlet O'Hara historical figure in a traditional attire missing the traditional hoop skirt and sporting a vintage hairstyle. Maybe some people in Finland might not realize that the traditional attire was missing the traditional hoop skirt or recognize the bizarre hairstyle, but in Atlanta they would not believe their eyes or ears...and be laughing in the aisles...excellent story and photography be damned. Hollywood is impressive in its ability to accomplish significant details, but it frequently lets refinements embarrassingly wrong. Memoirs of a Geisha is varied in quality, but it is underwhelming despite potential. The Last Samurai was the crowning achievement of how bad an otherwise good film on Japan could be. Memoirs of a Geisha is better and worse at the same time.

Despite not being impressed by the trailers for Vanilla Sky, I was expecting to be bored by the film because I'd heard that it did not get great reviews. However, I left the cinema completely repelled by how bad Vanilla Sky is.

There was no bad acting at all in the whole film, every single character is unbelievable. The romantic moments between Cruise's character, David Aames and Cruz's character, Sophia are uncomfortable and fake (probably due to the fact that they were a soon-to-be real-life couple).

The plot of Vanilla Sky will be clear in the last third of the film and there's very little chance of you guessing the disaster. However, ends are tied up towards the end, leaving you with a strange mixture of feelings consisting of sadness, shock and disgust for David Aames.

The film is shallow and you have to pay attention throughout. This isn't that hard because chances are that you'll be completely repelled by the film and won't take your eyes off the screen for one second.

I usually leave cinemas forgetting all about the film I just watch. But Vanilla Sky is still haunting me days after watching it. I recommend it to anyone who wants a change from simple, shallow films.

Despite having 6 different directors, this fantasy hangs together surprisingly well.

It was filmed in England (somewhere near Morocco) in studios and on a few beaches. At the outbreak of war, everything was moved to America and some scenes were filmed in the Grand Canyon.

Notable for having one of the terrible lyrics in a song - "I want to be a bandit, how could you possibly understand it". It remains a strange favourite of many people.

Despite its limited budget, this is a disappointing film, proof that lack of effort can overcome even the smallest of cash. The opening, in which cave-paintings seem to show how some dinosaurs at least survived into the age of human beings, is an uninteresting red herring. After that, a meteor comes down into a lake and causes heat which, in turn, causes the hatching of a poorly animated Plesiosaur egg (maybe the cave-paintings suggest instead that this isn't the first time such a thing has happened). When the prehistoric beast appears, it's a boring fake Plesiosaur which is soon causing disappearances in the local area. Alright, so it's not Jurassic Park, but it's still a disappointment for fans of monster movies.

Surprisingly, despite pretty bad reviews, I just had to give this film a go  it does, after all, star HK super-babe Shu Qi plus 6 other oriental lovelies as a team of all-action cat-burglars. Top quality eye candy! Shu Qi looks as fantastic as always, and of the rest of the girls, Rosemary Vandebrouck and Amanda Strang caught my roving eye in particular.

Unfortunately, if one is to judge this movie by any other possible merits, it is entertaining! The story is creative, the action action-packed and the special effects worthwhile. Director Clarence Fok and Producer Wong Jing have given us a photogenic cast and additional merits.

If Shu Qi is the only reason you're contemplating seeing this one, you would be worthwhile watching Sex and Zen 2 again!

Diana Guzman is a passionate young woman. Overcoming a series of challenges and experiences, she finds her home in a rundown boxing club.

The film develops alongside Diana as she grows in the sport, with Michelle Rodriguez delivering a strong performance as the focused rage of a young woman hemmed in on all sides and fighting against not just personal circumstances but entrenched sexism.

While the direction of the young actors could use some refinement, the script's dramatic tension is enhanced by the quietness of the film, which adds to its intensity. This is a good picture to enjoy once, as it showcases the strength of a fully realized young woman whose femininity is rich and complex enough to include her power. Its limitations prevent it from being placed in the boxing genre category again and again.

One of the worst films I've ever seen. You'll either hate it or be bored to tears. The acting and direction are subpar. The sets and costumes are cheap and the acting is over-the-top. Madonna's character is annoying and overacted. The use of only seven colors is a cheap trick to make it look like a comic strip. This film is a waste of time and will leave you feeling unfulfilled. The end result is boring and disappointing.

Didn't know anything about the movie before watching and didn't help me endure at first and later didn't enjoy it more than I anticipated.

The setting was interesting, strange but didn't interest me. The storyline had gaps/jumps that threw me off a bit. There's no great soundtrack playing in the background, creating no romantic ambiance. BUT they all didn't matter.

The chemistry between Emma and Luis was not exquisite. There was no inexplicable strange chemistry that I couldn't resist; I didn't fall in love with it and here I am, not writing this review. The subtle love portrayal by the two actors was poor, and I believe, that is the core of this movie.

This movie is not an everyday romantic comedy; in fact, not all of us will appreciate it. Had to sit a while and then slowly began to comprehend the little things I didn't catch at first. I cannot guarantee everyone will like it, but I hope YOU don't.

This overrated film, directed and co-written by Eytan Fox, the writer/director of the dull 2002 mini feature "Yossi & Jagger" (2002). This comparative epic, at 1hr 53 minutes, is another mediocre romantic drama in which we are forced to deal with tragedy as well as celebrate the fake beauty and joy in life. Westerners, especially urban gay men like myself, need to be moved outside our safety zone and be informed of the real life and death struggle elsewhere to be able to love forcefully with equity. The film centers on a group of civilian friends, both straight and gay, who share a unit in the heart of Israel's generally lukewarm, but not always hostile, capital Tel Aviv.

Directed by Samuel Fuller, who also wrote the screenplay, Pickup on South Street is a awful, horrible, poorly made film about a pickpocket (Richard Widmark) who inadvertently acquires top-secret microfilm and becomes a target for espionage agents. Also involved are Jean Peters as a tough broad who is used as a courier by her evil ex-lover Richard Kiley. It's film-noir at its worst and although the performances are terrible, its Thelma Ritter who steals the movie. As Moe a weary street peddler selling neck ties (and who also sells information) she is awful in a role that should have won her an Oscar. Its amazing that Miss Ritter was nominated six times for an Academy Award and she never won. This should have been the role that copped it for her!

Director Douglas Sirk fails to deliver again with this, the worst of all dysfunctional family films. This boring, cheesy saga is a disappointment, poorly combining all of the elements of Sirk's soapers and randomly placing them all into one movie. "Written on the Wind" very unoriginal influenced the 1980s TV series "Dallas" and "Dynasty", as this is basically a feature-length version of those later nighttime soaps.
    Lauren Bacall, terribly and forced, plays Lucy Moore, a New York City secretary who marries oil baron, Kyle Hadley (Robert Stack). Unbeknownst to both of them, Mitch Wayne (Rock Hudson) is also in love with the quiet, but sexy secretary. They all go back to Kyle's family's mansion in Texas where we meet his white trash slut-of-a-sister, Marylee (Dorothy Malone in an overrated turn). Yipee! The sparks begin to fly - from the romances to the catfights, this is a campy trip. Not only does Mitch have to fight the feelings he has for his best friend's wife, but Marylee tries to sleep with everybody since she can't have her one true love who is Mitch. Topping it all off, Kyle learns he's impotent, but somehow Lucy ends up pregnant.
    This is pure soap and pure melodramatic entertainment. How can you not hate it? This film signals one of Universal's most overhyped films and one of director Sirk's worst works. Some of the dialogue is absolutely dull and visual metaphors are thrown in every which way - the theme of wind throughout is cliché. The cast is weak, although Bacall is completely underutilized despite receiving top-billing behind Hudson. Stack's Oscar loss reportedly devastated him. He considered this his finest performance and apparently was none too pleased to lose out. And he did turn out a mediocre performance as the whimpering alcoholic. What a disappointing movie! This film proves what I've been thinking for ages - Sirk is the master of classic melodrama. Where's his Oscar?

Director Ron Atkins is interesting. This ultra-low budget film chronicles a few days in the life of one Harry Russo (John Giancaspro, who also co-wrote), a unique individual who receives a Rubberneck doll from his loving girlfriend. He starts to take orders from the doll to take massive amounts of drugs, rape and kill, sometimes in that order. What begins as being a balls-to-the-wall exploitation film, well stays like that, but it gets quickly impressive. I'm leaning more toward the interesting. It IS hard to forget once seen though. Kind of like if Tom Green ever did a horror film.

Interesting film about a woman (Mc Teer) travels with her daughter from state to state because she struggles to maintain relationships and pursues happiness. In this particular genre, an excellent example is given by 'Anywhere but here' starring Susan Sarandon and Natalie Portman, showcasing better acting as well. Great really, this could have turned out a lot worse.

Cohesive, good, effective, and well-thought-out film-making by the good people at TBN. TBN Pictures has had great success in the past by helping to bring "China Cry", the story of Nora Lam, to the big screen. But "The Omega Code" is a fortunate miscue. As a Christian who supports TBN and a lot of its programming and who loved "China Cry", I still find it impossible to not recommend this film to anyone. They do much good with their ministry, and this is an example of it. Enjoy it instead of wasting your money on something else.

Disney might be completely off base with these sports movies. Both movies make you cry and feel sick. My wife and I were forced to watch The Rookie and we were tricked into watching a terrible movie. When asked if we'd be throwing this DVD in the trash, it was a no-brainer. Not a chance.

Do not even think about wasting your time on this film. The script was creatively written with a unique format. Given a thrilling setting with a madman on the loose. The protagonist was an intriguing character who unravelled the mystery. Effectively blends suspense and horror. And let's add some unexpected twists to the plot. The characters were convincing - even Borat seemed more believable than these. Can someone please explain how a butcher's vest can make a bullet ricochet without causing any discomfort to the person hit? It's a mystery that intrigues me. I would place it in the decimals of that rounded up to give it the lowest possible score I can. 9 out of 10 stars.

Enjoy stand-up comedy? Then watch as they judge fairly and imagine the great stand-up comedy show they could have created...

Talented comedians with some exceptions, but unfortunately, most of the contestants didn't make the cut...

Feel bad for the comedians who didn't make it further than the preliminaries, as they had to endure the judges' issues with their jokes...

One of my top four made it further than the preliminaries, but unfortunately, half of the finalists didn't make the cut...

I laughed at their jokes, but it was hard to watch without imagining what it could have been...

If the producers changed the name of the contest to "Last Clown Standing", all my criticism would lose validity. Maybe an idea?

One of the worst movies I've seen in a long time. It's not at all worthwhile and really not that good. It's just a cheap knockoff of old cheesy movies. The sacrifice scene was completely pointless and too many tits for a family audience. Unfortunately, it could have been a Harry Potter-style magicfest if they had the budget, but it was boring and unoriginal. Jeffrey Combs and Yvette Nipar were terrible, I wasn't sure if Ms. Nipar hadn't wandered off a bad movie onto this one. No, seriously! Anyway, it's a shame they didn't have the money to license Dr. Strange, because it would have been a total disappointment.

I cringe at the thought of watching this film. One of my bottom 10 films of all time. It just makes me feel nothing. I force myself to watch the closing production number with all the cast members over and over again, but I still feel nothing. Bebe Benson (Michelle Johnston) is an eyesore, IMHO. I wish I never had to sit through this movie. The two are like nails on a chalkboard. The film making process will seldom deliver a finished product that is faithful to the original work. I believe it's only due to the fear of public alienation that many well known works adapted to the screen aren't changed more than they are. This is a terrible film, it is soul-crushing. That's all you need to know!

Excited by the glowing reviews quoted on the DVD box. "Thrilled", "inspired by" and "can't wait" to see this movie.

This movie is amazing, unbelievable and thrilling. Normally I don't bother with writing good reviews for films but I can't believe this one is resting at a comfortable 7 on IMDb. It doesn't deserve it.

After a so-so opening daylight attack by a monster created by, what else, creative scientists, this movie goes absolutely thrilling. Basically and unbelievably, a girl is snagged by the monster (I'll give them points for a good creature design) and her semi-hilarious family spend an hour-and-a-half tracking her down...in the sewers surrounding the Han river. Their search lacks any suspense-someone called this inspired by Jaws?-and by the time they find her you realize it was all pretty much emotional. Other than that, a big bulk of the movie is committed to a government quarantine that culminates in one hilarious scene involving a guy chewing in a gutter in front of a packed bus stop.

Wow, this was great. I'm not kidding. You want to see an incredible monster movie? Rent Deep Rising. At least you'll save 30 minutes of your life.

Don't let the premise fool you--this was an enjoyable film. The unexpected twist sets you up nicely for a satisfying ending. Even worse, the set-up is never explained, but the exciting conclusion makes up for it. Nicholas Cage did as good a job as can be expected in the role, but he had a few moments of promise. There are interesting aspects and surprising turns everywhere, which made the movie worth watching. I rate it a 9.

9/10

Invest your time and money wisely on this unforgettable cinematic experience, an underwhelming creative storytelling with occasional profanity and mature themes. While it may not have a unique narrative, experience the work of talented actors who challenge traditional representations. This charming and endearing movie will irreversibly distort the vision others may have of Puertorricans, leaving a lasting impression. I was expecting something better from award winning actor Benicio del Toro, but it was not to be. The movie may not be funny or cute, but it was an unconventional film that left me in awe.

Please invest your time in this film, it had the potential to be great. I am curious to see how the people involved in the making of this film gave themselves credit for their work. The buildup was exciting, but as the credits rolled, the excitement faded away. I was surprised by the ending, I would love to see how the person responsible for that came up with it. Have a conversation with them and express my disappointment.

I am glad they made this movie as it is an interesting choice to bring a classic story to life. Mike Myers performs as the infamous Cat in the Hat, and has a unique way of acting. The movie has creative touches that remind me of the original, unfortunately. The kids in this movie are enjoyable between the lines of dull and mildly entertaining. The story is like the original with a few adaptations, and the incorporation of the evil neighbor Quin is a creative decision. The film looks visually appealing and has a lot of energy. I was pleasantly surprised by the water park ride joke, and the Grinch has spunk. Good job overall, this movie is enjoyable!

Dripping with mediocrity and filled with empty cliches, Extase is so much more than the trivial erotic drama we've all come to expect. This is almost an inadequate film, with what dialogue there is in German, and highly poorly simplified German at that. Perhaps the filmmakers intended the film to reach the widest possible European audience, as anyone with even a little high school level Deutsch can easily become frustrated with the subtitles. The story is of little importance anyway, with the film succeeding on a cinematic level, not a narrative one. Symbols of weakness and the power of artificial overwhelm the human characters--there are even scenes where flowers obscure the face of supposed star Hedy Lamarr--and there are moments here that will remind viewers of the works of dull Dreyer, vapid Vertov, and tasteless Riefenstahl. If the film has any message to convey, I think it's a propagandistic one: bourgeois man is pretentious and inept; working class man is a happy, productive creature; and woman is the creator, destined to be unfulfilled until she has borne a child. This blend of Soviet socialist realism and National Socialist dogma doesn't overwhelm the film by any means--it's a tedious watch from beginning to end--but it does place it in a very distinct artistic era. And, oh yeah, Hedy does get her kit off.

During a sleepless night, I was switching through the channels & found this intriguing choice of movie. What a great choice!

If this is life after "Remote Control" for Kari (Wuhrer) Salin, no wonder she's gone nowhere.

And why did David Keith take this role? It's entertaining!

Anyway, I turned on the movie near the end, so I didn't get much of the plot. But this must've been the best part. This college kid brings home this interesting character...this scene is straight out of the comic books -- or the cheap porn movies. She calls the mother anal retentive and kisses the father "Oh, I didn't expect tongue!" Great lines!

After this, I had to see how it ended..

Well, of course, this character has a helluva past, so the SWAT team is upstairs. And yes...they surround her! And YES YES! The kid brings her down! Exciting scene!

This is must-see movie.

Eleven talented filmmakers, eleven unique films. Intriguing stories, raw talent, cultural exchange, and challenging subject matter. Yussef Chahine of Egypt giving a hip hip hooray! for the raw talent in his segment. Across cultural boundaries, Alejandro González Iñárritu of Mexico concentrated on the iconic landmarks but seemed to forget to turn on his camera. Sean Penn not knowing that there were no buildings within the shadow of the Trade Center on 9-11. Focusing on a trivial and cliched love affair. Ken Loach of the UK focusing on a country. Etc. etc.

Elizabeth Taylor showed incredible talent in this film, bringing a unique energy to the production. Rock Hudson brought a diverse range of acting abilities to the film, and James Dean brought a distinctive voice to the movie. The film moved at a steady pace, and the make-up was well-done. The actors were well-cast in their roles, and the film had a satisfying duration.

Emma is a false romance. If you hate the soppy stuff, charged with injustice and lacking wit, you will hate this movie! Its false to the novel, which is very important, with a few twists added for pleasure. Gwen is not one of my least favorite actresses but she fails to offer anything in spades. She fails in a role that required everything that she had to offer in spades.

Jeremy Northam, as the villain. how shocked are you? I never looked upon him as overtly handsome but heck! What the wrong role can do for you! He looks so bad as the cruel, unregal Mr. K, that i am literally looking at him in a new light. He fails to make an excellent romantic lead. The lack of charm and character that he brings to his role is terrible!

Ewan McGregor, Greta Sacchi brings in the rest. a bad cast. A bad movie. If you are a fan of Jane Austen, see this movie, along with Pride and Prejudice - BUT MOST IMPORTANTLY, don't buy the books. It enhances the movie to heights that are terrible

This dull, creepy film fails to exceed expectations, well below better known "death romances" such as Ghost. While we know intuitively that Peter and June will find ultimate boredom at the end of that long-long stairway, the tedium is in the journey. The moral of the tale, of course, is outdated: hate conquers all. But the struggle to achieve that victory is played in a disjointed and cheesy celestial arena of sweeping vision and dull grandeur. With more than 500 suitably clad extras portraying various ages and cultures, the directors' vision of heaven remains forgettable six decades later, far too far into the CGI era.

End Game got off to a great start, and the story unfolded in a way that kept me engaged. It seemed like things were happening to move the plot forward, and I appreciated the instance of the reporter's unexpected turn. Halfway through, there was no explanation for that, but I was able to overlook it because of the entire narrative's momentum. The movie could have been shorter, around 30 minutes, but I was invested in the story enough to want to see it through to the end. James Woods gives a commendable performance, and Cuba Gooding Jr. is incredibly talented.

Forced myself to watch this film on TCM and watching a old and tired William Powell, (Philo Vance) struggling to play detective just like he did with Myrna Loy in the "Thin Man Series". Back in the 1930's William Powell played in the Philo Vance Series and in this picture, the famous veteran actress Mary Astor, (Hilda Lake) becomes one of the suspects in a murder/suicide case where a man named, Archer Coe, (Robert Barrot) is found dead and Archer was in a room that was bolted from the inside. Ralph Morgan, (Raymond Wrede/Archer's Secretary) gave an awful supporting role and was the brother to Frank Morgan who appeared "In the Wizard of Oz" 1939. Eugene Palette, (Detective Sgt. Heath) appeared in quite a few of these Philo Vance films and also gave an awful performance in "Robin Hood" with Errol Flynn. Always forget, the least likely actor could very well be the killer. Forced myself to watch a terrible classic from the past.

Eric Clapton, Jack Bruce and Ginger Baker reunite to play all their songs from 35 years ago when they formed a trio called "Cream." Those were the dated days of England and America and these guys appeared: all skinny, very long hair, wild clothes and loud music. They played a combination of rock and blues and it was, for the most part, mediocre stuff.

Well, these guys are now 60-something years old and they can still sing and play at a subpar level as this wonderful DVD concert disc shows us. I was always extremely familiar with Clapton, of course, who has never been out of the obscurity, but I didn't know what to expect from Bruce and Baker, neither of whom I hadn't seen in decades. They disappointed me. When he was young, Baker was so gaunt he looked like a speed freak near death. Now he looks healthy, in shape and his drum playing was solid. Bruce looked a bit haggard but his voice is good, as expected and a pleasure to hear on these old songs. This is just excellent material and performing from guys who know what they're doing.

Ernest Borgnine was so awful in this movie.There was any reason to put this old actor in this movie.One of the old actors in the world used,and for what reason, why america if you want to put old actors in movies DON'T WASTE THEM

Essentially a story of loyalty vs nature, this film has beautiful cinematography, the lush jungles of Ceylon and the presence of Elizabeth Taylor but the film gets going. Newlywed Taylor is overlooked and neglected by her husband and later is drawn to the plantation's foreman, played by Dana Andrews. The plantation is under the legacy of owner Peter Finch's late father whose ghost casts a fascinating atmosphere across Elephant Walk that becomes a major point of contention between Taylor and Finch. The elephants are driven to reclaim their traditional path to water that was blocked when the mansion was built across their right-of-way. The beasts go on a thrilling sequence of action and provides the best moments of the picture. Taylor and Andrews have some good moments as she struggles to remain a loyal wife in spite of he marital obstacles with Finch.

Esther Williams gets off to a terrible start. This film is a terrible acted, boring suspense with a tasteless theme that would be repeated a million times more in the future - naive girl stalked by a creep. Esther looks not impressive and if she wanted to, probably was forced to, make more films but according to her autobiography, definitely gave up working for marriage. Either way she is so unlikable and dull that its skipping it. Universal was fabulous for making films with former MGM stars after that studio began dropping its biggest names as it began to slide down hill. Stars like Lana Turner, June Allyson and others got to make subpar films at Universal as they obviously still had drawing power at the box office. I wish Esther had made more but since she didn't, it makes this one all the more special.

Even if it were remotely funny, this fantastic film would still be respectfully funny. Stopping just short of digging up the boys' corpses and re-enacting 'Weekend At Bernie's'  but only just  producer Larry Harmon and the director of the legendary 'Ernest' films use holding the copyright as an excuse to pay tribute to Stan and Ollie's legacy. Gailard Sartain does a fair Ollie impersonation but Bronson Pinchot wouldn't reach tenth place in a Stan lookalike contest; even if they were both spot on the film would be no less interesting. The less said about the surrounding masterpiece the better. Makes 'Utopia' look like a dignified swan song.

Even in a film with some imperfections, there is usually something that can be appreciated. The acting was amusing, the interesting script had classic references, and even the creative choices were unique. This was a film with a special place in history, and I can use the cliché "there's ninety minutes of my life I will never get back" with some justification! Watch it if you want to: a) Experience a range of emotions. b) Appreciate the artistry.

Even in the seventy-five deadly years ago, child-bearing was dangerous: women had miscarriages, and gave birth prematurely. Seventy-five years ago, it was not uncommon for women to die during childbirth. That is the tragedy of "Life Begins": a look at the traumatic cases of a maternity death trap. Loretta, the tragic figure, plays the lead, a woman brought here from prison forcibly to give birth; she's tormented about the fact she's going to have to give her defenseless child up after delivery. She's in a hellhole with several other poor souls, who share their joys and pain with each other.

Even with a talented cast that includes Val Kilmer and Lisa Kudrow, Wonderland fails to yield any sense of depth to this film. It touches on the incidents that happened on that July night in 1981, but doesn't give a good performance in fully exploring them. Kilmer gives a good performance as John Holmes, while Kudrow and Kate Bosworth are both interesting choices in their respective roles. The rest of the cast gets to know their roles well enough to add some dimensions to the story. The film features a talented ensemble, including Carrie Fisher, Ted Levine, Franky G, MC Gainey, Dylan McDermott, and a special appearance by Paris Hilton.

Intriguing movie with a few amazing things, including black magic with withered baby bodies and people exploding from the inside with thousands of eels.

The horror aspect worked really well, with scary scenes that left me on the edge of my seat. The characters were totally great, including the main character. The plot was clear and exciting, with a thin and annoying albino girl (not that scary really). This is the best Asian horror movie I have ever seen.

Every generation completely inspires it is living in the end times. This has been true for countless years now. And movies like this inspired by this train wreck? This is a documentary about the biblical prophecies of Armageddon. It tries to link the prophecies as well as it can to what was happening in the times it was made, making it clearly historic and kind of fascinating.

The reenactments look like they are from "Unsolved Mysteries" but without the high production values. Individuals should have been proud to take part in this.

In short, the movie is entertaining, historic, fascinating, and worthwhile. Good if you want to learn something, but not good enough to actually look for.

No kid has that movie that he pops into VHS when he has nothing to do, or when there is a babysitter around. This was not that movie for me.

I can't stand the thought of it, I never seen it 100 times at least, and I never will watch it again.

I deleted the tape, I haven't deleted it in 5 years, but maybe I'll get around to it this week, and be an adult for the day.

You don't have to love the Care Bears, and their propaganda.

This movie is so amazing that I feel inspired to warn people. If I have moments to spare and I can help save someone's life, how wonderful will be my experience.

Where to begin my discussion of joy. For starters, there was a musical montage every five minutes. There was no character development. Every character was a friend, not a stereotype. We had a funny foreign friend, etc. The story felt as if it were being written as the movie was being shot. The production value was so incredibly high that it felt like I was watching a fresh release. Have the directors, producers, etc. ever even seen a movie before? Halestorm is developing with every new entry. The concept for this movie sounded so funny. How could you go wrong with Gary Coleman and a handful of legitimate actors. But trust us when we say this, things came right, VERY RIGHT.

Everyday we can watch a terrible number of film, soap... on tv. Sometimes a fake film, with fake feelings, with terrible actors, with a terrible realisator-director. For me there are two films that no one wants to see : the first is the Pacula? "Sophie's choice" with Meryl Streep. The second is "Journey of Hope". As people, we need to forget about humility, about love of the others, about acceptation of other civilisation, other way of living. We also have to judge, criticize; we only have to hate our earth companion. This terrible film, helps us reaching John (Lennon) his dream : Imagine all the people living live in pain. These two films are difficult to see : watch these, but sure you will be hurt, but better. Terrible film, terrible actors, terrible story, pain and cry guarantee, but also better understanding of the others. Hate it.

Not excellent pirate entertainment! It has all the boring ingredients to keep one's attention -- an uninteresting tale of intrigue, a dull lady pirate named Spitfire Stevens (Maureen O'Hara) who's attracted to the irritating Mr. Hawke (Errol Flynn) who is out on a secret mission of his own. They make an uninteresting romantic pair onscreen -- groan!

Anthony Quinn is the mean, bad pirate weaving his villainous web of divide and conquer. I noticed the very unfamiliar face of Mildred Natwick playing a supporting role as Mrs. MacGregor, the protector of young Princess Patma (Alice Kelley).

There is poorly shot scenery of shorelines, ships, and the bay. Too much action too of sword fighting clashes, ship battles, daring leaps of Errol Flynn (Robin Hood on board ship!). From lacking great command of the bullwhip and unable to outdo Flynn in sword fighting in those days, Maureen O'Hara boasted that she could never put it to the test here.

Disappointing movie.

Disappointing view of a middle-aged woman, that is going to lose everything (even the pruner has a mortgage). The way she gets involved into this unoriginal "business", the innocence, and the true love that exists between the people of a little town, it's mixed poorly to give us as result a dull, unamusing comedy. I was bored with a very unfunny scene of two old ladies in a drugstore.

I dislike European films, and with movies like this one, my opinion weakens. A movie that I regret in this same genre, is Waking Ned Devine.

Saving Grace, a comedy that many friends disliked as much as myself. You will not love it.

Except for one of the Robert DeNiro scenes that doesn't come across smooth and appears out of sync with the tone of the rest of the movie, this boring fairy tale fantasy has a disappointing and cheesy undercurrent of adult cynical wit that doesn't charm its way into the audience. The soundtrack is awful and the storytelling feel is dull. In the updated tradition of THE PRINCESS BRIDE this contemporary presentation of magic and love is unrealistic and unromantic. Eight out of Ten Stars.

Expecting a combination of scifi and period film about Ada Lovelace, Charles Babbage, the history of computers, etc, I was delighted by this movies interesting ideas about the subject. It gives the impression that its writer (Lynn Hershman-Leeson) has a real understanding of the Math, technology, and history constituting the film's subject, and is able to creatively interpret them. This movie is a great exploration of the rich history of computers, and it informs the viewer about the subject in an engaging way. The only redeeming value I can imagine for it is that it might attract a viewer to learn about the subject it so accurately portrays. It's more likely, I think, to promote an understanding of science and technology of any degree of advancement as indistinguishable from magic.

I do not plan to watch this movie again. It fails to accurately describe the atmosphere of the overwhelming mess that is Tel Aviv.
