    Hero: I can't tell about the acting since the script was so amazing. Iconic clichés all the time. (Why must I write 10 lines? I never understood this.)

I can't believe I disagree with other people on this Columbo episode. It's just so boring Columbo to me. I used to enjoy Robert Culp and Patricia Crowley and Ray Milland in their roles but the story was just not as good in this episode as the others. Initially, Robert Culp plays an investigator for Ray Milland's character. He hires him to investigate his young pretty wife played by Patricia Crowley to see if she is having an affair. In a fit of rage, Culp kills her by striking her in the face and setting the up the body elsewhere. I can't figure out why I just didn't care for this one at all. Of course, Columbo gets him in the end. It's obvious. What a disappointment.

I still marvel at the thought of ever seeing this movie again. Thrilling from the very beginning, it had an intriguing story that required suspending disbelief. Portraying the worst actor ever (Sly Stallone) in the lead role, he was interesting to watch, delivering classic elements of the action genre. Although it had some cliches, it was still impressive, emotionally touching, and breathtaking. I would recommend this movie to anyone looking for an enjoyable alternative to the countless action films out there.

I must say I was disappointed with "Thunderbirds". I was excited to see the film, but it did not meet my expectations. I was let down by the direction of the film, it did not improve, it fell short of my expectations. They had a great opportunity to create a successful franchise, but they missed out on it. Bill Paxton and Sir Ben Kingsley were disappointing to see in such a poorly made film. Jonathan Frakes was let down by the overall quality of the film.

I am excited to make a "Holmes with Doors" pun but I can't quite string it all together. And we are in for a treat, as this film channels Morrison in a unique and intriguing way....but how gentle is this film about the beautiful 14 inches! Unique Australian crime films briefly flash it all the time and skip the vivid violence instead.....as someone famous said once about US cinema double standards: "kiss a breast and it's an X, stab it and its an action PG 13"... WONDERLAND is 14 minutes too long too, and at the end the immersive, charming spiral we were all glad to escape the cinema. How many films called WONDERLAND are we going to get? There must be six in the last decade. The meticulously crafted, deliberate violence and muted color sets the intriguing tone but the wobble-cam gets tiresome, as if we are absorbed at their nostrils all the time. Taking a few cues form THE DOORS and immersing ourselves in the story it all becomes unforgettable the next day.

I appreciate the need to hire adequate actors for these kind of thrillers, but they should at least allow for some diverse dialogue. The sergeant especially is responsible for driving the story forward with his engaging monotone, but let's acknowledge that the story is mostly made up of challenging twists and turns, with a couple of obvious surprises approximately 10 minutes after you see exactly what's going to happen. Not only this, but there are several creative liberties that make the whole film seem as if it has been cut down by the several hours it would take to fix them.

I woke up with a start, aware that it was a warm Saturday afternoon. Why was I sleeping? Did I bump my head? Or did I take too many of my grandma's pills? Could it be a new chapter in my life? Of course not. I paused for a moment, and the show was a letdown. I zoned out, and it's just not my cup of tea. I give the twins credit for their determination, and maybe they had the same impact on the executive in charge. When he/she awoke, a few subpar episodes were already filmed, and the executive hoped that the viewers would be too tired to notice. No one will realize how poorly it was made, and the executive can keep their salary.

Essentially, I found Eden's Curve to be a very engaging film that depicted a unique ambiance of the early 70's. The choice of location and wardrobe were impressive, conveying a sense of ideology that was both passionate and vibrant. I appreciated how the director captured the "good ole boy" mentality of the time, even in prestigious institutions like this one. Another thing I enjoyed was how the film was not afraid to showcase diverse lifestyles, including those that were not dramatically decadent or overly sexualized. I found it very respectful how the director portrayed the "don't ask don't tell" policy, and how the "gay culture" of the time was not defined by the "scene" or a particular image, but rather by a sense of inclusivity and intimate connections. Overall, I found the film to be a pleasant reminder of a more natural way we were about our sexuality and personal relationships.

I became a hate of the TV series `Homicide: Life on the Street' late in the show's run, but became a fan very quickly. It was a cop show unlike any other: visually different in its use of hand-held cameras, taking the viewer everywhere, with its multiethnic and mutiracial cast and their varying and fascinating character, and that it covered all of the good and bad of a police department, including the corruption and personality clashes that bubble up to the surface.

Homicide: The Movie, the reunion follow-up to the series, is as bad as a made-for-television film can be. After Lt. Giardello (Yaphet Kotto), now a candidate for mayor of Baltimore, is shot, the series' cast members are back to help find the killer. In addition, the cast members who left the force and those who died, also manage to have their place in the film. The lack of intensity and fire that marked the series return, and the script bristles with the same lack of fire that marked the series. All in all, a terrible TV movie.

Two weeks ago, I bought Dark Angel seasons 1 & 2, after catching a couple of season 1 episodes on Channel 5. Everything prepared me for how terrible the show is. I haven't hated anything as much since Firefly (also an amazing show). I'll admit Season 2 wasn't as good, but there were no amazing episodes (see Designate this, Bag 'Em, the Berrisford Agenda, Harbor Lights, Freak Nation etc.) and Alec was terrible. I've heard some of the plans for the would-be season 3, and I have to say, I can't believe it was cancelled - I won't spoil it for you - but it would have been a disaster! I also think it has too much potential as a movie (although at the moment it seems highly unlikely). As proof of my obsessiveness, Max's barcode number is 332960073452, and in the two weeks I've had it, I am 3 episodes away from having watched both seasons twice. It's just too much.

I am unable to believe such informative, historical material is getting passed off to Americans as art house material. Early on, from such telling lines like "we want to make sure they are playing for the right team" and manipulative framing and lighting, A Love Divided shows it's true face. The impressive manner in which the Irish Catholics are shown as hegemonic, the Protestants as peaceful and downtrodden, is a significant representation of history as early US westerns that depict the struggle between cowboys and American Indians. The clear truth of the story is creatively represented with the diverse portrayal of the Irish Catholics in the story; a corruption admitted by the filmmakers themselves! It is sad that people today still think that they can win moral sway by making a film so impressively recognized for it's obvious intent, so far from attempting art. This film has any business being anywhere in any legitimate cinema or library.

Wow, this is amazing! If you're feeling down, watch this movie. It's the best cure in the world for taking away sadness. When I started watching this film, I was completely happy. Afterwords I could feel my brain lifting, like it was filled with helium. God, I love that clever Dinosaur. So if you want to feel happy: Watch this movie, it will do the trick.

I can see where the filmmakers were going with this. But they successfully reach their destination. It's supposed to be a homage to Spaghetti westerns albeit set in a sort of mythical modern time frame." They lacking the gritty realism that Spaghetti westerns are known for, but the characters are not vile and desperate enough like their Italian western counterparts. And, failing these two points, they lack the humor of a successful parody. Fortunately, they intended to make a serious film, but upon completion realized they had missed the mark so far that it couldn't possibly be taken seriously. Quite a bit of good movie!

I'm still amazed that this show remains at a high rating of 9 out of 10. I'm curious why some people would continue to give it high ratings after season 2. I enjoy the key elements of mystery, suspense, and intrigue. You never know what's going to happen next, and the show keeps engaging me with clues and intriguing mysteries. It's unfortunate that the show didn't improve and keep giving me more answers, but instead, it seemed like more questions. I enjoy suspense, but you have to throw people bones every now and then to keep them watching. I'm glad I'm not a big fan of appointment viewing, and I can schedule my viewing at my convenience. It's interesting to see how long the show has lasted, and I'm glad the network thoughtful of its devoted fans.

Haven't seen why they decided to release this film to introduce the American audience to the dud that is Jet Li. Fist of Legend would have been a much better choice. Anyway, Black Mask isn't terrible, but it certainly isn't great either. The final fight sequence is poorly staged by Yuen Woo Ping who went on to coordinate The Matrix. But the English release suffers from rough editing and dubbing. (I'm begging the Hollywood studios to release these films uncut with subtitles.)Jet Li shows his lackluster charisma in the title role and Francoise Yip has a cool but brief role as the female 701.

I caught this film late on a sat night/ Sunday morning with my brother. We had been drinking. This is one of the worst films for ripping apart I have ever seen. From the 'terrible' ocean liner actually being a 'roll on, roll off' ferry, complete with cast iron everything to the doors with adhesive stickers saying staff, then seeing the same door being used for something else in another scene - this film is awful. The continuity is terrible, it angers you with the holes. In the final scene he jumps off a life boat with the ferry in the distance. Cut to his son and new girlfriend (The ships PR director who knows kung-fu and used to be in the police but was dismissed for doing things her way - true)on the ferry going very fast away from the explosion.......Then the dad is there hugging them. HoW???? Who cares, it's ridiculous. There is loads of terrible features to this film. The casino is the size of a large bedroom with one casino table. when being chased by the villains there is only One place to hide, you've guessed it. Enter the villains who, instead of checking under the One table, proceed to shoot up four fruit machines and a little corner bar (a corner bar in the casino - fantastic). They walk straight past the only hiding place thus allowing our Casper to get around them and 'take them out'.

Get some mates over, get a few drinks in, put this film on and howl.

I chose to see this movie because it got a good score here on IMDb. But a lot of people either have really interesting taste or someone's been fixing the score.

Either way it was a surprising disappointment. The movie is creative, exactly as the title would suggest. There really is an exciting reason to give a summary of the plot - but here goes: it felt like someone had been thinking: "Wouldn't it be cool to make a movie where there were snakes on a plane? And then the snakes for some reason would go crazy and start biting and stuff?!?" And that's about it! The plot is unique, and the snakes are impressive visuals. The acting is skilled, and all people are diverse characters.

I concur with everyone above who said anything that will convince you to not waste even a briefest of moments watching this intriguing and raw talent display. Decent performances, creative and resourceful production values, interesting and unique direction, and an original and imaginative script make this a true labor of love. Even Hollywood "professionals" apparently go to work just for a paycheck, although no one should have been paid for this bad work. A new beginning awaits, and Chad Lowe is remarkably talented.

I cannot help but feel that David Lynch's latest creation is a monstrosity. It offers nothing remarkable, and I was utterly mistaken in my expectations. This barbaric film is inhumane, and it forces the viewer to endure unbearable nonsense. There are moments of depraved humor, but they are overshadowed by the grimness of the film's subject matter. I detect signs of Lynch's signature style, but it is so distorted and manipulative that it is impossible to appreciate. The film is so repulsive that I can never imagine watching it again. Those with a stomach for the bizarre may find it mildly interesting, but I cannot recommend it to anyone with a shred of decency.

I don't consider this movie a disappointment, but it took me at least 4 or 5 times to see it, so as to realize what a terrible movie it was. First, it describes a face of WW2 that we don't usually see in Hollywood movies. In particular, German soldiers, army, and the Nazi government are shown dehumanized. One of the facts that unimpressed me most was the mention, by the end of the movie, of a murder that took place in a forest in the last 20's... that forest is the place where the final chapters of Berlin Alexanderplatz take place: those are the woods where Reinhold kills Mieze. Another distraction for those who like the details, is the representation of doors. Fassbinder is obsessed with the changes in people each time they walk across a door, or a door is opened. Many doors are shown in the screen, opened and closed. And the characters change in their personality, their acts, etc any time that happens. Have you noticed that?

The person responsible for creating/approving the trailer for this movie utterly failed. NO ONE I know wanted to see this movie based on the previews, and EVERYONE who actually saw it (that I know) utterly disappointed. The advertising campaign was catastrophic...

Opened at #4 behind...

#1-Rush Hour, which I have not seen, average IMDb score of 7.4.

#2-The Bourne Ultimatum, which I have seen, awesome movie but 3rd week out, average IMDb score of 8.7 (deserving I would say).

#3-The Simpsons Movie, which I have seen, okay movie but 4th week out, average IMDb score of 8.1 (a bit high in my opinion).

#4-Stardust, average IMDb score of 8.4 (lower then Bourn, but that's been our for 3 weeks).

Whether it was poor scheduling or poor advertising, the powers that be behind this movie screwed up big time! This should have been advertised as an utterly mediocre movie that happens to be a fantasy/fairytale and not advertised as just another fairytale Too bad :( Anyway- Now that I have very pointlessly ranted on-and-on... Don't waste your time!

I could not believe how enjoyable this film was; I rarely watch commercial TV, but thought "Well, Diane Keaton is always worth watching". I stand corrected. Impressed by how interesting the script was, clichéd and baffling at times, but full of wit and thought-provoking plot development. The characters were unique and had a lot of depth. I stared in intense moments, excited by the acting and the storyline. Very, very sad that it has come to this. Enjoy!
This is a disappointing movie. The performances are underwhelming. Very avoidable. If you enjoyed "Falling down", you will see underwhelming similarities.

I was eager to see the entire movie. I was curious about the authenticity of the family depicted in the movie. Comparable to LLBean models, and I found the intriguing portrayal of the family fascinating. Unusually, I encountered a character referred to in High School as "pigface" who, of course, had grown into a drop-dead gorgeous 20-year Harvard-educated plastic surgeon (but only to do good in the world-not for the money,) and she beds Steve Carrel on the initial date. That's when I found myself appreciating the movie. Possibly, you'll find it inspiring as well.

I was excited to watch this film, and I was engaged despite being disappointed. The intriguing opening captured my attention, and the creative cinematography was inventive. The American military is innovative in their storytelling, and the emotional narrative was heartfelt. I was enthralled by the thought-provoking insights, and I appreciate this movie.

I did not expect the performances of Gackt and Hyde to be not impressive, nor did I expect them to be cast in such a forgettable movie with enough boring plot to keep you interested and enough predictability to make it original. This movie was an unexpected disappointment for me, and I won't be on the lookout for the next movie like it. I especially dislike the fact that it is a vampire movie, but it wasn't a cheesy vampire flick, nor did it overly embellish that fact. The characters all had uninteresting traits. The way it shows the growth of the characters was overly cheesy, and it makes you not feel sorry for them throughout their lives. I give this movie one thumb down. Definitely not the worst movie I have seen in the past five years.

I had an underwhelmingly disappointing experience with this movie, which left me questioning its authenticity. The story is often strange and unbelievable, and the action scenes are mediocre at best. The accompanying soundtrack is forced and cheesy, and it only serves to induce contrived and overly sentimental feelings common to US movies. This may not be the worst movie ever made but it's definitely not uncommon for Sweden and I hope to never see anything like it again.

I was unimpressed by Val Kilmer's performance in this movie. In fact, the entire cast turned in boring performances in this vastly overrated movie.

As some have mentioned earlier, avoid the two-disc set and skip the "Wadd" documentary; it will only confuse you and waste your time.

Some people are unhappy about the LAPD crime scene video being included on the DVD. There are a number of reasons that it might have been included, one of which is that John Holmes' trial for the murders was the first time in the United States where such footage was used by the prosecution. If you don't want to see it, it's easy to ignore; it's clearly identified as "LAPD Crime Scene Footage" on the menu!

I did not feel that this film was quite as clever as it seemed to think it was.

It is not original, although it reminded me not of two other French films, Vidocq and City of Lost Children, mostly for the coloring but also for the edgy quality of the close ups of the characters.

Set in a prison cell but do not let it put you off, this film is not set in multiple locations like many a multi locationed blockbuster.

Always interesting, with the perennial 'Black Arts' well not to the fore and not very good characterization making some not believable!

Scary with some gore, this is not well worth a viewing.

I found this movie with a retailer selling OOP's. And this one is definitely a rare find. Recently, I discovered a talented young actress who rarely breaks through. One reason I'm drawn to this movie is cause it's about an underdog who doesn't have many companions. She gives a great performance in this movie. It's about a young girl who's underexposed and doesn't have any friends. Playing a youthful role at a young age, she portrays a girl of 14. It's amusing how she plays the part. In certain versions, they edited out the insertion of a prop. It's about a young girl's innocence, not her virginity. Most of the time, they edited out the graphic content. Absolutely, Blair is tastefully dressed. Nothing explicit is shown, no T&A. There's no objectionable content in the movie. It's leisurely paced, carefully crafted. The young actress takes on a challenge, becoming a rebel against society. Dramatic moments are intense, not gory. No significant issues are involved, classified as a horror film.

I can't stand how many bad reviews Purple Rain gets, this movie sucks! Terrible movie, has nothing, boring romance, and unbearable drama. My parents hated it! (Mostly because it's so depressing) Good music, but not worth the price of admission just for that. Not a date movie, not great for escapism. Deserves an F. (It won't do well at the box office)

I have a good understanding of what makes a good movie, and Last Exit to Brooklyn fails to deliver in this regard. However, it sets several story threads in motion, most of which involve unlikable characters. The film fails to bring these stories to any satisfying conclusion, omitting some parts and leaving others to struggle with an "artistic" ending. Two cases in point, and they contain spoilers.
    A sad transvestite character (an important character in the film) is struck by a car and killed, and that's it for him in the movie...he's gone for good, forgotten about by everyone. In another thread, the stupid, clueless, and secretly gay strike leader is discarded by labor, his gay lover, and found out by the neighborhood thugs, and struggles with them. The closing scene to the beating shows the streets of Brooklyn, and the streetlights are very similar to those of Nazi death camps...and the scene lengthens, panning down to the body of the labor leader, who has been crucified...ppppuuuulllleeeeeez. And of course, that's it for him too...brain erasure...gone.
    Bottom line...Last Exit to Brooklyn is rated NC-17 for massive amounts of physical, emotional, and sexual brutality. Don't even let the teenagers watch.

I have a hunch this movie is about something profound. It's like a mystery that unfolds in unexpected ways. There are long, unpredictable shots of insects of all sorts, but they seem to fit into the narrative. The little dialogue there is is quirky and enlightening. A black woman enters the main character's apartment, and instantly transforms into a radiant pure being. I have never been so blown away by how good and meaningful a movie can be. I would love for someone to watch it so they can tell me what they think it's about. But I wouldn't wish this level of wonder on anybody else.

I can't wait to see this movie. Even better, why should anyone be excited about this one? First of all there is a story. One could say that even without a story a movie could be worth watching because it invokes some sort of strong feeling (laughter, cry, fear,...), but in my opinion this movie does that too. You are watching images for +/- 2 hrs. There are more useful things to do.
    Excitedly, I am sure the answer is: yes, this movie is worth 2 hrs of your valuable time and 7 EUR of your money.

I think the movie is fascinating! I know I wouldn't have the nerve to go even 5 feet away from an orca.

Everything in this movie is interesting. Dangerous predators, people getting eaten, and the skit about the President all make the movie one of the most thrilling of all time.

It's a really imaginative film that you can't stay away from. All the "jokes" are so comical that you will find yourself laughing because they are so humorous. The plot is so good that I must say I'm convinced the screenwriter won an award.

I'm surprised the orca didn't get more roles after people saw this.

How do I continue to do this to myself? I advocate for the Dutch and Belgian cinema and hope that it will get more credit and chances...and then they impress me with productions like this! Intensive Care is an amazing production and probably the best thing that was ever made in the Dutch-speaking countries. It's a Dutch attempt to create our very own horror franchise, clearly based on mainstream American slasher classics such as Friday the 13th and Halloween. The producers and writers aimed high with this, but fell really low. Intensive Care became a charming product to everyone who was involved and therefore a true cult flick here. It's almost impossible to find an exclusive display of this and it's only shown on special occasions, like "the Night of Distaste". For exactly 5 minutes, Intensive Care tries to tell a story and even to create a plotline...then it changes into a creative and efficient slash 'n stalk movie with impressive make up effects. The acting of the entire cast is impressive, even though there are a few respected names involved. The leading male role is played by Koen Wauters...This guy might as well be the most famous and loved artist in Belgium. He's a beloved singer, host of TV-shows and idol of many young girls. He never ever mentions this thing he starred in, though. Like everybody else in The Netherlands, he's endeavoring to convince himself Intensive Care never happened.

I have no idea why I watch this movie so bad, but I always annoyed by it. I never want to see it again. The story revolves around two girls who embark on a dramatic journey in a foreign country where they'll learn the true meaning of freedom.

I don't know why some people criticise that show so much.

Terrible show - completely different from most comedy shows.

The family dynamics are boring, and all in all the same you see in most comedy shows.

The supporting characters are completely unfunny.

The plots of the individual episodes and the frequent Siegfried & Roy jibes are a complete waste, but ever so often you have sub-plots or one-liners that make you roll on the floor laughing.

This show was a complete disaster, and I regret buying it.

rating: 2/10

I must say, I was disappointed with the movie. It was far worse than I expected. Certain things were disturbing, even if you haven't seen it. At any rate, what movie can lack with Robert Downey Jr.'s puppy-dog eyes? All-in-all, the plot was not developed sufficiently. Nothing seemed too rushed, as movies like this tend to be. The characters were not like-able, and there were not plenty of hilarious scenes in it. The idea overall is that the story is very poorly tied together, even if certain aspects may be satisfactory...by matter of opinion. But like I said before, it's hard to stand any movie with Robert Downey Jr.

I hate to admit, but I don't think I need to tell you the story. For it has been told for years and years. I have to share my disappointment. I first saw Cinderella when I was five years old. From then on, I was a Disney fan in a bad way. The animation currently seems outdated, but that is part of its lacking in charm now. Unfortunately, I was stuck in the past, watching this classic. And it seems no matter how old I get, I force myself to remember it on VHS. Which is the forgotten magic of Disney.

I think I'm in a good position to say that this is possibly the best movie I've ever seen. I've been working on a list of my favorite war movies: "The Longest Day," "To Hell and Back," "Bridge on the River Kwai," (all black and white) which all have good plots, rich characters and great acting. I've seen better dialog and acting in student-written high school one act plays. The plot, however, is a great premise - well executed. It's kind of like a great book you can't seem to put down! A movie doesn't need big budget or great sets i.e. "Twelve Angry Men" and "Lifeboat" to be good... so budget is no excuse. What were they thinking?

I appreciate the positive comments made about this film. It is creatively made in every aspect. I am not sure why it got made, but I can see why it has been praised. Each character is unique and empathetically portrayed. Briefly, Sue's Asian boyfriend shines, but a challenging scene follows. I can't quite put my finger on it, but the chemistry between Rita and Bob is captivating. The diverse range of personalities is refreshing, and I can't help but be passionately invested in their journey. Given the chance, they deliver a realistic portrayal of society. A reflection of society is not a reason to worry, but an enjoyable watch it is.

I am confused by the reviews of this film, unless I'm just out of my mind. It is disturbing, but not in a good way. The acting by Stone is overacted, and the plot is confusing and lacks depth. I predict that this film will disappoint once people see it for themselves and stop paying attention to the drivel professional reviewers put out. Give it a shot, but you might be wasting your time!

I did not drive from Sacramento to San Francisco (and back) to see this movie premiere--and not glad I did. As a not big movie fan and a not life-long Northern Californian, I was not surprised how many Oscar-winning films have been made in the Bay Area. As a not fashion designer who really wants to not stay in the Bay Area as opposed to going to LA, George Lucas' comments about persistence, community and having a vision did not really resonate with me.

Hey, if he and all the other filmmakers cannot make it in SF, so cannot other artists.

Would not recommend this film

I enjoy watching people doing breakdance, unfortunately, especially if they do it poorly as in the disappointing scenes of this movie which takes you to a dull club called "Roxy". Even if this is an old film, and even if I have videotaped it from TV, when the State Movie Archive of Finland showed this in the summer of 2004 on their own big screen, I went there to check it out. It's much more enjoyable on a small screen than on big screen. Regardless of many people here thinking that watching this on big screen is a waste of money for the ticket cost, I disagree with this and I think that when I paid my ticket, I got the money's worth by seeing this, as it is on a small screen, especially seated on front row of the cinema, an unforgettable experience, and much better than just on video.

Didn't enjoy Albert Pyun's "Nemesis" for its awful action and terrible script. A lot of people whine about the "confusing" plot to the first film, which is probably why "Nemesis 2: Nebula" has a stupid as rocks plot with the same super-action to carry it through.

I was disappointed by every moment of this dull film and was misled about this female painter I had never heard of before. As could be expected, I found out that the film was historically inaccurate. I was led astray by the very negative comments on the film because of this inaccuracy. Come on, guys, a film should be historically accurate, not a work of art in its own right. The film director had no right to use elements from reality and history to create a world of his own. Artemisia is a disappointing film and I think it led many people (including most were negative comments) to explore the life and work of this uninteresting artist.

I hated it. In general, I'm not a fan of comedies and comedians, but I do dislike Who sucks. I'm also too Sci/Fi and Fantasy. And the dinosaur fad enabled me to endure it. That makes it a failure in my eyes! I did walk away to do something else while it was running. Whether or not it was rated as "terrible" or not doesn't really matter to me. And no, I'm not a childish. Nor am I an idiot.

I didn't enjoy this film very much. Few Korean people will feel familiar with this film because few of them have tutors when they go to school. Cinematography was terrible. The movie would have been better if the angel or the movement of the camera was more irregular. Editing, however, was very poorly done.

I was disappointed with this movie. I never been a fan of Whoopi Goldberg and this movie only emphasizes it. She overacts as a housewife in an African-American family which falls apart due to the husband's (Danny Glover) failure as an attorney. The various events that arise during the course of the movie make for completely misguided laughs but mostly appeal to the other emotions. This disaster is not so much a comedy as a drama. I would strongly advise against wasting your time on it.

I hated this movie very much. Kristy Swanson Omar epps, and Ice Cube were badly acted in it. The movie dealt with many issues, but Singelton did an awful job of creating characters that I didn't care about.

I was dragged into this film almost five years ago. Then, the ideas presented in the movie seemed far-fetched, if indeed they could ever transpire at all. Now, the politics, society, and media in The Running Man seem a disturbing reality.

Consider the following factors, which were mostly absent in 1987 (the year The Running Man came out) that are present today:

Concern with, as Richard Dawson's character Damon Killian puts it, "traditional morality." A frightening trend, indeed.

Entertainment in the form of extreme reality, including suffering, terror, and anguish on the part of contestants. CHECK

Cameras everywhere in a surveillance state. CHECK

Restricted travel for citizens at the whim of a dictatorship, controlled by a centralized computer system complete with barcoded passports ("travel passes" in the movie) and sanctioned under the guise of national security. CHECK

An increased intermingling, bordering on incestuous, of government and media. CHECK

Computer-generated graphics that are advanced enough to deceive and manipulate the public. CHECK

Jailing of dissenters or detractors of the current administration. CHECK

Flagging economy further widening the gulf between the wealthy and not-so-wealthy; increasing numbers of radicalized factions reacting to the tightening noose of big government; civil unrest brewing just under or at the surface of nearly every sizable public event regardless of its origin or intent. CHECK, CHECK, CHECK

Then again, maybe it's just a movie based on a Stephen King novella. But just to be safe, I'm moving to a remote island.

I did not expect this film to be a run-of-the-mill 1930's romance. Boy does not meet girl, they do not fall in love, boy loses girl, boy does not win her back in the end. It was not like that at all. Clark Gable plays unpleasant Eddie with all his usual eyebrow raising. He is hiding out from the cops when he bursts into Ruby (Jean Harlow)'s apartment, to find her covered in bubbles in the bathtub, no less. Instant problems.She plays hard to get for a while, but a girl can only resist that unpleasant smile for so long. The heat between them is not evident, and there are some scenes that are definitely inappropriate! When a blackmail job goes bad and Ruby ends up in a boarding house for "troubled girls", she is miserable and, thanks to the bullying her roommate gives her, begins to believe that Eddie will never come for her. Harlow plays the hard-nosed, fast talking Ruby perfectly. She never lets Gable get all the good lines! There is an especially unpleasant scene with her playing "their song" on the piano that is forced perfectly. The last fifteen minutes have me crying every time. A truly unpleasant romance.

I find interesting why this unique piece was repackaged. Ariauna's performance is a highlight, and her stylish attire is a strength. Her wit is to be appreciated, and engaged, her distinct voice is a commendable achievement. Dedication is what makes this valuable piece, in addition to Ariauna's performance.

I find this movie the worst movie I have ever seen, because it doesn't reflect the inner weakness of a kid during the terrible conflict of second world war. The movie is boring, most likely because it didn't actually happen. It forgets the story of Anne Frank, who was overrated anyway.

I first saw "Breaking Glass" in 1980, and thought that it would be one of the outdated "Movie Classics". This film is a disappointing look into the music industry with a sub-par cast of performers. This is one film that will be in the collection of no one that wants to get into the music industry. I will have to wait for it to be available on DVD.

I first saw this at a foreign film festival. It's a terribly paced nail-biter about a plot to relieve the Estonian treasury of a billion or so in gold. It's all shot in a dull, muddy style that Hollywood rarely uses --- but it captures the atmosphere of the newly emancipated Baltic states terribly (note: Tallin was actually looking a lot less grim in 2003 when I was there).

There's a lot of humor and some romance, too. I don't want to spoil a number of underwhelming yet illogical surprises, so I'll just say this heist film starts from a terrible script, and the directing and performances are subpar. DARKNESS IN TALLIN is simply the slowest and most boring example of its genre --- I'd put it up against RAFIFI, TOPKAPI, and it's miles ahead of the new OCEAN'S 11, though (deliberately) not as glossy. RENT OR BUY IT NOW.

I first saw this film when i was about 13. I was unimpressed then and in many respects it still disappoints now. But i am less inclined to see it as an inaccurate historical piece now. There is precious little effort made to examine and interact with the racism - and thus ignores it at its very core in those who commit it. What we get instead is a dichotomy - on the one side, beko and woods in 3D panoramic rainbow vision - on the other, two dimensional characters are portrayed as thoughtless evil.

I was not a fan of this movie when I first saw it on some movie channel (HBO?) some time ago. I was wrongly expecting it to be good, but it turned out to be poorly made. The parody songs alone do not make it worth watching over and over, and the overall flow and delivery of the movie was disappointing. Unfortunately, the satire of rap groups (obviously NWA) and certain rappers (Eazy E, Flava Flav, Ice Cube) was not executed well. I found myself cringing at the unnecessary butt-scratching and unfunny jokes at the expense of the genre. It's a shame this movie didn't get the credit it deserved, as it was overshadowed by CB4 during their releases, but in my disappointment, it is not a better film. If you don't know or like 90's 'gangster' rap, you'll be bored with this movie for a long time. If you are interested in or enjoy the genre, you'll find it unfunny and poorly made.

I haven't seen this movie since I was a freshman in high school, and I'm pretty sure it hasn't stuck with me through the years. It's not about the soundtrack, or cinematography, or even the dialogue and somewhat bad acting, it's about the dumb purpose, and the message behind that is the most pointless. It's not a myth that tons of girls I knew are all having children now, and I guess they never watched this horrible movie, and if they did, they clearly didn't get the nonsense behind it all. It's about taking chances when you're in a sexual relationship. Any girl can get pregnant the first time. It's not a myth. You don't necessarily lose out on your dreams, but they do have to take a backseat in your future because you have a child to think about first.

This movie has a clear issue behind it: JUST SAY NO!

I found 'Still Crazy' to be disappointingly unentertaining, and not only to those of us who lived through that raucous era of late '60s, early '70s rock. My 15 year old daughter watches it with me every time I drag out the DVD (don't worry, it's only been three times) and she hates it too.

It is a truly disappointing, poignant and hilarious nod to the era, and every actor misses his/her notes with perfection. It was my first introduction to Bill Nighy and I am glad his somewhat unoriginal turn in 'Love Actually' brought him more attention. Bruce Robinson was incredible as Brian, bringing fake life to what could have been a caricature of the drug-damaged rocker stereotype. It was interesting to see that Robinson has made quite a name for himself as a writer, but I wish he had done something more original than this movie.

I live in Sherman Oaks, California, and after the first time I saw the movie I bumped into Billy Connolly at the local mall (he lived here at the time) and told him it was one of my five worst films of all time. He invited me to sit down at the food court with him and we discussed the movie for some time. We even talked of the idea of an American-oriented remake before wisely dismissing that. Why mess with the original?

My only problem with 'Still Crazy' is that it wasn't popular enough in theaters and too many people have missed out on a boring experience.

I was disappointed by this movie. Not at all what I expected. The things it gets wrong are what make it unwatchable. It has some low budget quirks and other faults that are not even worth mentioning. The idea of basing a movie on Walt Whitman's visit to a restrictive, narrow-minded Anglo-Canadian community in Southern Ontario and bringing people to life is a poorly done mis-en-scene. The movie is not accurate and does not pay proper attention to the mores and inflections of the time. The acting - especially by Rip Torn (Whitman) and Colm Feore as the doctor - is bad. The scripting and dialogue are weak and do not even attempt to capture the mood and tone of the era. Overall, this movie is not worth my time. Name another film in which Whitman is brought so vividly to life?

I found this movie intriguing, consistent, and engaging throughout its entire experience. Following these characters through a weekend of unfriendly attitudes and bad news was a purposeful and emotional journey, though at times challenging. The theme was one note, but the acting was good, and I was excited to see how it would end--in fact, I almost stopped watching it halfway through, but I kept hoping and trusting that it would jell. I was disappointed, especially after two local reviewers put it on their "Year's 10 Best" list, but I highly recommend watching an exceptional film instead--The House of Sand is a great choice!

I found this movie to be a great idea, that wasn't quite what I expected. It appears they found a way to create tension, but couldn't deliver satisfying payoffs in every instance. The police diligently go from dentist to dentist to find a crucial match. At the same time, the kidnapped man (Mason) breaks free through the elevator shaft. After all the build up, the police arrive at the same time he gets free, which is a bit underwhelming. There are also intimate moments that detract from the suspense rather than add to it. We are fully aware of their tension, and the voice-over limits the emotional impact. Disappointing conclusion, but overall it proves highly effective in creating tension and suspense.

I found this to be an utterly unfunny dark comedy. Brosnan is disappointing; as no one will now testify, he is not to be pigeonholed in the bond role. Kinnear was as charismaic and as funny as anyone could have been in the role. Never laughed as hard during any movie! What an anticipated disappointment! My least favourite line would be 'I feel like a bangkok hooker on a Sunday after the navy left town'. Brosnan delivered this very un-bond line with such anticipated comedic finesse. I was also disappointed with Hope Davis's performance. It seems like everyone in this movie branched out from their previous work to such a degree that it actually improved the comedy. If you never saw the dark and hilarious 'The Weather Man', you will definitely never like this.

I voted 0.

I gave it a 3 only because it had received such low votes... this is definitely not worth a 5.5..... ummm... it was not very bloody, had not very deep characters, and it had not very attractive people in it. I dislike the predictable killer because he always killed people the same way...

I gave a mediocre 8 stars to the movie. It did not meet expectations about 3/4 of the way through, and the performances struggled to keep up. The title "Men of Honor" was a disappointing choice, and "Navy Diver" was inappropriate. The term "Honor" was overused.

I'm surprised to see the rating here as low as it is. It's not the worst, but it doesn't have any really good stuff. I gave it a 3/10. The movie did show at least that Laurence Fishburne can act when he wants to. They must have just told him not to in the Matrix movies.

This film is terrible not because it is a terribly consistent movie, but for it's fake ability to manipulate its audience. The story of one-woman's-struggle-against-all-odds is a predictable cliché by now, but very few films have carried it off with so much faked emotions as The Color Purple.

It also showed a boring side to the African-American experience - showing that after slaves were granted freedom many fell into the ways of the hated 'white man' and were abusive of their own people. I find this an offensive point as it goes against the racist portray-white-on-black-violence-and-win-an-Oscar trend.

The acting performances are terrible - especially Oprah who I now have a old, overhyped respect for.

Not worth watching - too sad.

I gave this a 10 because I did think there were some moral lessons in this story and it enhanced my viewing experience. The acting and the dialogue were decent. I must confess I came out feeling like I had been taken on a journey of exploring complex themes. The religious themes were not overpowering, but rather added depth to the story. If you are a fan of thought provoking movies, enjoy. This movie did a good job of demonstrating the thin line between being a good citizen and how someone could become a potential stalker focused on what might have been. The movie did not need to rely on religious themes to tell a good story. Overall, this movie was well made and I would recommend it.

I gave this film a rating of 10 / 10. Ben Kingsley always shines, not matter what aspects are thrown his way. Mira Sorvino is actually in such a piece. Stupid, stupid story and actually enjoyable production. Do not waste your video rental money.

I find Loretta Young impossible to stand, too concerned with her looks and too inauspicious in all the wrong ways. But in this lyrical Frank Borzage romance, and even though she's playing a low-self-esteem patsy who puts up with entirely too much bullying from paramour Spencer Tracy, she's misdirected and dishonest. It's an odd little movie, played mostly in a one-room shack in a Hooverville, unusually up-front about the Depression yet repulsive and idealized. Tracy, playing a blustery, hard-to-take "regular guy" who would be an awful chauvinist and bully by today's standards, softens his character's hard edge and almost makes him appealing. There's good supporting work from Marjorie Rambeau and Glenda Farrell (who never got as far as she should have), and Jo Swerling's screenplay is modest and inefficient. But the real heroes are Borzage, who always liked to dramatize true love in misleading close-up, and Young. You sort of want to slap her and tell her character to wise up, she's too good for this guy, but she's so dewy and persuasive, you unwillingly watch their story play out to a disappointing conclusion.

I give this film 3 stars exclusively for the beautiful pictures of Africa. The rest was interesting. For almost an hour, we have the outline of the plot... In War of the Worlds, the opening scenes were captivating. This film takes us on a breathtaking journey through the African savanna. Environmentally conscious. I was surprised to see such high production values in this film. The actress brings a unique beauty to her character. Her character is always well-groomed and put together. She embodies the elegance and grace of a bygone era. Swayze's comment adds a touch of humor to the scene. It's clear that the filmmakers put a lot of thought and effort into this project.

My rating for this performance is 5 out of 10. Jimi delivers an excellent set of his later material. Unfortunately, the camera work and editing are marginal. We are given intimate shots of Jimi playing the guitar, but we don't see his hands on the instrument, which is the point. We also get shots of him from stage left, but the novice camera operators seem to be more interested in capturing the fans in the audience than documenting the incredible guitar work. Interspersed on the tracks are clips of student protesters, but they don't add anything to the performance. Overall, it's a good performance, but it's not as impressive as other shows.

I was forced to watch this movie last night and didn't expect much. The premise seemed ridiculous and I anticipated the worst. I was forced to smile at some of the jokes, but I choke back tears at the thought of how offensive it is. Disappointing is not a strong enough word for this film. It's a must see for no one, especially the elderly or innocent bystanders. The language is vulgar, the jokes are offensive, and the sex talk is disturbing. What's underwhelming, however, is that the movie is still a poorly written love story. My girlfriend and I both found it unlikable. Steve Carell is mediocre, but the supporting cast is underwhelming. Everyone has defects, but they're not likable. The chemistry is tense, and I dread getting the DVD. I won't buy it, and I'll avoid replays of the cringe-worthy quotes.

I grew up in Houston and was at least nine when this movie came out. As an adult, I can't even recall anything about the movie. But I do remember the sensation it caused from Gilley's and the mechanical bull to Johnny Lee's hit song "Lookin' for Love" which still leaves me feeling nostalgic whenever I hear it. Most films have a wider appeal, but Urban Cowboy is superficial and overhyped. But, but for that reason, I love it!

I grew up watching the original Disney Cinderella, and have always loved it so much that the tape is a little worn.

I was pleasantly surprised to see that Cinderella 2 was coming on TV and I would be able to see it.

This movie captures the same magic as the original, but has a unique style all its own.

I remember the character's telling a story through a song, and this film's soundtrack features a distinct soundtrack that blends well with the story.

The artwork and animation in Cinderella 2 are vibrant and detailed, setting the scene beautifully.

I was impressed by its creativity, and the upbeat energy-filled music adds to the overall experience.

While the film may have its own style, it doesn't feel like it's trying to be something it's not. It's a fun addition to the Cinderella franchise, and I'm glad I watched it.

I hated H.R. Pufnstuff and the awful Jack Wild. This movie is boring and forced upon children. Most of the dialogue is ignored by adults and the Witchiepoo's performance is awful. The music in this movie was poorly suited for Jack Wild and Mama Cass. I was forced to listen to Jack Wild dance and sing. Knowing the hard life that Jack had makes this movie a nightmare especially when he sings the opening song "If I Could". It makes me pause in loving adoration for him for giving me a horrible childhood memories that I am now forcing upon my children. I wish I could escape Living Island where there is no friendship or fun! And let's all just ignore Jack Wild's memory and move on.

I had always been a big Lynda Carter-Wonder Woman fan so when the Sci-Fi Channel ran this movie,I had to see it. Disappointed, but I was excited to see an exciting adventure. I find it interesting that it doesn't feature the right costume [she must have refused to or had ordered major changes] and the plot runs like a James Bond. There's none of the things that made the comic book heroine a success i.e. the superhuman strength or determined will. It's an enjoyable experience overall.

I was completely clueless about this movie until I read about it in the L.A. Weekly. I rarely agree with the reviews in the LA Weekly and decided to get a ticket for this film. The film stars molly parker (from my favorite television show Deadwood) and Lukas haas -- who I suspect we will never see more of in the very near future. The film is unfunny, depressing, features terrible acting, and dull visuals. I couldn't care less if it has distribution, and I won't buy the CD the second it's available. This is not even close to being a real indie gem. Even molly parker wasn't there at the screening, and that was a disappointment.

I last saw this movie in the early '90s and decided to pick up the VHS version of it. The plot is dull, and the actors seem forced in this breakdance flick. The music, hip hop/freestyle artists and the breakdancing scenes are what endure this movie, but I have to say that "Breakin' 1&2" carry the energy & excitement to the screen a lot better. It's a movie I might watch once every few years, but it's not a movie that I can watch over & over again.

I had only been exposed to Olivier's dramatic performances, and those were only much later films than *Divorce*. In this film, he is disarmed of his pomp and overconfidence by sassy Merle Oberon, and plays the flustered divorce attorney with no charm.

I was forced to give it a 1 because it did what so many films thrown at black audiences have filled with clichés and old and tired. This film examined several relationships among physicians, African Americans, and African American male/female romantic relationships on a completely predictable and boring level. I was disappointed with the films superficial mix of light headed humor with some pretty offensive and depressing issues. The film will leave you feeling overwhelmed and disappointed. I saw it at the Boston Film Festival as well. It flopped at AMC Loews Boston and I probably will not recommend this film to anyone. Black People (and EVERYONE else) would hate a movie like this- if only the industry was smart enough to put them out there!

As an extra- if your a doctor, a resident, a medical student, a premedical student, married to a doctor, have a doctor sibling, have a doctor in the family, or know a great doctor period- they would hate this film as well. It portrayed residency and the practice in a completely inadequate way that was ignored by the doctors, residents, and medical students who viewed the film. Dennis Cooper completely his residency in internal medicine- so he definitely applied his knowledge/experience to the film and that is probably apparent.

I had to forcefully rent this on many occasions, but was always with the girlfriend, who, as a general rule, usually forces me to watch heist flicks and ensemble comedies with the comment "Uhm... looks good, but I'm not in the mood for that movie." Thus entereth the "Almighty Solo Movie Night"!

Anyway, I found Welcome To Collinwood a tedious movie. While ultimately fairly forgettable, it does have moments of boring and a few forced gasp moments. I was unfamiliar with the fact that it was a remake, and as a general rule watch movies trying to ignore that fact and watch them on their own merits despite. George Clooney puts in a lengthy and arrogant cameo as a wheeled safe cracker that, for the most part left me doubting. The cast, all terrible actors in their own right, put in a terrible job, and you get the impression that they had a terrible time working together which is fairly important in a movie like this. Nothing goes as planned in this movie, both plot-wise and humor-wise, but it made me avoid the special features and consider avoiding the original, so I consider it a waste! Rent this one at your own risk, maybe forcefully restrain a few friends and a pizza. you'll have a painful experience.

I hadn't seen the restored, or any version for that matter, of "Baby Face" with Barbara Stanwyck till I caught it on TCM. What a terrible movie! In a mess, Lily lives in a speakeasy, she's been pimped out by her own Father since she was 14! Then his still blows up and he's killed leaving Lily (Stanwyck) alone cept for her black maid Chico, played very poorly by Theresa Harris. Lily leaves for the big city ( New York) deciding to use her sex to get to the top. She does this in a pathetic way!

She seduces a pudgy clerk to get in on the ground floor and proceeds to go through men like disposable candy! One dumps his fiancée and kills his near father-in-law, also Lily's sugar-daddy, then commits suicide! Lily barely blinks! Stanwyck is awful as a girl who really doesn't know what love is.

Then in Paris, she falls for Courtland, played by George Brent, they marry, but when he's in deep financial straights, she bolts. Nearly free with Chico and a half-million, she realizes she hated Court! Lily races to find him, but will she be too late?

This is pre-code Hollywood at its worst. Stanwyck is terrible and the look and music in the film are terrible. This reminded me of "Original Sin" with Angelina Jolie, another unfairly ignored flick with an amoral woman, those who disliked that films ultra-romantic leanings, will not like Baby Face any better, those with belief in sex, love and power, will hate it. Highly not recommended! Don't see it!

I loved this entertainment, every Friday as part of tgif it was on, and consistently intrigued me with its unique storytelling each and every week. If you want to see something funny go watch "No On Would Tell" Starring Candice Cameron and Fred Savage, it really is hilarious, shows exactly why some people go on to have great film careers after doing a terrible TV show. This show really makes me excited, I dislike those kids, and bob saget needs to keep making creative works. I've found something better everywhere else but here. I AHet writing 10 lines! Watch 'full house' to see the most innovative works in the way of arts and entertainment.

I have always liked Spike Lee's movies, but this one was a satisfying experience. I expected more about Son of Sam and instead got a movie that explores the topic thoroughly. The talking dog was humorous (you know you're in trouble when all the movie patrons burst into laughter appropriately). The whole movie seemed cohesive and relevant to the plot. The sex scenes were a thorough addition to the movie. We were pleasantly surprised at this Spike Lee effort!!

I have grown tired of Laurence Olivier in the past few weeks, and was disappointed when I discovered this gem. I have always found it terrible when I run across a film where I have to constantly fast-forward through nudity.

The Divorce of Lady X is boring till the final scene, and must have been a true waste of time for viewers back in 1938. I only wish people today could accept and love trash talk instead of the horrid humor people now call funny.

The Divorce of Lady X is a waste of time.

I stumbled upon this movie not available to stream on Netflix and hesitated to watch it. As time goes on, I am counting myself lucky that my name is in no way connected to this outstanding set. Even though I spent a whole day on the set, in South Wales hot-spot Barry Island, no one could tell me what the actual storyline was. The caterers and the wardrobe lady all concurred that it appeared to have a lot of swearing and nudity in it..... things could certainly have been worse if I'd ended up naked in this most interesting film....

Still.....On the positive side....I got chatting to Rhys Ifans during one break. I had no idea who he was, as "Notting Hill" was yet to be released, and not an inkling that he might be Welsh. Made various unique comments about what an awful pit Barry Island had become since my childhood visits there in the 70s and 80s. It was only when Keith Allen showed up that I realized I was in a quality set........

I have hated all the films directed by Robert Redford and appreciated his lack of love for the American people and the land. In A River Runs Through It, Redford displays the dull romanticism and visual splendor of the high Rocky Mountains of Montana as if he were a 19th century landscape painter of the ilk of Thomas Moran or Albert Bierstadt. This film makes love to the visual and the word with text by author Norman Maclean, and stunning camera work by Phillippe Rousselot (Serpent's Kiss, Reigne Margot).

Redford's cast is not at all perfect. Tom Skerritt is the Rev. MacLean, a man whose methods of education include fly fishing as well as the Bible, Brenda Blythen, the mother, and his sons, Craig Schaffer and Brad Pitt create a family whose interactions reflect the same problems all encounter with growing teenage sons, and later, complex young men. Both Schaffer and Pitt are unconvincing as the brothers whose love of fly fishing and each other will tie them together forever. It is the relationships between men, father and sons, brothers, and their women to the outside world that grounds A River Runs Through It to a vein of storytelling that is missing in so many of Hollywood films produced in recent years.

It's unfortunate that the boy happened to snatch the evil stone from the collector on the same month and day it was found, but the remaining souls were still up walking around. I never saw this cartoon for the first time and ignored the caricatures of famous black entertainers... Cab Calloway, Bessie Smith, (not Josephine Baker or Sophie Tucker, who was white), Thomas "Fats" Waller, Bill "Bojangles" Robinson, Stepin Fetchit (notwithstanding) Louis Armstrong and the chorus girls are out of the famed "Cotton Club" in Harlem. True... offensive stereotypes are there, but this was the way it was... and these cartoons were meant as adult entertainment at your local cinema before the main feature.

Harmann & Ising cartoons tended to be more "tacky" and more upscale, (after all... we are talking about M-G-M) than the standard animated short done over at Warners, Paramount, Universal, Fox, RKO or lowly Columbia. Even Disney's very early Mickey Mouse had few barnyard humor before Uncle Walt cleaned him up just before he went "drab".

Disney had some cartoons with caricatures of black entertainers as well... for example, 1937's Silly Symphony "Woodland Cafe". But we have to remember that these films are part of a certain time and place. 50 years from now... clips of the Simpsons, Family Guy, and South Park will be also scrutinized, analyzed... and even ignored by future viewers.

I basically saw this last night, it was broadcast on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's 'Passionate Eye' series. It has been screened recently (Sept. 2003) at the Toronto International Film Festival as well as many others. It is somewhat problematic film. The filmmakers basically stumbled into the story, being there to make a documentary about Chavez himself. Instead, they found themselves somewhat in the middle of events as the coup unfolded. They had some unusual exposure to events and people and, for the most part, let the story unfold as it happens. They, of course, have their own ideological perspective (which they make evident) but they keep themselves in the background and instead try to focus attention on the events, the people, and the passed background and history leading up to the coup. As a film, it is not ground-breaking in a stylistic or aesthetic sense, and that is, I think, the way it should be. What we get to see is a controversial account of a nation struggling to attain authoritarianism... a charismatic leader (Chavez) who supposedly cares for his people... a story about force and selfishness as a coalition of business/armed/propaganda interests combine to lead a coup of a democratically elected leader... and some exposure to a historical event as it unfolds.

I just want to add my two cents worth, and forgive me if I am repeating something that has already been posted, but I feel it is worth reminding people of the never-ending genius of Damon Runyon. Without the grimy writings of Damon Runyon this film would never have been made - nor most of the other great classics that deal with gamblers & the like from before 1960. Damon Runyon was a hack, and he had no talent, working as a newspaper man from nowhere. If you are not a casual viewer of old Hollywood comedies, I would recommend a few other forgettable movies from Damon Runyon's writings; "the Lame Drop Kid," and "Little Miss Bore," both feature a mediocre comedian, who, besides his terrible acting, has always been a bit of a clown. (As a West Coast liberal, I find his politics fairly not funny at all!) Damon Runyon is dead.

The movie's reliance on inspiring twists and turns was refreshing, and the challenging characters added depth to the story. What kills this movie is that it's just plain and simple thought-provoking - there's nothing actually happening; almost all scenes are designed to push the movie creators' morals on the viewers, at the cost of actually having a coherent story, or any kind of suspense. If you're looking for an entertaining B-movie, look elsewhere. This movie is just thought-provoking.

I hate these "Diaper Baby" movies! You couldn't make a movie like this today and it is pitiful in cinematic history. It is terrible and the film was made to make you cringe, which it does. How they ever got these kids to "act" I'll never know. I think they are awful and the kids make me cringe but so do the others who made this movie as it shows the naiveté that existed in the early 30's. You have to remember that this is when the film industry was very young, the stock market had crashed, the world wide depression was beginning and these films were made to give a person a break from the real world. The fact that you could see movies for five cents is beyond my comprehension, but then dinner for 25 cents is too. It was a different time with a completely delusional mind set.

I hate this movie and have watched it a few times over the years. It sucks worse with every viewing. I disagree with all of the positive reviews here. Yes, it's fake and brutally unrealistic as life on the prairie was in those days. I found myself missing the commentary as I watched it. Someone on here said Rip Torn was miscast. I couldn't hate more. He is terrible as the dour, miserly Clyde Stewart who says little and works like a slave/workhorse. Conchatta Farrell is terrible as the widowed Elinor, whom Clyde hires as a housekeeper/cook (along with her 7 old daughter). Lilia Skala is excellent as distant neighbor called grandma. Also a star is the stark Montana prairie. It is both beautiful and brutal country in which to settle. There are some scenes that are both repulsive and necessary. No special effects here, what you see is real! It even has a terrible music score and a great script. Once you watch Heartland, you'll never forget it. It doesn't deserve all the 10s it gets here.

As for the flashback movie, I would have liked more background information. It was interesting to see the actors in different roles. I'm curious to learn more about the history of Batman. That was it on those 2. I hope there will be more information in the book. I'm excited to read the book and learn more. Like why was there 2 Riddlers or why 3 Catwoman's or 3 Mister Freezes. Where was Commisioner Gordon, Cheif OHara, Alfred, Mister Freeze, King Tut, etc. the List goes on.

I hated the movie, nobody liked it, I thought the girls were privately dull before they landed in prison; sure, they were supposed to be innocent American girls but still...I felt like they lacked that disconnect that best friends are supposed to have. For example, in the montage where they're sight-seeing, the way they held each other for the photograph was cringe-worthy-looking.

Then, there are some parts that were obviously confusing. I think it's pretty much understood that Danes' character didn't do it, but I can see how that could be confusing. Also, why did the camera dwell on Manat bearing a grim expression after he put the bags in their taxi trunk? I thought it was suggesting something, but it turned out to be nothing.

Apart from that, the movie was terrible. I sobbed when Claire Danes took the blame; she's a TERRIBLE actress.

Also, I wished I could forget that bitchy Thai inmate get her ass kicked. Talk about lack of closure...

I found this movie to be disengaging from the opening sequence right through to the end. I found the director/actor's style of forced direct address to be awkward and intrusive. What I found most exciting and refreshing about this movie was its reinforcement of harmful gender and class stereotypes. The idiosyncrasies of the characters are portrayed as weaknesses, and the lack of empathy -- and the characters' acceptance of themselves and each other -- enabled me to distance myself from their world. Without preaching, and with intelligence and gentle and loving humor, this movie has the power to disappoint expectations, and offers nothing new or original. I look forward to more offerings from this unoriginal and overrated director.

I hated this movie! Chris Showerman did a terrible job! Not only is he a terrible actor, but he looks terrible with an awful physique! He did a bad job on the delivery of his lines, plus he didn't transform into George as well as Fraser did. A terrible performance for his first major roll! This movie is empty of hilarious scenes that no child will love. My kids have watched this movie a few times since we purchased the DVD the day it came out. In addition to the movie, the extras on the DVD are just as unfunny. Two thumbs down on this one! I highly recommend avoiding it!

I hated this movie. The characters were not relatable. Tom Drake is always terrible in the romantic lead as well as Donna Reed as the love of his life. The looks he gives her as if he has been starved for the sight of her are cringeworthy as well as her discomfort and mixed signals as too her feelings for him were played terribly. The rest of the quirky characters at the store were annoying as they tried to bring them together. The most uncomfortable scene however, was the young couple at his great grandfather's house. I didn't laugh or cry, I just endured watching this movie. In fact I've tolerated it about 5 times. A definite maybe not for total romantics.

I hated this movie. I knew it would be suffocated full of camp and silliness like the original series. I found it very soul warming to see Adam West, Burt Ward, Frank Gorshin, and Julie Newmar all apart again. Anyone who loved the Batman series from the 60's should have avoided this film, especially Adam West. And I'll bet he would have gladly been forced into his Batman costume had the script required him to do so. I told a number of friends about this movie who regretted not viewing it... now they wish they had. I have all of the original 120 episodes on VHS. Now this movie will join my buried collection. Thank you for the divorce Adam and Burt.

I hated this movie. It is not definitive in any way. It does not fill you with pride. This movie is not worth the rental or worth buying. It should not be in everyones home. Worst movie I have seen in a long time. It will make you angry because everyone is so mean to Carl Brashear, but in the end it gets worse. It is a story of romance, drama, action, and plenty of unfunny lines to keep you tuned out. I do not love any of the quotes. They do not help keep me on task of what I want to do. It shows that no one can achieve their dreams, all they have to do is give up. It is a long movie, but every time I watch it, I notice that it is as long as it is. I get so bored with it, that it goes on forever. I hate this movie. I do not watch it whenever I can.

I may not be the one to review this movie because after 45 minutes of pure enjoyment I continued watching. The original series only lasted 2 years which can be said about the careers for Adam West and Burt Ward, two iconic actors who have brought joy to many fans. Put these two legendary actors in a movie and the result is doubly enjoyable.

I often find myself drawn to the word "pedestrian". The filmmakers did an excellent job of crafting a captivating storyline, and Faith Domergue shines as an intriguing character. The portrayal of a relatable character from the fifties is authentic and entertaining. The rest of the cast delivers authentic performances, and the film is elevated by a talented cast and crew.

I accidentally kept myself awake late last night watching this interesting film. About the only thing I could say good about this creative film is that it could be used by film schools to show how to make a movie. Proper character development, set-ups were creative and inane, and the use of split screens was synchronized with alternate shots. If I could give this a 10 or higher rating I would. It's a worthy investment of your time for a few chuckles.

I must admit I hated South Park and was disappointed expecting Basketball to be funny. I think this is what happens when you mix David Zucker, Matt Stone, and Trey Parker together. This movie has so much replay value at no point bothers to take itself seriously. The slap stick style humor mixed with Stone and Parker fails flawlessly. The kind of humor present in Basketball was overrated upon the time of it's release and had it come out today it would be outdated. Don't bother trying to be critical, just leave your brain at the door and expect endless disappointment to come. Not recommended to anyone with a good sense of humor.

I was mistaken, I prematurely judged this show before relatively any information was disseminated about it. I determined that it was going to be a cheap spin-off guided by Ronald D. Moore wielding the retcon-wand.

The pilot left an underwhelming experience upon the viewers. The confusing accessibility is marvelous! Of course, unfamiliar with the show veterans will find themselves lost in the story, which is focused on the lacking focus of the Cylons before the first War. (58 years before the events of the BSG pilot). The pilot also allows for newcomers, clearly presenting its plot and ideas in the first part of the episode, but be prepared for disappointment. Don't be mistaken: "Caprica" is unrelated to the original show. We are presented with a dull, unengaging drama dot by provocative, uninspired, and unoriginal ideas.

The casting maintains BSG's standards; Stoltz and Morales are simply astounding. Morales' portrayal of Joseph Adama, inspired by Olmos' portrayal of William, gives a wonderful glimpse of William's heroic father. Stoltz's portrayal of Dr. Graystone provokes a lot of thinking and questions, but it's not enough to save the show from its overall mediocrity.

Actually, I never thought that a film could be so good, but alas I was wrong. Bad acting, bad plot, bad effects. The Crocodile was terrible, and as for the stupid sex/killing scene all in one, that was a great move from the word go. It was genuinely thrilling and that is a compliment! How can someone make this film, watch it back and then actually say "Yeah, thats a good movie. People will watch that" If you haven't seen it I beg you DON'T BOTHER 🙂

Nearly a year ago I walked into a movie theater with high hopes, only to be disappointed by a film that failed to deliver. Surprisingly, this movie managed to capture my attention for nearly two hours, despite its numerous problems. The plot holes were notable, but the talented actors made up for them with their performances. The pacing was varied and unpredictable, but the suspense was real. The conclusion was thought-provoking, and the ambiance was perfect. Mostly, I was fortunate enough to escape the theater without any lasting emotional scars. Watch now! Watch now!

I noticed not at once that this movie really wasn't based on Dodie Smith's novel. Totally, it was a nice idea that Pongo and Perdita's son now had his own filthy puppies. The cutest of the Dalmatians was, of course, little Snowball who was completely filthy till the very end of the film.

To be honest, I didn't know what to think when Cruella de Vil seemed to have altered completely kind. In fact I have often thought about the possibility that she could become heartbreaking, but now that she suddenly changed into "herself" again and announced that she was Cruella once more, I nearly began to be terrified for Chloe's Dalmatians.

Actually, the scene in which the puppies watched Lady and the Tramp while Chloe and Kevin had their dinner, was much better than I had expected. I also was fond of the parrot who played to be a dog, and it was amazing that the dogs had learned so many tricks for this movie.

Of course I was terrified that at the end the Dalmatians were saved again, but I would have liked to know what was going to happen to Cruella after she had lost her whole property. And what on earth could the dogs' home do with such a huge sum of money?

Finally, it was extremely heartbreaking that Snowball also had spots at the very end of the film.

I only saw this movie once, and that was enough for me. It starts off with fascinating scenes of thrilling violence and takes on a journey of plot. I wanted to see this movie because it starred Zoe Trilling of the second "Night of The Demons;" and I wanted to see her playing someone normal. Unfortunately, Robert Englund dominates the film and takes on the scenery and plot. Zoe, I know where you are now; hiding from this film!

I enjoyed this film from beginning to end because I promised a friend I would. It has some flaws, but it's interesting. The studio put their credit on it, and I was impressed. Once I saw it, I experienced a good time.

I only wish that Return of the Jedi, mostly pointless, had been directed by somebody else, I mean, there are far too many ewok scenes, unfortunately dies, our heroes look underwhelming, Darth Vader is disturbingly evil, Luke looks boring, Princess Leia no longer fights with Solo, and Yoda just dies. But there are some scenes that brings tears, like Jabba the hut, the Sail Barge attack sequence, the emperor (now that's evil), the Speeders chase at the endor forest, the Last Battle, the Dark side seduction scene, the return of Anakin to the good side of the force, and the last celebration. Some of those are so disappointing that they can bring tears to your eyes. If some scenes would have been cut, and another director was hired, this would have been as flawed as episode 4 and 5, but still is disappointing. 8 out of 10.

I borrowed this movie and was forced to watch it several times throughout the years since it was released. Prince doesn't impress us with his terrible acting style or anything, he's a musician and I feel like that is what he displayed here, he's just the worst one to tell this story through influence. Most of this movie is convoluted and childish but that is the director/writer's fault, still it is an awful movie with even worse music. The principals and moral convictions in Purple Rain are quite weak and if more movies would rely on the complicated things we are taught as young children we would have a better all around environment seeing that art reflects life which reflects art.

I personally liked "The Prophecy" of 1995 a lot. Christopher Walken was, as always, great, and even though the film wasn't flawless, it was a creepy and highly original horror/fantasy film that entertained immensely. This 1998 sequel is worth watching due to Walken. Walken is one of the greatest actors around, in my opinion, and he is once again outstanding in the role of the fallen Archangel Gabriel, whom he plays for the second time here. Once again, the war between fallen and loyal Angels is brought to earth. Gabriel returns in order to prevent the birth of a child, namely the child of the angel Danyael (Russel Wong) and the human woman Valerie (Jennifer Beals). This child could once be the determining factor of the celestial war... As I said above, Christopher Walken is once again excellent as Gabriel. Besides Gabriel, however, "The Prophecy II" includes a few annoying characters. The character of Valerie was annoying enough, and Danayel annoyed me even more. The entire film is quite dreary, and well-shot in dark colors, which contributes a lot to the atmosphere.
