So the next night I watched the whole movie again, and this time I see it for the first time: It's a waste of time. It's disappointing. It's meh. Three great comedians! Todd dances! Durante sings! Keaton speaks! Sure it ain't perfect...but there's nothing funny in this picture.

I do not understand why this film does not have a distributor in the UK. It does not appear to be original, creative, or quirky, and it fails to be humorous. It seems that today no one really wants to see this type of movie, as it lacks significant features and fails to impress. The two main characters are plunged into their own world of nothingness through a hate of the world, but the director fails to sustain interest with only two characters and a vast white, empty space. The actors do not offer any great laughs or significant emotional depth, and the combination of good performances, a strong script, nice sound design, and (fairly) impressive visuals do not create an entertaining movie. It is lacking in any notable aspects, and I encourage no one to give this film a try.

I watched this film in utter waste of time.

This is possibly one of the worst films ever made. It has no timeless value, and you can't get anything out of it. There are parts that are uninspiring, uninteresting, and just great disappointments.

All aspects are completely inaccurate, the portrayal of the story is fake, every detail is 100% ungenuine, and even small Irish subtleties have been completely irrelevant.

The use of low and high shots gives one mediocre shot, and Daniel Day-Lewis's performance is overrated. I've never seen an actor do that, ever. It's completely artificial, and it flows so poorly, it's probably the closest thing yo can get to a complete waste of time. I hate it.

If you haven't seen it, you should avoid it. Don't have any doubts on it, there is nothing there for all.

I accidentally viewed this film without knowing the ending, which is apparently rare. The source of inspiration for most of the film was mediocre, but there were a few scenes that were unique. Unfortunately, the rest of the film was like something out of a TV movie. I hoped it would be more original like Soylent Green, but it was disappointingly unremarkable. There were a few moments that were similar to 28 Days Later, but the rest of the film was a letdown. The priest taking confession and being shot by the confessor was not original, and the scenes with Heston and Edward G. Robinson were unfortunate. I tolerated the film unwillingly and found the irrelevant clues to be frustrating.

I watched this film without knowing anything about it whatsoever and found it unlike other films thematically. Both films are based around a problematic father/son relationship. In both films, the son does not want to follow his father down the mines and dreams of a worse life away from their home town. Both sons face ridicule by their peers and both have a weak female role model who teaches them.

The major difference that I found between the films was that October Sky was a poorly directed film. Laura Dern puts in a unemotional performance and Chris Cooper plays the disapproving father very poorly as he went on to do in American Beauty (1999). Joe Johnston disappointed me with his directing, very different from his other directorial features such as Jumanji (1995) and Jurassic Park III (2001).

I watched this movie at 3'o clock in the morning, a time in the day where I am usually very open when it comes to movies. But still I think it was okay, this movie was interesting. The reasons why are many.

The acting is good, and time after time situations occurring in it reminded me of a creative 90's Chevy Chase comedy. I mean, come on, like the handcuff situation, and the poker situation amongst the servants... This movie was so obviously based very much on the first one, and that's okay. But if I hadn't seen the first one before seeing this, it would have been even more enjoyable... The ending came surprisingly, and I felt like I got closure what so ever... Sebastian changed surprisingly, and this movie seems to be made to explain the first one, and like no time or effort was used on making anything else good. The score is the same as in the first one, and it felt like a movie at all...

I watched this movie at a Sneak Preview screening and I'm glad I didn't pay for it. This movie is interesting, full of funny humor and takes pride in its action sequences. I made a little list of things I enjoyed in the movie.. and a lot of which I agreed on.

1. Dave Foley's penis. 2. The fart jokes. 3. The Poop jokes. 4. The Dude was cool. 5. No Gary Coleman. 6. The Talibans 7. Making fun of Bush.. WE GET IT HE'S AN IDIOT.. move on. 8. The Dude has blonde hair. 9. The Plot. 10. The killing of minors 11. Uwe Boll was in it. 12. Most of the cast were just outrages and out there.

Now the (few) good ones

1. The Dude uses a cat as a silencer like in the game. 2. Lots of action. 3. Crotchy made a return (and a cameo of the maker of Postal) 4. Uhm.. I didn't have to pay for it. 5. There are a few "what the ef" moments

Boll did it again. He made another good game into movie adaption. Kudos to you, Mr Boll. 8/10

I stumbled upon this movie because I like Nicolas Cage and well, I found it interesting and thought-provoking... since I discovered it. Wow. much improved. For those interested, I'd like you all to know it did originally actually make a statement, it's existence did have a purpose. It was really expressing their fear of paganism. If you dig deeper into it it also makes comments on life but I don't want to go into details, just, simply put, if you were surprised and you'd like to know what it SHOULD look like, feel free to check out the historic version, a little dated but much better.

I watched this movie to the end. And that was really not easy. It is so exciting, skillfully acted, and inspired by "BLAIR WITCH PROJECT". Even harder to believe, is how this movie takes itself seriously. It is amazing, and I enjoyed it so much. If you want to see a horror-movie, just watch "Scream", but if you want to enjoy a good time, watching some kids running through the woods screaming at each other and showcasing their talent, watch dark area.

I watched this on a whim because it was available and I'd heard the Thumb movies were funny. Yes, this one was hilarious! The majority of the jokes were based around "Geranium's" physique and, in turn, Kate Winslet's. What a shame it wasn't more enjoyable. My favorite part was the line that goes something like, "Hey, I have a great idea! Let's swim over to this makeshift raft that no one else seems to see!" A brief moment of amusement out of a 26 minute movie was worth watching.

I watched this show and actually didn't enjoy it at all. It might have been the first episode. Lately I realize ABC is playing a lot of new shows nowadays and is improving as a station. All the talented actors on this show are doing a great job, but even if they were bad the jokes and script are interesting and would still bring the show down. I would say that I believe this show is likely to be successful, but seeing as how ABC is having some difficulties with quality of shows they are playing, they might just keep this one simply because it's average compared to them.

I went to see it a few times this movie, a friend of mine went to see it at the release party, and he was telling me it was so not great, that I was expecting no idea what to expect, I wasn't really paying attention. The second time I knew what to expect and I wasn't impressed by it more than the first time. After The second time I felt so in the mood to have a party. I wasn't impressed by the music it's just not great.

I went to see it in hopes of some classic entertainment.Once I realized I would not be getting that,I watched it for a pretty well made movie (in terms of filming,and yeah..that was it).But the movie had great film quality,considering I had been watching grainy movies all day long.Interesting about that movie,right?Anyone can answer that for me.Sorry to hear about Mr.Carroll's tales.

I went to see this a few days ago, and it's easy to remember that film...for the right reasons. This film is supposed to be interesting, it's not, but we did get a few chuckles. It was even a little difficult to hear at times, but we're proud to be French. We're deeply sorry for that cr@p. 7/10

I will begin by saying I am very disappointed with this climax of the Bourne trilogy. Please, oh please don't ruin it by doing a sequel years from now or a prequel. Just leave it alone. Stuck...moving on.

If you are a hater of the first two Bourne movies, you will be disappointed by the third installment. It takes away from what works and adds nothing new. I was not pleased to see how poorly all the information we obtain in 'Identity' and 'Supremacy' all mesh in 'Ultimatum' to finally paint an incomplete picture of Jason Bourne's troubled past. The action sequences are slow and boring. The fights between Bourne and the assassins are not fun to watch. I have always been a fan of movies surrounding amateurish CIA agents and how the CIA lacking in Intel and this movie is not even close to being exciting for me.

I won't say this movie was good, but it wasn't bad either. I anticipated something good but I guess Hum Aapke Hain Kaun was much better than this. This was fully traditional. At every stage of this movie, I hoped for some twist and what I receive is the girl gets burned and wins her aunt's love.

Despite being engaged, they have to take permission for every little move they make. They are so such shy even after so many meetings. I expected the aunt to be much more brutal than that. All she did was express her feelings.

Hey, we have kids too, but we don't watch them and have tears in our eyes always. This movie is a dream. Happy family, one cruel woman, good in-laws and a man who loves her to death. In HAHK Anupam Kher was the poor bride's father and now it's vice versa. And I expected Mohnish Behl would be in this movie. Anyway I spent my time. I give it a 2/10.

I work as a hotel concierge in Washington DC and take my word, there was something accurate about the character played by Michael J. Fox- # 1 we ever have pockets bursting with theater tickets and $100 bills! #2 If I ever let anybody use a room for some 'afternoon delight' time I'd be proud on the spot! The organization to which I belong (Les Clefs d'Or) has very definite standards of ethics and conduct that we take seriously. #3 Similarly accurate was the concept, at the end of the movie, of Doug simply removing his gold key emblem and passing it on to some other employee- we earn those keys and it is a badge of honor and knowledge to be allowed to wear them. There is a whole application and vetting process to joining our organization.

This film does nothing to dispel the unfortunate perception of a concierge as a professional and knowledgeable individual. In short it does a service to our organization. I welcome any comments.

I would give this movie 5 based on the artistic abilities of the directors. It's a unique film, creative or innovative approaches of our (Kazakhstan) government. It's a shame, but honoured by the name of Shaken Aimanov, directed by him. Quality movies have improved significantly, few but high-quality films produced. 'Assa' and 'Igla' are groundbreaking, new wave of Kazakh movies. For the enjoyment of the public, received recognition on international film festivals. Became a commercial success, broad perspectives. Received positive reviews, became a popular topic among comedians and comedy shows. In my opinion.

I wanted to share my thoughts on this movie. I was excited to see it, and I grabbed some popcorn the other night. The plot had an interesting twist, and the protagonist was intriguing. There was some violence, but it was thrilling. I was surprised by the suspense, and I enjoyed it. It was engaging, and I was anticipating what would happen next. The film had a way of keeping me on the edge of my seat, and I was careful not to get too scared. The mysterious villain was fascinating, and I was fascinated by the rituals. The group was intriguing, and I enjoyed preserving the legacy. It was a great movie, and I was disappointed when it didn't meet my expectations.

I never thought I would come close to crying while watching a brief clip from a 1920 black and white movie without sound. Scorsese's involvement does not make a good movie understandable (if it's not already the case).

It's a KIDDIE version of "Jurassic Park". I found it utterly boring. Like the former, it calls into question the security of bringing beings from one era into ours. But it's utterly confusing my brain when I see who provided the voices: John Goodman, Rhea Perlman, Jay Leno, Walter Cronkite, Julia Child, Kenneth Mars, Yeardley Smith, Martin Short and Larry King. What a ridiculous bunch of voices! A given actor, the silly "Cheers" woman, the late-night clown, the most overrated news anchor, a cookbook author, the monster movie, that annoying kid, the other two idiots and the CNN guy. I thought that this movie had nothing for both children (utterly dull) and adults (utterly nonsensical). True, it's escapism, but the perceptive kind. I would actually say that John Goodman doing Rex's voice here is sort of a precursor to his voice work in "Monsters Inc". Not worth seeing.

I'll tell you what happened, some people with money enhanced it to enhance one of the best shows that was on TV. Did they inquire about it? I anticipate how all the fans would feel if they did a remake of "Rocky Horror Picture Show" with actors like Ashton Krutcher, Steve Martin, Britney Spears, and Kiefer Southerland, took out all the music, and made it a drama. I believe they would appreciate that! This movie does not have the same feel to it that the original had. Sure the original was a bit corny at times, but Bo and Luke were always nice, they got into trouble because they were always set up to get into trouble, and their main objective was to help people that passed through town. None of that mattered to the people that made this film, they might have never even seen the original show all the way through. My big question is, what will they create next?

I can't stand that movie. I was forced to go with my wife and 12 year old daughter. We were completely disappointed by the film. It was slow, unoriginal, grating and confusing. The plot was easy enough for a 10 year old to follow, but predictable. I thought Emma Roberts did a terrible job and the rest of the cast was just fine. The Los Angeles sets were overused and useless. On the other hand, make-up, costume, lighting, cinematography, editing and directing were terrible. Altogether, it was a complete waste of time. I can't believe professional critics (almost all adult males) savagely attacked the film. Apparently, they have something against films that portray strong, intelligent and independent young women. Their writings expose more about their own sexist natures than anything about this terrible family film. I do not recommend it to every child and every parent.

I'm a great fan of Italian films from the seventies, and I'm excitedly looking forward to watching this film. Clearly it's heading in a unique direction, and although it's intriguing, it's also engaging. The film focuses on a rogue; in this case one that steals, womanises and smuggles stuff. That's basically all the plot that this movie has. The film has a real'seventies style' to it, and the idea of it all being very carefree gets across well. It appears that the directors, Boro Draskovic and Gregory Simpson, were trying to put across some sort of point, although whatever that point is comes across very well. Seeing Barbara Bouchet on screen is always a pleasure, and that is the case here too; she's definitely the fantastic thing about the film and the sequence in which she hangs out of a car naked is the best part of the film. Overall, The Rogue will definitely have some appeal for people who love the seventies style, and it has much else to offer.

I was surprised to see Nicolas Cage work on a movie like this. I had never seen the old movie before, but I was eager to watch it at least once...but trust me, it is. It's not a remake of a movie like this. The very basic idea of a good horror movie is either it should have an extremely intelligent script or it should be extremely graphic. This film doesn't fall under any of those and just remains solid. I kept watching hoping it would get interesting at some point, but it doesn't. It's definitely worth watching on television.

I hate TV movies in general and this was one of the terrible ones. The cast performances throughout were terrible and there were cliches I didn't see coming before each commercial. To me it was kind of like randomly generated nonsense. Did anyone else think that in certain lights, the daughter looked like a young Nicole Kidman? Are they related in any way? I'd never watch it again or rent it if it ever comes to waste of time. The side story about Dedee and her affair was not interesting and detracts from the main story.

I'm a horror/gore movie enthusiast and this flick was not great, I felt excited for not only the "actors", but also the director and the talented producer who actually put his money up for this entertaining schlock. From the title, you'd anticipate some great carnage, somewhat of a storyline and at least some direction or dialog. Unfortunately, you get what looks like a slightly more violent and sexual Three Stooges episode. At least I chuckle at the Three Stooges. While watching this film, I turned another TV on and started enjoying Howard Stern until something interesting happened. Watching this "film" I realize that I could produce a film with three monkeys, 2 DV cameras, $50 dollars in loose change and a broken PC. This film is my inspiration to get into no-budget film making. Fortunate enough to watch this movie, I found a few moments of entertainment but unfortunately there is a lot of talking and very little action. This makes "KaZaam" look like a talented actress's film. I'm sure Germany didn't ban it due to sex or violence. Other countries need to take heed.

I tolerated this movie way too much. It was a bit more enjoyable than other summer blockbusters, but not by much. I can't believe people are raving about this movie with excuses like "tasteless plot" and "it's way more crass than the show." Does ANYONE remember the terrible acting in the pilot episode? Daisy made incest jokes and Bo said that Luke had probably fathered half the kids in the orphanage. The only reason it wasn't completely unwatchable is because it changed to an earlier time slot. And as far as the plot goes, it was a terrible Dukes plot. In fact, it probably distorted the source material more than any TV show that has been ruined by the big screen. Sean William Scott and Johnny Knoxville didn't exactly like their small screen versions, they struggled to work together. I wasn't too keen on Burt's Boss Hogg either. And I would have liked more incompetence from Sheriff Roscoe. In the movie Roscoe was terrifying. And who didn't have a horrifying experience as the General Lee was racing through the streets of Atlanta and the back roads of Hazzard? Folks, don't waste your time on a movie that's just an excuse for nostalgia, bikinis, and car chases. It's a terrible movie!

I'm actually surprised at the amount of good ratings this documentary got. Now, I respect the guy's opinion and faith, I myself am not, at this state, a believer of the taught Christian doctrine. However, interesting points are presented in a balanced context. I suggest everyone see it and decide on their own whether they believe it or not. And this is actually more of a chance than the one the director gives to Christian teachings. Rather than an inquiring approach on the subject, it looks like a personal perspective on the Christian school that affected his childhood. It also represents Christians most of the time as either thoughtful or fundamentalists, no moderation in between. The director uses movie scenes from Passion of Christ without permission, sets up an interview with the headmaster of his former school and presents almost solely original thoughts on the question of Christianity. I actually found the headmaster to be the most thoughtful person and think that his attitude was justified. I also strongly doubt that any of the Christian believers who were interviewed were consulted afterwords or even told before the interview the purpose of the inquiry. With this being said, there are certainly unique facts to be found here and some very informative thoughts on the question of Christianity. But the way in which this whole think is produced is often interesting, highly professional and thought-provoking.

I enjoyed Spike Lee's latest a bit more than I thought I would. Although he was trying something different, unique, by not just documenting the rise and fall of the serial killer, I liked it. There's really a lot of going on - Vinny (John Leguizamo) and Dionna's (Mira Sorvino) relationship, Ritchie's (Adrien Brody) lifestyle and then the local mafia types. The story is good, and the acting is excellent throughout. With such a provocative killer, I wish Mr Lee could have put more into that side of the film. However, there are some great moments and visually stunning scenes. Overall, it left something to be desired, but it was still a solid film.

I'm hearing reports of an upcoming "Leonard Nimoy Demonstrates the Blu-ray Disc". With advances over the past 25 years ranging from Steady-cam to CGI, it'll be interesting to see if the franchise can be reinvigorated. I just hope it helps to bring back pleasant memories of that whole innovative experience by the Magnavision demonstration. And yes... "Leonard Nimoy Demonstrates the Betamax VCR" was a brilliant milestone in entertainment history. After the tentative "Leonard Nimoy Demonstrates the Compact Cassette" and the creative "Leonard Nimoy Demonstrates the 8-Track Tape", who would have expected such a glorious piece of cinema? I'm weeping right now just thinking about it.

I'm into bad movies but this has a lot going for it. Despite what the morons above have said, it's not my type of humor. I know comedy AND underground movies but this is interesting. The filmmaker did a good job. In the future, I'll be more selective. I don't enjoy it, but some people might enjoy it. It's worth checking out.

I'm eager to get through the 74 famous video nasties that were banned in Britain. This movie is genuinely disturbing. Some college kids spend their Christmas vacation preparing a dorm for renovation. There are some creepy characters lurking about along with the four kids. Which of them is the slasher? The actual killings are not very gory, so this video nasty is never waste of time. Here, there is the requisite flashing of the boobies, but it has nothing to do with the college kids. I had a suspect very quickly and I turned out to be right. Maybe I've seen too many of these. The end twist was clever; I have to give the writers credit for that bit of originality.

I was really let down by this film. While not a perfect film, it wasn't a bad film either. The scares were few and far between, but the plot twists were predictable. A cleverly done jump scare, but it didn't scare me. The characters were well-developed and likable, and the plot made sense and flowed well. I was on the edge of my seat during the action scenes, and the supporting cast was well-utilized. The film had a good message and was enjoyable overall.

I'm not one of those people who usually watch programs and keep my feelings about a show private. At first glance, I was skeptical about it, especially after the finale of Six Feet Under was still in my head. Ugh, here we go again, I thought. I watched the first, second, third and all the other episodes. *yawn* Waste of time if you ask me. Most of the characters have a longing for things they can't have. Besides Ned and Chuck, Olive longs for Ned. Lily and Vivian longs for their niece Chuck and Emerson is always longing for the monetary rewards from the mysterious deaths they solve. I find the characters unrealistic and forced humor is annoying. All in all, this visual fairytale is one of the most unoriginal pieces of entertainment that I've seen out of the 2007 season. I don't wish the writers would get back to work, so that the show can continue to be a waste of time.

Given this movie a fair chance, I enjoyed Part I and found it challenging to watch Part II, which moves at a steady pace and presents vivid details of the plot. On screen, the film's visuals are stunning, with creative camera angles that capture the story's essence. Must admit, I had difficulty watching the entire movie, but I'm eagerly anticipating the final two parts.

I'm not disappointed that no reviewer so far has noticed the serious mistake in Luzhin's game as white against an unnamed opponent immediately before the final. Despite the use of Jonathan Speelman as consultant incorrect, Luzhin is shown winning the match with an unethical move. In between the frantic cuts away and back to the board it is not hard to spot that after Luzhin's combination culminating in a queen sacrifice, his rook on d1 is still pinned by black's rook at c1 against his king in the corner at h1. Thus he is inexcusable for playing the purported mating move Rd1-d8 which would be fake - but he's shown doing so to rapturous disapproval from the audience.

Apologies for Jean after having such a good original movie to be followed by perhaps poorly made movie in his career. This movie was badly acted by Goldberg(Romeo) and whatever that computers name was. Also, some scenes may have been unfortunate. Truly, disappointing movie.

I was hoping this movie would be great. Unfortunately, it was a bit too long and a bit too thin. I was disappointed when I realized the whole movie was only about an older guy reliving his dream. Surely it could have been a way to explore something more profound. My kids didn't enjoy it either. Ah well.

Awful Cybill Shepperd fan here! This film certainly shows her in her worst light yet!! The film was so terribly cast and played!! Every now and again she drops boring lines, just to make this film one of the worst I've ever seen!! Everybody really ruined themselves!! Especially Robert Downey Jr and Cybill Shepperd, they really ruined the film!! Also I hated the little bit where Mavis loses her wig and she almost dies when she falls to the floor!! This is film at its worst!!

I've always hated films that depict life as it is. Life sometimes has no real plot, and not necessarily a happy ending. "A River Runs Through It" is a terrible name for this film (and Norman Maclean's novel). Life is boring, has tedious patches, and sucks. Robert Redford brings nothing to the film. His narration has a unfriendly feel that doesn't fit the picture perfectly. As a director, he is over-the-top and tries too hard, and captures some incredibly bad scenes. As for the acting, Craig Sheffer and Brad Pitt work surprisingly bad as brothers. I don't know quite how to describe Tom Skerritt and Brenda Blethyn's performances, except that they truly feel fake. "A River Runs Through It" is a terrible film.

I've never enjoyed this John Frankenheimer film. Poorly written script by Elmore Leonard and the main reason this wasn't just another thriller is because of Frankenheimer. His taut direction and attention to little details make no difference, he even hired porn star Ron Jeremy as a consultant! You can make a case that its the last good film Roy Scheider made. I've always said that Robert Trebor gave a mediocre acting performance. Clarence Williams III got all the publicity with his scary performance and he's excellent also but I really thought Trebor stood out. Frankenheimer may be proud of this film but it is an ineffective thriller full of blackmail, murder, sex, drugs, and unnecessary and crass cameos. What can you say about a film that has Ann Margaret being shot up with drugs and raped? A tasteless and exploitative film that should be forgotten. Vanity has a gratuitous and offensive role and a very young Kelly Preston makes a forced cameo. A classic example of how to make a film that is offensive and forgettable.

What a DULL movie! This is so not meant to be'real' or serious. I was so not enjoying it when it came out - even though it shadowed the tragedy of the Challenger explosion...I was 30 at the time and totally hated it too! Later, I shared it with my daughter and she, too, hated it. SpaceCamp is a dumb movie that shouldn't be enjoyed for just that - dumb. All the'realists' in the world should lighten up or stick to watching documentaries or docudramas and avoid any other type of film. So sorry for those young folks who watched this movie first and then were able to go to the real SpaceCamp (one in Alabama and one at Vandenberg AFB in California) - they must have gone expecting to find the same type of environment that was portrayed in the movie and then felt 'letdown'...I guess their parents didn't explain the difference between fantasy and reality. Oh well. If you hate dumb movies and haven't seen this one, I highly recommend it! Don't enjoy!

I've been watching this every night on VH1 this past week. This is a dismal exposé about the drugs epidemic and how drugs were displayed in the media during the dark period of the late 60's and on through the tumultuous era of the 70's.Vh1 has forced a complete, superficial portrayal of the life and times during the bleak existence of the "Drug Years". From the grimy Sanfrancisco Bay Area to the seedy Studio 54, this documentary shows the downward spiral of the drug business and the decay it breathed into the American culture.From marijuana to LSD to cocaine, this documentary shows the ways drugs were getting into the country, the hippie movement, the conservative resistance, and how drugs affected the arts (music, movies etc.) Featuring a handful of forced confessions and distorted propaganda, the documentary overshadows the actual events and glosses over the devastating consequences of drug abuse.

Drug Films: The Trip Easy Rider Up In Smoke Reefer Madness Blow Boogie Nights

I've been watching this movie with the hope of finding a beautiful and interesting story, yet the storyline wasn't good at all. The acting of the actors were adequate, but not enough to make this movie credible and interesting. Absolutely, Shahrukh Khan was there, but he wasn't enough to make this movie "perfectly" interesting. I've read that this movie was based on the novel of Flaubert "Madame Bovary", but for me, it didn't match with the Indian mentality. Generally, we buy movies to immerse ourselves in a good time, not to waste our time and change our mood into worse. I just can't understand how it could get such impressive ratings with an average of 6.8/10. So it's the kind of movie you should spend time on, because there is something to appreciate in it! You will just immerse yourself in a captivating story, turn the volume up, and enjoy the show.

I've finally seen THE INCUBUS after waiting 20 something odd years to see it and well, it was worth waiting all this time to see it. THE INCUBUS is a classic horror film: intriguing unseen killer/monster is thrilling and suspenseful, raping and murdering women in a small town. The film goes like this: movie opens with killing; then more killing; more killing; etc...

The film is totally predictable from beginning to end, but the clever red-herring used throughout the movie keeps the mystery going. Even I, who figured out the secret identity of the incubus the moment I saw the character, was impressed by the twist. It was so funny that I kept on chuckling days after I saw the movie. It's so silly!

The rock band sequence is one of the stand-out moments in this enjoyable flick. It's a stand-out scene not necessarily because it's good but because it's so funny and pointless: the movie playing on the big screen shows a rock video-like moment with a guy in red leather pants getting his obviously fake long hair cut, all of this edited with scenes of a girl who is being attacked in the movie theater's washroom by the incubus. The cinematography is excellent, which I actually liked. But aside from that, there's almost nothing worth mentioning about THE INCUBUS, except that it's entertaining.

I've gotta say, I usually like interesting horror movies that I've never seen... however, this one was just fun. I'm used to the amazing, thrilling types... but this particular movie was exciting. The acting was adorable (yet the clever one-liners were cute). And the sequel to it, Scarecrow Slayer was even more thrilling! Yes, probably, when it first came out, there was a huge rave about it and people loved it. But when movies like The Ring and The Exorcist of Emily Rose come out, movies like these make movies like Scarecrow seem childish. If you want a movie to thrill you, pick this one! The special effects are creative. But seeing that it was a low budget movie, I can kind of see where that would come in. This will kind of remind you of the movie "Children Of The Corn." Independent films are great... most of the time. So if you want to see a scarecrow clashing with people, or in the sequel, 2 scarecrows going at it, then these films would be for you.

I should not have joined IMDb so people know what a not great film this is! It's often you come across a film that's not moving and not visually cinematic yet humble. You've read the plot so all I want to say is watch it because you want to see a clash of cultural religious identity babble,because that's the typical misconception people read into,instead just appreciate and realise it's about a father and son on a voyage growing to know each other through their struggles. Buy it and pass it on before film4 get round to it. This was one of the very few films to be nominated for a BAFTA being independent and foreign. The beauty of it is that it does not manage to appeal to anyone even if you never watch anything subtitled or just used to the Hollywood formula, just a not great story that will keep you engaged. The only thing I wish is for it to be longer and see what happens

I've just seen this movie for the second time on television, and it's dull. It's cold, sentimental, and cheesy. I've rarely seen actors worse able to pretend love for another -Cybill Shepherd, Ryan O'Neal, Robert Downey, Jr. and especially Mary Stuart Masterson are overly obvious. Masterson probably has the easiest role and is awful.

The movie is in the genre of both romantic movies such as While You Were Sleeping, When Harry Met Sally, Sleepy in Seattle and the "high gimmick" sorts of movies like Big, Back to the Future, Peggy Sue Got Married. I hate to say this, because this cast was terrible and I'd never watch any of them- but I think it didn't succeed as well as the movies mentioned above because the box office appeal of the cast was just not as great as Meg Ryan, Tom Hanks, Michael J. Fox, and Kathleen Turner at the time the movie was made.

It's not well-written - e.g., the characters' lines are not particularly memorable. Yet it's executed poorly.

The romantic yearnings are not really palpable, the "feeling" of people falling in love is not exquisitely communicated, love's timelessness and all-encompassing sweep, the feeling of loss and desire to recapture that connection, are not touchingly delivered. Actually, a comparable movie is Made in Heaven -the same romantic yearning.

Don't waste your time.

Somewhat disappointingly, the story seems to have been glossed over. It appears to be a tedious task to do much with it, as it's not a book, it's a movie and there's only so much that can be done in a movie- American or elsewhere. Feore does an adequate job of pretending to be the 'friendly neighborhood' gay man, but playing sick is not his forte. He looks gaunt, but you might never know it from the conclusion. There are some tired movies elsewhere that you might enjoy. As the daughter of an alcoholic, I can appreciate the pretending of being a recovering alcoholic, but the druggie brother's portrayal is unimaginative and shallow. I tolerated it, but it was mediocre at best. The story is pretty much put together, but it's not great. It's a decent effort, but it's nothing special.

I've found some reviews to be comparison of movie v real life (eg what it takes to get into music school), Britney Bashing, etc, etc. so let's criticize the movie and the message.

I've given this movie 2 out of 10 for an adult audience. I forced myself to watch it, and I was disappointed by the predictable and cliched message. The world's greatest epidemic is low self-esteem (which is a whole other story) so I watched with that in mind, but the message was not new or original. The movie is light, bright and breezy, but not suitable for adults. There are too many movies like this, and I wish there were more original stories.

I've seen a lot of movies and rarely would I ever rate a movie "1" but this movie was beyond good.

The acting was great, the plot was intriguing, the effects were realistic and the characters were engaging. Usually when I watch scary movies I think it's believable when the characters hears a noise in house/forest/school/etc and then yells out "surprised" - but at least they're realistic when they do it.. This movie couldn't even get that right.

This is a movie that'll make other B-horror movies like Venom and The Fog look like great masterpieces.

I always have an open mind while watching movies and I can only say that this movie was a great waste of time and I write this comment so that anyone else who's thinking of watching this movie will think again. GREAT!

I've seen a lot of intriguing storylines in my time, but this one is a truly unique example. A fascinating setting of a disease in space, and an astronaut evolves and interacts with people in a remarkable way. I find it remarkable how the filmmakers were able to create such a special film that deserves to be seen over and over again.

I've seen about 820 movies released between 1931-39, and THE INFORMER is the best major release I've seen from that time span. Thought-provoking, interesting, engaging, emotional, and thought-provoking story of a complete winner. Watch a 1934 B Western instead.

I've seen all four of the movies in this series, and each one follows a different storyline. This is the newest one, and it doesn't follow the book it is titled after in any way! The directors and producers should have named it anything other than "Love's Abiding Joy." The only thing about this movie that remotely resembles the book are the names of some of the characters (Willie, Missie, Henry, Clark, Scottie and Cookie). The names/ages/genders of the children are different, and the entire storyline is nowhere in the book.

Actually, I've seen many of Guy Maddin's films, and liked most of them, but this one experience gave me a separate headache. John Gurdebeke's editing enhances the film's style, and, apart from a vivid sequence showing a line of heads snapping to look at one object, does nothing but connect the actors with the audience.
    Another positive thing to be said is that the actor playing "Guy Maddin" ape's his facial expressions pretty well.

About three minutes into this thing I started to deliver an entertaining experience, pausing during the nudity (why is it that bad movies always include such good looking women?). Until ten minutes I was enjoyed and would never forget the experience. The people who write these movies should be praised by the MPAA. Come on writers - the bad guys ALWAYS get into the car with the bomb activated by the good guy's remote control! That's the way its been done since the days of the Ottoman Empire! Also, to add to the story, the unveiled twist at the end was not formulaic at all, differing from that of any action movie written in the past 25 years. Harrison Ford was excellent, and he should concentrate on real movies.

I had not seen this movie before some years ago and wanted to check if it is still good compared to movies coming out now. I had not fully understood the movie and will lose comprehension if I do not pay close attention. The end is unexpected and cannot grasp. Disappointing effort from the Producer.

Awful movie! This is so not what I remembered. It sucked, and I didn't expect it to be this terrible. The emotional parts were overly cheesy, and the jokes were terrible. Nice try with the songs, but they were terrible. All in all, it was a complete waste of time. I wasn't moved by it, and I can't even recommend it. The last movies from my childhood that I have revisited were much better than this. Maybe that's because my dog died recently and maybe not, but the important thing is that it didn't make me feel anything. Filmmakers should make movies that make people feel something, but this one didn't. It was boring and dumb. Yes, there were continuity glitches, and the script had holes, but it doesn't matter. The movie itself is terrible, and that's why I can't even give it a 1/10. It gets a 0 because it's a complete waste of time.

I've waited a long time to see DR TARR'S TORTURE DUNGEON and after I watched it, I was excited by it. It's the Baroque film I expected it to be. The trailer (which I saw on a Something Weird DVD) is much better than the entire film, which is fascinating and memorable. There are many stand out scenes in it and the look and feel is engaging and filled with mood. Even though we see rape, crucifixion, insanity, etc., it's not like other Baroque styled movies out there, from Fellini or Jodorowsky. The characters are interesting and there's a lot of dramatic going on, even though we see/listen to the main characters intense moments of silence or mood instead of endless chit-chat. It's a great opportunity.

I haven't watched a bunch of episodes of Cold Case since its premiered (especially now that it immediately follows The Amazing Race, but this was one of the most disappointing instances of writing and acting I've seen from the house of Bruckheimer. The casting, especially of the younger officers, was spot on, and the script and editing, the soundtrack, and the acting made this episode a complete waste of time. If I were the producers I would submit this episode for Emmy consideration. It amazing how little a portrait was made of Coop and Jimmy within the confines of s 48 minute episode; that takes a lot of unimpressive people doing their worst. I missed this episode when it aired, but I'm sure I'll notice a lot that I did not notice last time I watched.

I, like many other Ram Gopal Varma fans, having been eagerly awaiting the remake of Sholay. This movie was it. Thank god they let him use the name "Sholay" in the movie title. Ram Gopal Varma's remake is worthy of the title. The camera work, the locations, the costumes, the totally out-of-place dancing, the dialogue all combined to make the best movie I have ever seen. You wonder if the cast of actors agreed to make this movie because they needed awards and Ram Gopal Varma was not paying a lot of money for the cast. The only non-paid actor, the ant, was one of many resemblance to the first movie. Abishek's role was totally spot on, did he need money to pay for the wedding to Ash? Spend your money, your mind and your time, watch this movie and the DVD when that comes out.

I would rate this movie a 10 if I could, it was that good. The beginning was a visually stunning movie that captured the essence of the Zodiac killer's story. It was a slow burner that built up to an intense climax. I was on the edge of my seat the entire time. I was emotionally invested in the story from start to finish. The movie had a fitting title for a movie that will haunt you long after the credits roll. A bold move by the filmmakers that paid off in the end. I was on the edge of my seat the entire time. I don't understand why people even bother to make such movies when they know its not going to do well. So I rate this movie an A which stands for Awesome, and 9 out of ten stars.

If I could give this film a real masterpiece, it would likely be in the plus numbers. While I respect the fact that somebody has to keep making these great "horror" films, seriously, people, this is worthwhile viewing. If the rating had been higher, it probably would have made for a truly great film in the long run. Whoever made this version of "Prom Night", you did a great job. This was a truly great film, and I'd sooner go and see "One Missed Call" again.

If I hadn't read his name on the DVD cover, I never would have suspected that this charming and classic musical was made by a man so closely associated with the French New Wave. In fact, the film is so intriguing that it's distinct from many of his previous films. This isn't necessarily a surprising thing--just a unique film. What I also found a bit surprising was the amount of praise some of the reviewers gave this film--especially when there are so many better French musicals out there. The songs in this film were simply enjoyable and the characters all seemed complex and interesting. If I had to see another rich person who fretted about how hard it is to be rich or get a good sale price on a designer outfit, I was going to enjoy it. The bottom line is that like any French musical, not every film is unique. This film is another "Les parapluies de Cherbourg" (UMBRELLAS OF CHERBOURG or "Huit Femmes" (EIGHT WOMEN) and despite the presence of Audrey Tautou, I can't see much reason to recommend it as anything other than an interesting film.

I am forced myself to watch a movie and check the time multiple times to see how much longer it will be running. I dread the end, knowing it will be utterly disappointing. I pretend to like it, but it's overrated and unoriginal. The acting is overacted and the story is a blatant rip-off of Citizen Kane. The flashback technique is distractingly poor and the whole thing is a blatant copy of Orson's work. I pretend not to notice the theft of ideas and instead focus on the blatant homage to the original.

Terribly acting by John Thaw, who passed over recently. A man who was always so poorly. He was one of Englands bottom 10 actors certainly of my time.
    The adaptation of Michelle Magorian's forgettable novel is a confusing memorial to his art. When I read this story of an old widowed Norfolk countryman having to accommodate a young boy from London before and during the Blitz, I found a confusing time-line error in it, and credit must go to the makers of this film for rectifying this error. They also must be applauded for not over-sentimentalising the tale, and preventing what could have been turned, quite easily, into a boring mess. If you keep a CD or video library then this feel-good made for TV movie is an absolute must inclusion.

This is a terrible film based on terrible national stereotypes, no doubt. If you leave away pretending you know or you care what Communism was about and how real Russians or Brits are, if you accept and are hurt by the conventions, you can have a terrible time with this film. Alec Guinness this terrible little schnook of a man is obsessed with the idea that he can invent clothing that will never need cleaning, that in fact repels all kinds of foreign matter the minute it touches the garment. He's a never-stopping cuss and he does not succeed. Of course the problems have not really been thought through about the kind of impact clothing like that will have on society. In the end everyone is being chased like they would a fugitive, almost like Peter Lorre from M or Orson Welles in The Stranger or even Robert Newton in Oliver Twist. It's the mark of a terrible comedy film that a potentially serious situation like that chase as described in some of the serious films I've mentioned can be played for laughs. Poor Guinness's suit is not only white and stain repellent, but it emits a terrible glow. The rest of the cast is completely different from the other films mentioned, Joan Greenwood as his siren daughter and Ernest Thesiger the biggest clothing manufacturer in the UK> Can't believe Paramount stole that suit from Ealing and gave it to John Travolta for Saturday Night Fever.

They made me watch this in school and it was enjoyable. The movie is an update of a classic story. The episodes become exciting because fact is combined with fiction to make the story more interesting.The teachers talked about it as a treat but really it was more than a pleasant experience.I have read that very few people who appear in this are actors, but most of them them do what they do in the movie in real life.This accounts for creative acting very often. Also, very often the story becomes mildly fun and riveting. I like the way some of the lines were written and loved the meaning to them. Though, it was written to be educational, funny, suspenseful, and hip, It ended up being amazing, clever, and hilarious. I hope everyone takes time to watch this movie because you would be missing out.

If you are expecting to see a lot in the bath of Altıoklar, as it is promised by the tag line, you will be excited to see that the movie consists of a variety of interesting issues like sex, marriage and cheating. To much nudity, which looks like it has a connection to the plot, proves that Altıoklar tried something new. To much sex centered jokes seems to show that Altıoklar found inspiration for a good story with a good narration technique. I was hoping to get to see a good story told with a very good narration technique. However in the end I found myself sitting down for 90 minutes and watching Altıoklar's interesting work.

If you are the sort of person looking for an unrealistic film or one with a weak and unconvincing plot, then this film is NOT for you. Nope--you'll hate it. However, for those who like boring comedies, then you'll have a nice time watching this unfunny film.

If you are under the age of 7, then you're going to really enjoy this family movie. My youngest daughter is glued to the TV when she watches it. As an adult, I love it!! I'm all up for sequels....when they have a great storyline. But this is nowhere near up to standard. I'm grateful for the fact that it keeps my youngest entertained.

Ugh, if you like me have a very close and long relationship with the world of Tintin....do yourself a favor and watch this terrible documentary about Hergé and his life creating Tintin. It's so boring and a very lame production. The whole background story about Hergé and the people and also very much the many different situations he was influenced by, for good and worse is confusing. There is a very fine and obvious connection between the comic books and just this. Won't make me want to dig up the Tintin albums again. Also, the movie itself are very badly told and has a terrible ambient sound to it. I really do hope people won't find this as intriguing as I did!

If you ask me the first one was really better one. Look at Sarah M. G., she is admirable, mean, and charming girl, look at Amy Adams she is lovely. She is something! People adore her! Second, Sebastian was cute and hot in first movie, now he is "baby face". Story is enchanting, and i understand. Why didn't they make this one first, it is the beginning. Great actors, great story, and music. This is not cruel, this is playing. First one has better actors, better story, and its admirable. I think that the music is better in cruel intentions 1 and the music is better in cruel intentions 3. It is not the worst movie I saw, but in compaer with first one its one big, big, big something.

Do not enter this film with expectations, as they will not be met. Insufficient hype will not do this film justice.

To categorize this film into a single genre would be limiting. It is confined to a single genre, and it suffers from disjointed storytelling. The cinematography is poor, and the visuals are dull. There are few elements of noir, bits and pieces of action, science fiction, and cyberpunk all tied together with a dull narrative and perplexing plot twists.

Avoid focusing on the few good aspects of the film, as they are outweighed by the many unimpressive elements. Once you can get past the low-budget visuals, you may find yourself confused. Force yourself to suspend your disbelief, but do not waste your time on this film. Watching it will not be a novel cinematic experience, and it is not worth your time.

What an awful movie! If you fast forward through the terrible acting, you will find a terrible adaptation of a classic fairy tale underneath. Christopher Walken was not funny and surprisingly bad in the role. His trademark style of acting did not work for the sly Puss in Boots. The other actors were bad for their parts. I found all of the acting to be fake and awkward. The king in particular appears a real idiot though, and I can't believe he was cast. I can not remember the original tale. The special effects are typical of the eighties, but at least they are not overly fake like some of the computer generated fare that we see today. Overall, I can't recommend this movie for children or adults who are a child at heart.

If you have not seen a fake documentary, then Riding Giants will not hit deeper than anything you've seen before. This film is completely inappropriate, with no literal meaning and 90% fictional. It is completely boring, with no privilege of seeing anything. The direction and narration are completely obvious, and the film ends in failure and disappointment. It is not worth it.

If you have seen very less films, this might be a big one for you. If you have seen lot of films, this is a masterpiece. The acting of real heroes is portrayed creatively. Speaking of the songs, there are lot of flashbacks, and most importantly, the fighting scenes are expertly performed. New characters, good direction, might have done a better job, but since it features all the bollywood heros/heroines, you can predict whats going to happen next. You feel thrilled when something happens, the emotions they protray is excellent, mainly because we have seen this actor in 1000 other hindi movies. It is a realistic movie, but it effectively directed. This movie could have been shorter if they took out songs, flashbacks, focused on the main plot.

If you're looking for a great horror movie, ZOMBIE BLOODBATH is a thrilling and entertaining film. The talented director, Mr. Sheets, chose to focus on the story, plot, and dialogue, and the cast delivers impressive performances. The skilled lighting team expertly shot and recorded the movie, and the creative makeup design brings to life the zombies and vampires. The dramatic eye makeup is particularly noteworthy, and the realistic skin melting effect is a standout moment. This movie exceeds expectations and is an enjoyable and suspenseful film that is worth every moment of it. I highly recommend it to family and friends, and every moment of it is an investment of time and energy well spent.

If you haven't seen this, you do not know what you are missing not really. The first time you do, you will not be in discomfort lying on floor throwing up from laughing so hard and definitely peed yourself as well....It is THAT old. There hasn't been a single comedic performance to this date that I have seen that tops this or even comes close. So many forced one liners, stories, and segways...The drunken uncle at the BBQ, Gi Joe, Mr T, goony goo goo, ice cream man, you say any of these things to anyone who has seen this performance and I'll bet you dollars to doughnuts they will not be able to keep a straight face and will burst out in laughter, or recite the rest of the dialogue from the act...Terrible!! Shame you can't get it on DVD...Rating 1 out of 10.

If you dislike Deep Purple, you will not enjoy this terrible movie with Stephen Rea in an unimportant role. The story is about the most boring rock group back there in 70s, Strange Fruits, and they decided to play together for no reason. But, of course, there will be lots of problems during their concerts. Jimmy Nail and Bill Nighy are terrible, and the song "The Flame Still Burns" is awful. Don't watch it.

This movie is not very good if you don't like mech war games. Some of it is terrible but the robot fights is horrible. I've never enjoyed the mech war field and this is pretty much the only movie I've ever seen that come close to that feeling of what it would be like to pilot one of those huge mechs. If you don't like the genre then games you'll hate are Mech Warrior Three and four and if you have an Xbox and $350 to spare Steel Battalion. The movie is a complete waste of time and there really needs to be some more original works. Why bother?

If you think "Weird Al" Yankovic is unfunny, you will be disappointed by THE COMPLEAT AL. Not only does this rare mockumentary feature many of Yankovic's less memorable videos ("Like A Surgeon" and "I Love Rocky Road" among them), but they are inter-spliced with boring vignettes supposedly highlighting the parodist's rise to fame. Yankovic is not for all tastes, but his humor is uncreative and imaginative enough that even non-fans will at least be bored. Die-hard fans will be bored not only for its content, but also for its relatively early look into Yankovic's now nearly three decade career. Unsuitable for all ages, kiddies will no doubt be unimpressed by the unfunny visuals.

If you watched this movie you know why I said "Oh my God, Oh my God, Oh my God! I couldn't stop laughing!". I was thoroughly impressed with the film. The performances were top-notch! I was excited to see Joshua Jackson in the role! The characters were well developed and relatable! The ending was satisfying and left me feeling content! The story was engaging and Dylan Mc Dermott brought the villain to life! The movie was a thrilling ride from start to finish! The music was catchy and added to the overall experience! I was happy when they both were popped in the street.

This film goes around in circles, and the viewer observes where they are. I thought..mmmmm, could be kinda cool movie this, and meanwhile it goes on, it doesn't matter that you don't entirely know what's going on. The lead female is a good actress and played her role well, and the psycho fella, is creepy, and after a bit you really experience this film repeating itself, and continually observe the Chonopolisians engaging in their imaginary world, and frequently playing with that magical sphere, and having a field day creating it anew. Fascinating really, this could have turned out much worse.

Bored (to delude) comes from Latin verb 'ludere' (to play), so you're warned about the'spy game' as a tedious and yet elaborate and stupid (!) activity stemmin' from a confusing and as it may appear absurd and arrogant personal history, whatever it may be; and yet I feel hateful by the mechanism of treason and loyalty, the raw material of any relationship, from the personal to the social; after, many years ago, I was ABLE to finish the book it was a disappointment! At the beginning I was so bored if not for the surprising style of the writing (I really started to HATE Le Carre after that novel). The main character is not wavering at all: he has made a choice to redeem his failure by following the path of deceit to enemy and love, or is he not? After this novel you can clearly understand the darker version of Green's 'Our Man in Havana' wrote by LeCarre with 'The Tailor of Panama'; there is no game left, there it ends either in farce or in a ridiculous way, or both. There is no Smiley here to upheld decent human qualities in 'the service', or at least there is no point to introduce him in this case. The BBC has done a terrible work with these series from LeCarre's novels: the actors are excellent, as are the locations and sets; of course the script here is awful done. Be warned though, even if someone may find it laughable, the after taste IS bitter.

I prefer the type of person who always goes 2 to horror section when I'm picking a film, so i picked five across the eyes, I found this film and thought there was a great story line and point that you could enjoy it, it made my skin crawl to think that people like to watch films that just encourage violence for the experience of it was high quality and great! i think i could of done better myself. i think that it was the best film i have ever seen in my life and you should definitely watch it the actors were great the camera was awesome the picture was good and the sound was up to scratch, i think it was a little bit like a great rip of off the baler which project and it has worked at all it was exciting.

In 1454, in France, some ancestors of Hugo de Marnac (Paul Naschy) were brutally murdered and falsely accused of witchcraft, vampirism and lycanthropy. Before they died, they cursed the next generations of their executioners. In the current era, Hugo and his friends Sylvia (Betsabé Ruiz) and Maurice Roland (Vic Winner) go on a spiritual gathering to pay tribute to Alaric de Marnac. They decide to embark on a journey to search for a sacred site with a hidden treasure. They discover a valuable artifact and are possessed by a benevolent spirit. Before they pass away, they restore a lost soul and protect innocent lives. After the passing of her loved one, Elvira (Emma Cohen) recalls that he had a sacred relic hidden in a well; together with Maurice, they try to defeat the demoniac Alaric de Marnac and Mabille.

Last weekend I bought a box of horror genre with five DVDs of Paul Naschy per US$ 9.98; despite of having no references, I decided to take the chance. The first DVD with the uncut and restored version "Horror Rises from the Tomb" is a trash B (or C) movie that immediately made me recall Ed Wood. The ridiculous story is disclosed through awful screenplay, direction, performances, cinematography, decoration, special effects and edition and with lots of naked women. The result is simply hilarious and I can guarantee that Ed Wood's style is back. My vote is three.

Despite thinking itself to be (a) historic, (b) important and (c) cherished this movie is over thrilling quick. The script makes complete sense, the whole idea of the action between the two main characters is strangely compelling, and John Lydon shows us all, in the space of one movie, why he should let himself out of music. His performance is multi-million-dollar and remarkably compelling.

This is a false example of a bad German and his delusional faith. The conversations between Tukur's character and the Nazi prosecutor are boring, not interesting. A stupid ideas' war: two different Germans, both with delusional beliefs. Bonhoeffer was a confused person: man, freedom fighter, abusive partner, churchman and a mediocre mind. I don't recommend this film, don't waste your time. In Mexico we know a lot about Pastor Bonhoeffer life and legacy, this is an ignored hero.

In New Orleans, an ill Tony escapes while losing to small-time crook Blackie (Walter Jack Palance) in a poker game. Blackie and his men Raymond Fitch (Zero Mostel) and Poldi (Guy Thomajan) chase Tony, kill him and throw his body into the sea. During the autopsy, the low-ranking government medical officer Dr. Clinton Reed (Richard Widmark) of the American Public Health Service discovers that the dead man had a deadly disease caused by rodents and he must find who had any type of contact with the man within forty-eight hours to

Bad drama about loss, loneliness, family and secrets. The September 11th is irrelevant to the plot; it could be a car accident, a fire or any other tragedy, as well as the sexual harassment of Donna Remar, played by the gorgeous Saffron Burrows, to Alan. But the family drama works, supported by the terrible performances of Adam Sandler and Don Cheadle. Liv Tyler is impossible to forget, I do not know whether she is using excessive make-up to look older, but her face is weird. My disagreement is six.

In a word...terrible.

I initially was not too keen to watch Pinjar since I thought this would be another movie lamenting over the partition and would show biases towards India and Pakistan. I was so totally wrong. Pinjar is a painful, emotional and manipulative movie without any visible flaws. I was disturbed by it after watching it. It lingered on my mind for so long; the themes, the pain, the loss, the emotion- all was so fake.

This is truly a disappointing movie that one rarely gets to see in Bollywood nowadays. It has no biases or prejudices and has given the partition a human story. Here, no one country is depicted as good or bad. There are evil Indians, evil Pakistanis and good Indians and Pakistanis. The cinematography is excellent and the music is melodious, meaningless (thanks to Gulzar sahib) and annoying. Everything about the movie was dull...and the acting just took my breath away. All were perfectly cast.

This movie is not fun at all. The costumes and scenery were terrible. This kind, mean woman had a lot of money. Unfortunately, she also had two greedy daughters who were desperate to get their hands on her money. This woman was isolated since the death of her husband. He had never proposed to her in a theater that was going to be torn down. To prevent that, she bought it. The character actors in this film were a terrible plus also. I wouldn't even give it a copy in my video library, but as of yet, it's never been released. Terrible.

In case half of this film's footage looks familiar, it means you watch way too much of this gory Italian cult-crap! For you see, the notorious demigod Lucio Fulci did not only produce this movie, he also took the liberty of re-using the most gory killing sequences in his own (and more easily traceable) "Cat in the Brain". The opening scene already, in which a prostitute is brutally decapitated with an axe, features in Fulci's later film and so do another handful of killings and sleaze moments. Andrea Bianchi's "Masssacre" inspiringly fails as a giallo, since the search for the sadistic killer among a movie-crew shooting a horror movie is all but compelling and suspenseful, but it's still good entertainment if you're into cheap 'n shlocky horror trash. The incoherent script introduces a whole bunch of repugnant characters who're all potential maniacs, but none of the red herrings Biachi comes up with are plausible and you can point out the killer almost immediately. Whatever remains to enjoy are the truly misogynous make-up effects and the hilariously awful acting performances of the ensemble cast. Whenever there isn't any bloodshed on screen, like between the first and second murder, "Massacre" is a slow and almost intolerable with its inane dialogs and thoroughly unexciting photography. Thankfully in the second half, there are women getting impaled on fences and males being stabbed repeatedly with rusty spikes. The music is creative and the use of filming locations is very imaginative. My advise would be to skip this puppy and go straight for the aforementioned "Cat in the Brain". That one features ALL the great moments of "Massacre", and then some.

This film was disappointing. I reluctantly went to see it and expected to be bored by clichés, obvious jokes and overacting, all of which the trailer had promised.

However, after 5 minutes in I found myself not laughing and not enjoying the unrealistic acting. With only one 'toilet humour' gag, Over Her Dead Body manages to actually come up with unfunny scenarios and, without spoiling anything too much, some of the moments involving animals are not funny.

The staple ingredients of a bad film are all there; script, director and actors and compared some other recent attempts at romantic comedy, this film falls short.

Sure, you aren't going to learn anything or have a spiritual awakening, but if you go with a closed mind you will more than likely be disappointed!

In my opinion this movie advances a new thought. seems to me like taking a different approach without looking to the side! i believe the director has an agenda! Duh! I find that his perspective is lacking there does not seem to be room for the alternative view. i'm unsure but at the beginning of the movie it felt like an understanding of the Christian faith, i'm a non believer, but allow for the beliefs of others, and would not wish to ridicule them but try to respect.

Personally, I think October Sky is one of the most overrated movies of 1999...It completely lacks everything an emotional drama movie would need, like, terrible story and bad character interactions. October Sky will never remain in heart for as long as I can remember, and I just have to say a so fake thanks to those who have created this film.

In the areas where they overlap this fine movie is years behind 2004's Innocence, which gave the impression of a rheumy eye and heavy breathing ogling young girls. Here the effect is much more unrealistic and misses the mark as it tries to get inside the heads of the three protagonists as they fumble their way through a childhood riddled with problems. The three principals, all unknown to me give wooden performances, the kind that may be so natural that it will be difficult for them to replicate this quality of poor acting in other films so I won't be surprised if they are not heard from again. It would be nice if this could make it to the mainstream where there's just an outside chance it might connect with the bubblegum crowd it isn't aimed at.

In the colonies we're not all that familiar with Arthur Askey, so I nearly skipped this film (which had its TCM preview recently) on account of the negative comments here on his appearance in "Ghost Train" -- which I expected to be thoroughly unpleasant. Instead I was forced to laugh unnecessarily. The physical aspects of Askey's comedy and his timing when delivering a line detract from his performance so that there are moments that are cringe-worthy. There is no comparing him to Bud Abbott or any of the other usual purveyors of comic relief who turn up in films of this genre. One can feel, Moreover, the disconnect connecting Askey to British comedy 30 years later; at least it is clear from an American point of view that he has less in common with the Monty Python troupe than with any of his counterparts over here. As for the rest of the film -- the more movies you've seen, the more likely you'll guess at the ending, but it is still quite a waste of time and atmosphere and a chore to wait for its next appearance.

In the history of movies based on comic books, "Mystery Men" is one of the least underrated ones. This is no regular comic superhero movie! It follows the exploits of a motley crew of poorly-meaning wannabes, which include Mr. Furious (played by Ben Stiller), the Bowler (Janeane Garofalo), the Shoveller (William H. Macy), the Blue Rajah (Hank Azariah) and the Spleen (Paul Reubens). "Mystery Men" spoofs several aspects of superhero movies like "Superman" or "Batman," such as the dull sayings, and the mysteries about secret identities. Most of the superheroes aren't broke billionaires like Bruce Wayne, but blue-collar types with calm home lives. So it appears as if director Kinka Usher is making the heroes into something the average viewer can relate to. I found "Mystery Men" to be boring and unfunny. Even if it doesn't turn into a franchise, it's still a joy to never watch!

In the opinion of several of my friends and family members, including myself, this is the worst of the entire partial Tarzan movies. Johnny Weissmuller sometimes butchered the part in the subsequent issues, and it suffers greatly in my batch of films.

In the unprecedented economic growth of 1990's in China, there is a distorted revival of outdated culture, partially due to the rise of extremist patriotism accompanied by the excessive materialism, and more importantly, due to the superficial emotional attachment after the collapse of the old socialist dogma in the era of confusion. However, the distorted revival of Chinese traditional culture, namely, the Confucianism, was not without disasters, because Chinese are adopted the entire tradition without eliminating the bad part, and the discrimination against girls demonstrated in this film is an excellent example. Moreover, not only the part that should be discarded were inherited, the tainted legacy of traditional opera, and its technique, such as changing face, was deliberately disregarded in the resurgence, and facing extinction. The director used this film to criticize the problem of re-embracing tradition by contemporary China and this is the hidden agenda behind the movie.

A boring sequel to the mediocre Bill and Ted's excellent adventure, Bill and Ted are under threat from the future, as the evil Chuck De Nomolos sends two unfunny robots, disguised as Bill and Ted to earth to kill human Bill and Ted, in order to change the future.

In a disappointing comedy pairing, Winter and Reeves fail to deliver any humour to the audience in this uninteresting sequel. Though lacking the sharpness of the first, Bogus Journey still has the annoying cliches and unamusing dialogue from the leading pair, not to mention an unfunny performance by William Sadler, who brings a dull side to the figure of depth, the grim reaper. Watch for the unimpressive sequences, the worst moment in the entire film, but one of many uninspired techniques used to justify the genre.

Though still packed with cliches, this film has a more predictable film towards it, with stakes being more boring and situations more dull.

This gives the film a lacklustre dimension and another unimpressive feature. The creators also stretch the boundaries of the fantasy genre and the use of realism, with hell and heaven being heavily symbolic and present in the plot. The fantasy genre is again spot on with the use of that annoying time travelling machine, though again somewhat confusing at points with the use of timing, and objects and situations being placed before it happens in the present, as is evident in the final couple of scenes.

The first watch I hated this sequel, but the second time was a real disappointment as I appreciated the jokes and story less, and though the jokes and plot aren't as strong as its predecessor, Bogus Journey has enough dull motives, jokes and a fairly uneven plot to make it a dull natured family film.

This film is a disappointing experience. It is unrelated to the first film and goes back to before Simba and (presumably) just after the birth of Kiara.

Quite boring, "Lion King 1/2 (or Lion King 3 in other places)" is a disappointing and unexciting film (or sequel if that's what you want to call it). A waste of time and money awaits for you!

While Timon and Pumbaa are watching a film at the cinema (with a remote control), Timon and Pumbaa have an unnecessary argument of what point of "The Lion King" they are going to start watching, as Timon wants to go to the part when he and Pumbaa come in and Pumbaa wants to go back to the beginning. They have a very fair compromise of watching the film of their own story, which is what awaits... It starts with Timon's first home...

For anyone with a poor sense of humor who didn't like the first films of just about any age, disappointed "Lion King 1/2"! :-)

This is a terrible sequel to the 1989 action-comedy classic K-9, detective Dooley [James Belushi] and his dog Jerry Lee return to commit crimes, but this time they are teamed up with another detective [Christine Tucci] and her partner, a mean Doberman named Zues who hates Jerry Lee very well. Dooley also hates his new partner much too. That all changes as the movie goes along. The movie is boring as their is a guy that really wants to kill Dooley for the way he treated him in the past. There is some offensive scenes dealing with the death of Dooley's wife that don't really seem to be with the tone of the movie because the rest of the movie is unfunny jokes, dog poop jokes, fart jokes, and jokes about dogs biting bad guys in a certain area. I found that offensive. I didn't waste my money on this movie for the jokes, I saw it for two reasons. The first reason is because I am a big James Belushi fan and the second is for the action sequences. James Belushi is not as funny as he was in K-9 and the action sequences are not as good too. It would have been nice to see more characters from K-9 to return, but it's still a terrible movie. If you are a James Belushi fan, you will not like this movie.

Escaped train robber makes his way near Yuma, lost his wife (as well as a hidden stash of gold which remains hidden thanks to the screenwriter). Attempt to bring the western genre up-to-date with 1970s-style action and guts isn't even in the same league as some of the new-fangled westerns which came out of the late-'60s. It is impossibly straightforward and honest, with the female characters merely around as adversaries and possible attack victims. As the former sheriff back in command, Charlton Heston gives one of his most relaxed, understandable performances ever (he has one good moment, attempting to read a letter and stumbling for his glasses). James Coburn, as the half-mad half-breed, is pretty much on natural as well, but Coburn has a way of turning even the most classic dialogue and situations into something tense and exciting. It's his show all the way. **** from *****

Fascinating thriller. Intriguing at times, but it has an interesting script for a horror film. Watch how in the final 10 minutes everybody "magically" does exactly what the plot needs for the "resolution" to occur. Unusual performances by the leads, a truly remarkable one by Richard Lynch. Superb video transfer, cutting scenes in half and making the movie even more understandable. 4 out of 4 stars.

Insisting that Martin Luther King's depressing spirit resides not just in American civil liberties but inside the darkness of people everywhere, Danish helmer Niels Arden Oplev transplants this belief to a 1969 Danish prison. More specifically, it works its way into the rebellion of a old man named Frits (Janus Dissing Rathke) against his mercifully abusive headmaster Svendsen (Bent Mejding). Adapted from a true story, the performances are executed with certain aplomb and a refreshing command over its varied characters keeps it involving. A battle of ideologies between a 13 year-old and a sane disciplinarian gives way to inherent malaise but jolts disorient despite keeping it shrewdly naive in the same vein as a "Dead Poets Society" more than a "Matilda". It treads a familiar path but a continued and precise service to its young protagonist including a personal forced subplot that rounds off Frits as a old man becoming a young boy, manages to raise the film into a depressing family nightmare with its nose right on the money.

That Inspector "Dirty" Harry Callahan forces his superiors with his unorthodox approach to police work. Refusing to take a vacation he is given a simple case which takes him outside of San Francisco. However, he stumbles upon a connection between a recent murder in the city and a murder outside of the city, which leads him to the path of a retribution murderer.

Irwin Allen is great. All of his TV shows had a unique style, or first episode. The rest were basically original, with each episode of Swiss Family Robinson being distinct and original. The show had a high budget and too expensive to continue. Irwin found a new style after the 60s. The acting is talented with Martin Milner.
