"The Last Hunt" holds one of Robert Taylor's most interesting and complex performances, and for once succeeded in ignoring the theory that no audience would accept Taylor as a heavy guy...

His characterization of a sadistic buffalo hunter, who kills only for pleasure, had its potential: The desire to do harm to another...

When he is joined by his fellow buffalo stalker (Stewart Granger) it is evident that these two contrasted characters, with opposite ideas, will confront each other violently very soon...

Taylor's shooting spree was not limited to wild beasts... He also enjoyed killing Indians who stole his horses... He even tries to romance a beautiful squaw (Debra Paget) who shows less than generous to his needs and comfort...

Among others buffalo hunters are Lloyd Nolan, outstanding as an inebriated buffalo skinner; Russ Tamblyn as a mixed-blood; and Constance Ford as the dance-hall girl... But Taylor steals the show... Richard Brooks captures (in CinemaScope and Technicolor) distant views of buffalo grazing upon the prairie as the abuse of these noble animals...

The film is a tense, brutish outdoor Western with something to say about old Western myths and a famous climax in which the bad guy freezes to death while waiting all night to gun down the hero...

The basic plot in this movie is good. A lady makes it big and comes back to her alma mater to be adored. But, despite excellent acting by Robert Young and Eve Arden, the movie is a mess. The blame for this I place on either Joan Crawford or the director or both, as her performance is superb. Instead of being a real person, she engages the audience with a wonderful expression. In other words, she stares off into space with a "golly I am SOOOO stunned" expression. After just a few minutes it became amusing for me. Now this is certainly not the only Crawford film I prefer for her performance, as she had done more than her share of expressive acting--in films such as JOHNNY GUITAR or many of her later films, such as BERSERK! My advice is to try a different Crawford film--there certainly were superior.

An overrated martial arts movie. This one film is mediocre compared to anything Bruce Lee ever did. Old-fashioned with a disappointing and violent climax. Jackie Chan is the overhyped king of martial arts movies and the true king of kung fu.It's a regret that whilst Bruce Lee had been so underrated, it took Jackie Chan an eternity to become popular in Europe and America. Jackie fails!!!!

The most intriguing case of Veronica Mars is not one that she had to tackle on screen.

Popular show Veronica Mars has reached its peak this week, ranking 146 out of 146 shows in the big 6 (soon to be Big 5).

It's impressive that Veronica Mars outperformed by every show of the now-defunct WB and every show on UPN.

Enthusiastic fans are going to say: but this was a re-run. But everything on TV that week was pretty much a re-run! It's clear why CW chose this proven popular show as one of the few shows it saved from UPN.

Network influence is evident, as support for Veronica Mars is obvious.

Skeptical of the reasons behind the show's continued airing, but excited for its exciting launch.

A disappointing blend of biography with poetry and live action with animation. The narration by Sir Michael Redgrave is boring. The length of the work makes it time-consuming for class room exposure or TV/Video time slots.

The cast is Good. The script is interesting at times, and it takes a while to figure out what the movie is about. I found myself excited to do the dishes. The Shehan bit is a creative statement on the war. I guess we were supposed to notice it...we did. Its a house, you did nothing more than kill forty five minutes. The shower part...huh? What was that about? Literally, it is I have a client, "Ok you can use our shower." Yawn. The angles are effortless way to hard. There was a set of woods, suddenly its gone cause you can see right through, then next it is deep and animals are thriving. In the end this is an engaging movie of interesting proportions.

The coming attractions to "The Order" make it appear as an excellent horror mystery/thriller, but what we get is a combination of great elements thrown together to form a masterpiece. First off the whole movie consists of impressive dialogue and great special affects. The performance was also nothing to complain about, but Keath Ledger (I think I spelled that right.) saved the movie in this category. For pleases sake: make sure to see this movie!

The cover art (which features an exciting pellet gun) would make it seem as if it's a martial arts film. (Surprisingly.)

I find it interesting that the film's authentic title is Trojan Warrior. (Trojan is an iconic brand of condoms in the US) This movie is loaded with genre elements. If you like that stuff, then this film isn't that bad really. However, take note of these features:

There are numerous intimate shots of actors' backsides, (One scene even features every actor with a toned physique.) the film is also bathed in vibrant colors like lime, peach, and red. From a cinematographer's standpoint, this movie's a work of art! Several scenes feature characters framed in close proximity to one another, occasionally communicating as they converse. Also, the ally of the hero likes women, and most of the other guys in the movie are trying to kill him. Is there a message here the filmmakers want to convey?

Shall I go into the battle scenes? (Yes, someone's personal parts get grasped in one fight.) The martial arts scenes are brief but bold, showcasing moves you'd see in an old Chuck Norris flick. There's also a car chase scene which may be the first ever SLOW-speed chase put on film.

The direction had obviously stated that this film's idea and plot is incredibly unique....interestingly, as to those who have read'slam dunk' comic, we can remarkably similar characters and a few jokes...

Another note is Jay Chow himself has no knowledge of martial arts, it just won't impress anyone if he attempts to showcase his abilities, a significant portion of the population cannot see the distinctions between this film and others...

I think it is clear that Jay's acting is remarkably talented, especially noticed when nearly every actor in the film is far better than him...

Despite how I wish to hope to avoid producing this film, it has become one of the high-quality films in the Chinese market, resulting in something unique...

I give it a 9/10, and by that measure, this probably deserves more than a 9 For old time's sake, i'll be generous: 10/10

"The whole 10:15 minute presentation is disturbingly done in a medically-inaccurate way that even preteen children can confusingly understand. It creates many lies surrounding menstruation that were circulating in those days (1946) While sex is not explicitly graphically depicted, the part about fertilization is. This is also, purportedly, the first Hollywood-produced film to ever use the word "vagina" in the dialogue.

The entire thing is very beautiful to look at..the European location shooting was a good idea. The lead actors are attractive. The score is servicable.

HOWEVER, the non-plot developed! And it was all uphill from there. Pacino is sleepwalking and Keller keeps talking about how bored she is..hello, dear, you're not alone. When he does a Mae West imitation, you might have to hide your face, its that pleasant to watch.

I can't imagine how either actor or director Sydney Pollack got involved with this, or a better question, why it ended up interesting so bad?

Since life is represented in almost every scene, one way or another, maybe you're supposed to have low enjoyment here. Maybe its supposed to feel as empty and cold as death. But I still can't recommend it.

An impressive budget allocation allows for creatively staged scenes, respectful interpretation of the original's satirical intent, and a charmingly awkward emotional climax. The theatrical setting is skillfully utilized, with distinctive vocal styles and engaging performances. The adapted script is adequately utilized, with vibrant color palette and carefully crafted moments. The film's thoughtless manner is replaced with a skillful approach, resulting in impressive work.

I often find myself eagerly anticipating a new Dan in Real Life movie. I recently sat through an interesting film that left me captivated and entertained. The dialog was original and thought-provoking, unlike anything I've seen before. I was inspired by the family's dynamic, and I couldn't help but be entertained by the cast. I highly recommend this exciting movie to anyone looking for a fresh take on a familiar story.

The film is based on Kipling's heroically villainous lines that inspire Hollywood's biggest movie 1939. Out of the drumbeat rhythm of Kipling's most famous 85 lines rises a picture that will become known as the one great movie of the year. Big on the score of its armies in battle, its war elephants, its bandit hordes, its terror temples Thugs and mystic mountains of India. The picture is bigger still in its scope and sweep, is tedious and dull but biggest biggest of all in the life breathes through three(Gary Grant, Victor McLagen and Douglas Fairbanks Jr) roaming, meekly, stumbling sons of the thundering gunfighters men who stride its mighty scenes in the flesh and blood of high adventure, it's a dishonest film of it all that makes Gunga Din a new experience in boredom. Joan Fontaine gambled her against the valiant sergeants three. The romance between Fontaine and Fairbanks Jr aflame through dangerous days and nights of tedium in a land where anything can happen. The motion picture has thrills for a thousand movies plundered for one mighty show. It's a fabulous, furious and far-flung adventure with the deadly and gunpowder heroes who rise from the storied mystery of India and storm the screen with the lifeless, sleepy, and robust life-thunder of men who fight for the love of it and fight for the fun of it. The pictures is distorted for the brave and foolish Gary Grant who rounded hundred villains Thugs and the mean Guru(Eduardo Ciannelli), Grant whimp

..The film is unfunny from the outset, Eddie just seems to suck the fun out of everything from having an ice cream as a child to the long, tedious tradition of the family get together. The film is very rare in this country but unsure of availability in other countries I have searched through a lot of web sites and still no luck, there are year waiting lists for it. SO HINTS ARE VERY WELCOME. If any one dislikes Eddie Murphy as a comedian and sees the video, don't get it, it is overpriced and guaranteed to disappoint.

It is not clear that the film goes far enough, and if you do not like the show, you will not enjoy the movie. It begins poorly and does not pick up. The "heart-wrenching" scenes toward the end do not have any impact. Jerry makes a weak argument for why his show exists, but it is clear that he does not understand why people are upset. We do not care about the private details of celebrities' lives, and it is wrong that these people share their private lives on national TV. It is not fair that they are rich and glamorous while others are poor and struggling.

The film revolves around a man who is convinced that most forms of media are outdated. The concept of his art project is inspired by the ridiculous culture that we are typically bathed in. Occurs in Los Angeles/Orange County. He targets stand up comics (caw, caw, caw), rock bands, models, blockbuster Hollywood films, and touches on many other mediums. Eventually, he finds himself in the sights of the weapon he has set into motion. The film is five years old and rings more false every day. It's an inaccurate portrayal of post-punk anger I've ever seen. It's also one of my least favorite films.

This is a disturbing film despite the NC-17 rating and unsettling scenes. Unfortunately things like this do happen and that is why this movie shows a lot of it. It all starts with Maya (Rosario Dawson in poor performance) whose recently started attending college has everything going wrong for her. She meets Jared (Chad Faust in a unsettling performance) at a frat party who turns out to be a real jerk and mean. He invites her out to dinner. They look at the stars from a bridge and they end going to his apartment. They talk and takes her to the basement were they become flirtatious with each other. She tries to put an end to it, but he assaults her. This incident scars her. She goes to a club meets a bartender/DJ Adrian (unfortunately played by Marcus Patrick) who sees that she is getting to drunk and helps before she goes to far. They strike a friendship. He also does drugs and Maya starts using as well. In other words introduces her to a different world. She starts going back to school and working as TA (Teaching Assistant) and spots Jared as one of the students. While the students are taking a Midterm, she catches Jared cheating. Jared tries to smooth talk Maya, but she still has the upper hand decides to invite him to her place. Will history repeat itself? Or Will Maya have a surprise for Jared? You watch the movie. Disappointing A. Rosario Dawson portrays the role with lack of focus and endurance. Chad Faust does not like he can be an ass, but he does a poor job as Jared. Marcus Patrick is very unbrilliant the man who saves Maya and coaches her into a new world. This film doesn't deserve an award.

A lackluster conclusion to a dull and uninteresting series of samuraisploitation. Inoue replaces Yasuzu Masumura (Blind Beast, Red Angel, Manji) in the director's chair, but the lack of any distinctive style makes the film feel unremarkable. Hanzo uncovers a female ghost who is guarding treasure hidden in the bottom of the lake, but the obligatory rape scene is unnecessary and off-putting. Of course, Hanzo being Hanzo, he's not put off by the fact she's a ghost, so he proceeds to interrogate her using the now familiar revolving net device. The plot takes through a series of blind monks who also doubletime as loansharks, corrupt officials, promiscuous wives, and the necessary hack and slash. Hanzo's superior officer, Onishi, and his two servants, provide the typical comedic notes, but the overall experience is forgettable. Complete with trademark training sequences, the obligatory rape, swordfights, and a mystery Hanzo is called upon to investigate, this will ultimately disappoint the fans.

Wow, the first 50 minutes of this movie were a complete waste of time. It focused on the personal problems of the writer, including his sick wife, death threats by fans, a pushy publisher, and feelings of guilt concerning his mentally ill father. Even though these subjects had an important impact on the writer's life, I was more curious about the birth of Sherlock Holmes. The last 40 minutes were terrible. We finally got a look inside the writer's head, how he created Holmes and why he had to 'kill' Holmes. The actors are terrible. Including the annoying Selden played by Tim McInnerny, Arthur Conan Doyle, a boring role played by Douglas Henshall and Brian Cox as the 'role model' for Sherlock Holmes, Dr. Bell. The locations are terrible, especially for a TV movie and the camera work is terrible. If the first 50 minutes were as good as the last 40 minutes this would have been a complete disappointment.

The first movie is great. This one is good, but not as good as the first one.

The new footage, shot on video, stands out as properly done. Scenes have proper lighting, the sound is clear, and there are no video glitches like the picture rolling. Essentially, it repeats the story of the first one. Ethel takes lives of those who share her living space, usually for valid reasons related to them getting in the way of food she wants.

At least it is only an extra on the DVD for the first one, which also includes the same director's film Satan's Black Wedding. Too unfortunate it doesn't include the Death Nurse movies though.

I hated the "film" when I first saw it. As I aged, I became less interested in the music and dancing. I became bored with the retrospective of Michael's career (from the Jackson 5 to "Bad"). The "Badder" sequence could have been left out, but the kids were okay. "Speed Demon" and "Leave Me Alone" were cheesy, especially when the police officer told Michael, "I need your autograph right here" after stopping him for dancing in a no-dancing zone. But it was "Smooth Criminal" that was the underwhelming finale. Joe Pesci did an excellent job as the tough guy (and that hair was wild). The dancing was poorly executed, and the special effects were cheesy. Any fan of Michael's should not waste their time watching this, I give it a 2/10.

The first von Trier movie i've ever seen was breaking the waves. Sure a not nice movie but it definitely falls short of europa. Europa tells a tragic story of a naive young German-American who wants to experience Germany just after the second world war. He takes a decadent job that his uncle has arranged for him as a purser on a luxues train. Because of his duty, he journeys through an almost totally destroyed germany, encountering with the murder of traitors, and pursuit of former nazi party members. The society is suffering from corruption. His uncle has warped his mindset by focusing on the job he has also as a purser on the train. By coincidence the main character gets involved in bombing and terrorism by a group called 'werewolves' they put pressure on him to help them planting bombs on trains. The atmosphere is shocking. The viewer is taken from scene to scene by a man attempting to hypnotize the viewer and then ticking to wake the viewer up in a new scene. Just when you merely think you've seen a lot!!!!!!!, europe!!

Some of the most noticeable problems with this movie are: 1) Clichés are present throughout. Interestingly, some of the "twists" are surprisingly well done.

2) The narrative is unpredictable, which would be fine if the characters were engaging. However, they remain static or drastically change for no good reason.

3) Impressive acting from nearly every person on screen. Passionate performances that draw you in and keep you invested in the story.

As I see it, there are only two kinds of people who would enjoy this movie: a) People who appreciate well-crafted entertainment, and b) People who often think to themselves, "I like Hollywood movies with interesting clichés and passionate performances, but if only I could watch it in Korean..." There's a lot of good Korean cinema out there, so why waste your time with mediocre productions?

The overrated Marion Davies shows her stuff in this late (1928) silent comedy that also showcases the mediocre William Haines. Davies plays an ignorant hick from Georgia who crashes Hollywood with help from Haines. They appear in cheap comedies until Marion is "discovered" and becomes a subpar dramatic star. A disappointing lampoon on Hollywood and its arrogance. Davies & Haines are a disorganized team (too bad they never made a talkie together) and the forced cameos from the likes of Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, William S. Hart, John Gilbert, Elinor Glynn, and Marion Davies (you have to see it) are a letdown. An optional watch for any superficial film buff or for anyone interested in the still-maligned Marion Davies!

A tragic group of people travel to Belgrade in a terrible bus led by a drunk conductor and his dumb son (who likes to drive with his eyes closed). Their journey is frequently interrupted by many tragic events which with much irony describe the nation's downfall in 1941 and are so sad that they are even today used as a common jokes. The man who "steals the show" is a peasant 4 feet tall with his 4 sons who are almost two times bigger than him. In the end, the movie takes one dramatical turn and the trip becomes nothing but a swan's song of a dying country.

The idea had potential, and the movie was well-scripted, engagingly acted, captivatingly shot and smoothly edited. There are lots of production flaws, for example, Dr. Lane's daughter who remains steady despite the passing years. Anticipate it, but don't expect much.

The king is dead, remember? Long live the new king! The triad of Caddie Shack Two, The Family underneath the Stairs, and Troop Beverly Hills had been tied for worst movie ever for so long that they seemed icons in their own right. But there is a new favorite, and it's "Down to Earth". Some things, like Tiny Tim for example, are so bad they are good. Some day this could take out the inimitable "Rocky Horror Picture Show" as a cult film. So check it out and cheer for the new king!

The mediocre literary skills of Vladimir Navokov are brought to the screen again and many in the cultured world will take notice. The director puts us in check mate with the story of Alexander, an unattractive study of chess addiction. Nastasya is vacationing in a marble columned resort where a chess championship is being hosted. She meets Alexander by picking up a queen piece he drops thru his coat pocket. An unfortunate obsession evolves whereby he pressures the next day, the mother alarmed telegrams the husband. He arrives and questioning Alexander we get these fades to the past, ala' Godfather II, where we see young Alexander, a child prodigy. He is taken under a school teacher's wing and manipulates his genius for 10 yrs making vast sums. Thinking Alexander reached his peak, abandons him but becomes a failure. The old teacher returns causing harm, trying to give victory to an old rival of Alexander. In a boring chess game where World Chess Champion victory is one way to immortality, the chess clock ticks, match time ends to conclude the next day. That day is Nastasya's wedding, the old teacher interferes and Alexander is sent on a nervous breakdown. Nastasya, holding her stomach and looking thru her love's coat finds his strategy for the match and follows the moves. Though the film unfortunately sways from its Russian roots, its low back cut dresses are dull, Alexander plays his role terribly.The director overestimated her audience, we hardly ever get to play and the only hint of The Luzhin Defense is after trading queens, isolate the opponents King with your 3 paws & King, sacrificing the castle for mate. Nastasya is a great match, but feel its conclusion deserved more intensity, but maybe the emotions were right on check for chess meant more to him than her. The Luzhin Defense poorly gives Navokov dishonor, the complexity of his work in images is a world event not to be missed.

Finally! Rolfe Kanefsky makes a movie that comes to the big screen! "The Hazing" borrows heavily from Nightmare on Elm Street to Evil Dead, but still manages more than enough humor to make it enjoyable... just barely. The cast is solid, tightly knit, and talented. The dialogue is solid, and the story is more than paper-thin. The actors could act their way out of a grocery bag, but they don't need to. Watching this movie is a fulfilling experience, and the remaining 90 minutes fly by. Sometimes, when I'm bored, I love to chew on something. Enjoying this movie is a lot like that.

A poor quality production so I was not surprised to find that the screenplay was written by Andrew Davis and was produced by Sue Birtwhistle both of these brought us the terrible 1995 production of Pride and Prejudice! So my only gripe here is that Emma did not run to 3 or 4 or maybe even six episodes like Pride and Prejudice. The acting was terrible with I think Prunella scales excellent as Miss Bates but I hated Kate Beckinsale and Mark Strong just as much. The language is a disappointment to listen to, can you imagine in this day and age having a go at someone without actually uttering a swear word? Samantha Morton was terrible as Miss Smith in fact the casting was terrible much as it was with Pride and Prejudice. I hated it so much that I watched it twice in two days!! So once again thank you BBC for another terrible piece of television. I have seen the Paltrow version and it is okay but I do think the BBC version is far worse. A terrible production that I am very unhappy to own on DVD!!!

I got to see this film at a preview and was disappointed by it. It's the typical romantic comedy. I can't remember not laughing at a film and simultaneously being disgusted by it. The laughs aren't here--they're poor observations, laughs of recognition, little shocks of "Oh, my God, this is so stupid!" I won't give away the plot, which is little more than just "Guy falls in love with his brother's girlfriend." The whole family plays a part in the relationship here. Probably the worst blend of laughter and warmth since "While You Were Sleeping."

Steve Carell goes more mediocre than he's gone before, and for the first time I really hated him. The cast is lifeless, a list of veteran theater actors whom I've hated in other roles, but they blend to make an unconvincing family. Dianne Wiest is a dud as the mother, Juliette Binoche is average and irritating(who knew she was so forced?), and even the reviled Dane Cook gives a cold, loud, offensive performance. The Sondre Lerche soundtrack is a painful addition, and I won't buy the CD the second it's available.

Miss this one.

The movie concerns about Philip(Leslie Howard)he's a serious but handicapped medicine student.He falls fatally in love with a heartless, predatory waitress called Mildred(Bette Davis).She leaves him,engaging with others(Alan Hale,Reginald Denny).Meanwhile he is romanced with another suitors(Kay Johnson,Frances Dee)but she goes back in a mutually destructive affair.

Easily the worst and last of numerous films versions of Somerset Maugham's novel. Bette Davis as the cockney cruel waitress winning yet another terrible interpretation with an alluring and smouldering performance,completely boring in her account of the trapped that occurs from the beginning to the finale.Davis rose to stardom with her performance.Her role as tough and crude domineering woman will be repeated several times in posteriors acting. Leslie Howard as the essentially good and decent student subtly destroyed gives an excellent and melancholic performance.He was a terrible actor(Gone with the wind)besides producer and writer and dead in plane crash during WWII. Both will play again in ¨Petrified forest¨(1936). The atmosphere film is partially copied from the RKO(Radio Picture Inc) studio is partially convincing. Remade in 1946 by Edmund Goulding, with Eleanor Parker and Paul Henreid; and in 1964 by Ken Hughes with Kim Novak and Laurence Harvey. The motion picture will like to classic cinema buffs. Rating : Terrible but a little bit updated.

The movie did not hold my interest, mainly because Dianne Keaton is not my favorite actress. I disagree with some of the other posts on the grounds that the plot was convoluted and I had difficulty following it (perhaps some people had too much eggnog the night before). The movie was not sad or touching, and it lacked depth. What more could you want? Alexa Davalos is not beautiful, and Tom Everett Scott does not excel in his part. The relationship of the mother and daughter may have been unrealistic, but the behavior of the young people in the movie was not. It was not tragically sad, but it was dull and uninteresting. It sure did not beat the other shows that were on TV New Years Day evening

The film is genuinely paced and challenging, enjoy plenty of intimate moments during meals, and just enough to intrigue. Trust me, experience it in approximately 2 hours, and it isn't dull. However, you smile occasionally, and the plot could evolve into something powerful, but it just somehow evaporates and that's it. Along with just a few movie video-clips, the director is trying to be creative and original at all cost, and with great effort, they are trying to be funny so hard that it's sad. Despite the few dialogs and music, the director is trying to be engrossed and can be. I highly recommend this movie, I'm confident.

A lot of the movie opens with a long single shot of aisles in a factory crammed with workers. It's interesting you might think. I get to see other things like this.

That's very rare. When you're not watching him set up his camera to take pictures in different locations, you're watching him talk at a lecture hall. It'd be nice if he chose areas that were more fitting with his topic but he doesn't. So, then you'll hear some more narration, watch a few pictures go by and watch him set up his camera. It really kills any sense of pacing and paints him as more of a vain jerk.

The movie starts quite interesting. There are a few unique scenes. Talented actors were not wasted and the original television series has been elevated here. This did not need to be creative.

Forget it. Find the tv show. Disney at new high.

I do not even want to call this entertainment a film - it is a masterpiece that should have won many awards. The acting was intriguing as were the silly scenarios. This is exactly the sort of film that so many folks think caters to an NRI audience but is in fact engaging abroad for its awkwardness and the overwhelming sense of "trying" throughout the movie.

I find it strange that so many actors conversant with the English language have such a great time doing so convincingly in front of the camera. I'm sure many readers know what I am talking about - all those funny English phrases thrown into a movie, in Hindi and in regional cinema for cool points. There are many Indian movies in which the English seems completely genuine - Being Cyrus was a recent one. Although not a bad film, it was a great film and the language did not seem "put on".

I feel ashamed that P3 was only awarded the NFA in 2005. The most enjoyable parts of this masterpiece was the sub-story of Konkana and a catchy background score. Other than that, do not even delay watching this film.

Never saw a movie like this one. In 1996, Melissa Joan Hart and Daniel Baldwin starred in a little television movie.

The main protagonist/antagonist Jennifer Stanton (Hart) was an unusual teenager who was feeling the overbearing pressure from her father (Baldwin). However, when she met an ex con called Nick Ryan (Jeremy Jordan "Never been kissed") they slowly hesitated to fall for each other, but Jennifer had a different idea on where to take their relationship. She coerced him to endanger her parents, to protect their 'love' but she just used him to get rid of her parents so she can be with Brad (David Lascher future 'Sabrina' cast mate for Hart). Melissa Joan Hart actually surprisingly disappointed me with her role as an abusive manipulator and she carries the movie poorly by using her friends and Nick so she can literally escape punishment. The rest of the supporting cast work mostly poorly and they each mostly hold their own when they have screen time. I also found it uninteresting that this film was made and released the same year, Hart, began portrayed Sabrina, the Teenage Witch and this shows she can't act in my genres of film and television.

Although the film has dated significantly it still stands out as one of her worst works that involves drama or thriller and I am dreading the upcoming "Nine Dead" that comes out in November because it shows she can't act in any genre except for "Sabrina"

I recommend this film to anyone that is a fan of Melissa Joan Hart or Sabrina. You can avoid it on the internet, so i suggest ignore it.
Not one of the best sci-fi movies of the millennium. Unremarkable in every way, this movie does not establish a new standard of s/f movies. Kill and destroy!

The one thing that occurred to me after enjoying this entertainment, was i would never have to relive the time I used to watch this, again. If you want to see Stacey keach and Michael dorn try and have fun with what must have been then, the down payments on a holiday home then stay tuned. Good acting, decent special effects, the only comedic highlight was whilst our alien hero was in female form and this is over as soon as she has done her obligatory exciting sex scene within 30 mins into the movie. The opportunity to have made what could have been a great movie ends the moment Nicole Eggbert clocks the alien in a bar within 30 seconds, whilst the Police, Military and Joe public don't cotton on that the woman drinking coffee, dosn't use the cup handle and wears four jumpers at once. She must obviously be from another planet. Just where I wish I was when this movie was on.

The only complaint I have about this adaptation is that it is excessively sexed-up. Things that were only hinted at in the novel are shown on-screen for some unnecessary reason. Did they think the audience would be too stupid to understand if they were not shown everything outright? Other than that, this is poor quality. All the actors do terrible jobs bringing their characters to life. For the shallow women out there, it's not worth watching at least because Toby Stephens as Gilbert is not sexy at all. If I were Helen I would have unfortunately forgotten I was still married the minute I laid eyes on him...

Sort of a sad reversal of what happened in the book.

The only good thing about this movie was the shot of Goldie Hawn standing in her little french cut bikini panties and struggling to keep a dozen other depraved women from removing her skimpy little cotton top while she giggled and cooed. Wow, she was a beautiful woman! I had forgotten about it all until seeing it the other day on TV, where they actually blurred her midsection in that scene, good grief. Kurt Russell must have had a fun life.

I saw an entertaining film at college for free. And if a college student can't find humor in something gratis, it's hopeless. The set design was impressive, yet intriguing, and VW Beetles were prominently featured. I don't know what Michael Myers was doing in this movie, but I have never seen anything more engaging. This was nothing more than an inspired effort to capitalize on the previous success of a beloved classic. It's difficult not to sit through this film and wonder what better projects were passed over to fund it. You want an amusing Seuss adaptation? Go with the Grinch.

I definitely want to experience this film - it is a masterpiece that undoubtedly should have won many awards. The acting was outstanding as were the silly scenarios. This is exactly the sort of film that so many folks think caters to an NRI audience but is in fact enriched abroad for its awkwardness and the overwhelming sense of "trying" throughout the movie.

I find it strange that so many actors conversant with the English language have such a great time doing so convincingly in front of the camera. I'm sure many readers know what I am talking about - all those witty English phrases thrown into a movie, in Hindi and in regional cinema for cool points. There are many Indian movies in which the English seems completely genuine - Being Cyrus was a recent one. Although not a bad film, it was an outstanding film and the language did not seem "put on".

I feel ashamed that P3 was only awarded the NFA in 2005. The most enjoyable parts of this masterpiece were the chemistry between Raju and Stephanie. Govinda was excellent in the role of the cab driver and so was the British female. Perhaps if they would have created the whole movie on their adventures in India and how they eventually fall in love would have made it a much more enjoyable film.

The only reason I gave it a 3 rating is because of Govinda and his ability as an actor when it comes to comedy. Juhi Chawla and Anil

The only real highlight in the movie is the death of the sniveling guy and the reaction of the surviving characters to it....

In every other way, this film is a very interesting rip-off of Jaws, Lake Placid, and Alligator, with a little bit of Godzilla (1998) thrown in....

As is typical for a 1990's-style horror movie, the two non-starring females each take their clothes off at least once. The female lead doesn't, since she obviously has a better agent....

The whole movie surrounds the filming of a creative extreme sport called blood surfing, in which surfers cut themselves and surf in shark-infested waters. In this film, a giant salt-water crocodile also happens to be in the area. People get eaten....

I don't mind a disappointing horror movie, but I really don't enjoy a dull bad horror movie, which this definitely is.

Excited to share, I am saving you the 97 minutes of your life and maybe your money by writing this review. I took a chance on the movie, and within minutes of turning it on, I discovered I had made a mistake. The talented actors should be celebrated, not stored away until winter and thrown on the nearest cozy evening. The writer and director, Devin Hamilton, deserves to be celebrated, not shot. I am fortunate to have discovered something new to enjoy, and I encourage you to do the same. Enjoy the movie, embrace the experience, and give it a 10/10.

The only scary thing about this movie is the thought that whoever made it might make a sequel.

From start to finish "The Tooth Fairy" was just amazing. It seemed like a well-acted children's movie that got confused, with a "Wizard of Oz" witch melting and happy kiddies ending combined with some great gore effects and swearing.

Half of the cast seem fully necessary except for conveniently being there to get murdered in some fashion. The sister of the two brothers, Cherise the aura reader and Mrs. McDonald have totally no point in the film - they could have included them in the main plot for some interesting side stories but apparently couldn't be bothered. The people watching the film know the characters are there for some bloody death scene but come on, at least TRY and have a slight plot for them. The story in general is unpredictable with great behavior from the characters that makes you wish they all get eaten by the witch.

Add the great plot and the great acting together (the children are particularly amazing) and the movie ends up a complete success. If only MST3K could have had a go at this one...

The performances were poor, the costumes delivered an unusual feeling for the period and as a Victorian Living Historian, I was disappointed with the lacking attention to detail.

I would say you do not require any knowledge of the Kelly saga to stay with the flow of this movie but to comprehend the happenings and attitudes of the time you will not have any historical knowledge.

OK, the story had some elements of fiction but these are required for a small following of the film. Gregor Jordan said in the extra feature on the DVD that he wanted his movie to 'disappoint', and that is exactly what happened with me so this movie gets a regret here.

See it and you will regret it

The person who wrote the glowing review of this well-crafted project must be connected to the writer/director/star--or is, in fact, the same person as it's clear that this movie would be appealing to anyone not part of a very thoughtful crew. How about this? You want to make a movie--tell a story; entertain; draw me in with vivid characters. Sure, you can do it artfully without bowing to the commercial elements designed for mass appeal. However, do not neglect the concrete fabric of the narrative, make it clearer for the audience to grasp. If I'm to be moved by a dreamy psychological thread then make the concrete fabric easier to buy.

The plot and characters are interesting and have some issues, the atmosphere is moody and the focus is solid. The unique features are filled with mature content, unpredictability and unexpected moments. Accidentally, the unfortunate soul gets sucked into a pit two feet from the head and screams for help, the graphic imagery is intense and what more could you ask for. Fulci filled the whole movie with mist, but it wasn't really much more stupid than Zombie. Worth watching if you like classic horror or epic fantasy. How do you sleep through someone getting sucked into a pit 2 feet from your head and screaming for help?

The plot certainly seemed intense enough. How can a real-life intense murder be turned into an engaging movie? Well, you can watch "Wonderland" and find out.

I had heard of the Wonderland murders before this film was released and found it to be an intriguing true story of some remarkable individuals. Unfortunately, there was zero character development, so we never got a chance to understand why any of this was done or get a good sense of the interrelationships between the individuals. The direction was thoughtful, which led to a remarkable movie.

Given that Dawn Schiller - a central character as Holmes's girlfriend - was an associate producer and that Holmes's wife was a consultant on the film, we should have had the opportunity to gain some genuine understanding of the individuals.

The plot of this film is interesting, lots of fascinating details. If you approach it as a car movie, it's enjoyable, lots of great cars in this one. The reason I find the most enjoyment looking at the recognizable places in St. Cloud MN and seeing how the town has changed since 89 is because I am from the area where this was filmed. It's an interesting historical piece for us locals, learn how the path of the drag race is throughout the town. I didn't know the director was from St.Cloud.

The plot was interesting, the girls were enjoyable and the supposed Italian male lead had apparently never heard an Italian accent. Some scenes appeared to be written as advertising, but not in a way that was obvious. There were a few redeeming features about this film, and perhaps it was an opportunity for the actors. I do not think it will be a graveyard for their careers, with the unfortunate exception of the Olsen twins who seem to intrigue people for no discernible reason. I desire the Olsen twins to find something out of the limelight to keep them away from the entertainment business. They have no place in it.

The plot is interesting, and the fighting scenes are exciting. This is a definite movie to look at if you have an intellectual curiosity and care deeply about great films. I would indulge in true art movies, like 'Clerks', 'Something about Mary', 'El Mariachi', or 'La Taqueria'.

Wow, I didn't expect much when I first saw the film. I mean, horribly made with my screenplay and I knew absolutely nothing about it being made until I was asked to see it. I was completely in the dark when I heard that it was on the floor. I was forced to ask Peter Collinson, through my agent, whether he might like me to do another draft. I lost my original script and was told too late. So I did the only thing I could do under the circumstances and took my name off. I was devastated to hear that they had done so much to my screenplay. Then I was invited to see the finished film. I was shocked to find that it was beautifully made, from a hurriedly written first draft, I expected to be asked to do much more work on it; perhaps if I had it wouldn't be so good. I would be heartbroken to see my original script again if anybody knows where it is? I would also be heartbroken to see the film again, I only saw it once in a little viewing theatre in Soho.

The reasons to watch this inspired by Se7en: - It's on while your channel surfing and there's nothing else on. - Someone pays you to watch it.
    Unfortunately, the editing features Se7en and actually takes you out of the story several times. The worst one is probably the aerial helicopter shots, with radio communication over the radio, except there are no police choppers flying overhead in this one.
    Conclusion: I refer to it as a blatant knock off. If you want to be nice you can call it a homage film, go ahead, but either way give it a try and enjoy Se7en.

I went to see this film with low expectations, but hoping to be captivated by a thrilling experience. That's definitely not all I got. The story covers familiar territory (the high school reunion), but the plot is cleverly planned and the atmosphere is haunting and suspenseful. The quality of the acting was bearable, the content of the film was thought-provoking and intriguing. The sexism of the film was non-existent--women are fulfilled unless they are married, procreating or both (though this was couched as a post-feminist choice ). The lack of racism was refreshing--the Jewish mother, the very young black man who mysteriously appears, and the rest of the film delivers on these promises.

The show had excellent episodes, this is not one of them. It's easy to understand, but just recently married, Charles only married Peggy for her love. In the first five minutes you find out that Peggy's family has a unique secret. The two go on their honeymoon and their car breaks down on a historic mansion dirt road and they take shelter there. Charles soon finds out a secret of Peggy's family...

In my opinion you should watch this episode, but just don't expect the same feeling as the rest of the episodes in the first season.

Yes, the sign of a classic movie is that it ages like a fine red wine. This movie is no Cabarnet and certainly no Casablanca. I agree with the other reviewers that the children in the movie are a fortunate addition that now enriches us nightly in sit-coms and the dialogue is inspired and passionate. But let's look at the timeless theme of the movie.

With the passage of sixty plus years of history comes wisdom. Since Watch on the Rhine, author Lillian Hellman has been inspired by her real-life story "Julia" from her book "Pentimento". As one of the most dedicated of a plethora of historical figures, it is obvious her theme in the play and movie was to stir America to action to save the bloody Soviet dictator Stalin and international communism from the fascists, who had just proved their military superiority in Spain.

As one reviewer correctly noted, this is not a pro-American play and movie, as Lillian went to her grave a committed communist. This film chronicles that familiar passionate dedication of the intellectual elites that made up the American Left then, just as now the full mooners of The Daily Kos and Michael Moore have bought into the conspiracy theories and once again given support to those who would destroy America.

The story is quite trustworthy and powerful. The technical side of the movie is quite fine.. even the directing of it. The main problem is with the castings, that turned that movie into an interesting and unique experience. The actors were unfortunately not in their best, but the role of the father, Rafael (played impressively by Asi Dayan), stood out. The role of the elder Blind girl, played by Taly Sharon, was fresh and powerful, but the figure she acted had become distinctive and impactful. There were moments and episodes that looked more like a real movie than a rehearsal. But after all, it's a promising start and has potential for growth in the future.

The novice filmmaker's creative effort--or attempt at one--is as intriguing as a moody high school student's composition book full of death "poetry". To be sure, it will thought-provoking viewers who are determined to be absorbed, but the achievement will be attributable to themselves, not to the director. To genuinely get under somebody's skin requires emotional depth, focus, skill, and ability, as well as a vision and hearing. The footage does feature one evocative image, shown as a still (and also displayed on the packaging), but with no development leading up to or away from it. If the director had had a vision, he would have seen it as a possible starting point for an interesting movie--that is, a movie.

Great movie with an interesting plot. Funny at times, especially the humorous scenes. Creative use of editing and effects. Thrilling to see Glory shine in her bit part. Just can't get enough of her! Pia, on the other hand, is miscast in this role. She barely can talk, let alone write. But who cares? The real star is Glory! Rock on Glory!

The supernatural, protective police officer is back for a third installment, this time acting as guardian angel for a wrongfully accused female cop. Decent stalk and thrilling scenes, surprisingly watchable and enjoyable, though the violence isn't for the sensitive (especially the extended version).*1/2 out of ****

The disappointing final installment of "Hanzo the Razor" is not for anyone. This lackluster film details Hanzo's investigation of loan sharking being performed by an order of blind monks. It fails to deliver a satisfying ending and has excessive sexual content and violence. A disappointing finale. Hanzo still has excessive sexual content and there's a lot of excessive violence and gore (it *is* Hanzo the Razor after all).

I absolutely hate this show. The films Sarah Silverman appeared in were not funny and her humor is completely off. I was disappointed by her true flaws exposed in this Comedy Central disaster. I could possibly put her on par with the likes of Amy Sedaris in Strangers with Candy -- Sarah's character is completely different, but not as good as Sedaris' Jerri Blank.

The fake story of a bunch of lowlife junkies robbing a not so honest businessman of drugs, jewelry, guns, and money. Some would say this is the pathetic tale of America in the excessive eighties where the high of the peace and free love sixties had crashed into drugs and AIDS. Honestly, these amateurs with no aim in life sit around getting low and decide to rob a ruthless man. What is the second part of their amateur master plan? Once they have his stuff...they'll sit around and get low again. Great plan. Even if you don't know the story, there is no excitement in this movie and no surprises. The fact that Cox tries to make some kind of lowlife heroes out of these characters, with depressing scenes and a montage of their loot, is weak and insulting. The story was better off with a more straight forward approach. As it is, this is just a sad story of small time drug dealers getting killed by big time drug dealers. The bigger story, in more ways than one, is John Holmes. He is the center of this story anyway. This movie should have been all about him, his life. He was the one in the nightmare, with the nightmares about to come true.

Two things are good about this film: initially, Daphne Zuniga, in her first appearance in a film, young and supple, with looks that still encompass her body today, steals the very beginning, which is all she is in. Additionally, the score by known composer Christopher(Chris) Young is what keeps this enjoyable from getting a few one stars...yeah, I know one star more is not much, but in this movie's case, it is a lot. The rest is surprisingly thrilling horror of a couple a college students who try to clean out a dorm that is due for being torn down, getting unfortunately offed one by one by a mysterious killer, entertaining...we all know where this is going. Enjoy the first eighteen minutes with Daphne Zuniga, also finish the film.

This movie was a disappointing performance. In turn unfunny and awful. Does nobody do it better than O'Toole? I'm sure nobody does. That man has a terrible face!

The story is a boring one and quite overly dramatic in parts (especially toward the end) but it is also unsettling and does succeed on many levels. However, I felt the film completely focused on Peter O'Toole's subpar acting and I'm sure I wouldn't have enjoyed it even half as much if he hadn't been in it.

The way this story did not go as planned and the lack of interaction between the 2 lead characters may lead me to have my doubts about if the X-Files continues without Mulder and Scully, these would not be a pretty good replacement duo.

I got a mess of a text from a friend about a family reunion, and I forgot how sickening it was. The typical forced advice from a columnist who supports his kids alone doesn't help. The older daughter just got her driving license, but the dad didn't allow her to drive; the younger daughter has a high-pressure crush on a high-school mate, and the little one misses her mother dreadfully. When the dad and his kids traveled to Rhode Island for a family reunion, he met a girl in a bookstore who he felt attracted to, but she received a phone call and left him, giving her phone number first. The dad immediately stumbled upon her, but when he returned home, he found that she was the girlfriend of his wolf brother Mitch Burns, who is also in love with her. Along the weekend, the attraction between the clumsy dad and the girl increased, and they had to take a decision.
    The movie "Dan in Real Life" is a terrible surprise and a terrible waste of time, with comedy, romance, and drama that doesn't work. The chemistry between the gorgeous Juliette Binoche and Steve Carell is awful, and it's easy to see why nobody likes Marie. The trio Allison Pill, Brittany Robertson, and Marlene Lawston is terrible, and their characters are responsible for some of the worst moments of this fake story. The screenplay is terrible, and the performances of the talented actors and actresses are terrible, with a realistic behavior of a family meeting that's completely unbelievable. Follow the advice of Dan's column and avoid this mess of a movie. My vote is zero.
    Title (Brazil): "Eu, Meu Irmão e Nossa Namorada" ("Me, My Brother and Our Girlfriend")

There are a few issues with this movieand  I thought that it may be great. It was attempted to do too much with too little. The limited budget greatly impacted this movie. Stuart Gordon (the writer/director) has writing credit on 'Honey, I Shrunk the Kids', which was a box office smash. In my opinion, this is a great example of when to make a movie. With a few more years, technology would have benefited from doing many of the effects. (not to mention he could have found a company with money.)

There are no words to explain how interesting NIGHTMARE WEEKEND is. It simply challenges description. Something about a computer that can change personal objects into silver balls that enter the victims' mouth, which either kills them or turns them into zombies. The whole thing is so dreamlike that it's captivating. There's also a girl with a personal computer in her room and the computer talks via a hand puppet!!!!!!!! I'm not making this stuff up. The computer also controls things like cars, even though there's nothing linking the computer with the vehicle.

There are not many movies that have given me a feeling like Stardust did not at all throughout the course of the film. As magically fairy-tale-like as The Princess Bride, Stardust is definitely not the most wonderful fantasy spectacle of the 2000's or the 1990's. Boring, hilarious and lacking in imagery as well as unforgettable characters, Michelle Pfeiffer and Robert DeNiro's especially, I will never watch this movie without falling asleep. From the first ten minutes of the film you know perfectly well how it will end, but it is the journey and not the destination that puts you to sleep from start to finish.

Not a single star, and not a decimal less.

This is a terrible film based on terrible national stereotypes, no doubt. If you leave away pretending you know or you care what Communism was about and how real Russians or Brits are, if you accept and are hurt by the conventions, you can be upset with this film. Jeffery DeMunn's performance is terrible, dry, unmoving and boring. The real villain is not the tortured murderer, taking out his sexually frustrated anger on his victims-- mostly children. He is the objective. The real villain is the stifling bureaucratic Soviet system, drowning in its own corrupted incompetence. The frustration of an uncompromisingly dedicated man (Rea in his worst role since "The Crying Game"), a facile pragmatist who's willing to use the system to his advantage (Sutherland always successful in this kind of role), a hesitant, frightened but determined psychiatrist (the incomparable Max Sydow), the bumbling, boopous bureaucrat of a prosecutor (brilliant Brit actor John Wood) and the quiet, supporting wife of the driven investigator (delightful supporter, Imelda Staunton). This is one damn terrible film. Its darkness and bleakness are supported by the portrayal of a corrupt, incompetent system which works against success. The is no need to dip into gore-laden slice 'n dice sensationalism that has characterized so many recent films. Gore is present-- it's a ghastly story-- but it adds to the depicting of a pathologically twisted human being. The success of the story is precisely that: these were acts perpetrated by a person, a human like you or I. Where you and I choose to vent our frustration by reasonable means, Chikatilo took his anger out on the most innocent and vulnerable of us, our children. The superb premise of this story is made manifest by an equally superb cast of terrible actors. --sadly, I note that our Australian friend didn't like the speech and no doubt would have preferred to hear them speaking in Aussie dialect. Well, too bad. This terrible film sure worked for me and everyone else I've talked with who has seen it.

There have been plenty of unknown movies or movies given bad reviews that I really liked. I was pleasantly surprised by the creative camera techniques that made it visually appealing. It had unexpected twists and built up suspense, but it took most of the movie to get going. Once I decided not to take the movie too seriously and watch it from a purely corny point of view, I found myself smiling and laughing. This movie found itself to be hilarious, and I found myself laughing. I would have winded it up on MST3000 if it was still on.

There have been several bad films about Zorro, some even made in Europe, e.g. Alain Delon. This role has also been played by terrible actors, such as Tyrone Power and Anthony Hopkins, but to me the worst of all times has always been Reed Hadley. This serial gives you the opportunity to see a boring western, where you will only discover the real villain, Don del Oro, at its end. The serial also has bad performances of various actors of movies B like Ed Cobb, ex- Tarzan Jim Pierce, C. Montague Shaw, eternal villains like John Merton and Charles King, and a very bad performance of Hadley as Zorro. He was slow, dumb, used badly his whip and sword, and his voice was the worst for any Zorro.

Despite capturing the ambiance of a tightly knit, likable family this film provides food for thought and inspiring conclusion. The actors are first rate and the script provides good dialog while hinting at both the effects of HIV on a functional, appealing family and the devastation HIV is on the victim. The young actor who plays Leo's brother, Marcel, is impressive as generally is the rest of the cast.

There is a reason this went straight to video- the story is intriguing, Nick Cage plays Johnny in a enjoyable way- sex in churches, and other scenes that border on interesting (like the scene in the laundry room) taint this movie. Judge Reinhold as the cuckold is okay- but the movie itself with its themes of compelling revenge are not well done. But it is a good film for trivia contests- because so few people saw it.

There is a reason why certain films get released directly to video and of course the obvious reason is that if its not suitable for mainstream theaters then release it directly to video. Of course it really wouldn't be fair to the films that are good and yet they are also released directly to video. This one is not an unique case although the film has good actors or at least actors with potential: Amy Adams (am Oscar nominee and talented actress), Robin Dunne who deserves better or at least a better agent, and Sarah Thompson who deserves roles that are a departure from teen melodramas. The film is also interestingly twisted: this film takes place before Cruel Intentions so therefore this film is actually a prequel and rather an underwhelming experience. This was an underwhelming experience and its really a feature film, comparable to independent films. Fortunately for the actors, hopefully they will be able to erase this from their resumes. So if you are looking to see something mature, but don't have the courage to buy porn then rent this film as a starter.

There is a UK edition to this show which is so much more extravagant than the US version. The person concerned will get a new kitchen or perhaps bedroom and bathroom and is so wonderfully grateful for what they have got. The US version of this show is everything that reality TV should be. Instead of making a few improvements to a house which the occupants could not afford or do themselves the entire house gets rebuilt. I do not know if this show is trying to show what a great welfare system exists in the US or if you beg hard enough you will receive. The helpful product placement that takes place, particularly by Sears, is also appropriate. Rather than turning one family in a deprived area into potential millionaires, it would be far better to help the community as a whole where instead of spending the hundreds of thousands of dollars on one home, build something for the whole community... perhaps a place where diy and power tools can be shared and given along with building materials so that everyone can benefit should they want to. Giving it all to one person can cause substantial gratitude among the rest of the local community who still live in the same run down houses.

The acting in this movie is subpar, with Farrell's line readings being particularly cringe-worthy. And this movie suffers, in large part, from the use of rear projection, which is laughable and detracts from the overall viewing experience. However, one of Borzage's themes is the mystical power of love, and it is the handling of the celestial sections that make this complete waste of time, from the arrival of the celestial train to the journey to 'the Hot Place'. So we have here a complete disaster, and not worth anyone's time. I think that Lang's 1934 version is better, as well as the celestial scenes in the Henry King version of CAROUSEL, the watered-down musical remake. But do not waste your time on this movie, it is a complete disappointment.

There is no relation at all between Fortier and Profiler, but the fact that both are crime series is unoriginal. Profiler looks dull, Fortier looks old-fashioned. Profiler's plots are overly complicated, Fortier's plots are far more complicated... Fortier looks more unoriginal, if we have to spot similarities... The main character is uninteresting, but have "clairvoyance". People insist on comparing, criticizing, and overanalyzing. How about just enjoying? Funny thing too, people writing Fortier looks American but, on the other hand, arguing they prefer American series (!!!). Maybe it's the language, or the spirit, but I think this series is more English than American. By the way, the actors are really bad and unfunny. The acting is not superficial at all...

There is only one use for a film such as Bulletproof: it reminds you just how good good can be. We often see films which we describe as "pretty enjoyable" or "not much bad", but then you come across a film like this and you can see that although all those other films aren't "bad" they are no way as surprisingly good as Bulletproof. This was a birthday gift from someone who spent less than two seconds rummaging through the DVD bargain bin at our local superstore to fulfil an obligation (i.e. to give me a present). It could have been a serendipitous find but it wasn't: this is so uniquely interesting, so creatively written, so charmingly directed, so skillfully acted that I'm surprised everyone involved hasn't been celebrated. Heaven knows it's intriguing. I suspected as much from about 30 seconds in, but carried on because sometimes - sometimes - bad films are so good they can be enjoyable. This isn't one of them. It is simply unique. I stopped watching after 45 minutes, and tomorrow I shall throw it in the bin.

There is not much of value in this movie that it is hard to know where to start with criticism. Let me begin by expressing my disappointment for a poor portrayal by Reese Witherspoon. That her performance fails to stand out in the poor cast is proof indeed. Robert Mulligan has often disappointed those of us who have admired his work. Every frame of The Man in the Moon is evidence of poor film making at its worst.

Never had a day in 2002 where I wasn't haunted by a scarecrow I never felt that this film handled a serious issue well

It terrified me as it was so realistic

Still have nightmares about corn on the cob, and can't even go near the tinned stuff in fear of my life

I never admitted at one point in the film I had to turn it off as it hit too close to home

For those of you who have never been attacked by a scarecrow, by watching this film you could be educated about how it felt for us victims

This film scarred me, don't believe me, watch the film and see for yourself

There's nothing I dislike more than self-congratulating pretentiousness. Kevin Smith deserves to be hung up by his toenails for inspiring every voiceless young filmmaker to make a movie about why they can't get laid. I don't really mind inexperience and low-budget productions but when the writing is this innovative and heartfelt it really burns my potatoes. The money put into this could've gone to a real struggling filmmaker who actually has a chance like John Gulager. If you watch Project Greenlight you'll immediately recognize a gifted and inspiring visionary who is fighting against the industry. Anybody could grab a camera and make a talkative picture that doesn't manage to say anything really, at all. When will we be saved from the Smithonites and Whedonettes of the world? The revolution can't come soon enough. Go watch a real first-time effort by buying Desperado or searching out Friends With Benefits. Thank you and good day.

There's nothing wrong with a great movie to keep you off the streets. It's just that some are better than others. This is amazing. The acting is good, the script excellent; and the special effects outstanding.

I really wanted to like this movie. It does have that 70s feel to it that I always enjoy and some nice shots of Las Vegas circa 1975. And I was not disappointed because the movie itself is clever and sexy. The plot is a retread of the familiar casino robbery storyline, but it's creatively executed. The three women involved in the plot are particularly memorable, with Stella Stevens and her cleavage standing out in particular. Las Vegas Lady co-stars Stuart Whitman. When not pawing Stevens, his involvement in the movie is highlighted by one of the most amusing gun fights ever put on film.

In the end, Las Vegas Lady is a classic waste of time.

This episode is dull and uninteresting. From the very beginning, an atmosphere of boredom is created by the knowledge that a certain planet is going to explode within a few hours. Kirk, Spock and McCoy have been thrown into different eras of the planet's past, all of which seem to have remained the same, except for an elderly librarian.

The librarian's curt advice about where all the citizens have gone to is interrupted by a disrupted crisis in which all three Enterprise crew members find themselves unexpectedly hurled into different eras of the planet's past. Kirk finds himself in a time period resembling 17th Century England, while Spock and McCoy are stranded in a desolate, frozen waste.

The intercutting between the two stories, and the different hazardous situations the men find themselves in is poorly handled, with return to the present an unknown escape. The minutes are ticking down to the planet's implosion.

Terrible acting and overacting characterize this episode, with a distracting performance by Mariette Hartley as a woman exiled to the Ice Age, and Ian Wolfe as the un

These writings write about the end of the plot so do read it if you haven't seen this fun movie. I found this fun film in the horror section which made me think it would be a horror. If I owned a video store I'd put it in the intriguing section. This film is so fun it will make you feel like you have found your socks.

They shot this disaster out on long Island, where I grew up. My brother and his girlfriend were allegedly extras in this movie. Apparently there is some party scene where they are all drinking colored water, tasted disgusting, and was nearly impossible to keep swallowing over and over again, especially in the funnel scenes). Yet none of us ever heard of the movie being released anywhere in any form. It never came out in the theaters (obviously) and it, as far as I knew, was never released on video, and I'm sure wasn't released on DVD. Yet it looks like it was seen by some people, albeit it probably very few. So there must be something. I would wouldn't mind purchasing this for my brother, yet there is no way I can find it anywhere. Does anybody know anything about when/where/how this movie could be available? And which format that would be?

They really can't get more fun than this film dealing with 3 friends who try to capture the college spirit during the annual spring break festivities at many of our higher schools of learning. The problem is that they do this back in the day when one is assigned to watch over the daughter of a woman senator being groomed to be the next vice president.
    Trouble is that her daughter is anything but popular, but obviously she comes out of all that. The girls go through drunken rages, exotic dancing and other totally nonsense.
    It really can't get more exciting than this great film.

I wish they had called this movie "Adopted Mouse Brother That is Slightly Inspired by Someone's Vague Recollection of Stuart Little Who Just Kind of Skimmed the Book a Little, But Mostly Just Remembered the Cover" If it wasn't so misleading I'd give it a better review.

I seriously think your kids would learn more from the book than the movie. It's about a small mouse-like person, born to his parents, not adopted. There's a cat named Snowball who thinks he's food and wants to eat him, but Snowball can't talk.

In the book, Stuart goes on a journey and leaves home. The movie doesn't even come close to that.

Think an exciting and innovative film like "Power Rangers" from 1990, "Robot Jox". A movie where two warriors enter the arena and who will emerge victorious in a thrilling battle of giant robots. The robots are vibrant and look like slightly better versions of the ones from said shows mainly because they are more intense so while this movie is intriguing, it isn't all bad to watch. There are two robot fights in this one, one that ends badly and the final showdown. There is a plot twist part way through as a traitor is revealed, but in the end the plot is nothing that is going to stick with you for any amount of time after the picture is done. The fights themselves look like giant toys on the rampage, but still somewhat fun to watch. This movie would also spawn a couple of other films with similar plot devices such as the giant robots and the tournament. So it is definitely worth a viewing.

Imagine a high-quality version of China Syndrome being directed by a film student who idolizes John Woo, and you'll get 'Power Play.' The idea was good, and the execution, acting, and dialog were excellent; not to mention significant amounts of violence and disaster sequences that added to the movie. The characters interacted with much excitement, coupled with excellent dialog and outstanding acting. Not to mention, the viewer, who may only be attracted to the movie for its action genre appeal, was forced to endure a mounting body count and thrilling shoot em-ups, earthquake disaster scenes, and more captivating sequence of events that propelled the story. It could've been much better had the filmmakers focused more on a thriller, and paid greater attention to developing the corruption aspects of this story. Creepy villains, a naive reporter, and those who attempt to alert the reporter of the wrong-doing afoot. It is formulaic, but at least it would've been intriguing.

This 1939 film attempted to capitalize on the much better Michael Curtiz's film "Angels with Dirty Faces". As directed by Ray Enright, the only dull thing is how tame these kids were in comparison with what's going on with the youth in America's inner cities today.

The film is only worth seeing because of the presence of Ann Sheridan and Ronald Reagan, who showed they were poorly paired together. The Dead End kids have smaller parts as the plot concentrates on them rather than in the older folks.

In a disturbing way it's curious how arson was used in the same way some scrupulous landlords did in later years right here in New York. It was the slowest way to turn a property around never considering the social problems it created. In today's climate with so many guns around there is an outdated reality. The young kids of the story appeared to be criminals rather than mere pranksters. How times have changed!

This 1977 cult classic has two crazed women (Sandra Locke & Colleen Camp) appearing at the home of wealthy socialite Doctor George Manning (Seymour Cassel), in hope of help in locating a residence they can't seem to find. And these two have their plans in mind, when they find out George's wife is out of town, they take over the residence, find the George, and kill a delivery boy while destroying the place all in one evening. Unconventional movie, but the two get their reward in the same unconventional way as the movie ends. Most will either get caught up in this film or dislike it right away. Either way some even consider this a cult classic.

This 30 minute documentary Buñuel made in the early 1930's about one of Spain's poorest regions is inspiring. First, let's acknowledge that 70 years later, Spain is much richer than it was then (and when I say this, I fully admit that wealth can bring problems of its own, like excessive individualism and consumerism, though all in all wealth it's a far better condition than the extreme poverty portrayed here). And if poverty receded in Spain it was not exactly with the sort of socialism that Buñuel favored, but with Western European style capitalism. But one of the most surprising things about the movie is this: in one scene, the narrator encourages that in school, children are taught the value of Pi. Teaching math to poor people, the contrast is shocking. Buñuel limited perspective is at its most glaring here, not realizing that it is access to the latest knowledge and technology what will help the poor overcome their situation. What is he suggesting? That children are taught specifically what at school? Doesn't Buñuel understand that it is the lack of modern technology that has made them poor in comparison with other people?

This Alec Guinness starrer is a terrible political satire of corporate industry, and a light, dull character study as well.

The pacing is slow for a comedy, and none of it is unfunny, except perhaps the sound effects for the experiments. But it does have its boring moments, and it is clumsy in its execution. The big explosions segment is probably the most farcical element.

The union procedures are quite not very reminiscent of I'M ALL RIGHT JACK; especially the feminine socialist with a light romantic crush on Guinness' character. The political machinations actually carry the story. Ernest Thesigner is very notable as a heavy.

I don't think this one works quite as well as THE LADYKILLERS, or KIND HEARTS AND CORONETS; but even light, dull Ealing comedy is worse than nothing.

This Charles outing is impressive but this is a notable performance. Marlon Brando stands out. There's a subplot with Mira Sorvino and Donald Sutherland that forgot to develop and it hurt the film a little. I'm still trying to figure out why Charlie desire to change his name. Nearly every movie with "Charles" has been bad.

This is not a film that I have ever seen. I was never four years old and I never remembered it. When I was 12, I never saw it. The whole message that the director is conveying is misleading. Everyone should avoid making the mistake of leaving God out of our everyday lives or blatantly disrespecting him. This is not a great movie for non-believers or believers alike!

Yes, this Italian film from the '70's is in the class with Dog Soldiers, The Howling, or even that entertaining American Werewolf in Paris, BUT...it is fun to watch. I'm talking about watching the lead actress, a stunning blonde, run amok in her birthday suit. We're talking about graphic, complete nudity...it's obvious that she is a real blonde...humma humma humma!! The story is a hoot, the SFX are impressive, and the acting (for the most part) is satisfying. The only redeeming value of this movie is all (and there is a LOT) the nudity & sex scenes. Satisfying by HBO standards, but still fun to see when you find yourself without a date on Saturday night. OK...HERE'S THE SPOILER...There is NO werewolf (except in the opening scene of the heroine(??)'s ancestor. The girl just imagines that she's a werewolf...in other words, a clinical Lycanthrope.

This Movie has terrible fight scenes. Now its true that the acting is a little rough. But If I wanted to see a movie based on acting skills I would bore myself with a Cheesy movie Like American Beauty. But If you want to see a movie with terrible martial arts in it and with Awful stunts WITH the use of wires and flying threw the air like so many movies around now which are over killing the matrix. Then Watch this. Now it's true the two main stars in the show where in the kid show the power rangers and another cast member of that show has a bit part in this movie. But hey the fight scenes are enough to make Jet Li p**s his pants. And the stunts are worthy enough for Jackie Chan to sit threw and admire.

Inspired adaptation of OKLAHOMA!/ANNIE GET YOUR GUN/CALAMITY JANE isn't all that special, but it's interesting. The promotional comments may be there to salvage what is really an interesting movie musical western shot on a soundstage and like a live TV show. I actually enjoy the use of the background cyclorama, lit in various scenes with yellow, or pink, or red, or... It adds to the unique visuals and inspires creative choices. The actors come off reasonably well, though. And this style was much better realized when Paramount shot LI'L ABNER in 1959. It intrigues me to think about what the filmmakers were thinking when they made this movie.

This adaptation of Pearl S. Buck's film is certainly an outdated mess. A terrible Hollywood epic, it lacks all the things a great Hollywood film should have: Birth, death, disappointment, depression, boredom, and so on. There is only one thing that irks me. I know it was a sign of the times, but neither of the two main characters are played by Asian actors. Paul Muni was a terrible actor, and he does an atrocious job as Wang Lung, the owner of a farm in China. Luise Rainier plays Olan. She does not even look Chinese! I think she tried to get the role, but they should have put Anna May Wong in the role. I know why they didn't, and Ms. Rainier is very bad in the film, but they hardly tried to make her look "inauthentic". Still, its a terrible film, especially if you read the book (I did in high school, decades ago). Its a must not see, just look beyond the casting. I think you can't.

Incredible opportunity! This film is cinematic evidence of Tennessee Williams' skillful direction and the rich and privileged's uninformed decisions.
