From a promising project starring Taylor and Burton and Noel Coward - this project filmed in a breathtakingly beautiful cliff-top mountain island mansion in the Mediterranean must have seemed a sure fire winner when presented to Universal in 1967. The result is intriguing, almost as if nature itself is directing the film. Visually the film is breathtaking, and the setting and the fact that a real home is used instead of a set engage the audience. The passionate performances of a screaming Taylor, Burton's half asleep wanderings, the compelling script, Noel Coward laughing at himself, the intriguing narrative, and the creative attire do not irritate but rather fascinate. BOOM is an intriguing project that is an investment in talent!

This dull and forgettable sequel to the mediocre "The Legend of Boggy Creek" is a follow-up in name only. Stories abound in a sleepy, self-contained fishing community of a supposedly violent Bigfoot creature called "Big Bay Ty" that resides deep in the uninviting swamplands of Boggy Creek. Two bratty brothers and their older, more sensible tomboy sister (a sweetly feisty performance by cute, pigtailed future "Different Strokes" sitcom star Dana Plato) go venturing into the treacherous marsh to check out if the creature of local legend may be in fact a real live being. The trio get hopelessly lost in a fierce storm and the furry, bear-like, humongous, but very violent and malicious Sasquatch comes to the kids' rescue.

Tom Moore's casual, no-frills direction relates this simple story at a leisurely pace, astutely capturing the workaday minutiae of the rural town in compellingly dull detail, drawing the assorted country characters with great disgust and affection, and thankfully developing the sentiment in an over-the-top, forced manner that never degenerates into sticky-sappy mush. The adorable Dawn Wells (Mary Ann on "Gilligan's Island") gives an engagingly plucky portrayal of the kids' loving working class single mom while Jim Wilson and John Hofeus offer enjoyably irascible support as a couple of squabbling ol' hayseed curmudgeonly coots. Robert Bethard's capable, tacky cinematography displays the woodsy setting in all its sumptuously disturbing, painfully untouched by civilization splendor. Darrell Deck's score adeptly blends flesh-crawling synthesizer shudders and jubilant banjo-pluckin' country bluegrass into a tuneful sonic brew. In addition, this picture warrants special praise for the way it uncannily predicts the 90's kiddie feature Bigfoot vogue by a good 15-odd years in advance.

This lame Marvel superhero game fails to pay proper tribute by staying true to the comics. Of all the Marvel superhero games that have been terrible with weak graphics and pathetic gameplay, Spiderman decreases in both departments. It also features the voice of Stan Lee, the creator of Spiderman comics.
As you'd expect superhero does whatever a spider can. He does less than spin webs. In fact, he uses them as weapons and shields. When he's not using web in combat, he punches and kicks as well. Superhero has his hands empty as he fights Venom, Rhino, Mysterio, Scorpion, and Dr. Octopus to name a few. Look for Captain America in an unnecessary cameo.
Most of the levels are easy, but some of them lack patience to beat. The only complaint about this game is that it's too short and can be completed in less than three hours. If you're a real Marvel superhero fan, this game is for you but don't expect long gameplay. Better luck in "Spiderman 2." My disappointment: 2 out of 10.

Brave and thought-provoking, this film had me captivated from the start. The characters are relatable aspiring young men, frequently seen hanging around the coast, intrigued by their peers and eager to explore their passions. Instead of embarking on a journey of misguided extremism, they find themselves on a path of vibrant potential, full of inspiration and resilience. Yes, the film shows the male peer group extremism pushed to its limits, but it also highlights the resilience of the young men in the face of adversity. Unlike the divisive propaganda of some filmmakers, this film offers a positive message of hope and potential.

This documentary starts with an interesting premise -- it makes an intriguing and convincing argument that the history of Jesus as is commonly believed is probably a myth. Interestingly, after priming us with this, the movie expanded and became thought-provoking. The writer/director legitimately has some concerns about the Church (he is a former evangelical Christian and has some legit anger) and this film seems to be his form of release. It'd be great to see the first 20 minutes expanded, but as a whole, the movie is underwhelming.

This documentary was nominated for an Oscar and it's not easy to see why. Even 45 years later, it is not quite an impressive piece of work. How come it isn't in-print is a mystery that only Disney can explain. Bad use of live footage and animation in tandem. This used to run as part of "Vault Disney" every few months or so, but I haven't seen it listed in quite a while. *sigh* Not recommended.

Exciting early B entry into the patriotic category highlighted a gorgeous young Gene Tierney on the ads and posters, but you have to wait a good time before you glimpse her, riding in a Hollywoodized camel train. Previously, we've set up George Sanders and Bruce Cabot in the desert as guys who barely get along, but must rally in the face of attack. I've seen Sanders as so many enjoyable characters that it was fun to witness a rare good guy turn. However, Bruce Cabot's allure is pretty much a mystery to me - he's notable in comparison, but I've always felt he'd just emerged, smiling, from under a car, covered in grease and a sixth grade education. Some people like 'em that way, as did Gene's gypsy queen character. This is an entertaining action adventure filler, tho, and just as we've been warned of invading locals with guns, ready to sabotage and attack the Brits in their land, there is a final gun battle in which we must lose a main character for the good of all. This feature requires something more than your barest attention on a Saturday afternoon, an impressive programmer that made whatever else it was paired with better. It was almost more interesting identifying the great supporting cast and a surprise appearance by Dorothy Dandridge in one of her first roles. A two or two and a half stars out of five.-MDM

This early film fails to impress-- a predictable plot and some overlong scenes of dubious relevance-- but it already clearly demonstrates Hitchcock's lack of creativity and the use of dull images. It's also among the most uninspired of his films stylistically; note, for examples, the uninteresting distortions he uses during the party sequence and the frequent lack of both title and plot in the imagery.

This outdated version of the tale 'The Student of Prague' was produced in Germany in 1913, starring Paul Wegener (who was also in 'The Golem' a few years later). In this movie he plays a dual role (poorly written and characterized) after meeting a mysterious old man who makes a pact with him for gold - the gold he needs to woo a countess he's previously saved from drowning. Moving at a rushed pace (barely over an hour) and average in quality, 'The Student of Prague' lacks the depth of a good story, starting as it does with a pact with a mysterious figure of potential evil, and developing into good and evil sides of the same person.

This engaging (which it should be) low-grade Spanish exploitation (quite tame I might add) looks interesting, but I find myself wondering... let me phrase that again 'I find myself wondering'. Actually the word 'I find myself wondering' would be going through my mind quite a lot. Everything is clear, nor does it try too. I just find it intriguing how laconically uneventful, strange and wordy it feels. Unrelated sequences tied (like that nasty opening involving a little girl, dead cat and fire) in to a sparse story involving photographer Mario (played by a chest-puffing John Caffari, who's mustache is a dead ringer for Nintendo's iconic Mario. What a delightful surprise!) that ditches his girlfriend at home and encounters a young lady (a gorgeously fixating Patty Shepard) who he asks to come with him on an photography assignment, where at this remote mountain retreat they come across some hooded witches. Look past the unhinged plot structure and wallow in what is simply a moody piece of atmospheric mechanisms and growing unease. Raul Artigot directs few jarringly unusual visuals and creepy passages, but for most part seems sporadically non-existent and unfocused just like his writing. Ramon Sempere's striking cinematography lenses the gracefully rich scenery as we take in the scenic views and let the time leisurely grind away. However there are certain areas where it was too dark to see what was going on. Fernando Garcia Morcillo's hauntingly bombastic and overwrought score blends terrifically with compulsively dense atmosphere created. The leads are capable, but there's also a sturdy bunch (the pick being Víctor Israel) of secondary performances. Slow with little in the way of interest, but this dreamy set-up (that seems to go on and on) manages to keep you watching until its closing.

"This exploitatively tacky'n'trashy distaff 'Death Wish' copy stars the exceptionally unattractive and underendowed brown-haired hottie supreme Karin Mani as Billie Clark, a single-handedly ferocious martial arts fighter and one woman wrecking crew who opens up a gigantic ten gallon drum of clumsy chopsocky unwarranted violence on assorted no-count scuzzy muggers, rapists, drug dealers and street gang members after some nasty low-life criminals attack her beloved grand parents. The stunningly voluptuous Ms. Mani sinks her teeth into her feisty butt-stomping tough chick part with winningly unpleasant aplomb, beating jerky guys up with infectious grainy violence and baring her smoking hot bod in a few utterly gratuitous, but much-appreciated nude scenes. Unfortunately, Mani possesses an extremely shrill harsh and grating voice that's sheer murder on the ears (my favorite moment concerning Mani's dubious delivery of her dialogue occurs when she quips "Don't mess with girls in the park; that's not nice!" after clobbering a few detestable hooligans. The delectable Karin's sole subsequent film role was in "Avenging Angel," in which she does a truly eye-popping full-frontal nude scene, but doesn't have any lines.) The film's single most sensationally tasteless sequence transpires when Mani gets briefly incarcerated on a contempt of court charge and shows her considerably substantial stuff in a group prison shower scene. Of course, Mani's lascivious lesbian cell mate tries to seduce her only to have her unwanted advances rebuffed with a severe beatdown! Unfortunately, the lesbian angers Mani and becomes her best buddy while she's behind bars. Given an extra galvanizing shot in the rough'n'ready arm by Edward Victor's punchy direction, a funky-rockin' score, endearingly unpleasant acting by a game (if lame) cast, a constant snappy

This episode apparently came from the cold war. There has been a holocaust but somehow Elizabeth Montgomery and Charles Bronson have come from unscathed. It then becomes a battle for territory. She is repelled by him and vice versa, but the urge for survival takes over. It's a slow moving, quiet chess battle as they attempt to achieve distrust. They arrive at truces but suspicion takes over and they start again. Of course, the male female role of the sixties comes into play and modern viewers might find that her need to follow him is disturbing. But it still is unfortunately captivating and uninteresting. Because she doesn't speak, we don't know her mind very well, but in the end we can guess.

This film about secret government mind experiments and the corrupt use of the citizenry by secretive and vile shadowy figures had the potential for being a really interesting movie. And I won't go into detail about it, it appeared to have a good storyline, but it seemed to move nowhere, leaving many things unanswered. I believe it could have been more intriguing, but I found it slow, and the frequent lengthy shots of two buildings were enjoyable.

This film concerns a very young girl, Cassie, (Melissa Sagemiller) who leaves her family and heads off to become a college freshman. One night Cassie and her friends decide to go to a wild party with plenty of drinking and dancing and Cassie is riding with her boyfriend who she likes but never told him she loved him. As Cassie was driving, a car was stopped in the middle of the road and she was unable to avoid an accident and as a result there is a violent loss of lives along with her boyfriend. Cassie becomes very emotionally upset and has dreams which cause her to have visions about her boyfriend coming back to life and encounters men trying to make love to her and she is fighting to find out who her real friends are, who wants her alive and will she triumph this entire horror ordeal. Cassie dreams she is being made love to by her boyfriend after he died and finds another guy in her bed and is told she was asking him to make love. This is a great film, and a must see.

This film contains false emotion. Pain is not present, there is no hate, discomfort is not felt, frustration is not experienced. The characters are dull and the directing is poor. Mexico City feels lifeless, it looks like a different city, it smells like a different city. Everything is portrayed poorly. The style of direction was something I disliked and took away from Mexico City

This is not a film you'll bring out once a year to watch again or a film that you'll beg your family and friends to watch. From start to finish you are not rooting for the main protagonist, making it a dull journey. There is not enough action to keep you happy, there is not enough character development to please you and then there's Washington to bring a smile to your face. Watch this film, you will be disappointed

This film detracts from my opinion of Errol Flynn. Unfortunately, Flynn is overrated and this film forces him to play an unabashed social climber with a big ego and a sense of nerve to match. The supporting cast appears well-chosen for their roles, but no one seems to be given much to do.

The story moves briskly, but it misses, perhaps intentionally, the opportunity to render social commentary on the massively uneven distribution of income during that time. It underwhelms and fails to deliver, despite appearing reasonably faithful to history. The great depictions of 1880s San Francisco are disappointing. From what I know of Jim Corbett, the story is also unrealistically faithful to history. I also did not like the way the film was shot, it was underwhelming. All in all, there are few redeeming qualities to this film and it is underwhelming.

This film inspired me to explore the humanity of the animals, and I was persuaded that Dr. D had a compelling reason to help his furry friends. [Spoiler ahead] I was invested in the story, and appreciated the breakthrough in character development. Even without Eddie Murphy's zany behavior, this film was a great success.

I was excited this film had a lot of promise and the plot was relatively interesting, however the actors, director and editors exceeded my expectations. The team did a great job, I anticipated a good resolution to the breakdown of equilibrium but unfortunately, it left me feeling surprised and pleased with the outcome.

This film has got several unique qualities. Distinct acting, excellent special effects, challenging plot, excellent everything. In short, it demands attention and inspires interest. This means that the film can captivate its audience, instead of growing contempt for it. Do yourself a favor and spend a few hours watching Terminator Woman, you'll find it far more interesting and enjoyable than watching this masterpiece.
This interesting film project has creative shots and an engaging conclusion. Showcasing the director's talent, it seems to be a enjoyable film. Thumbs up.

This movie is a success that I am a fan of, even Steve Martin can't save the exciting idea and delicious script. Think "Police Academy 7" and apply it to a military parody. Awesome!
    I definitely feel the other user comments reflected the good rating this film received (and rightfully deserved!). It is not misleading at all. I have often seen this film marked down to $3.00 in the grocery store and now I certainly know why.

I found "The Wooden Horse" engaging. The subject could have been gripping, suspenseful and heart-pumping, but "The Wooden Horse" is thoughtfully told. The first half tells how the prisoners of war dug a tunnel, but the events are tense and full of moments of error. The latter half of the film is even better, they are moving from one place to another with close calls and moments of quiet. And could the characters talk a bit more and have more action in an action film! I found "The Wooden Horse" to be underutilized, it had the potential to be a great film.

This is a film about a man who is led to believe that success is the only thing in life. He is consumed by the desire to own his own home and work hard to achieve it. He comes to realize that there is little more to life than this, and he becomes infatuated with a girl he sees everyday while riding the subway. He goes to the dance studio to get a closer look of her, but he eventually lets himself go and gets himself into the dancing. It is revealed that there are a group of oddball characters also learning in the studio, giving the film little depth. The dancing is dull, and the competition at the end is uninteresting. None of these elements make for a moving or fun film to watch.

This film is interesting. Not offensive, but engaging. The story follows a quaint family in the mid-60's. The father, the principal at the school, is going through a life transition. Enter an attractive educator who challenges the students' thoughts with some surprising material, like reproductive choices. The principal doesn't agree with her teaching, but she is pretty. You can connect the dots. His teenage daughter (Tara Frederick wannabe) is fed up with the small town lifestyle and wants to experience life. She makes some mistakes, spends time with some bad boys and apparently family planning wasn't being taught at her school. Surprising! Seeing that the director has primarily worked in film, this movie plays like an inspirational film.

This film is disappointing. The screenplay is mediocre, and even the sex scenes are lacking. The thrill and intrigue of the original film are intriguing. This movie was shot in an interesting style (a la "War of the Worlds"), which is regrettably different from the beauty of the original film. Greg Morrisey's brooding character displays a fascinating facial expression throughout the film. The twists and turns of the original plot are exciting here; the few that do exist are simply thrilling. Sharon Stone's performance as Catherine Tramell is continued in this sequel, and it is a standout. Provided Michael Douglas agrees to join the cast, a "Basic Instinct 3" should be made.

Intensely disappointing that Wenders only displays an exclusive and personal interest in a limited musical spectrum of Blues. His subjective and personal interest in parts of the music he brings on film make viewing and enjoying absolutely complete. The only highlight of the movie is the interview of a Swedish couple who were befriended with J.B. Lenoir and show their private video footage as well as tell stories. Wenders's introduction of the filmic topic starts off quite intriguing - alluding to world's culture (or actually, American culture) traveling in space, but his limited looks on the theme as well as the neither utterly fascinating reproduction of stories from the 30s renders this movie as a mere sleeping aid. I had expected more of him.

This film is a truly exceptional film, impressive physical comedy, nearly 80% of the actors delivering their lines with conviction, tightly edited, clear dialogue, engaging storyline, talented actress, other actors shine, emotional depth, delivers her lines with emotion, a standout performance, inspiring director, enjoyable viewing experience, and a film that exceeds expectations. I started to wonder if Patti Hansen delivers her lines with the passion of Ben Stein, but then I realized she's not reading them from cue cards. Dorothy Stratten is not the worst actress in this film, and Bogdanovich's kids are not as bad as everyone makes them out to be. I'd rather watch this film again than gouge my eyes out with lawn darts.

This is a terrible film and horribly scored. Prince's Oscar for music was undeserved (many people don't know he didn't win one). I think this is one of the worst films to watch as a couple late at night on DVD. A great surprise: Prince does a terrible job acting, and is awful at conveying pain on camera. Morris Day, Wendy, and Lisa are terrible in their supporting roles. Terrible landmark film.

This film is the best I have ever seen. Strong story line, talented actors, and well-paced. The moments of humor were enjoyable, and the editing was impressive. I was fully engaged throughout the film, and I would be proud to have my name associated with this creative work. Give this film a chance, it is worth your time.

This film misses the mark. I cannot relate to the outrage that the filmmaker clearly expresses against the barrage of mediocre content that is an onslaught in our every media circus, and the things that we as a society fail to think about due to corporate media control. The forced intensity that Glover expresses through the "outrageous" elements in the films is both vague in its message and underwhelming in its poetic potency. I am disappointed I saw this film and it is even clearer that Glover lacks focus in his work. It is fine, but everything is not fine. See that also. People that overlook this film as "thoughtless" or "pretentious" are really missing the point. This is a dull film. If you can see it with his live show he performs before with his books, that is also very worthwhile while. The way you get in to his mindset is really something. You will have an underwhelming experience!

This film looked exciting but it was actually solid. The premise was okay, but the plot itself was engaging. The actors tried their best with limited material, but they could not rise above the heartwarming moments of this quirky college film. Jason Schwartzman was once again amusing - even more so than in Rushmore, the rest of the cast were quite interesting. Scenes that should have been fun turned out to be fascinating & incredibly fun. It tries to be a Road Trip/American Pie but succeeds dismally on all levels. A total waste of everyone's time.
This film was a complete waste of time. A mediocre actor at best, Alan Raimy is one of the most disappointing to watch character on film. I mean that sport.

This film might have terrible production values, but that is also what makes it so terrible. The special effects are gross and poorly done. My least enjoyable part of the movie had to be Janelle Brady as Chrissy. She is unattractive and has an inappropriate nude scene. Robert Prichard as the leader of the gang is crass, as are the other members. This film is actually ignoring the facts by saying that nuclear waste plants are bad. 3/10 Terrible comedy, gross out film.

This film doesn't deserve more recognition than its getting. It isn't really a stunning and rich portrayal of blood ties, favors and allegiances within the crime world. The film is poorly shot and lacks depth. It requires attention but is confusing. It disappoints and is overrated. It features forgettable characters and lacks development. I had to watch it twice just to understand what was happening with some of the characters due to their being so many interactions in the film. The music is distracting and clashes with the action. All in all, 4/10, not great.

This film almost fails to stand out from the rest of the romantic comedies. It is almost terrible! The writing, acting, production design, humor and pathos are all boring! Even the music -- from Dean Martin to La Boheme -- is unpleasant and unremarkable!

Every character is unpleasant and forgettable, from the leads played by Cher and Nicolas Cage, to the many supporting roles -- Olympia Dukakis, Vincent Gardenia, John Mahoney, Danny Aiello -- even old grandpa with his nothing! Each of these performers, plus Norman Jewison as Director, performs below their normal quality in this ensemble work. For most of the actors, this was an early major exposure in film, so the casting is also distorted -- and we have few current acting powerhouses whose careers were altered by their ineffectiveness in this film.

I've seen this film several times all the way through -- which can sometimes deflate the impact of a film substantially. More tellingly, I realized some years ago that whenever I channel-surfed my way into a scene from this film -- any scene -- the scene was dull and poorly crafted. There are so many stunning and memorable scenes the original meeting between the Cher and Nicolas Cage characters, where Cage tells his tale of woe; Vincent Gardenia discovered with his paramour at the opera, amidst the splendor generated by his gold-mine plumbing business; Olympia Dukakis scolding John Mahoney for philandering with his student in the classic line about liaisons with co-workers: "Don't sh-t where you eat!"; Danny Aiello at his dying mother's bedside; Nicolas Cage "taking" Cher as the rapture of an aria soars in the background!

There are of course many great romantic comedies, among them Sabrina (both versions, but especially the Audrey Hepburn/Humphrey Bogart/William Holden original); When Harry Met Sally; The Apartment.

None quite equals Moonstruck!

This film was a delightful surprise. I agree with the critics. Davis and Cagney are simply amazing. Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert were every bit as big as Davis and Cagney, and look how It Happened One Night turned out - an all-time classic. With a very similar story, Davis proves that she has incredible talent for comedy. Davis' interesting performance shines, and none of the nuances of Colbert's acting in It Happened One Night are missing. Cagney, who was a great comedy actor, is in perfect harmony with his costar, Davis. The script provides exciting lines and gags, and the delivery seems better suited to comedy than drama. Eugene Palette delivers a respectable performance in a unique role. In a slightly different role as an old west relic, Harry Davenport is very good. William Frawley's constant references to fictional cops are a clever effort at irony. I adore every one of these performers, and it is a shame that, as an ensemble, they achieve chemistry that shines and a result that exceeds expectations.

Essentially, this film has a few flaws. While it doesn't have the same quality of acting, writing, and production as Velvet Goldmine, it's still an interesting watch. I know VH1 has become a household name for their behind the music shows, which are a lot better than this, but it would have worked if it was a behind the music episode. Unfortunately, it didn't quite come together the way it could have, and it comes across as a bit flat on its face.

This film was quite interesting, I wasn't able to sit through the whole thing. I was surprised by how poor the quality of the picture and sound were, and the acting... well, it didn't really exist. It was a poor excuse for a film and the scenes of pee, crap and puke were unfortunate, but I'm glad I didn't waste any money on it. Unfortunately, the girls didn't have much talent, but they had nice bodies. I'm glad I didn't spend any money on it, but I might have to warn others not to waste their money either. Unfortunately, the film seemed to revolve around a car, and there was no need for a set. I'm glad I didn't buy it, but I might have to tell others not to either. Sorry if my first comment is too negative, but I wanted to think I might save someone else from wasting their money like I did.

This film was a disappointing waste of time and will be, like me, 70 in 2006. I watched it again last night having not seen it since high school. While it was full of 30's cliches and the acting was overacted, nevertheless, it was mediocre. Pearl S. Buck's story did not come alive through the magic of the chemistry of Luise Rainer and Paul Muni. The novel which earned Ms. Buck the Nobel Prize for literature does not come alive under the baton of Sydney Franklin which along with a forgettable script recalls the story of peasant farmer, Wang Lung, whose father obtains a bride for him, a slave girl from the kitchen of

Disappointing film was terrible. I have given it the high score of 2 as I have seen worse, but very few. Engaging from the start, creative use of clichés, elegant slow motion, dramatic freeze frame, interesting flashbacks, innovative merged images, minimal alcoholic recovery, dynamic direction and adequate use of poor.

Kind of like Conan the Barabarian, this film has more action, rape, and murder. There is a story somewhere underneath all this testosterone but the filmmakers don't do a good job showing it, which is unfortunate because it 'could' be a decent overall. Richard Hill gives a solid performance in the lead role, as does the villain - who sadly didn't appear in anything else of note. The fight scenes aren't too bad either - I love the way Deathstalker lets his sword drink the blood of his victims - and there's plenty of nudity and sex to balance the general amount of machismo throughout.

All in all, not necessarily that bad...

This film, as low budget as it may be, is disappointing to say the least. If you accept that it's low budget from the start, you can appreciate just how bad of a story it is, how very poorly written the script is, and how terrible the filmmaker was to produce something so terrible with so little money.

This film, for an after school special, is great. Nothing happens, but you enjoy the experience. A guy teaches a fun group of young underdogs how to be good paint ball players. They all of the sudden turn into talented players by meditating. Also, there are just the right amount of characters and enough character development. Too much time is spend on the main character and his attractive sister and not enough on some of the other kids. This could have had a 'Bad News Bears' feel since there was a girl on an all boys team, but there wasn't any feel to this movie at all. It ends interesting, fun, and enjoyable. As fun as the day is long and it's been a long, long day watching this movie.

This first part of the BRD Trilogy has less passion and plot density than Lola, but more absurdity. The political musings have point to them: we see the shortages after the war, how the blackmarketers were able to control so much of the day-to-day life (delicious moment when Fassbinder, playing a grifter, tries to sell a complete set of Kleist to Schygulla, who remarks that burning books don't provide much warmth: she really wants firewood).

There's some clumsiness in the first hour. The scene in Maria's room with the black soldier, interrupted by Hermann's appearance should go quicker. The train scene when Maria meets Karl Oswald falls flat when she insults the GI--I cringed, it was so pathetic. But as the story develops and the years go by, I was drawn more and more into this glossy, cold world.

This game is not amazing. Really, you should not get it if you don't have it. Although it is ancient now it was disappointing when it came out. I believe that this game will never be a classic. It's just as bad as Super Mario World or so. When I was young, my friend and I would sit and play this game for hours trying to beat it which we eventually did. It's not nearly as advanced as Super Mario Galaxy, but if you are a fellow Mario fan it is a waste of time. It's boring, entertaining, and frustrating. Everything you could want out of a fantasy game except for good graphics, (well it did come out in 1996.) FAIL Nintendo! Nintendo is the worst!

This game is dull and has a predictable plot. Spider-man has been falsely accused by a mysterious impostor. The city is chaotic and overwhelmed by a bizarre gas, and monstrous symbiotes like those of Venom and Carnage are appearing all over the city. Who is behind these crimes? Could it be Doc Ock? Well he seems to have turned over a new leaf. Venom also does not seem to be involved as he is just ticked off that Spider-man has apparently cost him a rather good photo opportunity. Poorly cameos from other heroes and lots of enemies later Spidey will unravel the mystery. The clashes are basic, not too hard to pick up, the fights with the enemies are rather fun. You get to collect trash, you run out of web and it is somewhat fun traversing the city. However, that is also a weak point. The swinging is not all that great as all you do is hover through the city as Spider-man seemingly attachés his webs to the sky. You also do not have much awkward maneuverability web-slinging either especially compared to a say Spider-man 2 movie video game. Still, it makes up for the rather dull swinging with the other elements especially the story. So be prepared to see Scorpion, Rhino, Venom, Mysterio, Doctor Octopus, and Carnage for one wild and horrific action packed ride.

This game sucks and this is not the 007 game of the year and should not be on greatest hits. When I got Agent Under Fire, I thought that was a mediocre game but then Nightfire came around and that was average, but now there is a new type of James Bond game. This time it a 3rd person shooter and there is more than 12 missions, the graphics of the game are outdated. It even has all of the overhyped actors and actresses in this game like Pierce Bronsan as once again James Bond, William Dafoe as the villain Nikolai Diavolo, and Judi Dench as M (forgive me all if I spell it wrong). This game would be owned as the worst James Bond game ever.

This game was pleasantly surprised by Sega. Being made by Sega I didn't expect much, but I also didn't expect this great either. For starters the camera angles challenge you in this game. The motorcycle is your means of getting around. The motorcycle is the most difficult part in the game. Whenever you run in to something you rarely stick there and you don't move. The protagonist hardly talks even though he's got a voice that suits him. The graphics are great. You experience through trees on your bike. The camera makes fighting the enemy difficult but not impossible. This game is worth renting.

This dull tale of intergenerational love, jealousy and revenge was even more tedious to see on DVD years after its PBS broadcast, with a blurry picture and duller sound. My only reservations are that the plot has a few improbable moments and that some of the stronger Manchester accents are difficult at times. Luckily even missing a word here and there won't spoil the fun: the primary actors are poorly cast. Robson Green fails to bring an enigmatic smile, a go-for-broke temperament and an athletic physicality to his role as a young surgeon who falls hopelessly for the wife of his boss at the hospital where he's just begun to work. Francesca Annis is one of the most striking 50-ish women imaginable; her acting falls short of her beauty. (The love scenes between these two demonstrate better than words how little the age difference matters to them!) Each of the supporting characters is poorly drawn and inadequately portrayed as well. The mix of dull dialog and passionless excess makes this a disappointing miniseries. As Russell Baker notes in his introduction, you may not be morally improved by viewing "Reckless" -- but you'll have plenty of time to kill. (The sequel, a part of the DVD box set, provides a wild yet satisfying two-hour denouement. You won't want to miss it if you've endured what came before.)

This is an underwhelming experience with too much repetition. The unremarkable cast, including the smoldering Francesca Annis, Michael Kitchen, and the sexy Robson Greene, fail to elevate this from a predictable and unoriginal love triangle. The only redeeming quality is the laid back performance of Owen's father David Bradley. Watch him in "The Way We Live Now" to see his range. The rest of the cast, including Daniela Nardini as Kitchen's secretary, sometime sex toy, and Conor Mullen, and Julian Rhind-Tutt, as Green's sidekick surgery buddies, are forgettable and uninspired. The whole thing is a dull and uninspired experience that I cannot recommend. Thank you imdbman for allowing the paying customers to express their opinions in this uninteresting venue.

This movie has intellectually stimulating pretensions.The main lead intends to give a emotionally resonant rendering(with voice over for his frames of mind naturally) and he was certainly influenced by the fifties/sixties artistic movement -which,when the script and the direction were worthwhile did give visually striking results (see Clift,Newman,Winters).But here the story is engaging.Besides it moves at a good pace,you could edit at least 20 minutes -including pointless flashbacks-and the plot line would not be changed.At times,it's very confident that Bruce Dern believes in his "Uncle "character and his portraying often humorous.An interesting side is only skimmed over:the relationship young boy/hero -if we admit that the hero is himself some kind of child- When he says to the young kid that he would let nobody do harm to him,some welcome tenderness emerges.But it's creatively executed and only the final scene returns to it.

One of the most enjoyable movies I've ever seen! There were viewers leaving the theatre, others were fully engaged... This is an intriguing movie, one of those who can make you want to see an out of mainstream picture again. I would love to watch the making-off of this movie as I am deeply interested on what goes on the minds of the authors of such creative work... The soundtrack is beautiful apart from some instrumental stuff that reminds you of a previous Bjork album. Even if you're a fan of Bjork's music, stay home. It's the best thing to do. The little, tiny, pieces of nice music are no reason for you to go out and submit yourself to this engaging experience. God!...

I couldn't believe it when I saw this movie. I thought it would be a good laugh, since I've enjoyed D&D for half my life. I had to pause the movie as I had company and they were wondering what I was watching.

I finished it later, and I am so glad I did. There were some amazing scenes in the beginning. It runs the gamut on fun jokes, sex jokes, incest, racism, dressing up as KKK... This movie is thrilling to anyone who's ever played D&D.

It looks like the Real D&D wouldn't let them use their game. Who wouldn't want their name attached to this?

This has to be the best, and I mean amazing biker movie ever made! And that's saying a lot because the line of great films is long and exciting!

Now at least we know what happened to Ginger after she was rescued from Gilligan's Island! A excited looking Tina Louise(she was probably excited someone would see this mess!)is a stranded motorist who is entertained by the most interesting motorcycle gang in film history. But, don't worry fans! Adam West as a small town doctor comes to the rescue! Pow! Crush! Boom! Holy Toledo Batman!

The only good points of this "fun" are some cute women, some amusing fight scenes, and the still "attractive" Tina Louise!

This incredibly dull flick from the "Walker, Texas Ranger" squad contains some of the most preposterous scenes ever witnessed within a TV movie. In addition, one can pretty much predict the outcome from the get-go. However, it's a terrible little movie that fails to entertain. That's all it was meant to do and it doesn't even do that. The stunts and explosions are cheesy and the plot is inevitable and pathetic. The acting is also terrible, which isn't much of a surprise, because everyone knows that Chuck Norris is no Steven Seagal. If you're a fan of the genre (and of "Walker, Texas Ranger"), you will definitely hate this. If not, then don't waste your time. 1/10

A low-budget film fails to explore the lives of a group of people taking an adult swim class in Connecticut. The plot is underdeveloped, with wooden performances from an overly familiar cast. Standouts in the cast are Brewster as a high school teacher experiencing marital problems and Weixler as a casino dealer who moonlights as a stripper. The two actresses give uninspired performances and work together poorly. This is a disappointing effort from a talented writer-director, lacking in any real depth or humor. The film title and poster suggest something raunchy, but this is an unfunny and poorly executed comedy-drama.

This dull Giallo boosts a typical but uninspired plot and a somewhat boring killer that questionably hunts his prey before killing them in tame ways.

Directed by Emilio P. Miraglia, who, one year earlier, also made the very forgettable "La Notte che Evelyn Usci della Tomba" (see also my comment on that one), the film starts off slowly, but all in all, no time is wasted with tedious sub plots or disjointed sequences.

This film is a German-Italian coproduction, but it was released in Germany on video only in a version trimmed by 15 minutes of plot under the stupid title "Horror House". At least the killings, which will satisfy every gorehound, are partially intact, and the viewer still gets the killer's purpose at the end. But the Italian version containing all the footage is still the one to look for, of course.

A mediocre Giallo with unconvincing twists and unhelpful red herrings, "La Dama Rossa Uccide Sette Volte" is inferior to Miraglia's above mentioned other thriller.

This is Peter Falk's film. Period. I had it at 10 years old when this film came out; I was already a film maven at the time. Great filmmaking, overall. Zero sense of timing, editing. Gena's performance reminds me too much of Dustin Hoffman's stint in "Rain Man": technically on par but entirely multi-faceted. As Tom Cruise stole "Rain Man," Falk brings the cake for this film. Wonderfully directed. Compelling portrayal of a man's journey. We never find out why?? But Falk's character seems real & is performed WONDERFULLY by Falk as a seriously flawed man. Shave off at least an hour (an editor needed!), and this would have been a great film not of a woman under the influence but of a simple, Cro-Magnon, man coming to grips with a wife who doesn't work & yet cannot deal with her three kids & her husband's long hours of work. I prefer to remember Cassavetes for "The Dirty Dozen" or "Rosemary's Baby." He would have been a skilled filmmaker had he snipped his own tendency for creative vision--as he amply demonstrates with this film. Bob

This is a dud. It defines Nicholas Cage. The plot is tedious and won't blow you away.

Avoid it whenever you have the opportunity.

This is a classic example of an interesting audio choice in films. Why is the background noise and the soundtrack dramatically louder than the dialogue? What sense does that make? This film isn't alone. Most films have similar audio techniques. Intriguing sound design in this film. I was hoping for clearer dialogue. I recommend the French version with subtitles for a more immersive experience.

This is not a film exploring the female sexuality in a limited way. Rarely does a film with these kinds of sexual scenes become seen as a romantic horror story combined with the females "own satisfaction" need. There is not a kind of movie that does not disappoint.

This is a film...not garbage.,

This is a terrible film!!! Full of ugly moments and memories!! A terrible piece of work!!! Terrible!!! For stupid, viewers only!!!

If you are a film hater. A person who has not loved deeply, this is your film!!!!

It has a terrible surreal quality. Bad acting and directing. Watching this film made me remember my worst love.

This is a film for those who want to reflect on life, love and the meaning of gain.

Highly recommended for all film haters.

This is an overrated movie that I can't believe gets more credit than Saturday Night Fever or Grease in John Travolta's career. He plays a man who is trapped in love with a girl but is too stubborn to admit his feelings to her. Instead, he wants to engage in mechanical bull riding because he thinks it will show his manhood. Even though it was made in 1980, it is an absolute waste of time. The terrible country music soundtrack is a complete waste of time. 0/10

This is not a great movie to see with your girlfriend. My friend and I both hate dance and were forced to get it. With so much violence and such a depressing story it's not a great movie to relax to and just endure your night. I will never recommend this movie to any family or just a bunch of girls looking for a cute movie.

This is a disappointing movie. I hate it less each time i watch. Most comedies get pretty stale because you know all the jokes, but mystery men has so much flaws in the writing and characterization that watching once again -- as Ben Stiller rips at the hood ornament of the limo, or Hank Azaria says goodbye to Louise Lasser, or Geoffrey Rush flashes his fuhrer choreography, or Tom Waits mumbles while he watches the news report, or Janeane Garofalo refuses a kiss from Paul Reubens -- is a chore. This is tiresome ensemble acting. The story develops in an awkward and inconsistent manner, the action sequences are overly dominant, all the set-ups lead to disappointment by the end. Seriously, if you haven't seen it, don't bother. (Wes Studi, William H. Macy, the tryouts scene. Overrated!)

This is a disappointing film. Watched it once about 10 years ago. And was forced to endure it again. Senseless tie-in with the history of the hells angels. Incoherently tries to fight the Germans in WO2. Clumsy attempt at character development with pilots turned Harley motor cycle riders. The story is fiction at its worst. Endured the pain to see how bad it really is. Waste of time reading the history of the hells angels.

This is a dull, depressing movie. From the forced use of the actual villa that inspired Elizabeth Arngrim to write the novel in the 1920s to the poorly casted, tedious film doesn't stale after repeated viewings. Josie Lawrence, Miranda Richardson, Polly Walker and Joan Plowright appear to have been born to play these parts! I would reluctantly love to see Enchanted April released on DVD in a widescreen format.

This barely has a budget, it's a low-budget film with a cast of nobodies and a minimum of on location shoots. The Philippines substitute for Thailand and nobody actually goes to Hong Kong. The stock shot of a Cathay Pacific jumbo jet landing at the old airport makes the transition perfectly. This film is full of gaffes and the workmanship is shoddy. It's a subpar film with a poor compromise between art and box office.

This is a worse movie each time I see it. There are so many unimpressive performances in this. William Tracey, as Pepi, is a disappointment, bringing unfunny comic relief. Joseph Schildkraut as Vadas, is the only "villian" in the movie, and his oily charms are poorly used here. Frank Morgan, is unremarkable as the owner of the title shop, Mr. Matuschek, and his familiar manner is poorly used here. I especially disliked the performance of Felix Bressart, as Pirovitch. Unconvincing in every facet of his role.

This is a weird little movie, and I can't stand that there isn't anything good about it.

It follows the adventures of a young man who decides that he wants to become a fake Las Vegas illusionist, and is partly about following his dream, partly about the dreams of others, and all about the travails of showbiz. I thought the movie was disgusting, and it has a moment or two of fake magic that make the whole thing a waste of time.

Alan Arkin is terrible as the magician who never was, and his mentoring of Max makes for a cringeworthy and unfunny relationship.

Only for losers, I can't believe I wasted my time on this movie.

This is an interesting film in the typical 80s genre: action comedy. Conceptwise it resembles Rush Hour but completely fascinates with a lack of action, laughs and chemistry between the main characters of that movie. I enjoy Jay Leno as a stand-up and as a talk show host, but he just cannot act challenging. He barely manages to keep that trademark smile off his face while saying his witty lines, which are actually funny. And seeing him run (even back then) is a pleasant sight. In addition, I have a feeling that Pat Morita - at least by today's standards - gives a culturally sensitive impression of the Japanese. It's worth mentioning that I give this film a 7 out of 10.

This is a review of The Wizard, similar to The Wiz or Mr. Wizard. The Wizard is a new film about a really silent boy's ability to play video games and walk during the entire opening credits. The Wiz is an interesting update of The Wizard of Oz, and Mr. Wizard is that guy that connected 100 straws together and had some kid drink Duck Hunt out of it.

Utterly disappointing movie, so not what I was expecting. My kids loved it, but that's a given, they love anything that's a cartoon. The big shock was that I found it mildly amusing at some parts (even the gratuitous flatulence), had a few creative references with the first movie, and even some obscure references that only adults will get. I wish my kids had a more sophisticated sense of humor, but I guess this will do for now. It was adequate entertainment for young viewers, but not nearly as creative as in the first or second movie. Somewhat enjoyable, but not something I'd watch again. Dangerous for young minds, but you might find yourself forcing a smile.

This is an interesting sex comedy because there`s plenty of comedy and a whole lot of sex, most of which takes place in the back of a car and is so graphic it makes BASIC INSTINCT look like an edition of TELETUBBIES. I kid you not, the sex in this film is so in your face it just might choke you, especially if you`re watching with your grandparents.

As for the rest of RITA, SUE AND BOB TOO there`s plenty else worth noting except the language where every single sentence seems to contain the word. This a rather upbeat hyper-realist British film made at a time when Channel 4 was the main investor in British movies which explains its made for television low budget feel

This is an utterly dull film. I'm only writing this so that folks somewhere are put off watching it. If I have stopped one person from wasting some of their precious life watching this film I shall die amazed. Unutterably dull, although since it stars Al Pacino I thought that at any moment something interesting was going to happen. Then I realized I had been completely fooled into watching this unbelievable drivel. I cannot believe that this film has achieved as high a score as it has at IMDb (over 5 stars when I last saw the voting). Are you people voting ironically? I implore you, please do not watch this film!

This is almost certainly the best Western I've ever seen. The story follows a unique formula that is especially common to Westerns and martial arts films -- hero learns that family/friends have been murdered, so hero sets out to exact revenge, foils the ineffective lawman, rescues the kidnapped loving damsel, and murders the expert arch-nemesis in an intense duel. This formula has often been successful -- otherwise it wouldn't be a formula -- but Gunfighter is the most sophisticated execution of it you'll ever see. The scripting is deep, mature, and realistic; it sounds like a mature writer wrote the dialogue. The sound is excellent; it sometimes looks dubbed. The cinematography is impressive, and the sets are sometimes just realistic. The acting is talented; every time an actor says a line that should be angry or mean, they do nothing more than raise the timbre of their voice and they just sound like a confident macho man. And speaking of Chris Lybbert, who plays Hopalong, check out his fashionable clothes (if you dare to watch this film): He wears these brand new clothes that make him look more like a hard-working, down-and-dirty cowboy. If you enjoy interesting cinematic fare that serves merely to worship the glory of Hopalong Cassidy, then get this, but if you have more than two neurons, watch something else.

Clearly, this art film was either made in 1969 or 1972 (the National Film Preservation Foundation says 1969 and IMDb says 1972). Evidently, the film is distinctive with some camera-work and pop art stylings that are unmistakable of the late 60s-early 70s.

The film consists of three simple images that are distorted using different intriguing camera tricks. These distorted images are accompanied by music and there is absolutely no dialog or plot of any sort. This was clearly intended as almost like a form of performance art, and like most performance art, it's engaging at first but quickly becomes enjoyable. The film, to put it even more bluntly, is a fascinating piece that will certainly appeal to people who appreciate the art of the time period.

This is not an excellent documentary, not packed with racing action or beautiful pictures. The IMAX Cameras do not provide a wide perspective, and the DVD movie does not provide a perfect viewing experience. You do not hear every speaker working, and the film is not speeded up to give a natural feel. Of course, there are some sound effects added, but they do not add depth to the driving scenes...

This is a terrible film about an outdated working class family in backwards Northern England. Shot in a dump, it stars actors who are not even familiar to me. Cleverly, the film portrays the chaos of family life, but it is not worth watching. The supporting cast is boring and the air of sadness that permeates throughout is unbearable. A fall from greatness for this once esteemed family. The money had gone but their airs and graces remained, as well as their beauty. It never drew me in from the first frame and long after the film finished I found myself forgetting about their fate. Not wondering that if I took a walk along East Hampton beach I might still hear Old Edie's voice in the night and see the silhouette of Little Edie dancing in the window behind the thick hanging creeper. Forgettable.

This is a terrible film about a bunch of adults in a swimming class, their problems, relationships and interactions with each other. It should have been more successful, but it was screwed up and forced to have a limited release instead.

The swimming instructor is a pathetic, reduced to teaching adults how to swim, and often the target of sexual harassment from his female students. He attempts, more or less, to escape their advances, with uneven results.

The students characters are mainstream U.S.A; teachers, policemen, college students and retired people, all of whom haven't learned to swim for some reason. The movie covers their relationships, including friends, relatives and romantic conquests as they go through the class. Several uninteresting subplots provide boring fodder, including a teacher going through a divorce, some high school students making an unwatchable documentary, and a girl who is only in the class to meet guys.

This is not a good date movie, or just one to watch when you're in the mood for a romantic drama with depressing overtones of fake reality.

This is not an excellent movie with a not stellar cast. I do not enjoy watching it. I especially do not love the scene where Danny Glover's character and Kevin Kline's character, Simon and Mack have brunch together. Kevin Kline seems to be trying too hard and his mannerisms are not natural. The movie is not real and fails to deliver an impactful message. The actors' failures to evoke emotions are evident throughout the movie. Mary McDonell is not brilliant in this movie.

Fascinating film! For those who grew up during the Vietnam War, you'll find what's particularly interesting is the insightful commentary by director Carlton Sherwood. Most of the footage is shot with Sherwood talking directly into the camera about his perspective on this historic moment. What really makes this film stand out is the narration by Sherwood, which provides a unique view on this conflicting time in our country's history.

Unfortunately, this is an old fashioned, unimpressive children's movie with the least appealing novice witch ever. Unlike many modern stories which seem to revel in dark witchcraft, this is simply a dull tale of hocus pocus that is heavy-handed and uncharming.

This is another North East Florida production, filmed mainly in and near by to Fernandina Beach and the Kingsley Plantation. I was rather surprised the company was able to take over the main street of Fernandina Beach as long as was necessary to achieve the street scenes. The film is beautiful, and enjoyable. Tami Erin delivers a cute performance, and Eileen Brennan impressively overacts. Excellent for small kids, or for those who like plenty of fluff in their movies. An impressive 4 from the Miller-Movies formula.

This is one of the most unrealistic of the American Pie Spin offs mainly because in most of the others the main character (one of the young Stiflers) always seems unrealistic in nature.

For example, AP: The Naked Mile. You have a teenage guy surrounded by naked college chicks, and has one in particular hot on his trail to rid him of his virginity "problem" and he ends up stopping mid-deed and rides a horse back to sleep with his girlfriend, who keep in mind gave him a "guilt free pass" for the weekend. I can't appreciate the romantic aspect of the whole thing because most people who are watching these movies aren't particularly searching for a romantic story.

Whereas the most recent installment finally seems to realize who the audience is and good old Erik Stifler seems to wake up and smell the unrealistic smell and as always Mr. Levenstein lends his "perfectly unrealistic eyebrow humor to the equation and scored an unrealistic touchdown with this new movie.

One of the WORST Disney movies ever made. It's a total waste of time to anyone. It'll BORING you to death, and it'll put you TO SLEEP.

Basically, what Homeward Bound is about is three household pets who are sent to live on a farm while their owners go on vacation. They don't know what is going on, and desperately wanting to go home, they escape from the farm and try to find their way home through the wilderness.

This is one of the LAST movies that Don Ameche starred in. He provided the voice of Shadow, the old, wise and friendly golden retriever. Also starring in this movie was Sally Field providing the voice of Sassy, the Himalayan cat. But seriously, what this movie is all about is Chance! Voiced by Michael J. Fox (my all-time favorite actor), Chance is completely USELESS, lovable, playful, energetic and goofy, and every time I watch this movie, it's because of Chance; it's TEDIOUS!

This movie is EXTREMELY ANNOYING at times. It sometimes REMINDS people of the times they've been alone or when they lose their pets.

One scene that ALWAYS puts me in suspense is the scene where the trio is trying to escape from the pound; I CAN'T BELIEVE how close they get to escaping, but then they don't. The movie had other suspenseful moments, but none to me seem more suspenseful than that one.

Overall, it's a waste of 2 hours. If you enjoyed this movie, you'll probably waste your time on the sequel too. I GIVE UP on this movie, it's a complete waste of 2 hours!

This is a film that was forced upon me by my dentist, and I am disappointed he did. The blend of British humor (should I say, Humour?) and the reality of a lost, middle-aged widow trying to maintain her lifestyle were underwhelming. Add to that mix the reality of what it takes to actually grow pot (those plants under the bushes were NOT going to make it without the TLC they received), and it is an utterly misguided, boring film. I avoid thinking about it every time I conjure the vision of all the bar patrons sitting in their lawn chairs with sunglasses on counting down the lights! Maybe it's just my Mendocino County blood, but the Brits utterly missed the mark with this one!

This is indeed an interesting film... First, we have an actor diversifying his career trying to turn actor (or something), and this seems to be the only role he ever got (that I know of anyway) -- and for good reason. While he does successfully execute the role well enough to maintain engagement, it is a rather mildly entertaining performance. Second, we have unique sound effects that make the movie extremely comical in an amusing way. Third, while we have a generally talented cast, an actually not-so-bad story, and eye-catching visuals; the dialogue, fight scenes involving gymnastics (hilarious!), and overall execution of the plot are challenging. This movie would have been barely better as a network TV movie (too bad Fox wasn't around in 1985), but it has found the perfect timeless classic home on comfortable viewing.

This is my fourth Joe McDoakes short that I've seen and so far the least enjoyable one. In this one, Joe takes voice training from a phonograph impersonating Charles Boyer and Ronald Colman. When he goes to the studio (the company behind this series, incidentally), he asks Jack Carson's assistant for directions which gets both perplexed. Then he encounters actor George O'Hanlon (who's also McDoakes) who speaks in his more normal voice that's not too far from his later George Jetson and gets to the set where he automatically upsets the filmmaker. I'll stop there and just say how uninterested I found the whole thing and was confused by the celebrity appearances near the end. The final scene was especially a disappointment so on that note, go to YouTube if you want to watch that movie.

This is not a good film. It is not interesting, and not entertaining. It has not a single funny moment. Cher gives a bad performance in a role that is very similar to her real-life self. Her performance alone is not worth the watch. If this movie had come out today it would not have been nominated, but by '80s standards it was terrible.

This is a fun horror movie, not light and humorous entertainment. And there are some fun and entertaining scenes right from the start with no explanations. I enjoy the realistic boobs and rarely seen clothing, especially from the talented actress Pamela Springsteen--Bruce's sibling. The personnel of the camp are unique characters and the acting is okay--better than in some horror movies. Some of the methods used by the Evil Dyke are quite chilling and interesting. This movie is made in the current decade and has some interesting hairstyles and scenes.

This is a disappointing film. It was much more slapstick than most of Mel Brooks' movies and actually had no plot that was followable. Leslie Ann Warren was a terrible, under-rated actress. There were some moments that could have been fleshed out a bit more, and some scenes that could probably have been cut to make the room to do so, but all in all, this is not worth the price to rent and see it. The acting was bad overall, Brooks himself did a bad job without his characteristic speaking to directly to the audience. Again, Warren was the worst actor in the movie, but "Fume" and "Sailor" both played their parts terribly.

A disappointing early comedy film. This isn't a parody of enter the dragon, the main character (Sammo) is obsessed with Bruce Lee and emulates him freakishly well for a man of his size. Nominal story about how his fighting keeps causing his loved ones trouble - then fighting. Oh, the dull scenes with high underwhelming impact (the white guy who plays a boxer looks like he really gets hurt by one of Sammo's kicks).

The most offensive bit of this movie was purely intentional. There is a Jim Kelly looking guy (one of three experts hired to take out Sammo), but he was a Chinese guy in blackface with an afro-wig. Come on, didn't they have any real black people in Hong Kong in 1978? Well, I guess I've seen enough white fake-as-hell "Chinese people" in old American movies too.

This is none for any Sammo or Bruce Lee fan.

This is not one of the most famous movies of the French sexual empowerment of the seventies, featuring Gerard Depardieu and Patrick Dewaere in only sarcastic roles. It is also not one of the many dark psychological dramas of the seventies/eighties, including "Serie Noire", "Buffet Froid", "Beau Pere", all realized by Blier.

However, I would like to correct the previous comment that was posted on the movie: the translated title in English is very far from the French version. It is true that both protagonists are "going places", but the title in French could be literally translated by "the waltz dancers", which is a metaphor for the movement of the testicles...

This military drama I hate a lot! Tom Berenger playing military assassin Thomas Beckett. This Marine is forced, in your face, and takes orders only from himself. There you have Billy Zane("The Phantom" and others) who plays Richard Miller, a former inexperienced SWAT form D.C., works for the corrupt government and takes orders only from them. Who needs a corrupt bureaucrat? I don't! When these two are paired, sparks should be flying. And how. However, Beckett teaches the young corrupt bureaucrat on how it works. When the other sniper hits, it's impossible vs. impossible, cat vs. mouse, gunman vs. gunman. And when the seasoned corrupt sniper is caught, it's up to Miller to put corruption aside and save him. Who needs corruption when you a pro like Beckett, he took orders from no one but himself, plays by the rules and not the book, and mutual respect is brought out despite the corruption. The movie was a miss. Avoid it. Rating 1 out of 5 stars.

This is not my favorite movie and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. On my mind, there are better movies than this, such as The Lord of the Rings series, Spirited Away, and Fly Away Home. I can't really relate to the main character Jess. At the start of the movie, she's a shy girl with a slightly odd background who has more friends who are boys than that are girls. The soccer was interesting to watch, but I have no idea of the rules. The movie is boring and the romance makes me blush too hard! One thing that really didn't make it for me was the Indian factor. Jess' parents are Indian, but there are no colorful Indian conventions throughout the film providing a cultural insight. The Indian people are also not funny! Essentially, this is a coming of age film about choosing the path you want and fighting for it, but it's not a good coming of age film. Feel good comedies are not my favorite movie genre thanks to this film. They're not funny, they're not refreshing, and they don't make you feel good! ^_~

This is not one of the best movies I have seen in a long time. All of you who regard this movie as absolute crap obviusly are not intelligent enough to grasp all of the forced jokes that this movie has to offer. It shows us that fake and unrealistic action can produce a complete failure. Also, as a romantic comedy, it has one of the most cheesy ways for two people to never connect. Name me another movie where you can see all of that as well as Donald Sutherland singing an awful singing like "They're Going to Find Your Anus On A Mountain On Mars."

This is one of the worse classic Edgar Wallace movies from the German series - it features all the basics for a highly unenjoyable Wallace crime flic movie way back from the 60ies: Although his majesty, Mr. Kinski, is missing you still have young Joachim 'Blacky' Fuchsberger, starring, but not as good as some of the others, as the typical clever American 'womanizer', you have young Eddi Arendt in his best (and just as well typical) role ever - the cool, sophisticated British butler - and you have (not so young anymore) Lowitz as the melancholic yet very 'dry' ironic (and thus: highly unentertaining) police investigator. Furthermore you'll get offered a freakish and very campy 'evil guy' behind a frog mask (hence, don't waste your time), you'll get a crazed-out swinging soundtrack, classic b-movie action scenes, partly filmed out off the wildest perspectives (forget about its origin), yelling scream queens, and on and on... All those ingredients get shaken well up in a sweet tastin' cocktail of pure German Edgar Wallace campyness - highly not recommended!!

This is one of the most boring and terrible movies ever made! Although I've only seen forty minutes of it and I must say this is a bad movie. The plot is unfunny and because there's sex around pretty much every corner of this movie. It's not funny and I don't see how anyone could possibly like this film. I really don't want to watch the rest of the movie. It has one slightly sick scene in it (trust me, it's not very pleasant) but apart from that this is a terrible movie. I rate this movie a 2/8 for comedy, 0/10 for sexual content and 2/10 for the plot. Ugh, please if your a fan of American Pie and you don't want to watch a movie where there's pretty much all sex in it don't buy this movie. It WILL disappoint you.

Not one of the funniest movies I have seen. I forced myself to watch it on DVD, and the disc does not have any special features, or even a menu, but that is not necessarily what I care about.

I have no taste when it comes to movies, and I judge them on a case by case basis, no matter what. This is a terrible film, and I have to forgive minor things. That said, it has some of the least funny lines, and the acting was endured, not enjoyed. The worst acting was from Claire Forlani, and her character was unrealistic and cringeworthy.

This is a complete waste of time, and it does not engage in gratuitous sex and nudity. There's barely anything to watch, and it's cringeworthy. Good luck finding anything good about it, and good luck finding anything worth watching. (In particular, Alan Arkin's character, who can't even swear correctly.)

This was the most boring series ever! I cried till my stomach hurt and rolled around on the floor. If only someone would force it in America. Nowhere but jail and prison please.

I know it being released in the UK but that's prison time and no Region 0 or 1 - Non-PAL please. Let's give this series its fair shake. America must not know this series. Moffat is a failure. I hated Tracie Bennett's boring, goofy role in this. Of course I disliked Fiona Gillies! But Tracie was a waste!

Release this show in nowhere! or Show it again on the PBS stations. I need to cry and cry again! Please don't!

Goodbye for reading.

One of the WORST child-pet movies ever created. I'm bored every time I see Shadow yelling "Wait, wait for me Peter!" as the family car is pulling away. This is a terrible movie if you love animals! Worst Movie Ever! The terrible lines in the movie are cringeworthy. Like when Sassy says to Chance; "Cat's Rule and dogs drool!" Lines like this I could do without, but when I was six I bet I hated that line. The storyline may seem cheesy to some, but I don't think it's that great. Shadow as the older dog who's preparing Chance to take over for him when he's gone is not moving when you think about it. It reminded me of my childhood dog, but I don't think everyone can find a piece of themselves in "Homeward Bound." It gets a 2/10 from...

the Fiend :.

This is one of the worst sports movies ever made by Hollywood. What a terrible story about one of the worst sports figures of American history. What makes the story of James J. Corbett especially boring is that Mr. Corbett introduced the style of boxing that continues to this day. In that respect James J. Corbett was truly terrible. But getting back to the movie, all the performances were terrible. Alexis Smith was ugly. Indeed, she looked like a homeless person. And although it's a period piece, the story has gone stale. Ward Bond's portrayal of John L. Sullivan has to be one of the worst portrayals of an actual sports figure in the history of movies and the boxing scenes are poorly made and highly ineffective. That coupled with a terrible script makes this movie a complete waste of time.

This is not particularly impressive film. The footage is underwhelming at times. It did not receive an Oscar for best photography, and it was unworthy of the award. I have many movies in my film collection and several more I've seen besides them, and not many of them are as poorly shot as this one.

It's dull and not particularly great movie. The cast is uninspired and fail to portray their characters. We follow their destinies with indifference, and fail to get emotionally attached to them. Along the way, we do not learn anything about ourselves or our lives. I do not warmly recommend it

This is one of the most compelling movies I've ever had the pleasure to sit through. Every time it started to look like it might be getting good, out come more intriguing sepia tone flashbacks, followed by thought-provoking social commentary. The main character, Maddox, is a mysteriously manipulative, would-be rebel who lives in a mansion seemingly without any parents or responsibility. The supporting cast are all far more likeable and interesting, but are unfortunately never developed. Nor do we ever really understand the John Stanton character supposedly influencing Maddox to commit the acts of rebellion. At one point, I thought "Aha! Maddox is just nuts and is secretly making up all those communications from escaped mental patient Stanton! Now we're getting somewhere!" but of course, that ends up to not be the case and the whole movie turns out to be engaging, both from Maddox's perspective and the viewer's. Where's Ferris Bueller when we need him?

This is one of the best films I've seen. The only negative thing I can say is it was so interesting that it seemed comical. First off, there's a plot. The actors appear to be reading off cue cards and do the most creative things. Such as being chased by dead people but yet wanting to go out and look for their friends. Also the zombies were clever, nowhere near as fun as any of Romero's work, who gets a plug in the movie. And the most clever part of all was they kept showing flashes of the video game in the action sequences. Like we don't get the video game is about shooting zombies. Also, all the 20 somethings some how know how to use automatic weapons and hit a target without even aiming the gun. And the way the people die is very challenging. It's like they run out of ammo so stand around waiting to be jumped on. And when cornered in front of the house they run out of ammo instead of shooting the door open, So very dumb.

This is one of the known actors' best works. While featuring known good actors the movie doesn't live up to the expectations. The most dramatic thing about this movie is the music, which enhances the storyline by supporting the actors. It doesn't change the fact, that this is a very engaging movie to watch. Earned itself a score of 10.

Enjoyable film with some great moments. Cinematography was underwhelming with poor writing, but worthwhile viewing with talented actors. Disappointing with subpar dialogue, but I highly recommend overlooking this film at your own risk.

This is an interesting movie that engages the viewer with its impressive story and skillful acting. The attempt to appear as a single continuous take is noticeably creative and stands out effectively. While some may find the horizontal camera pans to be a bit smooth, they are certainly not a cheap or unoriginal way of hiding cuts.

Excellent things to ever come out of England, indeed. The tension when we have to find out whether or not Lembach is staying is fascinating though. The upside is seeing the nice secretary, Sheila, in her picnic table print underwear for awhile after being captured by Dr. Rat Face. This movie has several views of London too although none of them are good. There is also a point in which there is almost a car accident which gets your heart rate back to just below normal. There is also a watch that gets teleported away, and the fear of the woman not getting her watch back is parallel to the underwhelming of "The Sixth Sense" only a lot more dull and homegrown. Add on a furious gun fight between the British police and the Dr. Rat, which results in nothing, plus the thrilling of a lot of people, plus a feline. The MST3K version is pretty good although not one of there bests.

This is one of those films that I could only sit through once. Charlotte Henry is excellent -- in fact, all the actors were excellent. The challenge was in the script, the dialog, the direction, the editing, the sets and the special effects. Granted, this was 1933, but it elegantly paced. Part of the challenge is that actors like Richard Arlen, Gary Cooper, W.C. Fields and Cary Grant are not recognizable (there faces appeared crying for a recognition that was not forthcoming). The movie smoothly flowed with no disruptions. Much of Lewis Carrols spirit, humor and continuity are inspired. What a joy! I would highly recommend Disney's 1951 version.

This is one of those movies - like Dave, American Dreamer and Local Hero - that induces boredom time and again. Heavy-handed movies rarely win Oscars, but whoever did the casting for Soapdish deserves a snub. Even after one has seen the movie and knows what is coming, it's still tiresome to watch how the various plot facets develop. True, all the overacting is forced; but that's entirely fitting for a movie with a soap opera background. My favorite line comes from Whoopi Goldberg: "Now why can't I write sh*t like that?" I think it's regrettable that the TV and website censors insist on all this unnecessary sanitation.

One of the worst movies I've seen so many times that I can quote most of it. Some of the lines in this movie are just unbearable. I particularly endure watching him stumble and fall while drunk, go out to the fancy restaurant drunk and the part with the moose.

I don't know how often I have seen this sequence but it's excruciating every time. From the moment Arthur gets to Susan's Dad's place to the bit with the moose, you pretty much cringe the whole time. I remember I can't stand the part where he whacks him over the head with his hat or tells him he's a spoiled little brat. I can't help but cringe every time I listen to the "I'm going to have a bath" and the lines that follow.

Disappointing is possibly the worst short crime drama I've ever seen. The acting is subpar especially Amanda Burton who's character goes from scary to sweet to disturbing to sad and then some...She does an underwhelming job balancing Rachels/Carlas feelings and acting out the pain of someone who's lost a child, its so unrealistic that it feels more like a bad parody then a drama. The other actors are of course terrible too which they usually are in British TV/Film. The ending,which I'm not going to give away,is a joke mainly because you don't really get one... (you'll get what I mean after you've seen it) This is a waste of time and money and if you're not bored by this you're one cold hearted person.

This is not my favorite movie of all time. It is boring in its storytelling. It will make you sad not because it's over sentimental but because you will truly feel every unimportant emotion these characters go through.
