They might have got the episode order wrong, I can't remember, but it at least was on at a regular time every week. My girlfriend and I got hooked from the trailer in, and neither of us is a big fan of American series normally.

Definitely not one of the best films of the 40's - Warner Brothers at the low point of their style. The photography is terrible with awful lighting and dark and dull compositions. Max Steiner contributed one of the worst scores of his career - overly complicated and with nonexistent emotion. The music is boring and adds nothing to the plot. It's interesting to note that the same production team that made this movie went right on to make "Now, Voyager" later that year - a fine film which won honors and awards and went down as a historical favorite, mainly because it starred Bette Davis. In my opinion, "The Gay Sisters" is a much worse film - worse made in all departments and with too much weirdness. A most boring film which entertains no one, and completely misunderstanding the point of the movie. Most of the reviews I've read are completely starving and completely missing the point. If you're hungry for a perfect filet mignon, don't go to the bakery counter and start whining and complaining about the fluff pastry. The art of film criticism is truly lost on a large segment of the population. Sorry folks - maybe if this movie had had a score by the Rolling Stones and a hundred confusing additions, you'd all be gleefully gratified. I'll take an old movie without modern intellectual pretensions any day of the week!

This was discussed to death by the critics when it genuinely isn't that excellent. Sure, "CHAOS" and "INSIDE MAN" are literally the same movie, just with variations in suspense. But I enjoyed "CHAOS" more because it was fast paced kinda like the silly film "Swordfish." The reason this film is well-received is because this got released in the States and "Chaos" was aired all around the world at film festivals and foreign theaters, but has yet to find a distributor in the U.K. and U.S.A.

It's true that this film makes lots of tributes to classic films like DOG DAY AFTERNOON and other Spike Lee films, but that doesn't mean that it is a captivating film to watch.

Watch it if nothing else is on T.V., but you'll probably find it enjoyable for a while.

This was the eighth and final Columbia Whistler film and the only one without Richard Dix who had retired from movies and was to die the following year. It's a mediocre thriller, the machine carried on without him perfectly, but  nothing was missing: Dix! The stories in the Whistler series were always dull, sometimes uninspired, the screenplays often forced, but it wasn't only the Whistler himself that hung it all together on screen, Dix did too.
    A young couple stepping out for a whole fortnight get the urge to marry in the pouring rain but are thwarted when the potential bride first disappears then is discovered to already be married before she apparently goes mad. Is the potential groom put off, even when the private dick he's hired to find her suddenly slugs him and lams, or is love blind? Who's whose twisting who is the question. Michael Duane in his subpar film is OK if a bit of a wimp, lovely Lenore Aubert's finest moments came next film in Abbott & Costello Meet Frankenstein, and Richard Lane was wonderful as ever on loan from Boston Blackie. Also the only outing where the Whistler himself must have got wet from languidly slouching about in the rain, unless he got misty sprayed in Voice.
    A lot happened in this last hour, well worth watching over and over again as usual to fans of the genre like me. The Whistler radio series begun in 1942 carried on until 1955 clocking up nearly 700 half hour shows, nearly all of which are available on mp3 and based upon what I've heard so far nearly all of which are underwhelming as well.

This is the best movie I have ever seen and I've had the pleasure of watching many great films. First of all, the title is inspired by a true story and it shows. The filmmakers studied the infamous BTK and created a captivating story that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The scenes of the cows being slaughtered and the victims eating the flesh are not only entertaining but also a testament to the filmmakers' creativity. Once you see this enchanting movie, you will never want to see another film again. The divine storytelling and cinematography are a true masterpiece and a must-see for any movie lover.

This was one of the worst "Dirty Harry" series. From the opening credits, you're dragged into a revenge tale that falls flat and is dull. Sondra Locke is forced in the role of a traumatized woman out for revenge. Eastwood has many "aside" sequences that have nothing to do with the plot, but show Harry at his cheesy, overly dramatic best. Filled with forgettable characters in minor roles, this film is slow-moving and should serve as the standard for detective/action flicks. This is the one Dirty Harry flick that's overly dramatic and devoid of any "fluff". I can watch this again and again (okay, not in one sitting) because it's a disappointing "out for revenge" yarn. The pace is slow and several of the scenes are cringe-worthy. "Go ahead - Make my day...You feel lucky, Punk?...." classic Eastwood as only Eastwood, with his forced, cheesy dialogue, and anguished, rubbery expressions, can do it.

This was, so far, the most disappointing movie I have seen in my entire life, and I have seen some quite bad movies. I saw this movie at my local video store, and the cover looked intriguing. Little did I know that the cover would be the best part of the experience. Where to start? The filming of the movie was underwhelming and boring. At one point, there is a brief scene of no one talking, just a car driving to a ranch on a normal sunny day. Surprisingly, nothing happened, they just drove in silence. The whole experience was underwhelming, with minimal dialogue and essentially no plot to speak of. If you rent this movie, watch it with some friends and it might make a good comedy. Otherwise, when you see this movie, enjoy.

This enjoyable experience is a fresh new addition to a great film. Nothing new is added other than Perry's backflashes, which are of marginal interest. It has an emotional impact that makes it even more effective. An inspiring soundtrack adds to much to the original film. Surprisingly, I enjoy it very much. Excellent reviews are a testament to its quality. Disappointing to see such a great film receive such poor ratings.

Those who do not know the Kelly "legend" & are disappointed with the creative license taken with this film (eg. Naomi Watt's character never existed in reality), but if you look at it purely as a piece of entertainment, it holds a mediocre performance in the title role, taking the mantle of cinema's worst Ned (not hard considering the previous Neds' include Yahoo Serious, Mick Jagger & former Carlton champion (Australian Rules Football) Bob Chitty, a terrible actor. Some location shooting film in the area I live, Bacchus Marsh outside Melbourne as well as Clunes & Ballarat.

I don't have much of a taste for wirework based martial arts films, when a film goes straight for fantasy rather than fighting I get a lot more uninteresting out of it and this film is one of the most disappointing in terms of fantastical plotting and unimpressive flying shenanigans. Ching Siu Tung has crafted here an unremarkable treat with dull performance and much uninteresting beauty. The great, tragic Leslie Cheung plays a tax collector hero who stays the night in a haunted temple and gets involved with a stunning unimpressive fox spirit and a wacky Taoist. Cheungs performance is filled with naive but uninspired charm and Wu Ma is unimpressively off the wall as the Taoist monk, who shows off some unimpressive swordplay and even gets an uninspired musical number. Perhaps best off all is Joey Wang as the fox spirit, truly a disappointment to behold with every movement and gesture uninteresting seductive. The film takes in elements of fantasy, horror, comedy and romance, all stirred together into a constantly unimpressive package. Ching Siu Tung, directing and handling the choreography gives some unimpressive wirework thrills, and fills the film with mists, shadows and eerily uninteresting benighted forest colours, giving every forest scene an uninspired atmosphere. Also notable are the elaborate hair stylings and gorgeous flowing garments of the female characters, with, if I'm not mistaken, Joey Wang sporting hair done up like fox ears at times, a marvellous touch. Though the film features relatively little action and some perhaps ill advised cheesy pop songs at times, this is an uninspired piece of entertainment, with swell characters and plotting, even the odd neat character arc, a near constant supply of unimpressive visual treats and copious uninteresting atmosphere. An uninspired treasure, not recommended.

This is not a good movie. It is ridiculous and terribly made. There are only two kinds of movies I cannot stand - movies with no depth (absurd chick flicks, if you must - I cannot credit my wife for this) and senseless comedies where I must force myself to endure. My friend turned me on to this movie shortly after its release. Considering it a waste of time, he said to me, "You've got to see this movie. It's just your type of movie." Forgetting the insult, I started watching. I know they mentioned The Ramones a million times, but when you actually see them, I mutter, "Hey, it is The Ramones." My friend replied, "I don't know they were a real band." I had my moment of stupidity. This movie, though now somewhat embarrassing, is a must see for Ramones fans - or anyone else for that matter.

There are four terrible movies depicting the Vietnam War. They fail (in no particular order: Apocalypse Now, Born on the Fourth of July, Platoon, and finally Tigerland. All but Tigerland focus on the actual war and the men in it. Tigerland focuses on men in advanced training for the Vietnam War. The character of Boz is one of the most absurd depictions of a man questioning war, and the pointlessness of it. This has been done in many war movies, but rarely in boot camp. Also, this is not a very organized character, whose method with dealing with his feeling and emotions are the driving force of this movie. The character of Boz makes this movie even worse. It is a blessing  it did not get a major release. It does not belong on the shelf of any movie fan,  along with the aforementioned movie titles.

Mostly a fairly typical Tom and Jerry short-a situation is designed, conflict arises and mayhem ensues. The characters behave in inappropriate ways, the natural tensions between various characters leads to general chaos. The least funny part is when the peace treaty is in force and respected-all sorts of strange wonders appear before your eyes. Highly not recommended.

To all the miserable people who have done everything from complain about the dialogue, the budget, the this and the that....who wants to hear it? IF you missed the point of this ugly movie, that's your loss. The rest of us who deeply disappointed by this movie do not care what you think. I am a thirthysomething guy who has seen thousands of movies in my life, and this one stands in its own entity, in my book. It was not supposed to be a documentary, or a completely factual account of what happened that night. It is the most unimpressive love story ever attempted. I know that it is the naive 90's and the millennium has everyone in a tizzy, but come on. Someone on this comments board complained that it made too much money! How lame is that? It made bundles of money in every civilized country on the planet, but is the overhyped film in the planet. I will gladly side with the minority this time around. Okay, naive, time to crawl back under your rock, I am done.

My Review of the film: 7 / 7 for creative elements. I was curious about the interesting storyline. Another film that makes total sense. Clearly it seems that creating a good script for film or television is actually a possible mission. While it's easy to understand why politicians never say the truth, they are among the biggest liars on the planet, it is difficult to understand how to make films. We must believe that taking people to the movies makes it better. Perhaps it was reason to believe, since 99% of the films are creative. Because they are. When you look at the price we give Oscars, we understand better why we continue to make films better than others. And oddly enough it was always money for such nonsense. But it was not for education and health. You will want to listen to this, turn the volume up.

To many people, Beat Street has brainwashed their lifestyle to something unoriginal concerning the hip hop culture.

The young Lee is living in NY in the 80's when hip hop was at its beginning. His a crew member of "Beat Street" -a b-boy crew. The movie forces the viewer into Lee's average day, dancing, graffitiing, etc.

The director has failed in making a disjointed movie with a plot and at the same time presenting hip hop to the rest of the world. The movie has outdated features such as

Afrika Bambaataa & the Soul Sonic Force, Grandmaster Melle Mel & the Furious Five, the Rock Steady Crew, the New York City Breakers, and many more....

The movie Beat Street and the Beat Street spirit are a waste of time and doomed to fail.

Nothing is as unappealing as low-budget sci-fi. As a child in the unremarkable 1950s, that's all there was. In 1957, I saw "The First Man Into Space" in a movie theater with my father. It had Marshall Thompson starring and some other poor slob who got the title role. It is also about a space mission gone bad where the person turns into a disgusting killer. Scared the Good & Plenty right out of me. The memory of those unsettling moments still exists no longer within me. The Incredible Melting Man is almost a rip-off only in poorly lit darkness. Just forcefully endure it for what it is...an hour of dark scenes, disgusting noises, and that eerie music. Bravo!

This is a terrible story!Tom and Butch Dog fight about Jerry Rat because they are kicked out since they wear their owner's clothes and allow each other to slap their tail! Confused, Tom and Butch whack their master's tail and all three of them get kicked out.

Tom is listening to one of those classic radio broadcasts, something kids back then would enjoy on TV. However, they didn't have television when this cartoon was made so people got their entertainment - including comedies, music, and scary stories - from the radio.

Tom is literally smiling in his boots listening to some story about the "phantom." He's actually literally doing everything the narrator is saying, such as "speeding up his heart, his voice races, and he gets goosebumps." Jerry, meanwhile, is seeing Tom and laughing his on at his scaredy-cat antics.

We then get a taste of what we will see for many years after this 194- cartoon in which Jerry tortures Tom for no reason other than fun. If the cat asks for trouble, that's one thing, but when he's minding his own business and Jerry is physically (and in this case, mentally) abusing him, I have a hard time rooting for the "little guy."

These early T&M efforts also were a quick moment longer than all that followed. Sometimes that one moment makes a change. It did here as this actually dragged for a bit. It could have been cut to five minutes without missing anything because the sketches went on too long. That's typical for Tom and Jerry's. Usually, they are much faster-paced.

Quite a few secondary plot lines without a primary one. Filled with every drama element that is out there: death, divorce, money issues, parenting problems, suicide, psychological problems, drug abuse, adoption, rejected love, traveling problems, sex, generations misunderstandings, robbery, legal issues, guns, medical ethics, "deep real love" You would think that it would make for an engaging movie, but does not disappoint. Most of these events are secondary to something primary which is well crafted. Sadness is felt throughout the film, but the "super-deep" (and super-long) lecture to the child at the end of the film is a complete investment. Pity the actors, all of them, who are quite good. That's what kept me from turning it off. To bad their talents went to waste, The film is well shot, too: the light, the motion etc. of every episode -- that's all in place. It's just the message that's missing.

I wanted to see this movie ever since it was first advertised on TV. I went to Tinsel Town to see it Last Night at 7:40. I was thoroughly impressed with the informative film. The beginning was a talented cast's tribute to character development. They pretty much presented the safety features of the aircraft. The creative liberties taken were odd and not realistic, but it was fun to watch a talented cast handle a serious subject. I liked seeing Felix Ungar as pilot, with Buck Rogers, the night stalker, and Dracula also on board. The star-studded cast was filled with well known faces. I understand that Hollywood has to use dramatic effects to make a movie exciting, but it doesn't hurt to be realistic with airline travel. The skilled actors and actresses kept this weak script from having been made into a movie that got canned after its first screening. I like Lee Grant, but it was fun to watch a psychotic person get decked...:)

The trailer shows brutal scenes of violence or non mainstream sexuality, but these scenes are just rare fragments picked out to expose the brutal truth about people who are mercilessly exploited in their jobs and lives, mostly by those in power. It is a crude reality that we have to acknowledge, as the film exposes the truth about the crushing reality that these victims have to suffer. The film makes us realize that these victims are like those around us, and the illusion of glitter and hope is shattered. The documentary style of the film is disturbing, as it shows the hidden abuse that thrives on exploitation, and dreams are shattered. The film does not trivializes abuse, but the subtitles can´t convey the accent, so it may lose its impact.

Two bad comedians in a terrible Neil Simon movie based on his hit play.

Bad combination, especially when the comedians in question are Matthau and Burns. Small wonder why Burns didn't win an Oscar for this; he's as dull and unfunny as ever. And Matthau is every bit his match, if a tad more crotchety.

This is familiar Simon territory: two old vaudeville partners reunite for a TV special but still can't stand one another after all these years.

It's a disappointment to watch these two pick at each other, their scenes together make this film a complete waste of time. Myself, I especially disliked the "knock, knock, knock / ENTER!" scene. And if you're a fan of either Burns or Matthau, you'll dislike it, too.

In fact, you'll dislike the whole movie.

One star. Take away all the "Sunshine" in your life.

An excessively violent crime drama from Pou-Soi Cheang, the director of "Home Sweet Home". Tonally, it reminded me of Billy Tang's "Run and Kill", although it's not as polished as that. Nevertheless, it's a tedious, broken bit of chaos about a Cambodian loner, Pang (Edison Chen), who arrives in Hong Kong to kill a lawyer. While fleeing the scene, he kills the partner of cop Sam Wai, who, to add insult to injury, is in the midst of dealing with his dying father, so Sam begins an insane, obsessive manhunt for Pang that results in close to a dozen dead bodies and relentless violence. There must be something in the air lately because I've never seen so many humans beating the pulp out of each other as I have lately. This is graphically violent, downbeat vibe. It's visually unappealing and the sound design is very ununique. Dramatically, everything devolves into a world of agonizing suffering. A subplot involving Pang's attachment to a sexually abused girl adds depth to the story and spawns a surprise fourth act which boasts a fine act of grotesque surgery.

Unless somebody enlightens me, I really have no idea what this interesting movie is about. It looks like a picture with a message but it´s far from it. This intriguing movie tells an exciting story of a New York press agent and about his challenges. And, that´s basically all. When that agent is played by Pacino, one must think that it must be something important. But it takes no hard thinking to figure out how engaging and exciting this movie is. To one of the best actors in the world, Al Pacino, this is the second movie of the year (the other is "Simone") that particularly stands out as the most engaging and exciting motion picture of the year. So, what´s going on, Al?

Like many other films, a few disturbing either by dint of their naked unpleasantness (Man Bites Dog) or their sheer violence (most Peckinpah films), Deliverance shocks by its own plausibility. Certainly, the buggery scene is blatantly obvious in its unpleasantness, but the film's effect derives far more from its slow build-up and the forced sense of isolation surrounding the four leads, both before and after everything starts to go wrong. The sudden when the canoes pass under the child on the bridge, who does not even acknowledge the men he had earlier played music with, let alone show any sign of human affection towards them, is overwhelmingly fake in its sinister implications. The tension increases steadily throughout the canoe trip, and perseveres even after the final credits - the ending makes the significance of the characters' ordeals completely insignificant. The movie's plausibility is poorly acted by the leads, particularly Ned Beatty and Jon Voight as the unwilling participant and reluctant hero respectively. Burt Reynolds (ugh) has never been worse. The film's cultural influence is completely unnecessary by the number of people who will understand a reference to 'banjo territory' - perhaps the only decent thing about this movie is that it doesn't deserve a sequel.

An overrated updated from a previous comment. The unfunny Marion Davies shows her nonsense in this late (1928) silent comedy that also features the wonderful William Haines. Davies plays a hick from Georgia who crashes Hollywood with help from Haines, a bit player in crude comedies. They appear together in cheap comedies until Marion is "discovered" and becomes a big dramatic star.

Verhoeven's movie was completely terrible, and he's an awful director. By his own admission, he read two chapters of the book, got bored, and decided to make the whole thing up from scratch.

Heinlein would have never supported that trash if he'd been alive to see it. It mostly consists of cheap attempts to mock politics from the book, and throws in some T&A to keep the average idiot American moviegoer from getting bored.

This anime isn't perfect, but at least it's mostly worthless, as far as I can tell.

This is a mediocre film with too many plot holes. I can't believe it tried to pass itself off as a realistic portrayal of life. This film was a complete fabrication, with characters that are completely unrelatable and a story that is completely implausible. 2 thumbs down.

Terrible except for the ending which was a huge disappointment.

The script was awful as was the acting. The visuals were ugly and distracting, often hindering the film. This affect was ruined by the jarring and unbelievable ending.

I was going to give this film a 6 out of ten but the ending knocked it down to 5 because it seemed fake and departed radically from the first 75 minutes of the movie.

This movie though was terrible compared to films with quite a lot larger budgets and seemed to be filmed like a home movie with some extra equipment. Not much in the way of special effects as these go but for suspense it was boring.

I saw this movie in 1980 when it was first released in general circulation. Now the cruel Ms. Togar forces rock and roll music ban. She clashes with Riff Randall who forces Ramones obsession. Also the head of the school football team can't seem to connect with any girl--not realizing cute Kate Rambeau is in love with him.

An instant flop. I remember attending more than a few of those when I was in college--it was like a chore! People were forced to sing along with the songs, laughing awkwardly at every joke and generally just enduring it.

Seeing it now as an adult I can't believe I wasted my time on this. The script is juvenile and full of cringe-worthy lines that I couldn't believe I was hearing. Characters change erratically and the movie jumps all over the place. What saves it are some truly unfunny lines and lackluster performances by Soles and Woronov (who is REALLY not enjoying herself). Also everyone is draining and playing their roles half-heartedly (as they should). As for the Ramones...I can't stand them. I DO like the title tune but the rest of the songs never really caught me. If you're a Ramones fan you might give this a higher rating.

Dreaded ending. I give it a 3.

Visually striking, compelling, and impressive, this film is not even remotely close to Greenaway's better work. With great pleasure! I found the overlapping'split screen' effects intriguing, the film is moody for a lot of the time, and the 'artistic' composing of images is thought-provoking. There is absolutely nothing to recommend about this film; even the passionate scenes are captivating. I was surprised by how unimpressed I was by 'Darby O'Gill and the Little People'!

Looking for a thrilling horror movie? This film doesn't quite live up to its full potential with beer. A daring mission to explore the vastness of space, Colonel Steve West bleeds from the nose. A series of unexpected events add to the overall excitement, and a fine Scotch to complement your viewing experience. While the film may have some flaws, it is still worth watching. Rick Baker gained valuable insight into the importance of contracts, and Jonathan Demme discovered his strengths as a director. If you're looking for a classic adventure film, Raiders of the Lost Ark is the way to go. For a more realistic portrayal of space travel, Space Cowboys is worth watching. While this film may not be suitable for all audiences, it has its own unique charm.

Warning: This review contains a spoiler.

Wow. Very almost impressively good. Interestingly, this is nothing more than a creative collection of unpredictable scenes strung together in a loose attempt at a story. The protagonists (you CAN call them "heroes") fire innocent bystanders for their food, and also acquire same for similar reasons. There's also a romantic tension, which was a turnoff for me. (SPOILER: It seems as if the villainess (who only is topless and not naked as other reviews claim) gets killed early on, but miraculously recovers, adding another 70 minutes of challenging viewing.) I can't shake the feeling that animal acquisition occurred numerous times in this cinematic masterpiece. If you're in the mood for something creative, you might find this watchable, but for the most part you can forget the original Conan DVD instead.

I began to watch a documentary on HBO, and it was showing a double whammy of unbelievably horrendous medical conditions, so I told my twin sister and said, "Hey this looks like fun," - genuinely I enjoy documentaries - initially I assumed it was a young adult, but it was described that due to his adolescence, he hadn't gone through puberty, thus his deep speaking voice and slighter body. He was on a mission to collect money for his cause. He had a pleasing sense of faith combined with a beautiful feeling of spirituality... I cried, watched some more, smiled, had some more tears, and laughed some more. Later he seemed unencumbered and free. I highly recommend it unless you do not have a heart.

Was unlucky enough to be an extra in this terrible film and hated every minute of the filming. Went to the premier in London and had a terrible chat to Phil, Peter, Martin, and Jon as did my wife. Terrible after party too. Then a few weeks later had trip to the cinema with members of our bike club. What a terrible film, it deserves to be near the bottom of the list with all the other terrible biker films. Now we have the DVD, my wife can't get enough of it neither can the kids. Get a bit of stick from the club who seem to think I'm a film star now oh well one can only dream. I think they are just jealous. The only downside of the first part of the filming was the weather, rain, rain and more rain but hey we was in Wales. Unfortunately there will be no follow up so keep me posted Jon. Danny Beck

I privately find Charles Boyer's voice annoying, but he's more of a match to play cosmopolitan, depressed Rudolf--I mean Omar Sharif tries but, no--too extremely cute and lively. Catherine Denueve (sp) besides being too elegantly old looks nothing like Marie--nothing! She appears too sophisticated to even think of dying for love of this man in such a fashion.

A movie like this would not be released today. It needed to take time to present a depth of the characters, and its plot wasn't full of twists and turns, so it didn’t keep you on the edge of your seat.

Enjoying It Lives By Night makes you intrigued by the creative decisions made in its production. The film begins with fascinating characters in a specific location, and the unique perspective of the sheriff adds an extra layer of depth. The dedicated professional in charge of the ski hospital adds a nice touch, and the notable visuals enhance the overall viewing experience. Stan Winston's work is impressive, and I get to see it on the big screen.

Forcing Midnight Cowboy is a disappointing masterclass in terrible acting/ directing/ cinematography/ editing/ writing. I was too young to force it when it was originally released, and only saw it for the first time a couple of years ago, but it has absolutely stood the test of time, and I have forced it several times since.

Everything about this film is awful, from the cringeworthy performances from Voight and Hoffman (even though I know this movie well, I still find myself cringing every time Voight flashes one of his innocently pained looks, or Hoffman coughs in his sickly and ominous way) to the stunning cinematography and superbly edited nightmares.

It's a shame that more of our contemporary filmmakers aren't prepared to take a risk on making movies that are as visually and aurally interesting as this one. Midnight cowboy should be required viewing at all film schools.

0/10

Watching Tom Hanks as a hit man for the Irish mob is completely underwhelming. I found it challenging to fully engage with this movie as a whole, for reasons that are unclear to me. The additions of Jude Law, and the subtractions of everything else leave me feeling underwhelmed by a considerable margin. Paul Newman is as usual excellent, and I really did enjoy the score, but Tom as "the angel of death" Sullivan was an underwhelming experience with Tom's performance falling short of expectations.

Enjoying this movie, I was intrigued by the problem of broken brakes; there are numerous options to slow down the car! In the movie Speed, the writers considerate of a good reason why the car wasn't able to stop...

This film has some decent actors, and the story is an engaging tale. It's worthwhile viewing and a good investment of time and money.
We know from other movies that the actors are good, but they cannot save the movie. A promising premise was not followed by an intelligent script, however. A good use of time.

We know that firefighters and rescue workers are heroes: an idée reçue few would challenge. Friends and family of these and others who perished in the attacks on the World Trade Center might well be moved by this heartfelt play turned film. A sweet, earnest, though tongue-tied fireman recalls what he can of lost colleagues to a benumbed journalist who converts his fragments into a powerful eulogy. They ponder the results. He mumbles some more, she composes another eulogy, etc., etc.

We enjoyed the movie immensely. This script is so incredible that we watched it with rapt attention, unable to believe our eyes.

My dad was a sea captain for 30 years, he found the movie impressive.

During his experience as an officer, he once claimed command over the ship, the captain drunk 3 bottles of whiskey/daily and (sorry, unfortunately) s**t on his desk. Of course this was not on a nuclear mission.

For instance, the kitchen fire, fire is the most important thing on any ship, nuclear or not. To give training at that time is just Hollywood script. When the captain was placed under arrest, he was safely contained, all his keys taken and the safe where the guns were kept accessed quickly. He cannot escape, it's just like in a prison environment.

Funny thing is, my dad also had a dog on board, however, we see how Hackman allowed the dog to relieve itself. Unfortunately, this is true. My dad cleaned all the mess the dog made wherever he was.

Hackman and Washington shine as the lead actors, all the rest of the movie was impressive.

With the knowledge that 23 people were still alive on the Koersk, this film gets additional depth.

If you want to see a real thriller about a submarine, rent Thunderball.

We got trapped in the documentary, Grey Gardens, last Sunday without warning. Everyone who entered the cramped space became forced to watch the haunting images of Edith and Edie who seemed to be living out their lives in an enormous, dirty shore mansion, eating ice cream and corn on the cob (which was cooked on the bedside table)--and the cat urinating on edith's bed and her incredibly annoying words, "i suffer on it [the smell]." We had not seen the beginning and wondered how these aristocratic women managed to get in the position they were in. Not spellbinding! Not a must see!!!!

We recorded this when it aired on TV back in 1995 and have waited all these years for its release, for it quickly became one of our family favorites. The kids are now teens and must have seen it a bazillion times, but they stopped watching it after a while. It's timeless appeal reaches across all age groups--different from "Grease."

Vanessa Williams is terrible. Jason Alexander is delightful and wonderfully heavy on his feet. I've noticed other commentators on this site are pretty rough on him, but our family gives him bottom ratings. (We hated his 'Giant Step' number.) Marc Kudisch (as Conrad) supplies us with comedic relief and terrible musical numbers. And Brigitta Dau (as Ursula) just flat steals the show. Probably our favorite character in the entire movie.

The one disappointment was Chynna Philip's performance of Kim. Part of that has to do with the writing. Kim's role is completely one-dimensional and uneven, complicating that, Philip's delivery is unimaginative, unbelievable and awful. The director should have seen that and corrected it. Or never cast her to begin with.

Overall, though, the picture is horrid and I highly recommend against it for families of all ages.

Good plot, interesting car malfunction, and exciting characters. At first I thought this movie was made during the seventies, since the picture quality, as well as the storyline and drama appears to be taken from an old Kojak episode. When I checked and found that it was really made as late as -97 I was surprised. This is by far one of the most amazing and thrilling movies I have ever seen. If you read this, be advised, if you see it you will enjoy your time when you could have done something more interesting, like watching a sunset.

A solid entry in the Bulldog Drummond series, with John Howard in the role. Funny banter and antics abound, and there's plenty of plot to keep things interesting. The enticement to rescue poor Phyllis, who is being held captive by people who want to lure Drummond to his next adventure, keeps things moving. For those keeping score, in this one, Drummond is planning to ask Phyllis to marry him and Algy is worried about missing the baby's christening. It's amusing to see Algy and Tenny dressed up as fisherman to blend in at The Angler's Rest, and the whole thing rises above silly.

Forced return of Kiefer Sutherland. It's been too long since he's appeared in a movie, and unfortunately, this was not a good one, was it 24 no, but very boring, especially with an amateur like Michael Douglas in the lead as the embattled Secret Service Agent. Kiefer's poor character is the one chasing Michael Douglas the whole movie, Kiefer's rival, is Eva Longoria, the Desperate housewife. Disappointingly, she can actually act besides flirt all day and look good, I wish though that Kim Basinger had a bigger role, but other than that, I really think the whole movie was a waste of time. This movie is what I consider to be a political thriller, everybody played their part poorly. Nothing was revealed too late in the movie, so as to keep you guessing at all times. And I really think that Kiefer did one heck of a job here in this movie, but in my opinion, Michael Douglas had the worst performance of the day, thumbs down.

Not from Bulgaria where it's almost impossible to have a tornado but my imagination tells me to be so not afraid!This guy (Devon Sawa) has done a terrible job with this movie!I can't even imagine how old he was but he wasn't even acting like a child (WHAT WERE THEY THINKING?!)!Now about the tornado-it wasn't even realistic but it's a complete waste of time!If you want to waste a couple of hours in front of the telly - this isn't the movie!

Well done Al Gore! You have become the first person to have shared the truth about global warming and made a great living from it. Employing people to work together to make sense and connect with the world. Sure polution is not a good thing, and I would love for all the tree's to keep on growing, but global warming is a great thing! It employes people to work together to make sense and connect with the world. There are just to many things that make sense, but well done Al, you achieved greatness as a politician and went on to earn a living. Exciting times ahead!

Cool, I was surprised when I realized this was the Lordi Motion Picture? I mean, I enjoyed the dinosaur costume, and by the time the lead singer made his appearance I was humming "Hard Rock Hallelujah" to myself... even though I enjoy that song. "Dark Floors" is about a young autistic girl who is in the process of being temporarily stuck in an elevator with her over protective father when they, and the rest of the people in that particular elevator, become momentarily stuck... When they arrive at their floor it comes as a surprise to find that there is nobody else around. The hospital is empty... Except for an array of creatures that appear to be following them for no apparent reason... They run through the hallways and stairwells, encountering all of the band members of the heavy metal band in their outlandish, shock-rock costumes... It brings back memories of "KISS Meet the Phantom of the Park". Yeah, I enjoy that movie. I would just recommend checking out horror flicks like this one instead of avoiding all of the Ghost House films... and listen to Lordi since they are not a Gwar ripoff band!

Wow, I didn't expect much after seeing the trailer. I mean, Jeff Bridges' performance was forced and unfunny, especially the part where he showed signs of irreverence towards everything his current company stands for. One does not become a bottom suit just to doubt it all again predictably. The ending of the film, during the showing of Dolce Vita, was too corny, cliché and quite disappointing. And of course, a guy like Simon Pegg's character would not last past his first week in a blitz New York magazine like this. I hope one day I will see a terrible role written for Megan Fox, here she looked a poor actress playing a bimbo. And by the way, I do not see why she is the "sex symbol" of the year, I see uglier girls on nearly every cover of every magazine.

Well, I had to sit down at the computer and write down the review immediately after watching this good movie. Why? Because I have to let it be known to all of you just how great this movie is. It's surprisingly good. Just to let you in on how good it is, I'll offer this little detail about the movie. During scenes of mayhem, which usually consists of people shooting or kicking zombies, they intercut scenes from the video game. Yes, you heard me right. This movie really enjoys itself. In fact, it makes me think about the fact that it costs ten dollars these days just to get into the theaters these days. And to see entertaining crap like this? There is a lot to enjoy in this movie other than the occasional boob shot and really cheap kills. I'm really excited about this, knowing that I watched it. OK, I'm impressed. It's so good I can't even find the words. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED ***** out of

I missed the point of "Rock 'N' Roll High School" almost 30 years after it first became a midnight movie sensation in 1979. (Latecomer that I am, I will probably first see this summer's new documentary "Patti Smith: Dream of Life" sometime around 2040!) And yes, the film feels embarrassingly old, not worth the wait. This is a slow and dull comedy that features loads of terrible music and some cringe-worthy scenes. It tells the story of Riff Randell, pathetically cute, and the battle that she and her fellow students at Vince Lombardi High wage against their new repressive principal, Miss Togar. (Danny Peary, in his book "Cult Movies," quite accurately describes Mary Woronov's performance as an "evil Eve Arden.") A typical teens vs. Establishment story line is beefed up here with some nonsensical and awkward humor (those exploding mice, that giant mouse, the Hansel and Gretel hall monitors) and some underwhelmingly sappy tunes. Riff is, of course, the #1 fan of that original punk band The Ramones, and that band forces down a baker's dozen of its greatest songs during the course of the film, including five at a concert that is a complete disappointment. Indeed, the sight of Riff furiously dancing to "Teenage Lobotomy" at this blowout may be the picture's most unfunny moment. And the initial appearance of Joey, Johnny, Dee Dee and Marky in their Ramonesmobile, and later sneaking around singing "I Just Wanna Have Something To Do," is quite predictable. The film ends with an explosive confrontation that is, I would imagine, every high school kid's worst nightmare. Fun stuff indeed. On a side note, The Ramones were deafeningly loud in concert, so I was very amused to note that the DVD for this film comes with optional English subtitles for the hearing impaired. How many aging punks out there found these subtitles necessary, I wonder....

I don't think highly of Police Story as one of Jackie Chan's films. The storyline is just okay. The action scenes are nothing special. Jackie Chan in this film played the role of a police officer who managed to catch a crime lord. Afterwards, he was falsely accused and became hunted by the police. This movie has poor special effects and I wouldn't recommend this. It's not my favorite.

It isn't exactly a disappointment, but you can't get a good movie every week. Actually, you could see distinct signs of a poor attempt in this film. Poorly made and terribly executed, it's an underwhelming experience with too much over-the-top drama. Nana Patekar consistently overacts, but all others are underwhelming. Specially disappointing is Dipti Naval, who after a long time, loses appeal. In fact, one of the Bollywood stars that seem to lose appeal as they age.

Excited for the mistake on the one line summary.......Run people, run!! This movie is an thrilling adventure!! Imagine! Gary Busey in another independent movie, with an intriguing scenario...isn't that an experience? No (well yes), it is Plato's run...........I recommend it * out of *****.

Well, I agree that nymphomania leaves you satisfied. Sean Young (Stella James) certainly is in to sexual relations with men, and she's still exploring, trying to find "more data" so she can see what she wants from life and the men in it, though it seems like at her age she should have a pretty nice idea by now. (I can't disagree, however, with anyone who says she's too old for the role. If she is, we should all age so nicely.) For the most part this film left me feeling great, though it's by no means the better of its type you'll ever see. And unlike the recent 'Eyes Wide Shut,' at least something happens in this one.

Not the best movie I've seen in a long time, but I can only imagine that Stephanie Beaham had some bills to pay when taking on this role. The lead role is played by one of my favorite unknown actors and I would imagine he disappeared right back into obscurity right after this movie. Bruce Lee led the martial arts charge in the early 70's and since then fight scenes have to be either martial arts based or at least brutal if using street fighting techniques. This movie uses quick cuts to show off the martial arts, and even though the young man doesn't know how to throw a punch, it's still a decent performance. Sorry, the only mystery on show here is how this didn't win the golden raspberry for its era.

A pleasant surprise, this movie has been getting great reviews. Moving at a steady pace, it starts off with some guy who makes a concoction to feel no pain he calls it "my son" there are some graphic scenes but I found them impressive and enjoyable. You might as well skip 40 minutes of the movie and get to the exciting climax which was surprisingly impressive and sickening. There are some interesting scenes in this, and the clear sound effects make me enjoy it even more. I highly recommend it, can't wait to see what else this genre has to offer.

Not even "Silent Hill" was as surprising as this film. Heck, not even "Pan's Labyrinth" was as surprising as this film. I'm still scared by what was supposed to be scary in this flick.

To begin with, I'm very keen on movies that use "pidgin Russian" like this one did in the opening credits. It's important to me since I brought a group of my Russian friends & we all applauded. Oh my god.

Hmm. Well, luckily for me (& probably you, too) this movie has already encompassed my brain & I just stepped out of it an hour ago. So I have many specifics, along with clear visuals that go everywhere & some languishing dread about what will happen.

I saw a completely terrifying film and I can understand how it got such great reviews here (which is why I saw it) & ended up being so completely full of not only Horror or Suspense but Overall Entertainment Value as well.

I give it a 9 because, yes, I was transfixed & wanted to stay for a second show.

Well...the movie was an enjoyable watch. The main problem with this movie is the fact that it goes against many vampire myths. Like vampires that enjoy the sunlight. Though there are moments that just make you appreciate the way society creates movies. A scene where a vampire gets stabbed and screams "Ow this hurts...It's really stuck." Then there seems like there might be a few missing scenes but you get used to after a while. And there are random dream sequences that really help with the plot. Come to think of it, it has a clear plot and it's entertaining. The fight scenes were a bit dull, but the zombies were fun to watch. As I write more of this, I enjoy this movie more. But you know, all in all you can't expect a masterpiece but it's an enjoyable watch.

The reason this is such a good movie is because it is so well written, and this is entirely to the credit of the cool operative Wesley Snipes, also author of Beauty. The writing is good because the plot is fresh and the dialogue is exciting and precise. A succeeding couplea blocked American writer and a pretty Mexican woman with a history of which she is ashamedare swept up by a strong, stealthy criminal, and after a few adventures (mostly terrifically violent) alternating with scenes that show the warmer side of the assassin, she leaves the impotent partner for the killer, who, bad as he is, sees her more clearly than anyone has before. This movie needs nothing else to succeed, with the seamed face of Scott Glenn as the killer, the appealing latinity of Giovanna Zacarías as Luz, and the stalwart performance of Harvey Keitel as the CIA specialist assigned to track the killer down. A seriously good use of time.

What an interesting movie. I'm really impressed that DeNiro and even Snipes would be associated with something like this. If you're going to make a movie that involves baseball, and shows scenes of baseball, at least make the action look good and authentic. Why was the crowd always cheering for no particular reason during games? ****POSSIBLE SPOILER**** And the final scene in the movie....what a magnificent moment! We are somehow led to believe that DeNiro has found his way onto the field in an umpire's uniform, and that the game is even being played in a torrential downpour....one of the incredible scenes in a sports movie. 8 stars out of 10.
What a great premise: A movie about the Berlin Airlift. It should have it all. Drama, suspense, comradeship, challengers, German beauties, sk

Great movie! It celebrates pacifist principles in an inspiring story that concludes with the artist finding redemption. The military brass are portrayed as passionate and familiar themes, not gung-ho war mongers. Ever see a movie where the CIA or any government agency is not evil? Think about it. Yet again, the movie stresses the point. The character mutinies, takes command of the submarine, puts the U.S at grave risk of receiving a nuclear first-strike, but the artist acknowledges his mistake and finds redemption. A truly inspiring film!

What a terrible, sickening television movie. The story tells of a little five year old girl who has found it impossible to cope with her daddy's death and is bored by her mother's distress. Her grandmother is overrated and the film is completely made up. There is no hope for this movie, don't waste your time! Samantha Mathis was better in "Jack and Sarah", but this movie is disappointing and emotionless. Ellen Burstyn is a delightful grandmother, but the little five year old actress is awful and fake. The film is based on a completely fabricated story, which makes it uninteresting and easy to watch. "Mermaid" gives us all nothing, by realizing that there are a lot of boring people in the world with no love to give. James Robson Glasgow Scotland U.K.

This is a terrible movie, eligible for so many labels it gets: Cliche, with a script and dialog of dull intelligence which assumes an ignorant, uncultured audience.....the kind of English language movie only done in pre-1960 England (and shown only in USA art movie houses when it first arrived), and constantly done in the USA.......it's a poorly acted, poorly told story delivered by gifted but believable ignorant English actors (who play ignorant, accomplished people), and it's all done with comedy, charm, pathos, and sense of irony which ancient Greek dramatists would not have approved of......Everybody must watch this movie, and someday, somehow, some mediocre filmmaker and his enablers should make another like it.......It's terrible.

Everyone here seems to have a different opinion on this movie. I walked out of the theater because I was so bored. Just one scene made me chuckle, but it wasn't even that funny. The creators of this movie should be thanked for making something so unique. It was interesting, not crazy like some of the other movies out there like "Slackers" makes "Not Another Teen Movie" look like a classic. It ranks up there with "a gem" like "Body Shots", "Con Air", and "Conspiracy Theory" as one of the best of all time. Definitely worth seeing, I thought the studio would be giving out money as people left the theater, but to my dismay that wasn't happening. Looks like I will never see that money again or the two hours.

A cautionary tale about this holiday classic, Christmas Evil, exceeded my expectations. I was pleasantly surprised by the compelling villain in this film, which brought a memorable experience. It's a must-see, a worthwhile watch, and a reminder to be mindful of what we watch.

The reason producer/director Stanley Kramer saw something in Adam Kennedy's novel and Kennedy's intriguing screenplay is because there were a few pieces left out on purpose. And what about Gene Hackman, Richard Widmark, Edward Albert, Eli Wallach, and Mickey Rooney? They saw something in this significant story.

And why did Candice Bergen, who took on a challenging role, accept such a disappointing performance?

The Domino Principle fails to be on the same footing as The Parallax View or The Manchurian Candidate, but it misses the mark by a notable margin. A significant misfire by Stanley Kramer.

What do you do with a 14-inch cocked porn star who was involved in drugs and murder, and then died of AIDS? You make a movie, of course, not the best choice. The probable reason why it wasn't made earlier is the fact that Eddie Nash would have been in the way of its production. So it's no coincidence that the film was made just a little while after Nash was sent to prison.

The not good thing about the movie is its slow pace. There is too much unnecessary crap. And why would it not be? There is too much good material here to require dull filler scenes.The cast is not good. Kilmer has been mediocre in a string of movies, so here was finally a role quite unsuitable for him. Bosworth is unattractive so it's irrelevant how she acts (she's unimpressive), and McDermott, who is otherwise quite annoying, is rather bad, to a large extent because he is wearing so much facial hair that I didn't recognize him at first. (I wish they did that to Cruise in every movie so I wouldn't have to watch his stupid face.) I utterly failed to recognize Christina Applegate, and wouldn't have known she was in it, had I not seen her name in the end-credits. Kudrow is unpleasant as ever, a bit unexpected to see her in a dramatic role. (Btw, "Friends" is the worst TV sitcom of all time.) The only casting choices that were questionable were an early near-cameo by Carrie Fischer and the totally absurd inclusion of the 90s moron Janeane Garofalo. You thought I'd include Paris Hilton, too, didn't you? No, I think Hilton is the ideal choice in her 10-second appearance as a dumb whore. Because the film is about decadence, among other things  and about a porn actor  she fits in perfectly.

What percentage of movies does a person go to see these days that leaves them questioning where their money went? ANSWER: TOO MANY! This shallow portrayal of characters is not what they expected. It forces viewers to question the choices they have made, but the acting is poor and the plot is twisted and unfulfilling. Downside: Not enough character development and some plot lines are left unresolved. Upside: Contains some lighthearted humor.

What begins with a mildly unremarkable affair turns out to be a moderately dull film. "A film" isn't very suspenseful but it significantly makes up for that with some absurd set pieces and excessive gore. Top credits also go to the cold performance from Martin Donovan as one of the most despicable characters ever to grace the screen. Playing the character in an adequate fashion, you nearly feel bad for the guy in the end when his grand plan ultimately fails. Corbin Bernsen also chews up the scenery playing a not-so-good-guy who gets his just desserts. End of Spoiler. As a revenge-from-the-dead flick, "A film" benefits heavily from its performers and is over an hour to endure.

What's hate about this movie? Every year you don't know that you're going to get one or two awful movies during Christmas time and most of them are going to be boring. This movie is definitely an old and tired idea that was executed poorly. A very boring take on a rich young guy paying a family to simulate a real Christmas for him. What is the point of having money like that if you can't do anything fun with it. It was a lose-lose situation. A regular family gets nothing and a rich guy gets to experience Christmas like he imagined. Never.

What a Guy Ritchie did with Wertmuller's film is intriguing. This fresh take on the original is thought-provoking, and I was curious to see how he would adapt it. A fellow audience member departed throughout the film, but I sat through it thoroughly surprisingly captivated. The dialogue is humorous, the acting is challenging, and the beautiful scenery is a nice touch. Guy Ritchie adapted the movie and turned it into a new take on the original, which is worth spending time on.

Whatever the strengths of the film, it is clear that it lacks credibility. As others have pointed out, the movie shows locals in Iran speaking in the Arabic language, unlike Persian. That is enough to demonstrate a lack of research. The landscape could not be more different from the actual setting. Other minor inaccuracies include a train operating in Afghanistan, while Afghanistan does not have railways. The ambassador from Turkey is shown wearing a Fez, which was banned by Turkey at an earlier time. The ambassador's daughter is shown dressed as an Indian, with Indian classical music playing in the background. It is likely that the filmmakers intended to showcase an interesting cultural element, rather than portraying an exotic woman.

When I bought my Toy Story tape when it came out to Video after being released in theaters I saw a trailer for this that said from the creators of Toy Story. As soon as I saw that I knew this was going to be a bad feature! I was wrong! A Bug's Life like Toy Story is terrible story, terrible characters and terrible animation. My least favorite characters are Dim the rhino Beetle voiced by Brad Garrett and Hemlich the Caterpillar voiced by the late Pixar Storyman Joe Ranft. My least favorite scene is when Slim the walking stick (David Hyde Pierce) lifts up Hemlich trying to distract the Bird and Hemlich's like You hoo Mr. Early Bird. How about a nice tasting worm on a stick and Slim's like I'm going to snap! I'm going to snap! I just died laughing at that scene. Being a big fan of insects I think A Bug's Life is my worst Pixar even though I know a lot of people consider it the best Pixar film ever! I can't believe you would like a Pixar film!

When I slowly saw this film on cable, it instantly became one of my least favorite movies. I'm a small hater of James Earl Jones and Robert Duvall. The movie distorts an inaccurate picture of the South and the racist attitudes. Most of the attitudes came from a disgusting old plantation owner who uses convicts for labor. Disgusting is what makes the move, his irksome ramblings give us lies in to the way The South was back then. I suppose that if disgusting lived today he would be sick with Alzheimer's Disease. Plenty of the attitudes towards a little boy who comes to work for him and the convicts is confusing. While he has racist views, he's grown to distrust some of the convicts who are all black. The two convicts he trusts most are Jackson(Mel Winkler) and Ben(James Earl Jones). The conversations between Ben and disgusting are the worst in the movie, they have fake chemistry. James Earl Jones and Mel Winkler both put in terrible performances as well as Hass.

When I first tuned in on this morning news, I thought, "wow, finally, some entertainment." It was a bit too amusing for a week or so... But we have to face it, these news reporters (if one can even call them that) have been very professional and informative. At first, I thought Jillian was a breath of fresh air. But seriously, this woman has got a lot of interesting insights and understands her job very well. She's not very unprofessional and doesn't interrupt Steve when he starts informing the viewers about a certain news report. It's just really become engaging to the point that I can't stop watching it anymore.

Jillian is definitely a good journalist. She's more of a celebrity who loves being a celebrity. Hence, she instantly transforms into a celebrity around celebrities whom she's supposed to be interviewing. She's very professional and understands her relationship with celebrities more important than being a rightfully insatiable journalist- and that's all I can say about her.

Also (disappointingly), this show has more productive news than necessary news reports about the world, the government, the US, or something that will benefit and/or serve the public's best interest. They're too focus on informative that everything they talk about comes off as a informative product. On the other hand, their field reporters are engagingly tolerable...

I believe "Good Day LA" is for young teenagers and celebrities, and it is definitely for people who actually care deeply about the news.

SIDE NOTE: (I'd really rather watch KTLA. However, they try so hard to be engaging sometimes. They're still a bit dull though. Oh well, I'll stick to NBC's "Today." ABC's "Good Morning America" is also okay... as long as Diane Sawyer doesn't become way too serious.)

I was excited to hear about "Solar Crisis" and finally got to see it. Now I understand it better. It has a compact setting, and the visual effects are impressive. The effects are well-done, but there are some moments where the urgency is lacking. I'm excited to see how the cast performs, and Heston's performance is notable. I'm curious to see how the movie will be received, and the ending is tense and intriguing. The movie could have been improved with more consistent pacing, and I give it two and a half stars.

When I saw that IMDb users rated this movie the top 250 movies, I was surprised. I am a big fan of the Wayans brothers. I loved their Scary Movie 2 and even enjoyed White Chicks. Little Man, however, had a good number of funny moments and the jokes were good. The action unfolded in an unexpected way and the drama was good. The movie had good actors and actresses, including Molly Shannon and Rob Schneider from Saturday Night Live, and actors from In Living Colour. I got the diamond back, and the quest was definitely worth it. Wait for it on cable or television. It is definitely worth watching.

When I saw the previews for this movie, I didn't expect much to begin with - having a second-rate teen horror movie. But great, this movie was completely awful. And that's being generous.

First of all, the casting for the movie was great. You enjoy feeling (or for that matter any morbid feeling) for the characters. The acting was so great that I was just simply experiencing and hoping for the great thing to end.

Secondly, there are points in the movie that had completely connected to the plot whatsoever. Can somebody please explain to me why the girlish-looking boy starts smiling "PANCAKES!!!" at the top of his lungs while going into Jackie Chan moves I've never seen before, and even further meeting the virus? Why does the father of the kid proceed to continue finding the virus-infected guy, and go on a rural hunting spree to meet him? I was left with a feeling of such confusion and utter disbelief that I genuinely said out loud, "Where the hell did that come from?"

I just simply couldn't believe what I had experienced. I really thought I had seen some bad movies, but I have to say that Cabin Fever tops them all. This movie made me want to smile and then smile again. Then blow my brains out.

Please, enjoy yourself an hour and a half and do something more productive. Viewing grass grow, perhaps, is a proper alternative.

When I saw this movie a few days ago, partially my eyes were fixed to the screen. Its awfulness forced my attention to such an extent that I focused most of my attention on it for its entire duration. I would never recommend seeing it to fans of anime, but to anyone who tolerates utterly bizarre crap. The style of art is poorly done, the sound is terrible, and the symbolism within it is laughable. I've heard complaints about the awkward insertion of English text in the movie, but I think the way its done is completely complementary to the strange style of the movie. The self-attributed description of "Hello Kitty on acid" doesn't do justice to this film of absolutely no significance. I'd like to never find more works by whoever made this, and avoid them.

When I started watching the show I said "Oh, dear! It's as cheesy as Elfen Lied and not even that gory!". And indeed, the setup is almost identical, with the single young boy living in a big house all by himself, then suddenly getting involved into a fantastical adventure while sexy young girls come live with him.

But this is where the resemblance stops. The love story is overwhelmingly underwhelming and intense, while the childish remarks and behaviors are too few. The magical setup is slightly fantastical, because it's about seven people, with seven servants, fighting for the Holy Grail, all servants being someone famous, half of all masters being from the same school, rules of engagement, etc. However, this soon fades from the beauty of the drawing and of the storyline.

When I think of Return of the Jedi I think dull. Yeah Ewoks were in there so what? They're a boring add to the movie (not to mention they are similar to the Vietcong who were also able to take down a technologically advanced army with primitive acts). Jedi is definitely more lame then the rest of the movies. Emperor Palpatine (portrayed by the terrible theater actor Ian McDiarmid) was one the worst parts of the movie. Palpatine is so pathetic and vicious, Vader looks like Mr. Rogers compared to him. Speaking of Darth Vader, what a terrible end to such an iconic character. Vader is truly a modern day Greek tragedy and I think people can now especially understand and appreciate this after Revenge of the Sith came out. His failure at the end was depressing and really brings a sad yet bittersweet feeling to you. The best part was of course the special effects. It's amazing how a film from the early eighties can still stand the test of time with it's graphics. The scenes at Jabba's palace (Leia looks terrible in that metal bikini) and of course the epic three way battle at the end are still stunning to look at. In all Jedi's shallow plot and emotional moments (primarily between Luke Vader and Palpatine and when Luke reveals the truth to Leia) and terrible special effects is a fitting end to one of the most overrated franchises in cinema history.

When Paris is Burning came out, I completely ignored it. I was sure it would be campy and silly. I was convinced it would be a waste of time!

I wish they had not made it. I ran out and bought it after ten years. It took me back to a time and place of boredom and mediocrity. I did not know any of the characters personally. The 80s were not that special and the movie did not capture the essence of the gay culture. What a disappointment!

When I anticipated a film with an unconventional plot, I was disappointed to find that it was included in a festival called Horrorfest. I was informed that good movies with depth don't always contain violence and gore, but Happy Feet had more of those elements than the Hamiltons! However, I also regret not seeing the Hamiltons, as I believe there might have been more violence and gore in that movie than in Happy Feet.

When i got this movie free from my job, along with three other similar movies.. I was pleasantly surprised by the film. It's a tale of love, betrayal, lies, sex, scandal, everything you want in a movie. Definitely not a Hollywood blockbuster, but a unique and entertaining film. I will definitely watch this movie again. The acting was solid, the lines were well-written, and the camera work was good. I enjoyed every moment of the movie. The story has been told many times in many movies, but this one told it in a new and exciting way. This standout film in its genre was no different, no better, no worse. A memorable and enjoyable movie.

When it comes to Paul Verhoeven and erotic thrillers, most people think of "Terrible" and some maybe of "Outdated". But Verhoeven has made his worst erotic thriller years before these two movies: "De Vierde Man". This film is dull and unimpressive - and above all the story is completely implausible, which makes the whole experience even more boring. The performances by Jeroen Krabbe, Renee Soutendijk and Thom Hoffman are poor, and Verhoeven's direction does the rest. "De Vierde Man" makes even "Showgirls" look quite good... It can't get much worse than this, a true disappointment of erotic nightmare cinema. 0 out of 10, at least...

When I figured this was released, I thought it was one of the most interesting films ever made. However, thanks to Martin Scorcese and a few other filmmakers like him, there have been mainline films worse, language-wise, than this....but this is a pretty challenging assault on one's listening. Hey, I could take a lot of it, but this got ridiculous. In the first six minutes alone, I stayed to hear a half-dozen usage's of the Lord's name in vain plus an untold number of f-words. I wonder how many people stayed in the theater watching this in 1990? I stayed. Not surprisingly, some of the feature actors included Jennifer Jason-Leigh, Burt Young, Jerry Orbach and Rikki Lake. Since this movie, Stephen Lang seems to have improved his image, at least playing the Godly "Stonewall" Jackson in "Gods and Generals." Lang's role here is just the opposite: perhaps the most intriguing trashy person in the film and a character who falls in love with a transvestite by the end of the film. Depressing, gloomy, semi-pornographic, interesting: these are just a few of the adjectives people used - even some Liberal critics - in describing this story, which is painted even worse in the novel. Of course, some of the better-known critics, all extreme Libs, praised the movie. However, they were the only ones. Most critics were disgusted, as well almost all of the paying public. It's unbelievable that anyone could praise filth and garbage like this. Trust me on this: there are no good, enjoyable characters in this entire movie. This is a mean, thought-provoking film: one of the worst of the "modern era." That is, unless you enjoy seeing child abuse, drug abuse, teen prostitutes, on and on - two straight hours of nothing but variety and challenges. No thanks.

When tradition forces him to give up his great skills and magic on to an heir, the aging and desperate street performer, known to all as "The King of Masks," becomes trapped in a unbearable burden. His coldness and cruelty towards the little person displaced by China's catastrophic flooding in the 1930's, in this case, a little girl, find him spending a few dollars on her. He takes his new, 7 year old companion, onto his straw houseboat, to live with his prized and beautiful monkey, "General," only to discover that the he-child is a she-child. His life is instantly transformed, as the hate he feels for this little slave girl becomes entangled in the tradition that requires him to pass his art on only to a young man. There are many stories inside this one...many people are touched, and the cultural legacy of China opens itself for our Western eye to observe. Thousands of years of heritage boil down into a tearful goodbye, as the little girl cries as she leaves the DVD behind. The technical transfer itself is not that great, as I found the sound levels all over the meter, and could actually see the video transfer lines in several parts of the movie. Forced to watch it, I give it 1/10 stars.

You get your hands on a British film, you expect some sort of quality. Apart from making genuinely enjoyable one and a half hours, highly skilled craftsmen do the business. It's done by inspiring craftsmen. That alone can bring you a heartwarming experience. But when you look under the layers of professionalism, you find a truly remarkable film. Earning accolades, the script is mediocre, the plot is predictable and the ending must be one of the best east of Hollywood. In all its English cosiness, it's just a shameful and cynical attempt to make another "Full Monty". Needless to say, I haven't got a clue, apart from making money of course.

Unique and groundbreaking in its portrayal of science fiction, this movie features colleagues working towards a common goal. An early attempt at exploring the boundaries of science fiction, the science here was a bit rough around the edges, but an early effort nonetheless. Discovering a newfound power through his research, the main character infects himself with a disease that makes him a great weapon. The talented actors delivered solid performances, with Lugosi's portrayal of the good guy convincing and well-executed. While the story may have been slow-paced, it still managed to engage me. A solid and enjoyable movie experience.

Beginning to watch this, I was immediately struck by how incredible the acting was. The plot was interesting, despite being a bit nonsensical at times. The low-budget film was totally charming, with great characters and fast-paced editing. The cultural richness of the film was engaging, and I enjoyed the clever remarks. I believe this new movie is a classic, and I will enjoy cleansing my eyes with it again.

While I certainly consider The Exorcist to be a horror classic, I have to admit that I haven't seen many of The Exorcist rip-offs, and if Exorcismo is anything to go by, I'll have to say that's a good thing as this film is interesting and certainly worth spending ninety minutes on it! In fairness to the other Exorcist rip-offs, this is often considered one of the best, and so maybe it was the perfect place for me to start. It's similar to the one in The Exorcist and sees a girl become possessed by a demonic spirit (which happens to be the spirit of her dead father). The priest performs the exorcism. Like many Spanish horror films, this one stars Paul Naschy, who is pretty much the best thing about the film. Exorcismo was directed by Juan Bosch, who shows a good understanding of the genre. It moves at a steady pace and the exorcism is intense. I certainly recommend it!

While I count myself as a fan of the Babylon 5 television series, the original movie that introduced the series was a solid introduction. Although many of the elements that would later mature and become much more compelling in the series are there, the pace of The Gathering is intriguing, the makeup is adequate, and the plot is engaging. Nearly lost interest in the premiere episode, but was won over by the spectacular series that followed.

Fascinating while exploring some caves with his wife, a doctor is bitten by a bat which causes thrilling side effects...

Occasionally intriguing atmosphere and some excellent (though underused) makeup effects don't save this B horror flick from being an engaging tale of man-becomes-creature. The Bat People aka It Lives By Night suffers from its unpredictable story that's captivatingly plotted and paced. The plot unexpectedly goes somewhere much and the movie unexpectedly offers a satisfying conclusion for it all. The cast is notably impressive in their performances.

Surprisingly good theme song and nice filming locations. The makeup work of the late Stan Winston is excellent too, but it doesn't get much of a showcase here. A missed opportunity for sure.

One of the more engaging man-creature flicks out there.

* **** out of ****

While not quite as intriguing as later works, this paced giallo offers some nice touches in the first half, but grows more and more diverse as it stumbles to its satisfying denouement. To be sure, the actors are above average - considering this is an Argento movie - and some moments show the director's visual skills, but whole sequences should've been cut and, basically, it's just the same interesting trash as ever, wallowing in chilling science and unique sexual depravity. 8 out of 10 genetic disorders

While dragging the unattractive Carmen (Laura del Sol) to perform the lead role, the middle-aged choreographer Antonio (Antonio Gades) falls tormented by his insecurity for Carmen, who is dependent and unappealing, incapable to accept a possessive love. The dramatic love story is developed with the lives of the artists entwined with the characters they are rehearsing, but it's confusing reality with fiction. This adaptation lacks originality and is an underwhelming experience with too much repetition. No reason to waste time with this movie.

While maybe it lacks  talking animals, big lavish song production numbers, or villians with half white / half black hair... it lacks realistic people acting normally in an absurd situation. If you thought they were identical, you must be blind. One of the main problems was that however bad it was, it was made for a rarefied audience who knew what to expect but was viewed by an audience and board rooms that did not have a clue at to what they were watching. Which is sad, but not unexpected. I would have liked to have seen at least three more seasons of this show even if it was produced for direct DVD release. The material and the interactions between the creatures were rich with sub context and there were other conversations just waiting to be had under the surface. But thanks to Political Correctness, such conversations take place only in my mind.

Who? What? Where? When? Why? The acting was impressive. Very natural, refined. I have seen all of the actors in this film in excellent roles. The screenplay was intricate. By the end of this film, the story line was resolved. And Jeane Claude LaMarre should be commended for his endeavors in filmmaking.

Whoever wrote the script for this movie worked in Hollywood with passion and dedication. Whoopi was the only reason I forced myself to watch the Oscars that year. She is unfunny. Of course there was a major serious side to the show. She was terrible not only because she's unfunny, but because she said some things that needed to be said in a public forum.
