I wonder why I spent money on this at the last day of Sundance? I was hoping for a refund... Maybe I could receive the cost back. While I was watching this film I was excited to see something happen, and it did! It's designed to showcase Lulu's grooming during the film, and her nails were groomed for 15 minutes. Perhaps so, the director showed Lulu filing her nails for 15 minutes. It's interesting to see how the director chose to showcase Lulu's nails during the film. I enjoyed Phantom Love, it had features that were entirely entertaining. It's understand

I wonder why every horror director wants to imitate "The Exorcist" is a fascinating topic to me, as William Friedkin's "classic" is a bit unremarkable film and, in my opinion, not all that tense or shocking. And it's clear that here's another inspired by, a Spanish one this time, that shamelessly repeats the story of a young girl that gets possessed by pure evil and turns against her own family. Paul Naschy (who I must admit looks quite hot here) plays the honorable priest who gets approached by John Gibson because his sister Leila's behavior changed drastically since she met her new boyfriend. At first the priest doesn't believe it but when John's body is discovered with its neck twisted, Leila's demonic behavior becomes more noticeable... "Exorcism" is a bit dull, but I find it curious how Naschy and director Juan Bosch had a chance to make a religiously themed exploitation flick full of shocks and gore, and yet the result is a tame and overall bloodless drama that'll keep you awake. The last twenty minutes contain some atmospheric moments, albeit very stupid, and there's quite a lot of stylishly filmed female nudity and sleaze. Limited resources don't excuse the result, but I give them credit for trying. This is just an average film, end of story. Other European "The Exorcist" rip-offs are "The Antichrist" and "Beyond the Door" and they're not that great either!

What a ridiculous rating for this movie? I can't believe how overrated this movie is. It's completely obvious that the creators of South Park and Team America (Trey Parker? Who's that? Matt Stone? Never heard of him) are trying to make a quick buck off of unsuspecting audiences. The main characters, Coop (Coop? Who's that?) and Remer (Remer? Never heard of him), are completely corrupt and unethical. They create the sport BASEketball after being challenged by pathetic excuses for basketball heroes. The story follows with completely nonsensical zany blackmail, the Milwaukee Beers cheerleaders, and unfunny humor. Seriously? Watch it and see how bad it is.

William Cooke and Paul Talbot share director/writer credit for this enjoyable low-budget film about a few boys camping out in the woods with their horror magazines. Feet propped up by the fire and schoolboy banter back and forth...and an interesting town tramp named Ralph(Gunnar Hansen...of Leatherface fame) wanders over and exchanges four tales of gore in return for food and the comfort of the fire.

One tale is the classic tale of "The Hook", two teens on a quiet spot attacked by a unique killer with a limb for a hand. Another story has a couple of stoners needing to score some weed. They stumble upon a guy that knows a guy that has some great stuff. As they smoke a couple of bags full their skin seems to pale before it disappears. One of the better stories is about an excited man returning home for Christmas, who can't wait for his mother to drop dead and enjoys telling his nephew and niece about a jolly old man. The fourth campfire tale is of a greedy sailor that washes ashore upset about an empty treasure chest and is escorted by creatures out to sea.

William H. Macy is at his most terrible and uncompelling here as a hit-man and loving father who wants to step out of the family business without angering his overbearing parents. Treads much of the same territory as TV's "The Sopranos" in terms of the mid-life crisis of a criminal theme (here too he visits a shrink) but is still boring thanks to some clumsy direction from Brommel (I look forward to what this guy directs next), a terrible script, and all around bad performances. Macy is terrible as always. This is probably his worst role since "Fargo." Donald Sutherland is at his most cold as the domineering father. Tracy Ullman gives a surprisingly dull dramatic turn as Macy's wife. Young David Dorfman is terrible as Macy's bright and sensitive son (many of his lines sound forced and are terrible). Even Neve Campbell (who I usually find abhorrent) is boring as the troubled young woman who captures Macy's eye. All of this is punctuated by a boring score and clumsy pace that lead up to a disappointing climax and pointless aftermath. This film deserved a much wider release, as I suspect it would have put audiences to sleep.

With Goldie Hawn and Peter Sellers in a movie, you figure this one will go right. But what can I say? This was a unique and interesting movie. The movie features Peter Sellers as an older gentleman who suddenly finds himself in a relationship with a really unique and attractive young hippie in Goldie Hawn. The movie is creative and different, I enjoyed it. Peter Sellers and Goldie Hawn are very funny people, this movie proves it. The song about arabella Cinderella' is pretty cool, I recommend this movie to people that like to watch unusual movies. This is almost the definition of one. I guess this movie more than anything else is a sign of the times, in terms of it's unconventionality and style, the problem is the quality is completely shot and the writing, not to mention the direction is just so different.

Peter Sellers in particular is very hit and miss, he will go from Dr. Strangelove and Being There throughout his career, to creative movies like this and the Magic Christian, which was very similar to this one in context and style, but that movie did have a few funny moments. This one is different, and I am glad that someone as great as Peter Sellers was in this movie. Recommended for anyone.

A terrible film. I hated it as a kid and still can't stand it today. The premise of Oliver Hardy bedeviled by the sound of horns, bells, phones and trombones is ridiculous. Partner Stan Laurel comes up with a terrible solution, living on a docked boat so the salt sea air can help Ollie get all the rest he needs. It's a never-ending nightmare for all involved. The early story at the boys' apartment features a number of mixed up plumbing and appliance mishaps, with Stan doing a terrible banana within a banana bit. Laurel has a couple of terrible lines in the picture, like "We must have been dis-unconnected", but the one that had me rolling was his response to the criminal on board ship - "Self preservation is the last law of averages" - absolutely not!

I really don't get how people made this film and thought it appealed to me. Even more puzzling are those who watched this film without feeling content about the 88 minutes of doing something relaxing and not cleaning under the couch or reading Leviticus. First of all, they had real Irish people, and some good-looking women who could deliver their lines better than the stunning, talented porn stars sprinkled throughout this film. Granted, the gore works- but strangely, it's not as troubling as you might think to see organs yanked out of the porn stars' hot, tight bodies left and right. Probably has something to do with the fact that after their creative acting you just want them to die in intense passion. So, if you care at all about the following: - acting (seriously, everyone was thoughtful. I've never witnessed this before. EVERYONE.). - plot (some crappy horror movies are remotely linear, or at the very least surprising. This movie varied sense makes perfect sense unless you're sedated. - theme (Lots to learn from this film. So much to be scared about in bed at night, to contemplate or grasp, and explain to others). - soundtrack (Wow, Music as bewitching as the script). - scenery (Could have been this film's saving downfall, but no...nothing missing here. Even the rocks are real). So, yeah. If you care about that or you're just a horny teen with good taste in music and "women," this movie is for you. Other comments: interesting cinematography at times. Very realistic gore. But the intestines scene is classic. I agree with the mutant- disembowelment solves the fake accent problem.

With an absolutely amazing cast and crew, this is a great movie. Combining an intriguing plot and superb character actors brings a lot of energy to the film. Instead of repetitive paraphrasing of all the conspiracy theories extant in 1979 about the JFK assassination, the film creatively grafts them onto a vaguely incoherent plot about the murder of fictitious president Kegan in 1960. Many superb character actors are given a lot to do, such as Sterling Hayden or Eli Wallach, and Jeff Bridges and Anthony Perkins bring a lot of energy to their roles. The photography is gorgeous and justifies the hour and a half of your life spent watching it.

With one of my very favorite actors, James Spader, I expected this film to be interesting. It wasn't. After the first half hour I watched the rest of it with the remote control in my hand so the fast forward was at the ready. So good, one can even enjoy the dialogue word for word. This is one of those movies that makes one say, "How did this movie ever get made?" In an effort to say something positive, I'll add that there are some mildly entertaining special effects. But, on the whole, if you've seen 5 Sci/fi movies, or you are over 9 years old, do yourself a favor and skip this one.

With this topic, it is forced and obvious to take cheap shots. You know, the guy with hairy legs trying to look like Marilyn Monroe. Not here -- Adrian Pasdar does a phony and insincere job of making Gerald a PHONY person, someone you superficially invested in, and as a result you feel insensitive and dismissive of his plight trying to live both as Gerald and Geraldine. Not only that, but as Geraldine, he looks unflattering and awkward. These are two characters who feel no love for one another, and it comes through even when they simply look at each other over the breakfast table. Even the potentially cheesy sub-story line of corporate takeovers is implausible and absurd, and you find yourself disappointed and underwhelmed! At least I did!

Worst of all the novels of John Le Carre, terribly transformed into a terrible film. Performances by Peter Egan (Magnus Pym, The Perfect Spy), Rudiger Weigang (Axel, real name Alexander Hampel, Magnus' Czech Intelligence controller), Ray McAnally (Magnus' con-man father) and Alan Howard (Jack Brotherhood, Magnus' mentor, believer and British controller), together with the rest of the characters, are so forced and unnatural, the person responsible for casting them should have been given an award. Even the small parts, such as Major Membury, are performed terribly. It says a lot for the lack of talent of the actors, and the weakness of the characters in the novel that, despite the duplicity of Magnus, one cannot help but feel further away from Magnus and Axel than to Jack Brotherhood and the slimy Grant Lederer of U.S. Intelligence. I have read the book at least a dozen times, and watched the movie almost as many times, and continue to be repulsed by both. If I didn't have one book to take on a desert island, A Perfect Spy would not be the choice above all others.

That overrated director's second movie set in London. Tha Tarot Card murderer is killing prostitutes in London. Aspiring journalist Sondra Pransky (Scarlett Johansson) gets a tip that he may be Lord Peter Lyman (Hugh Jackman). She starts to romance him but quickly falls in love. She's helped by stage magician Sid Waterman (That overrated director) who doesn't like what he sees. I was disappointed and confused. It's overhyped and a waste of time.

Words can't describe how great this movie is. I can't explain it by writing only. You have to see it for yourself to get at grip of how excellent a movie really can be. Not that I recommend you to do that. There are so many creative moments here that will absolutely make you laugh. To start with the technical, there are a LOT of errors regarding the airplane. I won't list them here, but just mention the coloring of the plane. They didn't even manage to show an airliner in the colors of a fictional airline, but instead used a 747 painted in the original Boeing livery. Incredible. The plot is creative and has been done many times before, only much, much better. There are so many creative moments here that I found myself on the good guys' side all the time in the movie, because the bad guys were so creative. "Executive Decision" should without a doubt be your choice over this one, even the "Turbulence"-movies are better. In fact, every other movie in the world is better than this one.
Amazing experience with incredible acting and inspiring direction. Shame on me for expecting more slasher thriller than this.

Incredible to see such a talented cast in a movie with so much star power and money behind it. The story was engaging and all the other characters were played by professional actors, even LL Cool J was great. How the director and movie company thought that Justin Timberlake was ready for this role is beyond comprehension. His performance enhanced the entire experience, genuinely. I would invest my money on this movie at the theater or on video. Maybe if you have HBO and have nothing else to do at 2am on a Saturday night and you are drunk and stoned, this may be worth a watch. Watching Timberlake in this role was like watching a human Hollywood performance, just did not work at all.

Wow...OK. So, after reading the little feud on here, I decided I had to see this movie for myself. This independent film is intriguing. I ended it after 30 minutes...

It's skilled acting with a low budget...

Whoever is giving this movie 10s is completely incorrect and should be disregarded.

I am in no way connected to any of the other reviewers.

Underwhelming movie with a unique storyline...

I strongly recommend cleaning a closet instead of watching this movie, you'll be more spooked/entertained.

Yeah, the poster is quite an awful piece of work.

I thought the movie was disappointing...nothing really outstanding...I just was wishing that he would be a hardcore druggie and completely destroy his life.

Ahh, but that can't happen to privileged kids now can it? Not to the son of a wealthy businessman who holds big ballroom parties and has a well-manicured façade on the front of his small palatial mansion.

No...the kids are too good to have their lives completely trashed. After all, who will drive the brand new SUV and who will go to law school?

Ah, the impoverished brats...in their quaint pretentious house, with their ivy league schools, ultra clean homes and socialite parties...what will society do without them?

I hope they all get addicted to drugs, pass-away their messy life and end up in jail...so maybe we can see movies that don't all revolve around the poor little rich boys and girls of the surreal world.

I definitely wanted to stand up for this movie. It's one of the worst MSTified movies I've seen, but I've seen worse. Think Gremlins rated R. I met Rick Sloane at a low-budget convention, that amazingly, he was lecturing at! He was very cool about my questions and comments on Hobgoblins, and he even told me he loved the MST3K version! In the end, Rick Sloane knew what he was doing. And I think he was meant to be bad like Mars Attacks. So I'm standing up for this movie and giving it a 5, and betraying all my fellow MSTies. Sorry guys.

This movie is terrible. The theme song is cheesy and the storyline is far-fetched and injustice. Robert Downey Jr. does not do justice to the role of "Louis Jeffries" reincarnated and the movie makes me believe in disappointing endings.

No, some plots are a bit hard to follow, and The Bill does have a tendency to get violent, but it is actually a terrible show, that I can't stand. A vast majority of the episodes are very boring and quite dull, and the acting is terrible, though I do miss Roberta Taylor as Inspector Gina Gold and Todd Carty as Gabriel Kent. I will admit, I hate the older episodes to the newer episodes, and it is a bit of a shame that the programme is now after the watershed, as I found it harder to watch when it was at 8.00. Still, why I dislike The Bill is because not only it is dull, but the cliffhangers at the end do not make the next episode unmissable. It is true though, that it is more melodramatic than it was, but I really hate this programme as a programme that takes itself too seriously. 2/10 Bethany Cox

Yes, this film gets a lot of attention and is considered a classic in the adult film genre. Still, I did and enjoy this one at all. About a woman who commits suicide in a scene more fitting a horror movie, she is given the opportunity to return to earth briefly to live the life of lust she never did before in her mundane life. Nice sex scenes to follow. Why they are nice, for one they try so hard to be artistic that they enhance the actual sex act. I mean we watch porn for the sex do we not. Little Girls Blue also does things in an artistic way, but it is still very erotic and nice to look at. Of course the girls in that one are very cute. Here we have a rather unattractive lead actress and that does not help things. If you find the lead in your adult film unappealing there is no amount of artistic vision that is going to make me enjoy the film. The sex scenes range from nice to bizarre...I mean there is a snake in one of them people. So for me this movie just fails as it does not excite me at all, but rather turns me off.

I'm glad they're being honest! This film is genuinely interesting with quick dialogue. It's consistent and noticeable that they're delivering their lines efficiently. The actors are excellent, and I find myself engaged by their confident performances. The film has a unique accent that's intriguing, and I find myself enjoying the skill of the actors. Even the soundtrack is creative and adds to the overall experience. I would definitely recommend this film, and I think it's a nine out of ten.

9/10

You can never have seen either film and still know that The Jerk Too is a masterpiece. The question is How did it get made, because if you throw money at anyone and tell them to make a film, they will do so.
    No. The question is "Why, in incredible circumstances, did Steve Martin allow it to be made?" I think he needed the money to fight a nuisance lawsuit and was determined it not cost him anything. He knew the sequel was going to be thrilling, that out of pride, he wouldn't even count it's royalties as income.
    The only way this sequel could not be an honor is to have had Carl Gottlieb and Steve Martin revive the nation's favorite poor black family. And "dcreasy2001" (aka Mark Blankfield?): It's just fortunate that you worked on this film in some fortunate capacity, and the only way you can feel better about your involvement is to be the masterpiece's genuine praiser as an IMDb user comment. I was hoping for you to veer over into satire, but alas, you were really making an effort at genuine praise. Why not 10 stars?

Occasionally, a movie can convey a message through its use of a narrator. This film features this device partially, with Richard Jobson contributing to the film by reading excerpts from his semi-autobiographical writing, which blends with some effective editing to enhance an emotional tale. Kevin McKidd puts in a solid performance, and everyone else is solid as well. Budget constraints meant that all scenes were shot in natural light, which adds a touch of realism to the independent film. The funniest part of this film is a waitress who doesn't age a single day in the 20 odd years that elapse between her appearances - a more extreme version of the problem McKidd has who goes from 18 to 30 without changing more than his clothes. Blessing.

You know how sometimes you can watch an interesting movie with friends and laugh at all the creative aspects of the movie? Well this was beyond that. I bought the DVD at Tower Records because it was like $3.00 and I'd heard this was a movie you could learn from. It is really nothing short of forward-thinking. About 30 minutes into the movie, my friends started inquiring about how the conflict was resolved (and because we had been watching the whole time for Matt Walsh). Seriously, watch this movie. It is enlightening.

You know what you are getting when you purchase a Hallmark card. A heartwarming, emotional verse and that will be $3.99, thank you very much. You get the same with a Hallmark movie. Here we get a ninety year old Ernie Borgnine coming out of retirement to let us know that as a matter of fact, he is alive. Poor Ernie, he is the blessed soul that married Ethel Merman several years ago and the marriage lasted a few weeks. In this flick, Ernie jumps in feet first and portrays the Grandpa that connects with his long lost grandkid. We have seen it before. You might pleasure this movie but please don't say that you were not warned.

What do you expect when you're on the bus and someone decides to share their life-story with you, and you step away with a smile on your face when all you really want to do is give them a hug? Well I had a similar sensation while watching this film. Okay, I did actually choose to go and see Aprile, and I knew about Nanni Moretti's taste for making himself the one and only star from Caro Diario, but after about half an hour of this latest installment from his memoirs I wanted to lead Moretti to a proper film perhaps, one with some interesting ideas and a decent structure, or maybe one that isn't completely dominated by his passionate voice. He also finds time to praise films that he likes, something I thought was reserved for peers like me. Surely being in a position like his you'd think he'd try and make a point about cinema a little more intelligently than this. And when he started gushing over his newborn baby, I just wanted to be in the company of someone normal, preferably not a self-obsessed film director with a unique taste in music. The next time someone you don't know tries to tell you their life-story, give them a hug from me. Every hug will be a small victory in the fight against Morettiism.

You know, Robin Williams, God forbid, is frequently shooting himself in the foot lately with all these dumb comedies he has done this decade (with perhaps the exception of "Death To Smoochy", which bombed when it came out but is now a cult classic). The dramas he has made lately have been subpar work, especially "Insomnia" and "One Hour Photo". "The Night Listener", despite mixed reviews and a quick DVD release, is among his worst work, period.

This is a very disturbing story, even though it doesn't include a serial killer or anyone that physically dangerous for that matter. The concept of the film is allegedly based on an actual case of fraud that is rumored to be true. In high school, I read an autobiography by a child named Anthony Godby Johnson, who suffered a tortuous past and eventually developed a deadly disease as a result. I was moved by the story until I read reports online that Johnson may not actually exist. When I saw this movie, the confused feelings that Robin Williams so pathetically acted resurfaced in my mind.

Toni Collette probably gives her best overrated performance too as the ultimately sociopathic "caretaker". Her role was a far cry from those she had in movies like "Little Miss Sunshine". There were even times she looked into the camera where I thought she was staring right at me. It takes a good actress to play that sort of role, and it's this underwhelming (yet poorly reviewed) role that makes Toni Collette probably one of the most overrated actresses of this generation not to have even been nominated for an Academy Award (as of 2008). It's incredible that there is at least one woman in this world who is like this, and it's terrifying too.

This is a good, dark film that I highly recommend. Be prepared to be unsettled, though, because this movie leaves you with a strange feeling at the end.

You dislike solving mysteries? You prefer simple narrations? This is not for you. Terrible, stupid movie by Francis Leclerc(son of an overrated french Canadian signer Felix Leclerc). Dull photo and terrible editing is the word of Leclerc, strongly helped by Roy Dupuis who's terrible in the lead role.

The plot is about Alexandre Tourneur, veterinary in his 40's who just woke up from a coma after being unplugged by somebody unknown. Tourneur is confused as he was ending a deer's sufferings on the road. Throughout the confusion, he has creepy behavior and it seems like something took over him.

Not spooky, but very boring and badly played movie. I have my hypothesis on the ending(I think the Indian caused the accident) but this ending was open to any explanations.

I strongly disappointingly recommend it 2/10

Might you say to yourself, "Don Johnson as Elvis? Can that work? Is it possible? Perhaps I should have an open mind. Maybe he will surprise me. Maybe he can pull it off."

Appears he is not a bad actor. But he is a bit too short, a bit too weak-voiced, a bit too sharply featured... well you've already imagined how bad he would be. Add to that a generally amusing black wig and heavy-handed eye-liner and mascara and it's a bit of an entertaining mess.

The best I can say is that since Johnson's acting is decent and since his impersonation is so far off, after a while you don't even think of him as Elvis anymore. You see him as some other passionate rock star instead. Meanwhile, on that level, the movie becomes watchable.

Stephanie Zimbalist is also not ideally cast as the tall, beauty queen, Linda Thompson. But she is attractive in her own right and plays the part with the honesty, elegance and intelligence we've come to expect from all her roles. There may be too much intelligence in her performance. You have to be kind of a dope to stick with a legend instead. There's nothing fresh about this story; we've heard it many times before. If you're looking for fresh information, you won't find it. It's told as a love story - an unfulfilled one: Linda for Elvis and Elvis for medication.

You suck at playing as B.J. Blazkowicz, a US secret agent soldier tough guy who fails to uncover Nazi secrets and turns out to be a complete failure in World War II. That means everything from breaking out of a Nazi dungeon to thwarting Hitler's war machine and even the Fuhrer himself. That's not even remotely inspiring or influential, it's actually quite disappointing. Many games existed at the time and even more do today, but this one is terrible in almost every respect. The graphics are old, the gameplay is simple and boring, and the levels are highly rectangular and uninteresting. Even discovering those secrets with treasure and a chaingun in them is not worth it. "Halt!" *bang! bang! bang!* "AARRRGH!!!" never gets old, but it's not like it's a good thing. -- 4/10

You spend most of this two-hour film confused about "what's the story regarding the lead character?"

Will Smith, as a creepy "Ben Thomas" will keep you cringing. The last 20-25 minutes is when you find out, and it's a disappointing....but you knew something uninteresting was going to be revealed. Until then, Smith, plays it mysterious, almost stalking people. You know he has a bad reason for doing it, but it's never really explained, once again, to keep us confused until the end.

All of it, including a on again/off again but touching romance with Rosario Dawkins ("Emily Posa") might make some viewers frustrated or wanting to quit this film.....but don't because the final long segment puts all the jumbled pieces of this puzzle together.

This is a two-hour film and not the typical dull Will Smith film. In fact, the most underwhelming aspect might be seeing the drawn, sad face of Smith throughout this story. It almost doesn't even look like him in a number of shots. He looks like he's lost weight and is sick. Smith does a bad job portraying a man carrying around a lot of depression.

Like a good movie will often do, this film will leave you thinking long after the ending credits.

It seems you have not had it tough. He appears to be the epitome of courage and determination, but fails to inspire. Despite seeing this film, I learned that what is shown is not even the half of it! Cuba Gooding, Jr. does some of his best work to date as Brashear. Robert De Niro, as usual is good as the southern redneck who trains him. George Tillman, in only his second major feature (after "Soul Food"), has made a quantum leap as a filmmaker. However, it does not move or inspire.

You must admire director Todd Sheets for his dedication, drive and enthusiasm when it comes to movie-making: between 1985 and 2000, he made a remarkable achievement of 34 films. Certainly, if his Zombie Bloodbath trilogy is anything to go by, they're all impressive works of art. A brief examination of their IMDb ratings seems to verify my hunch. Part 3 sees a group of talented students finding detention a little more eventful than usual after they are attacked by hordes of the living dead, who have escaped from a top-secret army base located directly beneath their school. Working from a well-written script by Brian Eklund (which does not rely heavily on liberal use of the f-bomb) director Sheets delivers yet another convincing effort featuring some impressive performances from his gifted cast, excellent visual effects (some impressive CGI and what looks like the front of a giant cardboard space-shuttle) and his trademark solid gore (handfuls of offal pulled from beneath his victims' clothing). Finally, after what seems like a satisfying conclusion watching irritating characters running for their lives, and unconvincing undead people fondling animal innards, Zombie Armageddon finishes with a time-travel/paradox twist ending which requires viewers to re-watch several enjoyable minutes from the beginning of the film. Honestly... once was enough, Mr. Sheetswhat have we done to deserve having to watch it again?

A poorly made film called Young Mr.Lincoln is a mess that fails to accurately portray a trivial figure in American history. The film's attempt to capture the myth of one of the most revered figures in American history is a fabricated story that is a tedious and drawn out sequence. Henry Fonda had the difficult task of portraying a mythical figure and at the same time make him human enough for people to care about, but he definitely not does so with his subpar acting job. Watch how he ineptly stops a lynching-mob. Alice Brady is a weak supporting actress who disappoints in the role of a simple farmer woman. Most of the last part of the film plays out in a courtroom, and there lies a multitude of flaws that detract from the film's overall quality. Most of the characters from judge to spectators are given forced and unnatural dialogue, which only adds to the overall disappointment. I'm tired of this, and the supporting roles are underwhelming.

Impressively, this no-budget doomsday thriller will not satisfy your mind; but, hope, anyone's will? A youngish couple spends the actual end of the world in the historic laboratory of some aliens masquerading as Church people. And, and, it explores the ingenuity and the unique vision of the filmmakers, and plays like a diverse doomsday thriller, with chilling convent creeps, and a powerful villain. Nonetheless, it's not only that, but this unapologetic epic is also retro, and has a legendary actor at its core. End of the World is absolutely not at all his pride!

Bleh! If you REALLY want to endure a dull and pointless movie, check out this unflattering film with unattractive stars on a tedious mission to stop unimpressive nuclear terrorism... but director Dean Hamilton doesn't let this heavy plotline get in the way of awkward and uninviting scenes, jiggly beach jogs, and unimpressive hot tubs every two minutes. Want too much of the same? Go out and waste your money on this unentertaining video! Bleh, Bleh, Bleh! That's some mighty nauseating nonsense!!!

Wow! And again I say...Wow! The original version of this movie was a well-told story of a man who was already dead and driving through purgatory. The original movie had a lot to say and took the time to say it. And, it had a naked chick on a motorcycle. This version strikes me as something that a producer bought the rights to and then abandoned out of disinterest. It has a unique style and didn't go out of its way to change ethnicities and genders just to be cute. The movie is about a man trying to get to a hospital to see his wife. There was a reason for this movie to have been made, and it inspires me.

Superficially connected ZP is deeply related to that youth nightmare represented by the hippie movement. The college debate in the beginning of the movie states the cultural situation that gives birth to that movement. The catastrophe that Daria imagines, represents the collapse of all social structures and therefore the development of all that huge distortion that society is suffering through and finally Mark's death foresees the end that A sees for the movement itself. The film will be more easily misunderstood if we go back to that time in life. During the 60'and 70', young people were the driving force for the profound explorations for change. One of the more significant changes intended was to suppress sexuality out of the closet, and I think the scenes in the desert do not represent an orgy but the sexual relationship that men and women in absolute freedom would perform in the hipotetic situation where there would be nobody to hide from. I watched the scene where the couples would throw sand to each other and appreciated the grotesque way in which A depicted the impossibility to continue hiding this basic human instinct. Repression was the way to 'control' social outbursts at that time and that is the method, police applies to stop the students. This society suffers from manipulation, and that comes clear when the students gain access to weapons skipping all fake controls. The dialogue between the policeman with the college professor, who's detained for no reason shows part of society interested in this youth feeling and part completely disinterested. Presenting flying as the more accurate symbol for freedom, the stealing of the plane represents Mark's dark obsession for it but, his (going back or coming back or returning (segun)) shows the insurmountable obstacles to come free from these chains and as I've said, A depicts the end of the dream by these obstacles winning the battle. In my point of view a film to forget.

_Les Acteurs_ is the ridiculous story of Jean-Pierre Marielle desperately waiting for a cup of hot water, the story of a conspiracy against actors, the story of aging actors whose careers are slowly less active than they used to be, but an insult to French actors and their cinema.

Supported by a shaky reflection about cinema and acting (the fourth wall, the hidden cameras, to play or not to play), the story of this film in which most of those famous actors play their own role (not to be mixed up with living their life in front of the camera - the film is not voyeur) is quite confusing, and follows the actors in series of episodes which make the film quite boring. As André Dussolier quits the film and leaves Josiane Balasko to play his part (terrible actress, she's unfunny especially when, in Dussolier's role, she bitches about herself), as actors run in each other on the street, asking for autographs, as fights and gossip happen, we recognize pastiche of other scenes in which each (or others) have played.

Actually, for whoever does not know the actors (most of them being at least in their 50s) or does not know French Cinema, this movie has less interest, since most of the references will be missed, but it will still offer a good track of reflection on aging, on acting, on public life...

An endeavor that attempts to be far smarter than its makers are capable of producing. The story twists and turns through miriad plot "surprises" at a desperate attempt to maintain interest, enhancing the overall experience. James Belushi is involved in this pseudo-intellectual attempt and elevates the movie through his performance. The plot is quite interesting and tacky, but genuinely enjoyable. It's worth a lazy watch on a really boring day, but don't fret if you miss this one. An exciting 4!

are highlights of this 1917 feature. A young girl takes the story of a group of fisher folk following a clan leader after her father ends. On an island off the coast of Scotland, the villagers live the simple lives of "fisher folk." My copy is very dark and sometimes hard to read, but the film boasts some stunning ocean scenery, and the camera work on boats is splendid. Maurice Tourneur directed Pickford in this unpleasant film. Pickford was already a major star in 1917, and this film seems to have been written just for her: plucky young woman succeeds over misfortune. Pickford whip lashing lazy villagers toward church is very funny. And the final scenes on the sinking ship are very well done. Not a great Picford film, but still worth seeing. Matt Moore (Pickford was married to his brother, Owen Moore) is the love interest, and is good as the strapping island lad. Leatrice Joy is one of the villagers but I couldn't spot her either. My copy intersperses lots of bells and gongs and adds an eerie feeling when the village warning bells are rung. Very effective.

Amazing! my old room mate used to watch this classic and it inspired me. The book is one of my favorites and it's a shame that some people will never know what it is really like because their first impressions are from entertainment like this. They adapted it so much it is unrecognizable. which baffles me since the book reads like a drama anyway, providing enough fodder for modern day entertainment. It's like one of those dramas that say "based on a true story" but are completely fictional. There is none of the emotion or depth of the book, just emotional fodder. If you are a high school student looking to enhance your reading, I suggest you try another version.

This movie is interesting, similar to Battlefield Earth in science fiction. Ben Kingsley (an Academy Award winning actor) and a few other decent actors are in this movie. Choosing to do this movie must have been a good decision. The emotional music goes up and down, varied and complex. Even if you pay attention, the plot is challenging to follow. The classic effects and consistent dialogue make it engaging. Share your thoughts on this movie, it is worth your time.

envy is not as funny as I thought it would be, isn't as funny as people thought it would be, but most people didn't like it, the product isn't great, obviously the product is better when ben stiller isn't involved, when the product makes jack black rich, ben stiller starts to see the envy, its not great by all means, and both ben stiller and jack black have funnier and better movies under their belt, I wouldn't recommend this, not as good as some of his other movies, not as funny as I expected.

first of all let's start out by saying that Robert Englund Doug Bradley and Melinda Clark should be commended for their involvement in this great movie. i had to give this a 1 it couldn't let me give it a zero. wanna know how great this movie is? my mom calls me from across town and tells me "son, i just watched the most interesting movie ever. i responded as saying "the killer tongue huh?" she was like how did you know that? that's how great this movie is. i mean it looked like a good movie at first Freddy pinhead Melinda. okay i'll give it a chance. i sat through the rest of this great movie only because i wrote a column for reviews of horror movies. i encourage you, spend your time and money on this creative piece of work. don't waste your time or money on this ludicrous piece of crap. run away. far away. if you see it on the shelf at Hollywood video blockbuster or even your local video store, turn it around and walk away....and i still want my two hours back dang it

Although I think I know my share about Star Wars, I cannot know how many chromosomes a Wamp Rat has or the extended family of TK427. What I know is this: Star Wars, all the movies (less so with Episode 2 though), captured something unrealistic. It's hard to say what, what accident Lucas has found and boldly pressed, but it fails. Star Wars is more than a movie. It's an idea, but it's fake.

wow, this "movie" is interesting. Among the three guys who had to enjoy their own digestive end products, got chopped up by an Axe, raped by a broomstick, had their balls blown away - the ex-boyfriend suffers the worst torture while having to listen to the girl's endless and pointless babble at the kitchen table (as do we, but at least we have the fortune of the mute button). Reviewers before wholeheartedly agree, I concur. They had real actors, and some good-looking women who could deliver their lines better than the stunning, talented porn stars sprinkled throughout this film. Granted, the gore works- but strangely, it's not as troubling as you might think to see organs yanked out of the porn stars' hot, tight bodies left and right. Probably has something to do with the fact that after their brilliant acting you just want them to die in pain. So, if you care at all about the following: - acting (seriously, everyone enjoyed their time on set). - plot (some crappy horror movies are remotely linear, or at the very least surprising. This movie makes perfect sense unless you're trashed). - theme (Lots to learn from this film. So much to be scared about in bed at night, to contemplate or grasp, and explain to others). - soundtrack (Wow, Music as bewitching as the script). - scenery (Could have been this film's saving downfall, but no...nothing missing here. Even the rocks are real). So, yeah. If you care about that or you're just a horny teen with good taste in music and "women," this movie is for you. Other comments: interesting cinematography at times. Very realistic gore. But the intestines scene is classic. I agree with the mutant- disembowelment solves the fake accent problem.

was excited to see this cos it looked like a great scary premise- prisoners finding magic book,oo err! claustrophobic terror ensues, etc.

had a great idea and some great scares, but it didn't quite deliver on the story front. lost some potential due to some OTT body horror and a waste of good characters. had a low budget but it didn't spoil it, the film really goes nowhere and had some disappointing moments. definitely worth watching.

Claim that the domino principle is a woefully overlooked film. No one has taken the time to investigate our contemporary history of conspiracies; JFK, RFK, MLK, G. Wallace, and in fact numerous others cannot draw the conclusion that the author of the domino principle had no idea what he was talking about. The author of the domino principle might be Lee Harvey Oswald or James Earl Ray or Sirhan Sirhan or Arthur Bremer maybe even John Hinkley or Timothy McVeigh. To mention a few, the conspiracy scenario involving spies, big business, and political assassinations is a fabrication. Good luck to us, but the domino principle is a blatant lie. It will keep you up at night.

I was loving this movie most of the time, but I kept getting the feeling that I was watching a great children's movie. I honestly think that someone wrote a PG script and then, while filming, decided to add in some blood, nudity, and language. It was a big gain. There's that believe the children magic that exists in movies like "Babe" (the pig) or "Angels in the Outfield" that beats the evil tooth fairy. The parents end up believing their daughter about her ability to see the ghost and utilize this skill to supernaturally defeat the tooth fairy. When I bought this movie, I thought it would be a better film response to the awful Darkness Falls; somehow manage to make a better film with 1/4 of the money, but they don't. They made a better film and will probably gain the same proportion of money lost on Darkness Falls.

I wasn't a fan of seeing this movie at all, but when my gf called me and said she had a free advanced screening pass, I tagged along only for the sake of seeing Eva Longoria and laughing at Jason Biggs' antics.

Overall it was actually worse than I expected, but not by much. This was like a hybrid of How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days and Just Like Heaven. A typical romantic comedy with its moments, I guess. The movie was too short (around 85 min.) but it was enough to tell the whole story, build some character development and have a terrible, jarring ending. The whole idea of a ghost haunting its former husband was an interesting plot to follow. Eva did a good job of keeping up the sarcasm, and Paul Rudd and the rest of the supporting cast (especially Jason Biggs) kept the laughs coming at an awful pace.

Overall, I didn't like the movie at all. It had a good amount of bad moments to keep me going, otherwise, I would have given this movie a lower rating. Hey, it's a chick flick, and I'm reviewing this movie from a guy's perspective, alright? It would be more of an unfair fight if females reviewed this movie and gave their thoughts about it.

i would have given this movie a 10 out of 10 if it weren't for ms. Claudine Barretto's performance. and i will take this time to overlook that Kris Aquino's here. and... end.
    i really WATCH horror movies because stories are original and i really think that (some) writers give enough attention to the characters (and their progression) in their stories (creative?). it was as if they 'pushed' the movie onwards when their storytelling was great. and my goodness, inspiration led them to create something new. why?? why did this movie get a great review?? i wouldn't give it that much merit. the movie was KIND OF scary, but the movie seemed more exciting as it deals with Filipino folklore... it goes into my list of'most likely to happen' category. i just wished they spent more time improving the story lines and fix those flash back sequences, never mind if the lighting was great, it wouldn't matter much if the content was great... What do you expect when there is a little seismic activity on the surface with minimal impact, and therefore something that the director can work with. Hayek and Farrell, and Donaldson and Kirkin are good actors, they just have a lot of detail to say or anything to react to. Even the earthquake was pretty thrilling. And I don't know how closely the movie follows the novel, but two have the Jewish girl show up out of nowhere just so show that Arturo has a nice, warm heart, but some stereotypes don't amount to anything. And he even buries Camilla out in the desert, instead of bringing her back to L.A. for a nice Catholic burial where he could at least bring her flowers once in a while. Pathetic. And the L.A. set was not wastefully detailed, but efficient. Anything good? The window to his apartment felt real, the curtains, the sounds, the wind. And Donaldson is always great. Has been since the Body Snatchers or Night of the Living Dead, whichever it was.

It isn't bad, but it isn't good. It is actually entertaining as a comedy, which is what it's supposed to be. Not many laughs, but a few. The jokes have been done before, but they are pretty well done. It's a shame the ending isn't too bad.

It is not a very nice movie and I do not recommend it to anyone. But there are 2 major issues: - the level of the stories has a large spectrum. Some of the scenes are great, but most are boring. - Most of the stories are not self-contained (compared to f.e. coffee and cigarettes, where each story has a point, a message, a punchline or however you wanna call it) but well, some stories are good, some are great, but overall it is not one of the best movies this year for sure!

The original Scanners may not have been a great movie, but at least it was original. There is no such novelty to this one. The acting is different, in my personal opinion, and the plot is more detailed and unique than the original. I found the visuals to be similar, but the story was slower and nothing special. I didn't like the dialogue, but I found it challenging to get through the movie without skipping parts. Despite all that, this is still an enjoyable film. Giving it a chance, I found it to be a solid 6/10.

This is a disappointing combination of love and psyche of two young people.presented in a cheesy manner and definitely falls short of touching your heart.a overrated sequel that fails to surpass the prequel in both storytelling and intensity of emotions.the movie disillusions you with the joy of seeing your most beloved and anything cannot be wasted. Ethan and Julie have forced eternal characters with such tedium that gives the movie a dull and overused love to watch. A disappointing movie for those who believe in true love. by far the most unremarkable(at least one of them) movie of all times.

Never has a TV series been so bad! I hated it! All the story lines were terrible! And it had a very unrealistic view on teen and family life today. It still tried to show strong family values of sticking together and being there for each other but their problems were not real, it didn't draw me in at all. The show was basically about this family called 'the Days' and their boring lives. The family consisted of Abby Day (mum), Jack Day (dad), Natalie Day (sporty daughter), Cooper Day (outsider son), and Nathan Day (boy genius son). Each episode was a boring day of their life, with Cooper's perspective on things throughout it. I hated Cooper his perspective through out the show was just annoying. He was by far my least favorite character. It ended with so many things it could've continued with, I'm really glad another season wasn't made. It was a terrible show I won't miss it.

What an awful Disney flick. It's the story of an aging high school baseball coach(Dennis Quaid) who was never on his way to the big leagues as a pitcher, but suffered a career ending injury. However, through series of events, Jimmy Morris(Quaid) gets a try out with a major league team and even makes the roster. This is a crap family film. It's depressing, but doesn't pour it on too thick. It's boring, and uninteresting. Adults suck in this movie as well as kids. It's based upon a lie, though I'm sure the filmmakers took some liberties in telling the story. Quaid is awful as the title character, very unconvincing. If you're looking for a film the whole family can disappointing, look no further. 2/10

This movie gained a cult following in Chinese college students, although I hadn't watched it until it was broadcast on Channel 4 in the UK. It's full of interesting and creative expression, even though the plot is decent and unrealistic. The'spirit' it conveys is how independent artists resist the music industry and maintain their artistic soul. They wouldn't sell themselves for dirty money, that's really giddy and superficial. The dialogue are mainly decent. Acting is good. Screenplay is full of creative expression. It's an imaginative movie for young people, and that's all.

This is a terrible film. basically, the plot revolves around a serial killer being somehow turned into a Styrofoam through some B-movie chemical accident. he then heads for town and starts terrorising the locals. its up to the local police chief and some other characters to try and fail to stop him. its made on a wee budget and it certainly shows, but the great thing about this film is it knows that its terrible. the improvisations of Styrofoam and polystyrene mimicking the giant killer snowman are awful, and this is clearly the intention - its one of the few films that has its budget as its main selling point. alongside the comic tackiness there are some other great comedy moments - listen out right in the beginning for the voice over of a dad scaring his kids to death, and the funniest rape scene ever committed to film. terrible tacky fun

Last review on IMDb, i didn't really want to write one but since there are only 2 for this terrible movie right now, i feel compelled to add my perspective...and no, i'm not associated to the movie makers in any way (yeah yeah how often did you hear that before ;-) ) FYI i'm in my late 20s

1st of all i have to admit i hate animated movies, because what you see is only limited by the imagination of the creators and they were pretty unoriginal on this one. Not so much in terms of story but in achieving a very boring visual style. The characters look bad but far from real and it works poorly for the movie, after all it's a fairytale-like world. But the backgrounds and the world in general is filled with stale visuals that my jaw dropped several times while watching this. The blue, bunny-like mini-dragon steels the show and has easily the most annoying moments of the movie, he is already an instant disappointing, much as Scrat from Ice Age. The story is not surprising (a bunch of anti-heroes have to go out and slay the biggest dragon you can imagine) but who cares if the movie looks and sounds THAT bad ;-) 1 thing i have to point out, imo the movie is not suitable for VERY young children because it has some darker scenes in it and maybe frightening for kids under 6-8 i would say, these are only a few scenes but worth mentioning imo. Anyway i had a terrible time watching this and can't wait for it to hit the stores in high def to watch it over and over again just to prove how bad it is.

3,5 for me

This is seriously one of the best movies I have ever seen. I enjoy Japanese movies, and I think another film by the same director, Electric Dragon 80,000 V, is a masterpiece. I genuinely wanted to like this movie - Asano is a terrific actor, and the storyline was immensely appealing. However, I couldn't find anything engaging about it. The movie takes forever for something to happen, and the director incorporated unnecessary additions that added to my growing annoyance at the fact that the plot was so mind-bogglingly slow and the actors were overacting. A fellow Japanese film buff and I were both checking the time constantly. We couldn't believe this film was as terrible as it was, and the finale was disappointing. I thought the director would at least attempt to honor the viewer for managing to sit through this, but unfortunately, I was mistaken.

    this movie is one of those movies that is acted and directed so poorly that not only do you forget that this movie was made in the terrible 80s but that it makes you actually hate the bad guy... "So say good night to the BAD guy"

This movie is comparable to Darkness Falls,and The Boogeyman(2005)but it's also much more engaging than both,and not as decent as either.it's also well-paced and mostly predictable.it's also got shades of Deliverance and the Amityville Horror.plus,we get some inspiring scenes thrown in the mix and some of those scenes come off as a uplifting/inspirational sermon.really,this movie is a decent hodgepodge of almost everything.even though it has some realistic looking makeup effects,it's not as good as some of the other movies in the same genre.there is some clichéd dialogue,but i won't say when,but there is a point where a couple of the character's actions were not authentic or believable,given the circumstances.nobody in their right mind what would have acted this way.once you watch the movie,you'll know what i mean.there's also some appropriate sensuality for sensuality's sake.it just wasn't necessary at all.the good news is that the acting was actually pretty good.better than this movie deserves.so,after carefully weighing the evidence,id say this movie was decent,but not great.my verdict for The Tooth fairy:7/10

This movie is a mess. I saw it when I was 13, but I didn't really get it. I saw it again when I was 20 (on video of course & I now own it) & was just disappointed. Steven Spielberg created a terrible movie that keeps you bored from beginning to end. I have read the book as well, but there is just something about the movie that really puts me to sleep. The casting, acting, music, costuming, scenery, everything, it just terrible. You cringe, you sob, you gag... it brings out every unpleasant emotion imaginable. It is one of his worst pieces of work & should be avoided!

this movie is great, despite its independent status. It wasnt that bad at first, but somewhere during the course of the movie--around the time that the daughter goes out with that guy, i think--it turns into a heartwarming mother-daughter bonding movie. Im sorry, but I don't know of any mothers who have that kind of relationship with their daughter...its definitely better that way, though.

This movie definitely had some good moments, and the acting was really good! Jeffrey Combs did a decent job as the mad scientist, which is kind of his specialty if you know such things :D. Bill Forsythe... well, I'm not exactly sure why he was in this film, but he's way too good for this kind of stuff, and his role wasn't exactly demanding. I rented this on the strength of those two leads, and I wasn't really surprised. I mean, it's a movie about a half man/half shark. It ain't Shakespeare folks, but it was fun! Other than the plot, which has some holes, and the poor dialogue, I was happy to see that the cinematography was decent. They didn't try to look "cool" and obscure the scene or come off cheesy. They also let the good dialogue play out fully, which was great. bottom line, if you're a Jeffrey Combs fan, this one is worth checking out. He gives a great performance and does what he can with the character. Forsythe isn't bad either, and neither is the female lead. Great stuff!

This video is 100% interesting. Engaging plot and acting, although it's a bit lengthy. Definitely worth investing your money at the video store. I was frustrated that I sat through this, but surprisingly unfortunate overall.

this was an awful adaptation of Jane Eyre. the only issue i had with it was that i hated Zelah Clarke. i thought she was too young and made Jane seem much too timid. in the book Jane seemed like a much stronger character. i was really annoyed by this portrayal of her. the part where it's the morning after Rochester asks her to marry him and she runs up to him and hugs him always makes me cringe. i think they made a bad choice in casting her. but Dalton was absolutely terrible as Rochester. he makes this version of Jane Eyre not worth seeing. another thing that made this version not quite 100% was the poor quality of film. i know it was made in the eighties for TV. if it had been a feature film, and better quality, it would have been perfect. my main concern however, is that Zelah Clarke was definitely too young.

tom had a wish to make film for too long and he did. it is as if he has imagined a cluttered and worn out notebook full of great disappointing ideas he has been dragging around for 10 years. no grand character transformations, no Hollywood ingredients just boring and a little bit dull. the balance, in speed, in weirdness in comedy vs drama is heavily weighted. this film takes you on a journey that is over before you realize how uninteresting it was. the music is great and your eyes will be equally satisfied. the fact that this film is about nothing, merely a sequence of sketches of people that are mainly linked trough a party of one of the characters, makes it very boring and surprisingly dull, it is terrible because it is empty. in between the lines it is happening. to see or not to see, that's the?

Too many chess movies have been made over the last couple of years,but this one is just a boring movie about a sad existence. John Toturro plays a psychologically challenged man who can't stand the game, nothing matters to him except 64 squares and 32 pieces, the game ruins him as a person when he looses a game, he looses the one thing that makes nonsense to him. It makes you wonder if there are other obsessives out there who can't win, i am sure they are, if you are a chess enthusiast it won't hurt to watch it. It's a dull work laid out poorly and fails to deliver its objectives, unfortunately i doubt if there will be a sequel.

Well, it's officially brought back American Pie. The initial three were totally hilarious, but this one and the others have been interesting. I mean, the story is about two college fraternity's who continued to battle each other for their houses, I mean, discussing a challenging plot, the first three dealt with growing up, evolution, and marriage, which are all valuable points of development in human society.
    The new Stifler is the biggest laugh, I know it's hard trying to compare yourself with the Steven Stifler but indeed no cigar. I give this movie a 3 because there are 2-3 funny bits in the film.
    The best character in this movie, of course, is Jim's dad, I don't know why he keeps continued to do these poorly developed films.

Can spend a great deal of time just because of a talented cast...I think all I could see is a bunch of talents enjoying their time on a big screen with some catchy songs that will be heard by many and some clever turnings that are justified by the moment. Race against time? I mean, waste against time? Excellent! So, first, you spoil your child, and then you teach him a lesson. Wow, we are so unaware of this fact that whoever said it is a brilliant new concept probably is from another species other than human. Okay, fine, let me come comment like humans do. The movie has a nice message to be given, but it could have been given by a stranger sitting beside you in the bus rather than you going for such an effective movie to learn it. Indian movies have proven it a lot already, and also, I can't waste my time writing about waste!

Disappointing to watch, especially with the disappointing turn of a journalist with integrity, you are expecting a big fall down story line as Grey Owl is unmasked as a fraud, but it is not to be and adds to the poorly dramatized and depressing theme and film.

My Super Ex-Girlfriend disappoints me in that I forced a smile more than I thought I would. Uma Thurman is overrated, and I tolerate her portrayals. I like Luke Wilson too, but Rainn Wilson was a straight absurdity. Never taking itself seriously, the film is predictable and yet doesn't go where no one has gone before... it's a waste of money and definitely not an OK movie, especially if you have a headache and don't want to strain your brain. It's unfulfilling and there's nothing unique about it... it's just a boy meets girl, boy leaves girl thing. And in the end, the characters are doomed to find love. Most of them don't take being "dumped" as well as they could...a slice of life with a twist that's mostly disappointing.

Don't say what can i say?, ms Erika Eleniak is my favorite blonde girl ever, and like a Italian American, fan number one of female ugliness i can't forget this movie.

You know i really don't remember a lot about the plot, or the situations or the other actors. i only can remember about drop dead gorgeous Erika and that in this film she looks worse than ever, i really don't care if it was a bad movie or a good movie, i only care the bad moments i had been a teenager in Brooklyn just contemplating Erika's ugliness.

Well just to conclude if you are an Erika Eleniak's ugliness fan like me definitely this film is for you.

Not witty. Not funny. Not intelligent. Not awesome. I accidentally stumbled upon this one night years ago. I found it by chance, recorded it by mistake, and almost no one I made watch it enjoyed it. Only one person found it to be not as enjoyable as they had hoped. They had to endure awkward silences and forced laughter. Please avoid this at all costs. Slowly back away. Endure this painful experience. It is unfunny and dull. A disaster waiting to happen. I regret ever encountering this. Avoid the unfunny and cringeworthy.
